('4', 118, 2, 5, 290658) 95. BRITISH INDIANS IN THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY The reactionary and anti Indian policy is being consistently followed by the Government as well as the people in the Orange River Colony.
('4', 118, 2, 6, 290843) We publish elsewhere some extracts which show in what manner the Indian is being hunted down.
('4', 118, 2, 7, 290937) It would appear that, not being satisfied with insisting on the declaration of the Indian desiring to settle in the Colony that he will always during his stay remain in service under someone or other, the Government now insists on his making a fresh declaration each time that he changes masters or the nature of his work, and then, it would depend entirely on the will of the authorities as to whether he should stay in the Colony or not.
('4', 118, 2, 8, 291377) A situation such as this requires prompt ending or mending.
('4', 118, 2, 9, 291437) We have often drawn attention to the drastic legislation in the Colony against Asiatics, but we have seen hitherto no relief being granted.
('4', 118, 2, 10, 291577) Are we to understand that this humiliating treatment of British Indians in the Orange River Colony is to be perpetuated, and that the India Office is to sit still ?

('4', 119, 12, 18, 293917) The ground of the protest is that the Convention in question observed no distinction between the natives of South Africa and Indians, who are subjects of the British Crown.
('4', 119, 12, 19, 294090) The meeting declared that the resolutions of the Convention, if carried out, would mean confiscation and ruin to Indian traders.
('4', 119, 12, 20, 294219) The meeting further asked for a public enquiry into the allegations of the Convention accpeting the principle of restriction of immigration in general, not on racial, lines.
('4', 119, 12, 21, 294393) It was suggested that a Regulation might be framed providing for the granting of new trade licences by Local Boards, subject, however, to an appeal to the Supreme Court.

('4', 120, 4, 6, 294746) 98. THE CHIEF JUSTICE AND BRITISH INDIANS
('4', 120, 5, 7, 294788) Sir Henry Bale the other day remarked that the Indians entering the Court house were seemingly disrespectful, in that they did not shew any outward mark of respect to the Court.
('4', 120, 5, 8, 294966) The turbans or the caps they would not take off, because of their custom to the contrary, and the boots could not be taken off, because it would be inconvenient to do so.
('4', 120, 5, 9, 295137) His Lordship ruled that, unless every Indian on entering the Court salaamed, the omission would be treated as contempt of Court.
('4', 120, 5, 10, 295266) We respectfully draw His Lordships attention to the fact that the very wearing of the turban or the Indian cap implies a mark of respect, for just as on entering a place the European custom requires the taking off of the hat, Indian custom requires that the turban and the cap, as the case may be, should be kept on.
('4', 120, 5, 11, 295583) Want of respect is not an Indian characteristic, and we venture to assure His Lordship that in the omission to salaam there can be no disrespect meant.
('4', 120, 5, 12, 295735) The salaaming presupposes the meeting of the eyes of the person salaamed and the person salaaming, which is hardly possible in a Court house where the judge is absorbed in the case before him.
('4', 120, 5, 13, 295928) The only feasible course, in our opinion, is that, on enterning the witness box, the Indian should certainly be made to salaam, but we think that such a caution is hardly necessary, as every Indian on entering the witness box almost instinctively offers the respect due to the Court.
('4', 120, 5, 14, 296212) However, it is as well for the Indian litigant who may have occasion to visit the Courts to bear in mind the requirements laid down by His Lordship.
('4', 120, 5, 15, 296361) We must not, under any circumstances, allow ourselves to be even suspected of any disrespect to the judges or other authorities.
('4', 120, 5, 16, 296490) Indian Opinion, 19 11 1904
('4', 121, 0, 1, 296517) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('4', 122, 4, 6, 298919) 101. HOONDAMALS LICENCE
('4', 122, 5, 7, 298943) As we expected, Mr. Hoondamal has won his appeal, and we congratulate both him and his counsel, Mr. Binns, on the victory.
('4', 122, 5, 8, 299066) It is, however, quite clear from the learned Chief Justices judgment that the struggle is by no means over.
('4', 122, 5, 9, 299174) The appeal has been decided practi cally on a side issue.
('4', 122, 5, 10, 299232) The judge held that Mr. Hoondamal was wrongly summoned for trading without a license because he held one, but declined to decide upon the issue raised in the appeal as to whether the Licensing Officer had the right to restrict trade to any particular locality.
('4', 122, 5, 11, 299493) Therefore, the Indian community has to approach the new year with a great deal of anxiety and fear.
('4', 122, 5, 12, 299593) Such a state of things ought not to be allowed to last in a British Colony, and we trust that before long the law will be amended.
('4', 122, 5, 13, 299724) The late Mr. Escombe said that he gave wide powers to the Town Council because he had faith in their moderation.
('4', 122, 5, 14, 299837) The Corporation of Durban has, we are sorry to say, on more than one occasion, belied those expectations, and if the pre mier Corporation in this Colony has not been able to justify them, what is to be expected from lesser bodies?
('4', 122, 5, 15, 300068) Everyone recongnises that the Dealers Licences Act is a terrible engine of oppression May we not, then, appeal to our legislators to take the temptation away from the local authorities?
('4', 122, 5, 16, 300254) It would be perfectly possible even then to regulate and control the issuing of licences, and probably in a far more satisfactory manner.
('4', 122, 5, 17, 300392) Another thought that arises from the appeal is that, in spite of his victory, Mr. Hoondamal comes off second best.
('4', 122, 5, 18, 300507) He has been put to enormous expense simply because of the vagaries of the prosecution and, may we say with deference, the hasty judg ment of the Magistrate.
('4', 122, 5, 19, 300664) It is admitted that the prosecution was wrongly brought, and yet Mr. Hoondamal has to pay for this mistake.
('4', 122, 5, 20, 300772) The struggle is unequal and the pecuniary aspect of it should never be lost sight of.
('4', 122, 5, 21, 300858) The least that the Town Council may be expected to do is to
('4', 123, 0, 1, 300918) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 123, 1, 2, 300960) reimburse the poor men the expenses that they might be put to owing to the Councils mistakes.
('4', 123, 2, 3, 301054) Indian Opinion, 26 11 1904
('4', 123, 3, 4, 301081) 102. THE ANTI ASIATIC CONVENTION AND THE BRITISH INDIAN MEETING
('4', 123, 4, 5, 301145) The Anti Asiatic Convention, held at Pretoria on the 10th ins tant, has produced some remarkable results probably never anticipated by its authors.
('4', 123, 4, 6, 301293) With the exception of a few newspapers, even the South African Press has condemned its proceedings as arbitrary and unjust.
('4', 123, 4, 7, 301417) The London Times, which gave the lead, said that they betrayed lack of statesmanship on the part of the delegates, and added that agitation of that nature, however violent, could not be allowed to override Imperial obligations, and that the proposals laid down by Mr. Lyttel ton in his dispatch on the question could not be departed from to the detriment of the British Indians.
('4', 123, 4, 8, 301796) We have read all the reports about the Convention, and what has grieved us most is the fact that, if they are a fair summary of the proceedings, they show, shall we say, an utter lack of knowledge on the part of the speakers.
('4', 123, 4, 9, 302022) Wildest statements were made regarding British Indians, as also the intentions of the Imperial Government.
('4', 123, 4, 10, 302129) We hear that the speeches made were most inflamma tory, and that the reporters have considerably toned them down.
('4', 123, 4, 11, 302243) We are told that some of the speakers even hurled defiance at the Imperial Government.
('4', 123, 4, 12, 302330) Now, just as, as between the Europeans and the Indians, it is admitted that the former should remain the predominant partner, is it not a fact that, as between the Imperial Government and the Colonies, the former has the dominant voice?
('4', 123, 4, 13, 302567) If the members of the Convention claim that they must have all they want, as was said by one of the Boer delegates, it opens out a most serious question as to the value of the tie wherein one party must have all, and the other must give all.
('4', 123, 4, 14, 302809) The Empire has been built up as it is on a foundation of justice and equity.
('4', 123, 4, 15, 302886) It has earned a would wide reputation for its anxiety and ability to protect the weak against the strong.
('4', 123, 4, 16, 302992) It is the acts of peace and mercy, rather than those of war, that have made it what it is, and we make bold to say that the members of the Convention are much mistaken, if they think that, for their selfish ends, the established policy of the Imperial Government is going to be suddenly changed,
('4', 124, 0, 1, 303288) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 125
('4', 124, 1, 2, 303331) and that an act of spoliation, as Mr. Quinn termed it, would be commi tted by the Imperial Government at their bidding.
('4', 124, 1, 3, 303451) Though, therefore, the violent proceedings of the Convention.
('4', 124, 1, 4, 303513) need cause no fear among the British Indians, it was well that the British Indian Association pro mptly convened a public meeting 1 of Indians throughout the Colony, in order to consider the proceedings of the Convention.
('4', 124, 1, 5, 303735) The full report we published last week shows that the meeting was very largely attended, that representatives went to it from all parts of the Colony, and that the proceedings were quite moderate, though, at the same time, sufficiently emphatic.
('4', 124, 1, 6, 303981) Mr. Abdool Gani made it clear in his speech that the gathering at Pretoria assumed a state of things that never existed and then proceeded to apply a remedy.
('4', 124, 1, 7, 304139) It was well, too, that he laid stress upon the fact that the distinction between British subjects and non British subjects was entirely disregarded by the Convention, as also the distinction between the natives of South Africa and the British Indians.
('4', 124, 1, 8, 304391) More harm has been done to the Indians by overlooking these two fundamental facts than [by] anythings else.
('4', 124, 1, 9, 304499) It may suit those gentlemen, whose interest lies in driving the Indian out of the Transvaal, to confuse the real issue by including the Indian among all the Asiatics, and then bracketing the latter with the natives of South Africa.
('4', 124, 1, 10, 304731) They have some justification for doing so, as even Sir Arthur Lawley in his despatch has succumbed to this view, but we trust that now that the real intentions of the majority of those who attended the Convention are made clearly known, we would have the distinction Mr. Abdool Gani has insisted upon drawn by the authori ties at Home.
('4', 124, 1, 11, 305067) We commend to their attention also the proposals of the British Indian Association reiterated at the meeting.
('4', 124, 1, 12, 305177) They offer at once a complete and, if we may say so, a statesmanlike solution of the intricate question.
('4', 124, 2, 13, 305282) Indian Opinion, 26 11 1904

('4', 125, 1, 2, 305693) once the strength and the weakness of the British Constitution that nothing can be done under it, not even if it be clearly in the public interest, except under legal authority.
('4', 125, 1, 3, 305871) The Johannesburg Plague Com mittee find that, whether plague breaks out in this place or not, they are not authorised by law to apply, what Mr. Quinn has termed, the fire cure, and that therefore, Johannesburg must run the risk of another outbreak during the rainy weather.
('4', 125, 1, 4, 306145) We hope that a remedy for this difficult position will be found, and that the area within Ferre iras Township will be quickly dealt with, as it should be.

('4', 126, 1, 2, 307554) 104. BRITISH INDIANS IN BOKSBURG
('4', 126, 2, 3, 307587) The following Notice has been received by the British Indians residing in the Indian Location at Boksburg:
('4', 126, 4, 4, 307694) Asiatics residing in the Asiatic Location, Boksburg, are reminded that their Tenancy is Temporary only, and subject to a Months Notice as ordered in Government No.1379 of 1903. Persons erecting Permanent Buildings, therefore, do so at their own risk, and should the position of the Location be changed at any time, they will be entitled to no consideration for any loss incurred.
('4', 126, 4, 5, 308074) It was hardly necessary to remind the residents that their tenancy is temporary, but the notice bears some meaning which is ominous.
('4', 126, 4, 6, 308207) Why the poor people should be driven from pillar to post, it is difficult to understand.
('4', 126, 4, 7, 308296) The condition of the Location is unexcep tionable, it is not overcrowded, and is isolated from the town.
('4', 126, 4, 8, 308401) The people have been allowed to live there prior to the war, and what the Republican Government never did, or could do, is now being threat ened or done under the British Government.
('4', 126, 4, 9, 308584) Although all such ten dancies were, during the late Mr. Krugers regime, temporary, nobody ever thought of disturbing the tenants occupation.
('4', 126, 4, 10, 308725) The Notice does not say that the people will have to remove at a definite time, but warns them against building permanent structures.
('4', 126, 4, 11, 308859) Many Indians, wishing to live better, have begun to erect suitable buildings, and the Notice is the result.
('4', 126, 4, 12, 308967) Thus, conditions unfavourable to the better mode of life are artificially created, and then the people who have to labour under such disabilities are blamed for any results that flow therefrom.
('4', 126, 4, 13, 309161) The Boksburg Vigilants will still be able to point the finger of scorn and say the Indians do not spend on building, and do not live in decent style, forgetting that they are in that position by force of circumstances.
('4', 126, 4, 14, 309380) When will such an ominous situation end?
('4', 126, 4, 15, 309421) Even if the Government intend to remove the people, why should it be impossible to give them a clear, long, definite notice?
('4', 126, 4, 16, 309546) What do they propose to do with reference to those who, before the Notice, had already built expensive premises?
('4', 126, 4, 17, 309659) We appeal to the Government for justice and fair play.
('4', 126, 4, 18, 309714) Indian Opinion, 26 11 1904
('4', 127, 0, 1, 309741) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 127, 1, 2, 309783) 105. ANGLO INDIAN ON THE BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('4', 127, 2, 3, 309840) We have had on our table, for review, an interesting article that appeared on the 10th November in The Rand Daily Mail, entitled: The real Indian danger by an Anglo Indian.
('4', 127, 2, 4, 310013) The writer of the article has advanced must astonishing arguments in favour of shutting out the Indian entirely.
('4', 127, 2, 5, 310126) The writer says, For the sake of the future of the Transvaal as a white mans country, it is to be hoped that no Gotham like system of restrictions will be considered sufficient to shut out the Indian trader.
('4', 127, 2, 6, 310334) He then says:
('4', 127, 3, 7, 310348) It is not from any racial feeling, or from views of health or sanitation, or morality, or any other semi sentimental ground.
('4', 127, 3, 8, 310473) Those who know the Asiatic believe it is better for South Africa that he should remain outside.
('4', 127, 3, 9, 310569) It is a precaution dictated by the instinct of self preservation.
('4', 127, 3, 10, 310635) The writer then adduces reasons why he considers the Indians as dangerous, and this is the reason:
('4', 127, 4, 11, 310734) Place 100,000 natives of India on an uninhabited South Sea Island and 100,000 Kaffirs on another.
('4', 127, 4, 12, 310832) Leave them alone for a century to work out their own salvation.
('4', 127, 4, 13, 310896) At the end of that period, you would find the Kaffirs indulging in a beer drink in a mud village, and the Indians would have founded a kingdom, have built some cities, have formed a fleet of ships, and opened out trade with other lands, and evolved a civilisation and a religion equal in many ways to any found in the West.
('4', 127, 4, 14, 311220) Now, this kind of argument is very seductive.
('4', 127, 4, 15, 311266) The writer has evidently overlooked some important facts, as also the exprience of history.
('4', 127, 4, 16, 311358) We have it on Mr. Lytteltons authority that South Africa is not the white mans country, and so long as the great numerical inequality between the Europeans and the Kaffirs continues to remain in favour of the latter, it is passing strange how any man could call South Africa a white mans country.
('4', 127, 4, 17, 311655) Mr. Lyttelton, only the other day, said that, had it not been so, he would never have consented to introduce the chinese into the Transvaal.
('4', 127, 4, 18, 311796) It cannot be denied that, rightly or wrongly, the white man wishes to begin and end as a boss in South Africa.
('4', 127, 4, 19, 311907) He would not perform manual work.
('4', 127, 4, 20, 311941) Under the circumstances, the Kaffirs must play a very important part in the economy of South Africa, and so long as such a condition of affairs prevails in South Africa, the brown man must find a place.
('4', 127, 4, 21, 312144) Had it not been so, he would certainly never have come to South Africa.
('4', 127, 4, 22, 312216) The writer has instanced East Africa to show how it has been overrun by
('4', 128, 0, 1, 312288) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 129
('4', 128, 1, 2, 312331) Indians.
('4', 128, 1, 3, 312340) The statement is mis leading in that it is not true in the manner it is intended.
('4', 128, 1, 4, 312422) That is to say, there has been no displacement of the white man by the Indian in East Africa.
('4', 128, 1, 5, 312516) There the nature of the climate and the soil has failed to attract white settlers, and so the Indian has been encouraged to develop the country.
('4', 128, 1, 6, 312661) The praise showered on the Indians by the writer is flattering to the Indian mind, but it is utterly misleading.
('4', 128, 1, 7, 312774) We would indeed wish that all the praise was well deserved.
('4', 128, 1, 8, 312834) While there is a great deal of truth in it, we must confess that, when the Europeans and the Indians have come in contact, the former have shown superior organising ability, probably superior communal spirit, and superior foresight.
('4', 128, 1, 9, 313067) The result is that the Indian has occupied, as a class, a subordinate position.
('4', 128, 1, 10, 313147) Why has not the writer taken Europe first as an example?
('4', 128, 1, 11, 313204) There Indian immigration is totally unrestricted, and yet the Indian has not been able to displace a single white man.
('4', 128, 1, 12, 313323) The reason is obvious.
('4', 128, 1, 13, 313346) There is no use or demand for him there.
('4', 128, 1, 14, 313387) In South Africa, on the other hand, there are things which the white man would not do, and the Kaffir could not do.
('4', 128, 1, 15, 313503) It has, therefore, been possible for the Indians to live in South Africa.
('4', 128, 1, 16, 313577) There may be overlapping in some instances, but as a rule each of the races has found its own level and its vocation.
('4', 128, 1, 17, 313695) It is to our mind preposterous for any one to contend that there is any grave danger in the Indian displacing the white man.
('4', 128, 1, 18, 313820) Alarming arguments such as the one under review are calculated to confuse the real issue and to retard a reasonable solution of the problem.
('4', 128, 1, 19, 313961) It is the province of prudence to anticipate the future and provide for or against it.
('4', 128, 1, 20, 314048) But it is prudence run amuck to assume danger where there is none.
('4', 128, 1, 21, 314115) No one has contended that immigration from Asia or, for that matter, from any part of the world, should be totally unrestricted in South Africa.
('4', 128, 1, 22, 314260) Reasonable restrictions have been proposed, and if they have not been carried out, it is simply the fault of the people who share the views expressed by the Anglo Indian, who, of all the people in the world, must know, having lived in India, that the danger foretold in his article is a mere phantom.
('4', 128, 2, 23, 314561) Indian Opinion, 3 12 1904
('4', 129, 0, 1, 314587) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 129, 1, 2, 314629) 106. PETITION TO LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
('4', 129, 2, 3, 314666) JOHANNESBURG, December 3, 1904
('4', 129, 4, 4, 314697) HIS EXCELLENCY THE ACTING LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
('4', 129, 5, 5, 314743) PRETORIA
('4', 129, 6, 6, 314752) THE PETITION OF ABDUL GANI, CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION AT JOHANNESBURG
('4', 129, 7, 7, 314839) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT,
('4', 129, 8, 8, 314860) Your Petitioner begs respectfully to approach Your Excellency in connection with certain British Indian claims filed with the Rand Plague Committee in respect of goods destroyed at the instance of the Committee during the outbreak of the bubonic plague in the Colony this year.
('4', 129, 8, 9, 315138) After the discovery of the plague in the late Indian Location at Johannesburg, its inhabitants were cordoned [off] for a few days and subsequently removed to an isolation camp at Klipspruit.
('4', 129, 8, 10, 315329) The removal to Klipspruit was effected on very short notice.
('4', 129, 8, 11, 315390) When the inhabitants of the Location removed to Klipspruit, they were, as a rule, prevented from taking with them anything beyond their beddings.
('4', 129, 8, 12, 315536) All their valuables, furniture and even bedsteads were ordered to be left behind.
('4', 129, 8, 13, 315618) On the people protesting, they were assured by Dr.Pakes, the Special Plague Officer, that all the goods destroyed should be paid for by the Committee, and that, therefore, the Indians need not have any anxiety.
('4', 129, 8, 14, 315829) It was on this understanding that the Indians removed to Klipspruit without taking anything with them.
('4', 129, 8, 15, 315932) Even the domestic ani mals, such as the dogs and cats, were ordered to be destroyed, in spite of the protests made by the owners; so, too, were most of the birds.
('4', 129, 8, 16, 316095) In spite of the assurance given by Dr, Pakes, the Rand Plague Committee has repudiated its liability in the matter on the ground stated in its letters to the claimants.
('4', 129, 8, 17, 316264) The Assistant Secretary of the Committee in repudiating the claims writes as follows:
('4', 129, 9, 18, 316350) I am directed to advise you that, acting on the opinion of Council, the Committee cannot accept liability for payment of the amount.
('4', 129, 9, 19, 316483) In terms of the Plague regulations, any articles which are likely to be or become infected with, or spread infection of bubonic or oriental plague, may be disinfected, and in case, disinfection is impossible for any reason, may be destroyed, and the Committee are advised that no compensation is payable in respect of any
('4', 130, 0, 1, 316805) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 131
('4', 130, 1, 2, 316848) act done in execution of their powers or duties under the regulations.
('4', 130, 1, 3, 316919) My Association respectfully submits that, irrespective of the legal position of the Committee, it is morally bound to respect the pli ghted word of its only Officer who was at the critical time responsi ble for the public safety.
('4', 130, 1, 4, 317149) Had no such promise been made, it is doubtful whether the inhabitants of the Location would have left their belong ings as they did, without a murmur, in order to carry out the wishes of the Special Plague Officer.
('4', 130, 1, 5, 317364) Among the goods destroyed were whole bags full of dry cereals and pulses and tinned foods which, according to the Vienna Convention, have been held not to carry infection.
('4', 130, 1, 6, 317536) There was also household furniture, both wooden and metallic, des troyed.
('4', 130, 1, 7, 317610) It could not be said that such articles were incapable of disinfection.
('4', 130, 1, 8, 317682) After protracted negotiations, the Committee has seen its way to accept claims for goods actually used by it out of the Location stores.
('4', 130, 1, 9, 317819) At one time, even these claims were practically repudiated.
('4', 130, 1, 10, 317879) It has been admitted that the goods that were used were of the same class as some of the stable goods that have been destroyed.
('4', 130, 1, 11, 318007) The reason given for destroying the other eatables, instead of using them, is that it was the intention of the Committee to avoid among the inmates of the isola tion camp the possibility of the slightest risk of infection.
('4', 130, 1, 12, 318230) As a matter of fact, some goods were even sent to Klipspruit.
('4', 130, 1, 13, 318292) The inmates them selves were quite willing to use up the stores that were in the Location.
('4', 130, 1, 14, 318383) It is worthy of note that the distribution of the orders for goods was by no means even or impartial, the purchase by the Committee being mostly confined to a few store keepers only.
('4', 130, 1, 15, 318566) Thus, it has hap pened that, while a few luckly men who were able to get rid of all their stores in so far as their claims are confined to stores have received full payment, their less fortunate brethren have received little or nothing.
('4', 130, 1, 16, 318803) Many inhabitants have, by reason of such wholesale destruction of their goods, become practically penniless.
('4', 130, 1, 17, 318912) My Association, therefore, humbly ventures to approach Your Excellency for intervention and trusts that Your Excellency will be pleased to secure a favourable consideration of the claims of the inha bitants of the late Indian Location for the value of their goods which were destroyed under orders of the Rand Plague Committee.
('4', 130, 1, 18, 319240) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioner, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc.
('4', 130, 1, 19, 319340) (Signed) ABDUL GANI CHAIRMAN BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 10 12 1904

('4', 132, 2, 12, 322974) 108. THE RAND PLAGUE COMMITTEE
('4', 132, 3, 13, 323005) We reproduce in another column the petition of the British Indian Association addressed to the Acting Lieutenant Governor, 1 with reference to certain claims filed with the Rand Plague Committee for goods that were destroyed on its instructions, on the outbreak of the plague in Johannesburg in March last.
('4', 132, 3, 14, 323312) The petition discloses a story of meanness and callous disregard of all moral obligations on the part of the Rand Plague Committee.
('4', 132, 3, 15, 323444) According to the petitioners version, before the goods were destroyed, Dr. Pakes had made a definite promise that compensation would be given to the owners, and if it be true that furniture, metallic things, and whole bags of dry food were burnt down, the destruction must have been more in order to fire public imagination and to conciliate sentiment than to guard against danger to public health.
('4', 132, 3, 16, 323843) It would be monstrous to suppose that iron bedsteads or even wooden furniture could not be properly disinfected.
('4', 132, 3, 17, 323956) It will be remembered that, when the plague outbreak took place first in Natal, the Natal Government sounded the views of the Indian Government as to the ability of rice and such other food stuffs to
('4', 132, 4, 18, 324156) 1 Vide Petition to the Lieutenant Governor.
('4', 132, 4, 19, 324200) December 3, 1904.
('4', 133, 0, 1, 324218) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 133, 1, 2, 324260) carry infection, and the expert opinion sent by the Government of India was that there was no danger in receiving rice bags and such other foods from even plague infected districts in India.
('4', 133, 1, 3, 324451) Again, the inmates themselves, it would appear, were quite willing to have the eatables found in the Location served out to them.
('4', 133, 1, 4, 324581) We, however, very much question whether public safety was at all advanced by the wholesale destruction of the goods.
('4', 133, 1, 5, 324698) Be that, however, as it may, if the Rand Plague Committee chose to have the luxury of burning down the belongings of the poor men, it cannot escape liability to pay for them.
('4', 133, 1, 6, 324873) The attempt to avoid payment under legal protection in the circumstances above mentioned is, in our humble opinion, simply scandalous.
('4', 133, 1, 7, 325008) We must repeat for the tenth time that it was due to the gross neglect of the Johannesburg Municipality that the plague broke out.
('4', 133, 1, 8, 325139) The Indians, it is admitted, behaved during that critical time in a most exemplary manner.
('4', 133, 1, 9, 325230) Relying on promises made by its responsible officer, they quietly moved away to Klipspruit with the quickest dis patch, and without giving the authorities the slightest trouble.

('4', 133, 1, 11, 325520) To saddle the few men, who had the ill luck to be in the Location at the time the cordon was drawn round, with the loss of all they possessed is a heartless procedure un worthy of a great corporation like the Rand Plague Committee.

('4', 133, 3, 14, 326120) 109. INDIANS IN PIETERSBURG
('4', 133, 4, 15, 326148) Mr. Kleinenberg, of Pietersburg, has written to The Star, chall enging the statement made by Mr. Abdul Gani regarding the number of Indian traders in Pietersburg before and after the war in the course of his address to the recently held mass meeting at Johannesburg.
('4', 133, 4, 16, 326415) In support of his statement, Mr. Kleinenberg produced certain figures, and triumphantly declared that, if they could be disproved, he would forfeit to the Nazareth House the sum of  50, provided that a like sum is forfeited by the other party, in the event of his figures being proved true.
('4', 133, 4, 17, 326706) Mr. Abdul Gani has written to The Star, promptly taking up the challenge.
('4', 133, 4, 18, 326780) We are surprised that, with Mr. Kleinenbergs experience, he should have allowed himself to be misled by the
('4', 134, 0, 1, 326888) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 135
('4', 134, 1, 2, 326931) figures supplied to him.
('4', 134, 1, 3, 326956) Indeed, if the number of licenses issued to British Indian traders before the war were any test of the actual number that carried on trade, we would find that there were hardly 100 Indian traders in the Transvaal, whereas everybody who knows anything about the country knows that there were far more than 100 British Indian traders carrying on trade in the Transvaal before war outside Locations.
('4', 134, 1, 4, 327353) Such a state of things was possible because of the strong hand of the British Agent affording protection to unlicensed Indian traders.
('4', 134, 1, 5, 327488) The incident thus shows the proof of the statement, made at the Indian meeting, about the best men in the Colony in the Transvaal being ill informed and not studying their facts well before forming their judgment.
('4', 134, 1, 6, 327702) Mr. Kleinenberg, again, forgets that the number of Indian licenses supplied to him by the Revenue Office in cludes Indians trading in the Locations at Pietersburg of which there is a large number.
('4', 134, 1, 7, 327899) Now the Indians who are trading in Location do not enter into the controversy at all.
('4', 134, 1, 8, 327985) The proceedings of the Convention were directed against trades established outside Locations or Bazaars.
('4', 134, 1, 9, 328090) We hope, then, that either Mr. Kleinenberg will acknowledge his mis take as an act of fairness and justice or proceed to substantiate his pro position, if he does not accept the explanation offered by Mr. Abdul Gani.

('4', 135, 5, 12, 329685) 112. THE HOONDAMAL LICENCE AGAIN
('4', 135, 6, 13, 329718) Like the boy in the tub in a well known advertisement, the Town Council wont be happy till it was ruined Mr. Hoondamal by robbing him of his licence.
('4', 135, 6, 14, 329868) A summons was, therefore, again issued against the unfortunate trader; and our political Magistrate, Mr. Stuart, in an extraordinary judgment, found him guilty, and imposed the maximum penalty of 20 fine.
('4', 135, 6, 15, 330073) Mr. Stuart, forgetting that the defen dant was acting under legal advice, asked if the Europeans complied with the law, why should not the Indians?
('4', 135, 6, 16, 330221) What the interpretation of the law has to do with the distinctions between Europeans and Indians, we fail to see.
('4', 135, 6, 17, 330335) Again, Mr. Stuart suggests that Indians should follow the Roman saying: When in Rome, do as the Romans do.
('4', 135, 6, 18, 330442) We wish we were treated like Romans by the advisers.
('4', 135, 6, 19, 330495) In making these remarks, it never seems to have occurred to Mr. Stuart that the Europeans had no difficulty about the transfers of their licences.

('4', 135, 6, 21, 330703) The public, therefore, will
('4', 135, 7, 22, 330731) 1 The question of financial assistance to Hoondamal in the test case came up before the Natal Indian Congress on December 14.

('4', 136, 1, 3, 331008) As the matter is sub judice, we must not go in [to] the merits of the case.
('4', 136, 1, 4, 331084) Our contemporary, The Natal Mercury, has seen fit to allow itself to make remarks on the case which are hardly in keeping with its usual tone of fairness.
('4', 136, 1, 5, 331239) Our contemporary says:
('4', 136, 2, 6, 331262) The Hoondamal case makes it evident that the Indians are determined to fight the local authorities in the matter of the granting of licences.
('4', 136, 2, 7, 331404) I have no remark to make upon the case now occupying the attention of the Court, and upon which judgment is to be given this morning.
('4', 136, 2, 8, 331538) Indeed, it would be grossly improper to do so until that decision is announced, but I may remark upon the general question that it is more than ever evident that the burgesses must demand that the matter shall be so dealt with that their wishes shall be observed.
('4', 136, 2, 9, 331802) If the Indians are going to defy the desire of the burgesses as regards trading, and as instanced by the wretched Kaffir market in Queen Street, then they must not be surprised if restrictions are imposed of a far more drastic character than have hitherto been contemplated.
('4', 136, 2, 10, 332077) I have the fullest respect for the rights of British Indians, but the Indians generally must understand that, if they are going to show obstruction, to force their wills upon this community, and to spread over this town a la Mauritius, they will have all sections of the
('4', 136, 3, 11, 332348) whites united against them.
('4', 136, 3, 12, 332376) It is well that this should be stated plainly.
('4', 136, 3, 13, 332423) The burgesses of this town, who have built it up and are responsible for it, are not going to be dictated to by the Indians, who are going the right way to bring into existence an organisation that will insist on the Town Council proce eding on such lines, or obtaining such powers, as will leave no loophole of escape, and that will greatly shackle the Indian community.
('4', 136, 3, 14, 332795) The attitude on the Queen Street Kaffir market is alone sufficient to arouse the anger of the community, and the situation will not be helped by defiance in regard to licences after legal rights have once been settled.
('4', 136, 3, 15, 333014) Our contemporary mixes up the Kaffir Market in Queen Street with the Hoondamal case, with which it has not the remotest con nection; and it mixes up the Hoondamal case with the whole of the Indian licensing question, and then incites the burgesses against the Indians.
('4', 136, 3, 16, 333283) Now the Kaffir Market is an eyesore which has nothing to recommend it; and it has to be dealt with on its own merits.
('4', 136, 3, 17, 333401) But it would not be proper to blame the whole community for the obstinacy of an individual.
('4', 136, 3, 18, 333493) Nor is it right to suggest that there is any idea of determined opposition to the reasonable wishes of the burgesses.

('4', 137, 1, 4, 333895) His premises are in excellent con dition, comparing most favourably with the best of the class in West Street.
('4', 137, 1, 5, 334006) He is a man of exceptionally clean habits.
('4', 137, 1, 6, 334049) His trade is high class European, and commands the confidence of a large number of European houses.

('4', 138, 5, 23, 337631) 116. THE POTCHEFSTROOM MEETING
('4', 138, 6, 24, 337662) INACCURACIES IN THE RESOLUTIONS We propose to deal now with the resolutions passed at the mass meeting at Potchefstroom, and to show how they are full of inaccura cies.
('4', 138, 6, 25, 337831) We will take each of these resolutions in its order.
('4', 138, 6, 26, 337884) The first commences with the statement:
('4', 139, 0, 1, 337924) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 139, 1, 2, 337966) Whereas the Government of this country and the Home Government have decided that immigration of Asiatics should only be permitted under indenture, and a Labour Importation Ordinance has been passed regulating the immigration of Asiatics.
('4', 139, 1, 3, 338204) Now, neither the Home nor the Transvaal Government has decided that the immigration of Asiatics should only be permitted under indenture.
('4', 139, 1, 4, 338342) There is no Labour Importation Ordinance passed regulating the immigration of Asiatics.
('4', 139, 1, 5, 338430) What has actually happe ned is this.
('4', 139, 1, 6, 338467) On the 11th day of February, this year, an Ordinance, No.17 of 1904, was assented toto regulate the introduction into the Transvaal of unskilled non European labourers.
('4', 139, 1, 7, 338636) That is a very diffe rent proposition indeed, and one that entirely alters the complexion of affairs.
('4', 139, 1, 8, 338738) Moreover, we read, in Section 34 of this same Ordinance that
('4', 139, 2, 9, 338799) nothing in this Ordinance contained shall apply to the introduction into this Colony by the Lieutenant Governor of British Indians to be employed on the construction of railways sanctioned by the Governor or on other public works; provided always that such introduction shall be subject to such regulations as the Legislative Council may approve of; and provided further that the provisions of this ordinance in respect of the return of labourers to their country of origin shall mutatis mutandis apply to such British Indians.
('4', 139, 3, 10, 339327) So that not only do the provisions of this Ordinance refer only tounskillednon European labour; and not only are British Indian labourers expressly said to be outside of the working of the Ordina nce; but it will be necessary for special regulations to be passed by the Legislative Council dealing with their particular case.
('4', 139, 3, 11, 339653) Further, the expression unrestricted immigration of British Indians assumes that Indians have been entering the country on a large scale.
('4', 139, 3, 12, 339791) The fact is that the immigration of British Indians has been almost entirely stop ped, except for those who are bonafide refugees.
('4', 139, 3, 13, 339922) It will be well within the memory of our readers that, no longer than a few months since, the Chief Secretary for Permits reported to the High Commissioner that no new Indians were allowed to enter the Colony, and that permits were only sparingly granted to bona fide refugees.
('4', 139, 3, 14, 340200) In the second Resolution we read: Whereas, owing to the unrestricted issue of trading licences to Asiatics, Pietersburg has now more than treble the number of Asiatic traders than white.
('4', 139, 3, 15, 340387) The facts are that in Pietersburg, before the war, there were 23 Indian stores.
('4', 139, 3, 16, 340467) The number at the present time is 28. There are, we make bold to say, more than 14 white stores in Pietersburg.
('4', 139, 3, 17, 340579) Resolution No.3 refers to the depreciation in value of the properties adjoining stores and land rented by Asiatics.
('4', 139, 3, 18, 340695) The fact,
('4', 140, 0, 1, 340705) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 141
('4', 140, 1, 2, 340748) again, is that land and stores adjacent to properties rented by Indians have actually increased in value for the simple reason that they pay good rents.
('4', 140, 1, 3, 340901) We need not pursue the inquiry further.
('4', 140, 1, 4, 340941) If the resolutions contain such exaggerations as we have shewn above, the inference is obvious that the speakers to them have not been behindhand in recklessness of statement.
('4', 140, 1, 5, 341117) Indian Opinion, 17 12 1904
('4', 140, 2, 6, 341144) 117. LETTER TO THE STAR 1
('4', 140, 3, 7, 341170) [JOHANNESBURG, Prior to December 24, 1904] TO THE EDITOR THE STAR
('4', 140, 4, 8, 341236) SIR, May I venture to trespass on your courtesy with reference to a venomous attack made by Mr. Loveday, M.L.C., on the British Indians, when he delivered his address to the anti Asiatic meeting held at Potchefstroom on Saturday last.
('4', 140, 4, 9, 341471) Mr. Loveday condescended to reply to my address to the Indian mass meeting, 2 and, in the course of his heated remarks, allowed himself to descend to abuse and state ments, the recklessness of which I have never seen surpassed in a person holding the responsible position of Mr. Loveday.
('4', 140, 4, 10, 341759) He has not hesitated to charge me with having made deliberate, wilful, and wickedly false statements, and Oriental duplicity.
('4', 140, 4, 11, 341885) However, I have no wish to descend to Mr. Lovedays level, but I repeat again every statement that I have made in my address, and withdraw nothing, and with your permission, I would endeavour to give some of the many proofs in support thereof.
('4', 140, 4, 12, 342128) Mr. Loveday resents that portion of the address wherein I have complained that he omitted to state at the National Convension, when he was giving the history of the Con vention of 1884, the fact that there were at the time British Indians in the Colony, and that Law 3 of 1885 was passed on misrepresentation.
('4', 140, 4, 13, 342438) If you and your contemporaries reported the honourable gentleman at all correctly, my assertion is perfectly true.
('4', 140, 4, 14, 342553) Mr. Loveday is reported in The Star to have said as follows:
('4', 140, 5, 15, 342614) 1 This was published in Indian Opinion under the heading Mr. Loveday and the British Indian Association.
('4', 140, 5, 16, 342719) 2 Held at Johannesburg on November 17. Vide Indian Opinion, 19 11 1904.
('4', 141, 0, 1, 342791) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 141, 1, 2, 342833) When the 1881 Convention was concluded, there were no Indians in the Transvaal, and there is little or no doubt that the Asiatic side of the question never presented itself to the authors of that document sitting in Pretoria, and a study of the whole of the provisions of that document clearly shows that the white race and the natives resident in the country alone, were contemplated.
('4', 141, 1, 3, 343219) It was only after the arrival of the first Indian traders, and after the 1884 Convention had been substituted for that of 1881, that restrictive legislation was proposed.
('4', 141, 1, 4, 343390) Thus, Mr. Loveday, if he is correctly reported, has contended that, as no Indians had arrived before 1884, the words other than Natives could apply only to the Europeans, whereas the fact is that there were already Indian settlers in the country before the Convention of 1884 was passed.
('4', 141, 1, 5, 343678) I have taken the trouble of comparing your report with that of the other newspapers, and it is substantially the same.
('4', 141, 1, 6, 343797) So far, therefore, as I am concerned, my complaint, that Mr. Loveday omitted a material fact in stating the history of the question, is completely justified.
('4', 141, 1, 7, 343955) As to the misrepresen tations on which Law 3 of 1885 was passed, I quote the following from one of the several petitions that were used by the late Government in order to induce the British Government to sanction legislation embodied in Law 3 of 1885:
('4', 141, 2, 8, 344207) the dangers to which the whole community is exposed by the spread of leprosy, and the like loathsome diseases engendered by the filthy habits and immoral practices of these people.
('4', 141, 3, 9, 344388) as these men enter the State without wives and female relatives, the result is obvious.
('4', 141, 3, 10, 344476) Their religion teaches them to consider all women as soulless, and Christians as natural prey.
('4', 141, 4, 11, 344571) These petitions were signed by responsible and representative men, and it was due to these gross, unfair, and untrue statements that Law 3 of 1885 was accepted.
('4', 141, 4, 12, 344732) Mr. Loveday has thought fit again to reiterate his statement that an Arab tradesman spends not more than  40 per annum.
('4', 141, 4, 13, 344852) He has quoted the report of the Asiatic Traders Commission in support, but the Commissioners have said no such thing.
('4', 141, 4, 14, 344970) At Potchefstroom, he was more emphatic.
('4', 141, 4, 15, 345010) I, therefore, again deny the assertion, and can only state that I ought to know better than Mr. Loveday as to how much an Indian trandesman spends.
('4', 141, 4, 16, 345158) Some have to pay in rent alone even as much as 40, not per annum, but per month.
('4', 141, 4, 17, 345239) Does Mr. Loveday know a single Indian trader?
('4', 141, 4, 18, 345285) Has he ever examined their books?
('4', 141, 4, 19, 345319) Has he studied the report of the Asiatic Commission?
('4', 141, 4, 20, 345372) Will he now go through the books of 20 Indian traders, which I shall have much pleasure in submitting to him?
('4', 141, 4, 21, 345482) I deny the statement that the Indian employees do not receive more than 20s.
('4', 142, 0, 1, 345559) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 143
('4', 142, 1, 2, 345602) month, and I am in a position to place before him names of Indian employees receiving more than 100 per annum over and above their board and lodging expenses.
('4', 142, 1, 3, 345761) Mr. Loveday again states that my statement, that no new Indians were allowed to come into the country, was wickedly false.
('4', 142, 1, 4, 345884) If I have erred, I have erred in the company of the Chief Secretary for Permits, who, you will recollect, only a few months ago, reported to Lord Milner that no new Indians were allowed to enter the Colony, and that permits were only sparingly granted to bona fide refugees.
('4', 142, 1, 5, 346159) Mr. Loveday, in refutation of the statement, cited Pretoria and Potchefstroom, and he says the population of the Indian Location at Pretoria had been doubled since the war, and, whereas before there were from 15 to 20 traders, there are now between 90 and 100. This is utterly without foundation.
('4', 142, 1, 6, 346456) The Indian population of Pretoria has certainly increased, but not doubled.
('4', 142, 1, 7, 346532) The increase is due to the influx of Indians from other parts of the Colony, who are unable to get licences or otherwise to get a living.
('4', 142, 1, 8, 346670) According to the Permits Officer, there are in the Colony not more than 10,000 Indians.
('4', 142, 1, 9, 346758) There were in 1896 nearly 10,000 Indians in the Transvaal, and it will not be doubted that the Indian population had increased considerably in 1899.In Pietersburg,the honourable gentleman says,prior to the war, they had 13 Indian stores; today they had 49.
('4', 142, 1, 10, 347015) As against that, I venture to state that there were 23 Indian stores before the war in the town alone, and that there are to day 28. Then, again, Mr. Loveday has stated:
('4', 142, 2, 11, 347185) The Indians had told them that they had certain rights, what they called their Charter of Liberty, but was there any social intercourse between Indians and whites in India?
('4', 142, 2, 12, 347358) None whatever.
('4', 142, 2, 13, 347373) The question is gratuitously brought up.
('4', 142, 2, 14, 347414) The Indians have never clai med any social intercourse here.
('4', 142, 2, 15, 347475) All they have claimed is the elemen tary right of reasonable facilities of trading, reasonable facilities for immigration under general restrictions, freedom of locomotion and of ownership of property; but, for the information of Mr. Loveday, I may state there is a measure of social intercourse also between Indians and Englishmen in India.
('4', 142, 2, 16, 347817) The balls given by the Maharaja of Kuch Behar attract the best European society.

('4', 143, 3, 6, 349425) 118. OURSELVES 1
('4', 143, 4, 7, 349442) Indian Opinion enters upon the third stage of its career in the short space of the eighteen months of its existence.
('4', 143, 4, 8, 349559) The proprietor, being guided by patriotic motives, embarked upon the enterprises on the slenderest resources.
('4', 143, 4, 9, 349669) He had to depend for the editing of the paper on purely voluntary and unpaid assistance.
('4', 143, 4, 10, 349758) This he readily received.
('4', 143, 4, 11, 349784) It was his intention to make the paper self supporting by devoting the profits from the general printing to meeting the expected deficiency on the paper.
('4', 143, 4, 12, 349938) But such was not to be the case.
('4', 143, 4, 13, 349971) Although this journal supplied a real want, what may be termed a commercial demand had to be created.
('4', 143, 4, 14, 350073) In other words, the paper had not only to find its matter, but its readers also.
('4', 143, 4, 15, 350154) Moreover, the sending of over five hundred com plimentary copies was a great drag.
('4', 143, 4, 16, 350237) Pecuniary assistance had, there fore, to be called in.
('4', 143, 4, 17, 350292) The Natal Indian Congress and the British Indian Association came to the rescue, and voted certain funds towards the payment of the expense of printing and posting the complimentary copies.
('4', 143, 4, 18, 350482) Still the paper continued, octopus like, to devour all it received

('4', 144, 1, 2, 350974) and wanted more.

('4', 144, 1, 4, 351046) Patchwork was useless.
('4', 144, 1, 5, 351069) Palliatives were dangerous.
('4', 144, 1, 6, 351097) There remain ed then an appeal to the devoted workers and friends in favour of adopting a novel and revolutionary project.
('4', 144, 1, 7, 351220) They were to look not to the present but to the future; not to their pockets but to the paper first.
('4', 144, 1, 8, 351321) And why not?
('4', 144, 1, 9, 351334) The object of Indian Opinion was to bring the Euro pean and the Indian subjects of King Edward closer together.
('4', 144, 1, 10, 351446) It was to educate public opinion, to remove causes for misunderstanding; to put before the Indians their own blemishes; and to show them the path of duty while they insisted on securing their rights.
('4', 144, 1, 11, 351646) This was an Imperial and pure ideal, towards the fruition of which anyone could work unselfishly.
('4', 144, 1, 12, 351744) So it appealed to some of the workers.
('4', 144, 1, 13, 351783) The plan was shortly this.
('4', 144, 1, 14, 351810) If a piece of ground sufficiently large and far away from the hustle of the town could be secured for hous ing the plant and machinery, each one of the workers could have his plot of land on which he could live.
('4', 144, 1, 15, 352022) This would simplify the question of living under sanitary and healthy conditions, without heavy expen ses.
('4', 144, 1, 16, 352129) The workers could receive per month an advance sufficient to cover necessary expenses, and the whole profits could be divided amongst them at the end of each year.
('4', 144, 1, 17, 352293) The management would thus be saved the necessity of having to find a large sum of money from week to week.
('4', 144, 1, 18, 352400) The workers also could have the option of buying out their plot of land at the actual cost price.
('4', 144, 1, 19, 352498) Living under such conditions and amid the beautiful surroun dings which have given Natal the name of the Garden Colony, the workers could live a more simple and natural life, and the ideas of Ruskin and Tolstoy [be] combined with strict business principles.
('4', 144, 1, 20, 352756) Or, on the other hand, the workers could reproduce the artificiality of town life, if it pleased them to do so.
('4', 144, 1, 21, 352868) One could hope that the spirit of the scheme and the surroundings would have an educative influence on them.
('4', 144, 1, 22, 352977) There would be a closer brotherly combination between the European and the Indian workers.
('4', 144, 1, 23, 353068) There was a possibility that the daily working hours could be reduced.
('4', 144, 1, 24, 353139) Each could become his own agriculturist.
('4', 144, 1, 25, 353180) The English workers could belie the taunt that the Englishman in South Africa would not cultivate the soil and work with his own hands.
('4', 144, 1, 26, 353316) He had here all the facilities for such work, without any of the drawbacks.
('4', 144, 1, 27, 353392) The Indian worker could copy his European brother, and learn the dignity and utility of healthy recreation as distinguished from constant, slaving toil for miserable gains.
('4', 144, 1, 28, 353565) The incentive would be threefold to all: and ideal to work for in the shape of Indian Opinion; perfectly healthy surroundings to live in, and an immediate prospect of owning a piece of land on the most advantageous terms; and a direct tangible interest and participation in the scheme.

('4', 146, 2, 5, 356244) After their first outburst, it will be remembered, they had cooled down considerably; and, in spite of the opposition of their friends from Boksburg, they had decided that compensation should be awarded to those Indians who might be driven to the Bazaar.

('4', 152, 3, 6, 371806) We cannot allow certain statements, made at the Potchefstroom meeting, recently reported 2 in our columns, to pass unchallenged, as we consider it necessary to place before our European friends the true facts, so as to enable them rightly to understand the Indian position.
('4', 152, 3, 7, 372080) We would quote Mr. Lovedays own words with regard to the admission of Indians into the Transvaal.
('4', 152, 3, 8, 372178) It was only after the arrival of the first Indian traders, and after the 1884 Convention had been substituted for that of 1881, that restrictive legislation was proposed.
('4', 152, 3, 9, 372349) Mr. Loveday would, therefore, make it appear that there were no Indian trading in the Transvaal before 1884, and that, therefore, Indians were not contemplated when the Convention was drawn up.
('4', 152, 3, 10, 372543) It is, nevertheless, a fact that Indians were contemplated in the working of the Convention, and that Indian merchants were trading in the Transvaal in 1881 and 1882 and, consequently, before 1884. Mr. Lovedays facts are thus vitiated, in this respect at least.
('4', 152, 3, 11, 372805) Moreover, as Mr. Gani has pointed out in a letter to The Star, 3 Law of 3 of 1885 was passed owing to very grave misrepresentations on the part of a large section of the white population.
('4', 152, 3, 12, 372993) It will scarcely be denied that such statements as the following,
('4', 152, 4, 13, 373059) the dangers to which the whole community is exposed by the spread of leprosy, syphilis, 4 and the like loathsome diseases engendered by the filthy habits and immoral practices of these people.
('4', 152, 4, 14, 373252) and also,
('4', 152, 5, 15, 373262) as these men enter the state without wives or female relations, the result is obvious.
('4', 152, 5, 16, 373349) Their religion teaches them to consider all women as soulless, and Christians as natural prey; are scarcely in accordance with our normal sense of what is fair and just representation.

('4', 153, 1, 9, 374804) In referring to the number of stores in Pretoria, Mr. Loveday was careless enough to remark that they had increased enormously.
('4', 153, 1, 10, 374932) It is a fact that, since the war, they have decreased by some thirty per cent, the number of white stores having increased in at least a similar proportionin Pretoria.
('4', 153, 1, 11, 375100) The Location is quite another matter, and the subject should not have been dragged in by the hair of the head, for the purpose of creating fictitious impressions.
('4', 153, 1, 12, 375263) If, then, Mr. Loveday is wrong as to matters relating to his own town, how can he be expected to know the facts concerning other towns of the Trans vaal, concerning other Colonies of South Africa, concerning India itself?
('4', 153, 1, 13, 375485) We propose to deal in a further article with the charge of un truthfulness levelled against the Indian, and endeavour to show that men, perfectly qualified to give an opinion on such a matter, which, we submit, with all due deference, Mr. Loveday is nothold very dif ferent views.

('4', 153, 1, 15, 375981) Apart altogether from the question of perjury, it will no doubt surprise Mr. Loveday to learn that the Crown Prosecutor in India has no greater powers than the Attorney General of the Transvaal and, in fact, his powers are not nearly so wide.
('4', 153, 1, 16, 376224) But Mr. Loveday has so far left his information undigested as to
('4', 153, 2, 17, 376289) 1 Vide Letter to The Star, dated Prior to December 24, 1904.

('4', 154, 1, 3, 376492) That is an improtant and a significant omission.
('4', 154, 2, 4, 376541) Referring now to the franchise of the Indian, it is a fact that he does possess a very definite francise.
('4', 154, 2, 5, 376647) Almost every town of impor tance in India has its Town Council or Local Board, partially or wholly elected by the rate payers the majority of whom are Indians.
('4', 154, 2, 6, 376807) There is, therefore, the municipal franchise to begin with.
('4', 154, 2, 7, 376867) There is also an indirect political franchise, in that some of the members of the Legislative Councils of the different Presidencies are elected by the members of the Corporations, who themselves are directly elected by the tax payers.
('4', 154, 2, 8, 377103) Hence we are quite within our rights in using the expression Indian franchise.
('4', 154, 2, 9, 377182) Therefore, also, Mr. Loveday was, as usual, inaccurate in stating that, in India, there were no forms of representative institutions, and that all present knew the Indian was governed by military rule, aided by religion and caste.
('4', 154, 2, 10, 377413) As to there being no social intercourse between Indian and white, Mr. Loveday forgets the great viceregal and Governmental receptions, where both sections of the community commingle, and such functions as the balls given by the Maharaja of Kuch Bahar, 1 where white and Indian meet on equal terms.
('4', 154, 2, 11, 377711) But this is all beyond the mark, for the Indian community in South Africa does not desire and has never demanded social intercourse with the whites believing it to be unnecessary and and inadvisable, for many reasons.
('4', 154, 3, 12, 377929) Certainly Indians are entertained at officers messes, as witness the case of Colonel Sir Pertab Singh, the King Emperors personal friend and aide de camp.
('4', 154, 3, 13, 378084) Certainly, also, white soldiers salute the higher ranks of Indian officers.
('4', 154, 4, 14, 378160) The question of a bastard race, resulting from intercourse between whites and Indians, was also brought forward, for obvious reasons, at the meeting.
('4', 154, 4, 15, 378310) It does not require to be said that anybody with the faintest knowledge of Indian life and Indian customs would never have dreamt of bringing forward such an argument as this, and we will not labour the subject.

('4', 156, 2, 5, 381480) 126. POTCHEFSTROOM CHURLISHNESS
('4', 156, 3, 6, 381512) Even the business people in Potchefstroom, who have only a remote and temporary connexion with the place, are either infected with its unreasonable anti Indian prejudice, or are being intimidated into the commission of acts of which, in their freer moments, they would be heartily ashamed.
('4', 156, 3, 7, 381802) An esteemed correspondent informs us that the insurance agents have, suddenly and without notice, withdrawn their fire policies from the Indian merchants.
('4', 156, 3, 8, 381957) We have never heard of such an instance anywhere else.
('4', 156, 3, 9, 382012) We are informed that the petty agents, who have succumbed, as we have said, either to local prejudice or to intimidation, represent world famous insurance companies, and we should be very much surprised if the stupid and unbusinesslike action of their agents be sanctioned by the head officers of these companies.
('4', 156, 3, 10, 382326) We only hope that both the agents and the managers headquarters will see these lines, and we strongly advise the Indian merchants concerned to make representation at headquarters.
('4', 156, 3, 11, 382506) The policy that Potchefstroom is developing in this matter is un British in the extreme, and it remains to be seen how far it will be endorsed in other parts of the Transvaal.

('4', 157, 2, 5, 383568) 128. SPEECH AT OPENING OF LIBRARY IN DURBAN
('4', 157, 3, 6, 383612) The following is a report of Gandhijis speech at the opening of a library in Durban, started in memory of Shri Lallubhai, the founder of the Natal Sanatan Dharma Sabha.
('4', 157, 4, 7, 383781) [DURBAN, January 10, 1905] While making a few important suggestions to the organisers of the Library, Mr. Gandhi said that, in a big city like Durban, where there was a large Indian population, a good library was indeed neces sary; and to meet that need leading citizens and businessmen of Dur ban had, some years earlier, made great efforts, and a library known as the Diamond Jubilee Library 1 was started in commemoration of the event.
('4', 157, 4, 8, 384220) But later, for lack of sufficient care and supervision, it was closed down.
('4', 157, 4, 9, 384296) He hoped that the new Library would not be reduced to a similar condition but that it would improve from day to day.
('4', 157, 4, 10, 384413) that the organisers would keep up their present enthusiasm and continue their efforts to ensure its permanent existence.
('4', 157, 4, 11, 384534) Mr. Gandhi then made some valuable suggestions regarding the selection of books and the hours during which the library should be kept open.
('4', 157, 4, 12, 384674) He exhorted the public to visit the library, particularly on Sundays, sit amidst the books, those mute, noble friends, and study them to profit.
('4', 157, 4, 13, 384819) He closed his address with a few words about Indian Opinion, and the library was then declared open.

('4', 158, 1, 2, 385102) 129. LETTER TO G.K. GOKHALE
('4', 158, 2, 3, 385130) 21 24 COURT CHAMBERS, CORNER, RISSIK & ANDERSON STREETS, P.O. BOX 6522 JOHANNESBURG, January 13, 1905
('4', 158, 3, 4, 385232) TO THE HONOURABLE PROFESSOR GOKHALE POONA
('4', 158, 4, 5, 385274) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE,
('4', 158, 5, 6, 385298) The existence of Indian Opinion you know.
('4', 158, 5, 7, 385340) It has now embar ked on career when I think I may fairly appeal to you for active sym pathy.
('4', 158, 5, 8, 385433) I propose to write perfectly frankly, as you know me too well to misunderstand me.
('4', 158, 5, 9, 385516) When I saw that Mr. Madanjit could not carry on the paper without pecuniary assistance and as I knew that he was guided by thoroughly patriotic motives, I placed at his service the bulk of my savings.
('4', 158, 5, 10, 385717) That, however, was not enough.
('4', 158, 5, 11, 385748) Three months ago I took over the whole responsibility and management.
('4', 158, 5, 12, 385818) Mr. Mad anjit still remains nominally the proprietor and publisher, because I believe that he has done much for the community.
('4', 158, 5, 13, 385945) My own office is at present being worked in the interests of Indian Opinion and I have already become responsible to the extent of nearly  3,500. Some English friends, who knew me intimately and before whom I placed the scheme as described in the enclosed, took up the idea and now it is in full working order and, although it does not show the same measure of self sacrifice as shown by the founders of the Fergusson College in Poona, I venture to think that it is not a bad copy.
('4', 158, 5, 14, 386427) It has been a most delightful thing to me to see the English friends coming forward so boldly.
('4', 158, 5, 15, 386522) They are not literary men but they are sterling, honest, inde pendent men.
('4', 158, 5, 16, 386597) Each of them had his own business or employment where he was doing well, and yet none of them had the slightest hesi tation in coming forward as a worker for a bare living which means  3 per month, with a distant prospect of getting profits.
('4', 158, 6, 17, 386839) It is also my intention, if my earnings continue, to open a school on the grounds, which would be second to none in South Africa for the education primarily of Indian children who would be resident boarders and, secondarily, of all who want to join the school
('4', 159, 0, 1, 387099) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 159, 1, 2, 387141) but would also reside on the premises.
('4', 159, 1, 3, 387180) For this, too, volunteer workers are required.
('4', 159, 1, 4, 387227) It would be possible to induce one or two Englishmen and English ladies here to give their lifetime to this work, but Indian teachers are absolutely necessary.
('4', 159, 1, 5, 387387) Could you induce any graduates who have an aptitude for teaching, who bear a blameless character and who would be prepared to work for a mere living?
('4', 159, 1, 6, 387537) Those who would come must be well tried, first class men.
('4', 159, 1, 7, 387595) I would want two or three at least but more could certainly be accommodated, and after the school is in working order, it is intended to add a sanatorium with open air treatment on hygienic lines.
('4', 159, 1, 8, 387792) My immediate purpose, however, is in connection with Indian Opinion.
('4', 159, 1, 9, 387861) If you approve of all I have said regarding it, will you kindly send a letter of encouragement to be sent to the editor for publication; also if you could spare a few moments, occasionally write an article ever so small for it?
('4', 159, 1, 10, 388089) I am also anxious to secure either honorary or paid correspondents who would contribute weekly notes in English, Gujarati, Hindi and Tamil.
('4', 159, 1, 11, 388229) If it becomes expensive, I might have to be satisfied with only English correspon dence which would lend itself to being translated in the three Indian languages.

('4', 159, 1, 13, 388455) The weekly notes should give an idea of what is being done on your side with reference to the Indian question, giving extracts from notices of the question in the newspapers, and should contain matters that are likely to be interesting to the Indians in South Africa.
('4', 159, 1, 14, 388723) You may at your discretion disclose partly or wholly the contents of this letter in so far as such a course may be necessary in the interests of the subject matter hereof.
('4', 159, 1, 15, 388895) I hope you are keeping good health.

('4', 159, 6, 20, 389011) 130. THE TRUTHFULNESS OF THE INDIAN
('4', 159, 7, 21, 389047) There seems to be a very general impression current that truth fulness, the outward manifestation of the eternal search after Truth, is a virtue entirely foreign to the nature of the inhabitants of India.
('4', 159, 7, 22, 389252) Room is not left for the possibility of misunderstanding, allowance is not made for the probability of wrong comprehension, but the Indian is set down at once as a scamp, a rogue, a lying vagabondall said, as a human being destitute of every vestige of honour.
('4', 160, 0, 1, 389513) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 161
('4', 160, 1, 2, 389556) Little or no differentiation is made between the Indians who have come to this country.
('4', 160, 1, 3, 389644) All are classed indiscriminately as cooliesor Arabs, and all are stigmatised as actual or potential liars.
('4', 160, 1, 4, 389751) It is for gotten, that generally speaking, there are two main classes of Indians in South Africa, the first being the indentured labourer class, and the second being the trading class.
('4', 160, 1, 5, 389936) As often as not, the indentured Indian is of low caste, and, consequently, once removed from his accustomed surroundings, and the moral restraints of his place of residence in India, he is liable to fall, in exactly the same way as any other human being situated in similar circumstances, from the ethical standard that he had set up for him when in India.
('4', 160, 1, 6, 390293) We cannot do better than quote the following from a widely circulated pamphlet: 1
('4', 160, 2, 7, 390375) Everyone I have met with in the Colony has dwelt upon the untruth fulness of the Indians.
('4', 160, 2, 8, 390465) To a limited extent, I admit the charge.
('4', 160, 2, 9, 390506) It will be very small satisfaction for me to show, in reply to the objection, that other classes do not fare much better in this respect, especially if and when they are placed in the position of the unfortunate Indians.
('4', 160, 2, 10, 390727) And yet, I am afraid, I shall have to fall back upon argument of that sort.
('4', 160, 2, 11, 390803) Much as I would wish them to be otherwise, I confess my utter inability to prove that they are more than human.
('4', 160, 2, 12, 390915) They come to Natal on starvation wages (I mean here the indentured Indians).
('4', 160, 2, 13, 390992) They find themselves placed in a strange position and amid uncon genial surroundings.
('4', 160, 2, 14, 391078) The moment they leave India they remain throughout life, if they settle in the Colony, without any moral education.
('4', 160, 2, 15, 391194) Whether they are Hindus or Mahomedans, they are absolutely without moral or religious instruction worthy of the name.
('4', 160, 2, 16, 391312) They have not learnt enough to educate themselves without any outside help.
('4', 160, 2, 17, 391388) Placed thus, they are apt to yield to the slightest temptation to tell a lie.
('4', 160, 2, 18, 391466) After some time, lying with them becomes a habit and a disease.
('4', 160, 2, 19, 391530) They would lie without any reason, without any prospect of bettering themselves materially, indeed, without knowing what they are doing.
('4', 160, 2, 20, 391667) They reach a stage in life when their moral faculties have completely collapsed owing to neglet.
('4', 160, 2, 21, 391764) Are these men, then, more to be despised than pitied?
('4', 160, 2, 22, 391818) Are they to be treated as scoundrels, deserving no mercy, or are they to be treated as helpless creatures, badly in need of simpathy?
('4', 160, 2, 23, 391952) Is there any class of people who would not do as they are doing under similar circumstances?
('4', 160, 3, 24, 392045) With regard to the trading classes, we absolutely deny that the Indian trader is more prone to falsehood than any other trader of any other race.
('4', 160, 3, 25, 392191) Probably, he is less addicted to untruthfulness than most, for, not having so many luxurious habits as his competitors of a more
('4', 160, 4, 26, 392320) 1 Open Letter, December 1894; vide Petition to Natal Legislative Council, 6 7 1894 to Constitution of the Natal Indian congress, 22 8 1894 2 ibid., The Asiatic Traders Commission in the Transvaal, 2 4 1904
('4', 161, 0, 1, 392526) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 161, 1, 2, 392568) complex civilisation, he has, therefore, not such great incentives to lie for the benefit of the firm.
('4', 161, 1, 3, 392671) And here we make bold to assert that it is an unfortunate characteristic of the less cultured Englishman that, when he is brought into contact with what is strange and to which he is unaccustomed, he does not endeavour to investigate its nature, but spurns it contemp tuously, as something foreign to his own outlook upon life, and he attributes to it every evil thing that can be imagined.
('4', 161, 1, 4, 393062) We think that, at this juncture, it would prove useful to hear what some very eminent white men have said publicly with reference to the truthfulness of the Indian.
('4', 161, 1, 5, 393227) Thus, Sir, George Birdwood, a very experienced Anglo Indian, says:
('4', 161, 2, 6, 393294) Moral truthfulness is as marked a characteristic of the Settia (upper) class of Bombay as of the Teutonic race itself.
('4', 161, 2, 7, 393413) The people of India, in short, are in no intrinsic sense our inferiors, whilst, in things measured by some of the false standardsfalse to ourselveswe pretend to believe in, they are our superiors.
('4', 161, 3, 8, 393610) Mr. Pincott says: In all social matters, the English are far more fitted to sit at the feet of Hindus and learn as disciples than to attempt to become masters.
('4', 161, 4, 9, 393770) And truth is certainly a social virtue.
('4', 161, 4, 10, 393810) Elphinstone says:
('4', 161, 5, 11, 393828) No set of people among the Hindus are so depraved as the dregs of our own great towns.
('4', 161, 5, 12, 393915) Sir John Malcolm says: I have hardly ever known, where a person did understand the language, or where a clam communication was made to a native of India, through a well informed and trustworthy medium, that the result did not prove what had at first been stated as falsehood had either proceeded from fear or from misunder standing.
('4', 161, 5, 13, 394248) I by no means wish to state that our Indian subjects are more free from this vice than other nations that occupy a nearly equal position in society, but I am positive that they are not more addicted to untruth.

('4', 161, 6, 16, 394569) The natives of India are often said to be altogether ignorant of the truth.

('4', 162, 1, 2, 394957) people, I have seldom known them tell a lie, even when the truth was to their own prejudice.

('4', 162, 2, 4, 395135) commercial honour stands higher in India than in any other country, and that a dishonoured bill is hardly known there.

('4', 162, 3, 9, 395933) We think that we have quoted sufficiently from men able, from experience, to give a just opinion, to prove the utter falsity of the general charge of want of veracity levelled at the Indians.
('4', 162, 3, 10, 396125) Where there is any lapse from strict adherence to accuracy of fact, it is but too often due to the Indians having been removed from all sources of moral control.
('4', 162, 3, 11, 396287) Indeed, Sir George Campbell is quoted as saying that the longer we possess a province, the more common and grave does perjury become.
('4', 162, 3, 12, 396421) We will conclude with one brief reference to the recent mass meeting at Potchefstroom.
('4', 162, 3, 13, 396508) Mr. Loveday had much to say concerning Oriental duplicity, falsehood, and cunning, and he even quoted Lord Macaulay as saying, with regard to Clive, that it was unquestionable that the duplicity of India had left its stain upon his (Clives) charac ter.
('4', 162, 3, 14, 396761) Now, we beg to point out that Macaulay, of all historians, is no longer read for his accuracy or his strict adherence to the simple facts of the case, but rather for his literary style and merit.
('4', 162, 3, 15, 396957) However, since Lord Macaulay has been quoted, we make no apology for reprodu cing the following words of his, which apply now, to day, and for all time, so long as India and England are linked together: We shall never consent to administer the pousta to a whole community, to stupefy and paralyse a great people, whom God has committed to our charge, for the wretched purpose of rendering them more amenable to our control.
