('4', 163, 3, 5, 397965) 131. INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS AND RUSSIAN ZEMSTVOS 2A COMPARISON: 1
('4', 163, 4, 6, 398033) The Indians resident in London, together with their European friends, gave a dinner in honour of Sir William Wedderburn and Sir Henry S. Cotton at the Westminster Palace Hotel on November 29, 1904, before their departure from that city.
('4', 163, 4, 7, 398270) Prominent people were invited to the function, and speeches were made.
('4', 163, 4, 8, 398341) In his speech Sir Henry Cotton made a brief comparison between the Indian National Congress and the Russian Zemstvos.
('4', 163, 4, 9, 398459) From a perusal of a later report, this analogy gives rise to a number of thoughts.
('4', 163, 5, 10, 398542) Every Indian knows in general and ought to know, if he already does not, what the Indian National Congress is, its origin, its function and its influence on the people as well as on the Government.
('4', 163, 5, 11, 398740) It is now twenty years since the Congress was founded.
('4', 163, 5, 12, 398795) The first session was held in Bombay; and such was the enthusiasm, insight, perseverance and courage of our Indian leaders of the time that far sighted persons felt convinced that the association would certainly be able to breathe new life into this country.
('4', 163, 5, 13, 399054) It is particularly necessary to remember this origin of the Congress.
('4', 163, 5, 14, 399124) Lord Dufferin believed that such a body should be founded.
('4', 163, 5, 15, 399183) He talked about it to Mr. Hume; the idea was very much to the latters liking and, as a result of his consultations with prominent public men in India, the Congress was ultimately founded.
('4', 163, 5, 16, 399371) It is necessary to bear this fact in mind, as it would be useful to us in refuting the numerous charges levelled against the Congress by its enemies.
('4', 163, 5, 17, 399521) The founding of the Congress caused great alarm particu larly in the minds of the autocratic, short sighted and haughty offi cials.
('4', 163, 5, 18, 399653) For they foresaw that the Congress would grow in strength day by day; that, looking upon the Congress as their very mother, the people would express their thoughts and feelings fearlessly at its
('4', 163, 6, 19, 399848) 1 Vide Letter to Mrs. A.M. Lewis, 4 8 1894 2 Local territorial assemblies in Russia regulating the affairs of the districts.
('4', 163, 6, 20, 399973) They were abolished by the Bolsheviks in 1917.
('4', 164, 0, 1, 400020) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 165
('4', 164, 1, 2, 400063) sessions; and that, consequently, autocracy and arrogance would no longer have their way unchallenged.
('4', 164, 1, 3, 400166) They were afraid and began to raise an outcry through their Press and made all sorts of unbecoming charges against the loyal Congress, hoping that as a result its life would be cut short.
('4', 164, 1, 4, 400354) These officers and their journals began heartily to abuse Congress leaders and tried to show that it was a seditious body and that, if the Government did not suppress it, the organisation would prove dangerous to the state.
('4', 164, 1, 5, 400578) The battle of arguments carried on during Lord Ripons 1 regime, however, opened their eyes and proved that not only could Indians understand their own interests, but that they could also formulate honest plans for the advancement of their country.
('4', 164, 1, 6, 400826) On the establishment of the Congress these thoughts recurred to the officials with the same intensity, and pressure was brought to bear on the Government.
('4', 164, 1, 7, 400981) Moreover, with a view to creating internal dissensions in the Congress, the Hindu Muslim question was raised and attempts were energetically made to foster disunity within the ranks of the Hindus and of the Muslims by creating distinctions as between Bengalis, Punjabis and Madrasis, etc.
('4', 164, 1, 8, 401270) In a short time, these obstructionists raised such a clamour that it influenced even a sound statesman like Lord Dufferin, who, speaking at the St. Andrews Din ner before leaving Calcutta, won Anglo Indian applause by venting his spleen upon the Congress.
('4', 164, 1, 9, 401526) It is no doubt true that, when the late Mr. Bradlaugh 2 expressed his opinion on this subject, Lord Dufferin had thought it fit to write to him [in order to clarify his speech].
('4', 164, 1, 10, 401704) But that is another story.
('4', 164, 1, 11, 401731) What we have at present to consider is just this: that, in spite of such difficulties, our leaders did not lose heart, but went on calmly doing their duty.
('4', 164, 1, 12, 401887) And thanks to their efforts, the time has now come when even the enemies of the Congress have to admit its stren gth, and haughty officials have to pay heed to its suggestions.
('4', 164, 1, 13, 402064) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 1 1905
('4', 164, 2, 14, 402106) 1 Lord Ripon, Vicerory of India and Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1880 4. 2 Charles Bradlaugh, (1833 91), well known public worker, Member of Parlia ment, and an avowed atheist.
('4', 164, 2, 15, 402291) He evinced a keen interest in Indian affairs and drafted, in 1889, a Bill for the reform of the Indian Councils.
('4', 164, 2, 16, 402404) He attended the third session of the Congress held in Bombay in 1889. While a student in England, Gandhiji attended Baradlaughs funeral.

('4', 165, 1, 2, 402583) 132. PLAGUE AND LIQUOR
('4', 165, 2, 3, 402606) The Punjab Government Report on liquor states that many people in the Punjab have taken to drink out of a dread of plague, and there has consequently been a great increase in the excise revenue from liquor.
('4', 165, 2, 4, 402813) The Report, moreover, states that the epidemic has bro ken out more virulently and casualties have been more numerous in places where people took to drinking in the belief that liquor preven ted plague infection, but that rather less harm was done by plague where people did not drink at all.
('4', 165, 2, 5, 403106) Although this does not prove that abstainers are immune from plague, this much it does prove that drin king leads to utter ruin.
('4', 165, 2, 6, 403235) Dr. Mellis, who was the Chief Medical Officer in the Plague Hospital in Johannesburg, is also of the same opinion, namely, that drinking does not check, but aggravates the plague.
('4', 165, 2, 7, 403415) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 14 1 1905
('4', 165, 3, 8, 403457) 133. PLAGUE IN JOHANNESBURG 1
('4', 165, 4, 9, 403487) JOHANNESBURG, January 16, 1905 Plague seems to have broken out in Johannesburg.
('4', 165, 4, 10, 403567) A few days ago, the son of a Muslim hawker in Sower Street caught the infection.
('4', 165, 4, 11, 403648) His doctor informed the authorities on Saturday.
('4', 165, 4, 12, 403697) On Sunday, he was removed to the Plague Hospital, the young man died to day and has already been buried.
('4', 165, 4, 13, 403802) No funeral rites could, therefore, be performed.
('4', 165, 4, 14, 403851) Normally, the authorities would gladly have handed the body over for this purpose.
('4', 165, 4, 15, 403934) Once again the dark clouds are gathering.
('4', 165, 4, 16, 403976) it will be to the great benefit of our people, if they bear in mind the following rules; otherwise, there would be immense harm.
('4', 165, 4, 17, 404105) What is more, it might be used as an argument for enacting more severe laws against us.
('4', 165, 4, 18, 404193) 1. No one should think that the Government will harass the patient after removing him to the hospital.
('4', 165, 4, 19, 404296) 2. The Government should be immediately informed in case of a sudden attack of fever or asthma.
('4', 165, 5, 20, 404392) 1 This appeared as From Our Correspondent.
('4', 166, 0, 1, 404435) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 167
('4', 166, 1, 2, 404478) 3. A doctor should immediately be consulted.
('4', 166, 1, 3, 404523) 4. Every one should stay where he is without becoming panicky.
('4', 166, 1, 4, 404586) 5. Those who might have come in contact with a plague patient should not try to conceal the fact, but should come forward to have their clothes, etc., disinfected.
('4', 166, 1, 5, 404750) 6. On should not, under any circumstances, have ones bed room attached to the shop in order to save money.
('4', 166, 1, 6, 404857) 7. One should not stock any goods for sale in ones house.
('4', 166, 1, 7, 404915) 8. One should keep ones house scrupulously clean.
('4', 166, 1, 8, 404965) 9. Every house or room should be well lighted and well ven tilated.
('4', 166, 1, 9, 405033) 10. One should sleep with the windows open.
('4', 166, 1, 10, 405077) 11.The clothes worn by day as well as those used during the night should be kept clean.
('4', 166, 1, 11, 405165) 12. The food taken should be light and simple.
('4', 166, 1, 12, 405212) 13. Lavish dinners and feasts should be stopped.
('4', 166, 1, 13, 405261) 14.Dry earth or ashes should be provided in latrines where buckets are used; and every one should, after easing himself, cover the night soil thoroughly with these so that no flies sit thereon.
('4', 166, 1, 14, 405455) 15. Lavatories and urinals should be kept clean.
('4', 166, 1, 15, 405504) 16. The floor and other parts of the house should be washed clean with disinfecting fluid mixed in hot water.
('4', 166, 1, 16, 405614) 17. No articles from an infected place should be used elsewhere without being properly disinfected.
('4', 166, 1, 17, 405714) 18. More than two persons should not sleep in a room of normal proportions.
('4', 166, 1, 18, 405790) 19. One should never sleep in the kitchen, dining room or the larder.
('4', 166, 1, 19, 405860) 20. Walls should be plastered with cement in order to keep out rats.
('4', 166, 1, 20, 405929) Care should, most of all, be taken to see that foodstuffs are kept beyond their reach.
('4', 166, 1, 21, 406016) 21.Those who always work indoors should go out into the open air and walk a couple of miles daily for exercise.

('4', 167, 3, 6, 406528) During that period I have been intimately connected with it.
('4', 167, 3, 7, 406589) In my humble opinion, it is discharging a worthy mission in that it acts as an inter preter between the two great communities in South Africa.

('4', 167, 3, 9, 407071) It represents a scheme which is briefly described in the enclosed, 2 and if it is at all successful, it may mark a revolution in business methods.
('4', 167, 3, 10, 407218) Anyhow the fact that there are four independent Englishmen who were engaged in their own busi nesses, [who] have given them up in order to work for its realisation and that there is an equal number of Indians who have done likewise 3 cannot but commend itself to you.

('4', 167, 3, 12, 407593) There are two ways in which, I venture to think, you could assist the enterprises.
('4', 167, 3, 13, 407676) The first by becoming a subscriber and by occasion ally writing for it either over your own signature or anonymously.

('4', 168, 2, 8, 409075) 135. INDIAN OPEN HANDEDNESSAND ITS SEQUEL
('4', 168, 3, 9, 409117) In another column of this issue will be found the published correspondence between the Potchefstroom Chief of Police and the Secretary of the Potchefstroom British Indian Committee, relative to a subscription from the latter body in support of a scheme for the esta blishment of a properly equipped fire brigade.
('4', 168, 3, 10, 409430) This correspondence passed some few weeks since, and it throws an interesting light upon a side of the Indian character that has been hitherto carefully ignored by the white residents of Potchefstroom.
('4', 168, 3, 11, 409632) It is to be hoped that other journals will give wider circulation to the facts chronicled in these two letters, for it is eminently desirable that the attitude of the British Indian community in Potchefstroom should be properly understood by our opponents.
('4', 168, 3, 12, 409889) We learn that the Municipality found themselves unable to contribute the necessary funds in aid of the fire brigade scheme, and, so far as we are aware, that scheme fell through.
('4', 168, 3, 13, 410068) But the point that we desire to make is this, that, at the time the proposal was made by Capt.
('4', 168, 3, 14, 410163) Jones and accepted by Mr. Rahman, several of the Indian merchants, and those, too, who would have sub scribed most largely to the fund, were already insured against fire.
('4', 168, 3, 15, 410334) We wish this to be very carefully understood in view of the sequel, for it throws the disinterestedness of the motives of the British Indian community of Potchefstroom in high relief against the some what gloomy background of Vigilance vindictiveness.
('4', 168, 4, 16, 410586) 1 The postscript is in Gandhijis hand, while the letter, possibly a circular addressed to influential persons, is typewritten.
('4', 169, 0, 1, 410713) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 169, 1, 2, 410755) In our issue of January 7th, we drew urgent attention to the action of a fire insurance agent in Potchefstroom in causing the can cellation, without notice, of certain policies that had been granted to British Indian merchants, covering their premises against the risks of fire, and that did not expire for several months to come.
('4', 169, 1, 3, 411086) It transpires that this gentleman represents one of the oldest established fire insu rance companies in the world.
('4', 169, 1, 4, 411201) At least six important merchants are affected, and their premises are no longer insured.
('4', 169, 1, 5, 411290) We are told, upon the best authority, that this gentleman has, if not actually joined the Anti Asiatic Vigilance Association, at least been adversely influenced by that body of terrorists.
('4', 169, 1, 6, 411479) The fiery cross has gone forth, and the world now knows that the white people of Potchefstroom have insti tuted a system of boycott that has, as one of its direct effects, the placing of the premises of inoffensive citizens in jeopardy, and that creates a serious risk to the Indian merchants of seeing the whole fruits of many years of hard, irksome toil consumed before their very eyes.
('4', 169, 1, 7, 411868) Malignancy could go no further.
('4', 169, 1, 8, 411900) With no fire brigade at hand, these unfortunate people are now helpless, and at the mercy of any stray spark that the winds may carry along, or of any incendiary whose morbid Colour madness may induce him to bring fiery ruin upon the head of the wretched owner of the first inviting store that may present itself.
('4', 169, 2, 9, 412214) We do not speak wild words of hysteria, for the danger is a very real one.
('4', 169, 2, 10, 412289) The dastardly attempt at incendiarism in Potchefstroom, shortly after the virulent anti Indian epidemic reached a crisis there, will still be fresh in the memories of our readers.
('4', 169, 2, 11, 412469) We use the world incen diarism, in this connexion, on the authority of the Chief of Police himself, and we regret to think that this courteous officer is not in a position to guard every store that is liable to attack in this cowardly way.
('4', 169, 3, 12, 412709) From the point of view of the fire insurance company itself, the Indian stores in Potchefstroom should at least be a favourable a risk as those of the European traders, for, from our own intimate knowledge of them, the comparison between the stores of the two sections of the community would not be unfavourable to the Indians.
('4', 169, 3, 13, 413037) Consequently, we are unable to find any grounds for the inexplicable action of the company in cancelling the policies.
('4', 169, 3, 14, 413156) There could surely be no question of commercial integrity involved, or the traders affected would never
('4', 170, 0, 1, 413260) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 171
('4', 170, 1, 2, 413303) have been granted polices.
('4', 170, 1, 3, 413330) Moreover, they are all well known merch ants of established character, and even the most superficial inquiries would have revealed the fact that there could be no foundation for any imputation against their honour and trustworthiness.
('4', 170, 2, 4, 413565) The whole affair does not greatly redound to the credit of Pot chefstroom, and the scandal thus perpetrated places a stigma upon the fire insurance company concerned.
('4', 170, 3, 5, 413732) It is our intention to call the immediate attention of the head quarters staff of the company to the matter.
('4', 170, 3, 6, 413841) We are certain that its British sense of justice and of fair play will induce it to make the most stringent inquiries, and we have no doubt whatever but that an intolerable situation will be terminated as speedily as is possible in the circumstances.

('4', 170, 5, 8, 414118) 136. INDIAN NATIONAL CONGRESS AND RUSSIAN ZEMSTVOS A COMPARISON: 2
('4', 170, 6, 9, 414185) Every wise ruler is eager to know the real condition of his subjects, their happiness and their misery, and so are, more or less, our King Emperor Edward and the Czar of Russia.
('4', 170, 6, 10, 414363) Both of them have the same desire, but employ different methods.
('4', 170, 6, 11, 414428) Fortunately for us, the officers in India are not so arrogant as those in Russia; nor have they the same [wide] powers.
('4', 170, 6, 12, 414548) That is to say, Indian officials have to conf orm to rules and cannot show the same arrogance and high hande dness as their opposite numbers in Russia.
('4', 170, 6, 13, 414700) So that, on the whole, officials in India cannot, even if they would, tyrannize over the people to the same extent as in Russia.
('4', 170, 6, 14, 414829) Even so, some of the sufferings of the Russian and Indian peoples are of the same kind, even if those in India are comparatively less acute.
('4', 170, 6, 15, 414970) But the people India in do not look upon their hardships as normal and this is but natural.
('4', 170, 6, 16, 415062) In Russia there is no difference of colour, creed, caste or language between the offici als and the subjects, while in India the officials are in every way diff erent from the people, and some aloofness though this is hardly nec essary is, therefore, always felt.
('4', 170, 6, 17, 415326) These grievances naturally cause the people some unhappiness.
('4', 170, 6, 18, 415388) There, then, exists, in both the countries, a certain coolness and distance between the officials and the people and
('4', 171, 0, 1, 415505) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 171, 1, 2, 415547) the latter smart under it.
('4', 171, 1, 3, 415574) They believe that the relations between the ruler and the ruled should be very close; that there should be mutual trust, that they should share in the others weal and woe and treat one another with love and affection.
('4', 171, 1, 4, 415792) In short, there should an identity of interest between the king and his subjects, the former being consid ered happy only if the latter are so.
('4', 171, 1, 5, 415936) The king no doubt wields power, but if he abuses it, both he and his subjects will suffer.
('4', 171, 1, 6, 416027) Hence it is that wise rulers are always eager to know the true condition of their subjects, their joy and their sorrow.
('4', 171, 1, 7, 416147) The kingdoms of old were generally very small compared to those of to day, and the king could easily rule over his subjects him self.
('4', 171, 1, 8, 416281) But, as the kingdoms grew in size, the need of employing offi cials arose, with the result that in all civilised communities kings have been reduced to the status of figure heads, and officials have become indispensable and all important.
('4', 171, 1, 9, 416520) The officials know quite well that, without them, there can be no king, and they naturally contrive in all possible ways to ensure that their prestige and authority are never det racted from.
('4', 171, 1, 10, 416712) Consequently, they begin to consider self interest more important than duty, and sufficient attention is not paid to the welfare of the people.
('4', 171, 1, 11, 416856) This leads to discontent and as the officials do not have the patience to listen to the complaints or criticism of the people, a cleavage between the two develops.
('4', 171, 1, 12, 417020) This leads to all possible efforts and plans by the subjects to break official high handedness and to protect their own rights.
('4', 171, 1, 13, 417148) Instances are few where the standard of adm inistration is good; more often it is inefficient or corrupt.
('4', 171, 1, 14, 417254) There is a great deal of difference between the policies of the Governments of Russia and India, and, consequently, between the peoples condition and feelings in the two countries.
('4', 171, 1, 15, 417435) But the officials in both countries have more or less excessive powers and, therefore, the relations bet ween them and the people are not what they should be.
('4', 171, 1, 16, 417594) It must be clear from the foregoing that the feelings and demands of the people are, in several respects, the same in both countries, though the con ditions differ.
('4', 171, 1, 17, 417759) This is due to the far too scanty contact between the ruler and the ruled.
('4', 171, 1, 18, 417834) As the causes are similar, so are the results.
('4', 171, 1, 19, 417881) Wonderful are the ways of Nature.
('4', 171, 1, 20, 417915) Last November, there was a public discussion regarding the agenda for the Congress session at Bombay.
('4', 171, 1, 21, 418017) About the same time, the local assemblies in Russia, called Zemstvos, declared their aspirations and demands.

('4', 175, 2, 3, 424973) The Johannesburg Town Council has been for some time considering the question of Native cyclists.
('4', 175, 2, 4, 425071) The Works Committee brought out, last week, a report, and advised that a bye law should be passed whereby every Native, holding a cycle permit and riding a cycle within the municipal area, should wear on his left arm, in a cons picuous position, a numbered badge which shall be issued to him, tog ether with his permit.
('4', 175, 2, 5, 425391) That, in a cosmopolitan town like Johannes burg, the Town Council should, by a large majority, have passed such a drastic bye law is to us a matter of painful surprise, notwithstanding the fact that colour prejudice is a strong ruling sentiment in South Africa.
('4', 175, 2, 6, 425653) Mr. Langermann was the champion supporter of the bye law against the mild protest from Messrs.
('4', 175, 2, 7, 425748) Mackie Niven and Quinn, and he justified it on the ground that they must make a distinction between Native and white riders of bicycles.
('4', 175, 2, 8, 425885) The badge, he said, must be in front.
('4', 175, 2, 9, 425923) It was absolutely necessary to distinguish the Native from the white men. This remark naturally excited some laughter, as, unlike Mr. Langermann, the other members were evidently quite capable of distinguishing a Native from a white man without a badge being necessary.
('4', 175, 2, 10, 426193) Mr. Langermann, in our opinion, proves the truth of the adage that those, who have suffered persecution, instead of sympath ising with the persecuted after they have escaped from it themselves, delight in the persecution of others.
('4', 175, 2, 11, 426425) Mr. Langermann is never slow in protesting against the persecution of his co religionists in Russia.
('4', 175, 2, 12, 426526) May not a Native ask the questionhas he no feelings?

('4', 175, 2, 14, 426738) The tone of the speeches made at the meeting was, we say with all deference to the Town Council, highly discreditable, and reflects all the greater honour on the minority consisting of Messrs.
('4', 175, 2, 15, 426931) Niven, Quinn, Rockey, and Pim, who had the courage of their convictions, and did not hesitate to defend the Native against unnecessary and wanton indignity.
('4', 175, 2, 16, 427088) We are, as a rule, very reluctant about expressing opinions on matters not specially coming within the purview of this journal, but the proceedings of the Town Council are, in our opinion, so scandalous, that we should be failing in our duty if we did not, in

('4', 176, 2, 4, 427504) 141. THE HOONDAMAL CASE
('4', 176, 3, 5, 427528) The Hoondamal case has now entered upon the last stage, or, shall we say, the first stage of a new phase.
('4', 176, 3, 6, 427634) Hoondamal, the individual, disappears from view, but the Indian trading community replaces him.
('4', 176, 3, 7, 427730) In the Test Case of Hoondamal v.
('4', 176, 3, 8, 427763) Rex, the Supreme Court has said the final word, and the Durban Town Council has won a momentary triumph.
('4', 176, 3, 9, 427868) We use the word momentary deliberately.
('4', 176, 3, 10, 427908) We cannot think that a triumph of prejudice and injustice can ever be permanent.
('4', 176, 3, 11, 427989) Such a conclusion would be entirely opposed to all the teachings of history and philosophy.
('4', 176, 3, 12, 428081) Is there anyone who will dare say that the Town Council of Durban has shown even the slightest desire or inclination to mete out justice to this unfortunate man?
('4', 176, 3, 13, 428243) Every means has been taken by it to bring about his ruin, because, in the words of the Licensing Officer which have been officially disapproved of, but which, we have only too much reason to believe, are privately endorsed by members of the Town Council further Asiatic licences should not be granted in West Street.
('4', 176, 4, 14, 428560) There are times when what is nearest the heart is nearest the lips, and we fear that, notwithstanding the official disclaimer of the Town Council, the Licensing Officers opinion is emphatically held by his employers, and the cat has, perhaps unwittingly, been let out of the bag.
('4', 176, 4, 15, 428840) The effect, then, of the Supreme Courts decision is to make West Street a close preserve for white traders, and no Indians need apply for licences to trade in that select thoroughfare.
('4', 176, 4, 16, 429025) But, we ask, can the matter be allowed to remain where it is?
('4', 176, 4, 17, 429087) Dare such a condition of affairs be permitted to be continued?
('4', 176, 4, 18, 429150) We think not.
('4', 176, 4, 19, 429164) We do not now deal with the legal merits of the case, but it appears more than strange that the Supreme Court should have ruled that a man, holding a trading licence, can have his, licence nullified by mere removal from one place to another within the boundaries of the same town.
('4', 176, 4, 20, 429445) However that may be, the matter seems to us to be sufficiently important to be taken to a higher tribunal.
('4', 176, 4, 21, 429552) It may well be that other arguments can be produced that will entail some modi fication of the present conditions.
('4', 177, 0, 1, 429667) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 177, 1, 2, 429709) Whilst the drama before the Supreme Court was in process of enactment, a side issue was being considered within the Town Council Chamber.
('4', 177, 1, 3, 429847) The Durban Corporation has attacked the Hoondamal citadel in West Street from all directions, and it would appear that the sapping tactics have proved successful in undermining its foundations.
('4', 177, 1, 4, 430041) By these devious methods, the fortress has, seemingly, fallen, but the defender has not been disgraced, for from the ashes of his defence will arise a yet mightier champion, who will wrench justice from relu ctant hands, an compel circumstances to his needs.
('4', 177, 2, 5, 430300) The side issue, to which we have made reference, was the appeal of Mr. Hoondamal to the Town Council against the Licensing Offi cers decision to refuse a licence in respect of the premises in West Street.
('4', 177, 2, 6, 430505) In spite of the dignified protest of Mr. Burne, the Town Coun cil has upheld the Licensing Officers decision to refuse the licence, and although dissociating itself publicly from the reason given by the Licensing Officer, it has not substituted a reason of its own for the one repudiated.
('4', 177, 3, 7, 430794) But another astounding point arises in connection with this hearing.
('4', 177, 3, 8, 430863) The Mayor has laid down the extraordinary dictum that the Licensing Officers discretion is arbitrary, and not, as contended by Mr. Hoondamals counsel, to be exercised within the four corners of the law.
('4', 177, 3, 9, 431066) It is not within our province to comment upon the legal aspect of this ruling; we merely place it on record.
('4', 177, 3, 10, 431175) The struggle promises to be a titanic one.
('4', 177, 3, 11, 431218) Indeed, the Indian community must either take it up or succumb.
('4', 177, 3, 12, 431282) It is no mere question of the annihilation of Mr. Hoon damal.
('4', 177, 3, 13, 431344) Whilst such a result would be deplorable, it would be compara tively insignificant.
('4', 177, 3, 14, 431428) The matter is of far larger concern than the con servation of the privileges of an individual.
('4', 177, 3, 15, 431523) The whole Indian trading community is threatened with extinction.
('4', 177, 3, 16, 431589) What has happened to Mr. Hoondamal may happen to every single Indian trader.
('4', 177, 3, 17, 431666) So long as the newly laid down interpretation of the law holds good, no Indians business is worth a days takings.
('4', 177, 4, 18, 431780) The net result of the decision of the Supreme Court is this.
('4', 177, 4, 19, 431841) It is known that the desire of the white population is to stamp out the Indian traders piecemeal.
('4', 177, 4, 20, 431939) It has been ruled that licences are granted for particular premises only and are not transferable.
('4', 177, 4, 21, 432038) A landlord may, in consequence, rackrent a tenant trader to the top of his bent, and the trader is abjectly helpless.
('4', 177, 4, 22, 432156) He must either be ruined by the landlord or
('4', 178, 0, 1, 432200) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 179
('4', 178, 1, 2, 432243) he must seek new premises.
('4', 178, 1, 3, 432270) If he chooses the latter alternative, his licence becomes invalid, and his trading privileges null and void.
('4', 178, 1, 4, 432379) He cannot obtain what will then be considered a new licence, for just as it may be (unofficially) judged to be unnecessary to issue new licences for Asiatics to trade in West Street, so every other trading locality within the town limits may be debarred to him, and he will be extinguished as absolutely as a moth in a candle flame.
('4', 178, 2, 5, 432712) This is a matter, not for individual consideration, but for the corporate deliberation of the whole Indian community all over South Africa.
('4', 178, 2, 6, 432852) The battle ground has been temporarily removed from the Transvaal to Natal.
('4', 178, 2, 7, 432928) What applies to Durban applies to the whole Col ony, and what now applies to Natal may not improbably apply to South Africa as a whole.
('4', 178, 2, 8, 433064) Evil example is quickly followed.

('4', 179, 2, 4, 434908) 143. PIETERSBURG TRADERS
('4', 179, 3, 5, 434933) We publish, in another column, a report from our Pietersburg correspondent, together with correspondence that has passed between the Employees Association and the local British Indian Committee on the question of early closing.
('4', 179, 3, 6, 435161) It will be evident, from a perusal of these documents, that there is a rather strong feeling existent in Pie tersburg on this subject.
('4', 179, 3, 7, 435296) We have repeatedly pointed out that invidious distinction is made between Asiatics and Europeans, in matters of trade especially, and again and again have we shown how the white population has endeavoured to saddle the Indian community with a share of responsibility and of penalty, whereas is has carefully refrai ned from granting them any measure of privilege.
('4', 179, 3, 8, 435660) Now it happens that human nature is so organised that deprivation of privilege is not considered, by those who are deprived, as an equivalent to equality of responsibility or imposition of burden and it cannot be wondered at that, in such circumstances, the Indian community has frequently refused to accept obligations thrust upon it by the white inhabitants who persist in refusing equality of opportunity.
('4', 179, 3, 9, 436069) The Pietersburg Indian traders, as a matter of fact, did fall in with the wishes and desi res of their white fellow traders, so long as the latter imposed upon them no special disabilities.
('4', 179, 3, 10, 436259) But when the white traders commenced their methods of boycott and ostracism, the Indian traders began to perceive that they must consider themselves apart from the rest of the community.
('4', 179, 3, 11, 436446) The sequel is to be found in this correspondence to which we make reference.
('4', 179, 3, 12, 436523) The white traders must alter their mode of procedure if they wish the Indian merchants to abide by the conven tion they would set up.
('4', 179, 3, 13, 436657) There must be give and take on both sides.

('4', 180, 3, 14, 438616) 145. ATTACK ON THE KAFFIRS
('4', 180, 4, 15, 438643) The Johannesburg Town Council could not bear to see the Kaffirs riding bicycles like the whites, and therefore passed, at its last meeting, a resolution to the effect that a Kaffir who had a permit to own a bicycle must wear on his left arm, while riding in the city, a badge with the number on it, easily visible.
('4', 180, 5, 16, 438958) The Transvaal administration is nowadays carried on in such a manner that this resolution causes us no surprise.
('4', 180, 5, 17, 439071) We write about it to day only to remind our Indian brethrenthough we do not think it quite necessarythat present day Johannesburg is far different from the Johannesburg of pre war days.
('4', 180, 5, 18, 439257) Most of the people how now hold the reins of power were known, before the outbreak of the war, as Uitl anders, and were always quick to raise an outcry demanding justice for themselves.
('4', 180, 5, 19, 439443) Foreign nationals called themselves British subjects and made all possible efforts to secure for themselves the rights enjo yed by the British.

('4', 181, 0, 1, 439639) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('4', 181, 1, 4, 439849) These were the very British subjects, who first incited the Boer Government against Indians, and later questioned its authority to legislate against them.
('4', 181, 1, 5, 440004) It was again these British sub jects who at last got Lord Milner and Mr. Chamberlain to go to war with the Boers.

('4', 181, 1, 7, 440346) This was the first act of the dramas.
('4', 181, 1, 8, 440384) In the second act, everything was forgotten, and these very British subjects became engrossed in serving their own interests.
('4', 181, 1, 9, 440510) Then followed the third act, in which open enmity to the Indians began to be manifested.
('4', 181, 1, 10, 440599) And in the fourth act, which is being staged now, opp ressive laws are being passed and put into execution with the utmost rigour.

('4', 182, 3, 9, 443035) He says that, of the slaughter houses inspected by him, one or two were extremely dirty.
('4', 182, 3, 10, 443124) On the main road in Meadland, he found entrails and fat hung against the wall from a hook.
('4', 182, 3, 11, 443215) Blood and offal had got stuck to the wall to a height of four feet above the ground.
('4', 182, 3, 12, 443300) He found that the common practice of the place was to lime wash the walls over the accumulated layers of waste matter, and this had resulted in solid accretions of lime and refuse on the walls.
('4', 182, 3, 13, 443494) The men working there were very slovenly, their clothes dirty and covered over with layers of grease.
('4', 182, 3, 14, 443596) These often came in contact with the meat.
('4', 182, 4, 15, 443639) Needless to say, all this has been found in slaughter houses run and managed by the whites, too.
('4', 182, 4, 16, 443736) The question arises how such offen ces have remained undetected all these days.

('4', 186, 3, 7, 452426) 150. CONCEALMENT OF PLAGUE
('4', 186, 4, 8, 452453) We regret that there are still Indian in Durban who do not yet know the serious consequences of concealing infectious disease.
('4', 186, 4, 9, 452580) On Monday last, an Indian employed by the Durban Corporation was sentenced to pay a fine of  20, or, in default, to three months hard labour, for concealing a case of plague.
('4', 186, 4, 10, 452755) The sentence is exemplary, and rightly so.
('4', 186, 4, 11, 452798) The case was that of a girl, who was removed to an empty house by her father, so soon as he found she was sick.
('4', 186, 4, 12, 452910) The reason he gave the Magistrate was that he did not want the European doctors to take her away from him.
('4', 186, 4, 13, 453017) That, perhaps, was very natural; but Indians must learn that, in this matter, they are under the same law as Europeans.
('4', 186, 4, 14, 453137) Each case of infectious disease must be notified to the authorities, whoever the sufferer may be; and everyone, whether he be Indian or European, has to put his own private feelings into his pocket, for the general good.
('4', 186, 4, 15, 453358) It is too much to expect that every Indian of the indentured class will look at the matter from this point of view, but it is not too much to expect that Indians of the higher class will assist Dr. Murison in dealing with disease.
('4', 186, 4, 16, 453589) We again call attention to the Health Officers letter in our issue of Dec.
('4', 186, 4, 17, 453664) 10th., and to our remarks thereon.
('4', 186, 4, 18, 453699) Our Indian friends must remember that every prosecution of this kind reflects, however undeservedly, on the whole community.
('4', 186, 4, 19, 453824) But the fault does not lie only on the side of the Indians.
('4', 186, 4, 20, 453884) We cannot agree with The Natal Mercury that it is due to the action of certain Indians that the plague is still with us.
('4', 186, 4, 21, 454005) It is true that Indians are generally the victims of this dread disease.
('4', 186, 4, 22, 454078) But, as in answer to the question, Who breeds our plagues? a correspondent very pertinently replied in our columns last week, Who puts the In dian under such circumstances as to make him a breeder of plagues?
('4', 187, 0, 1, 454287) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 187, 1, 2, 454329) There are plague spots in Durban under the direct control of the Town Council: why, then, lay all the blame on the poor Indian, if, as a natural consequence, plague is developed?
('4', 187, 1, 3, 454508) The matter is, indeed, too important to be lightly dismissed, and we propose to deal fully with the whole question of municipal sanitation in a succeeding issue.

('4', 187, 2, 5, 454696) 151. INDIAN LICENCES: NEED FOR VIGILANCES1
('4', 187, 3, 6, 454739) Sheth Hoondamals licence has been a subject of discussion for the past several months.
('4', 187, 3, 7, 454826) Our readers are aware that Sheth Hoondamal has been carrying on trade in Durban for nearly ten years.
('4', 187, 3, 8, 454928) At first he opened a shop in West Street, one of the principal thoroughfares of Durban.
('4', 187, 3, 9, 455016) As the landlord wanted to get the building repaired, he had the shop vacated.
('4', 187, 3, 10, 455094) Not being able to get a place to his liking in West Street, Sheth Hoodamal secured a good shop in nearby Grey Street and started his business there.
('4', 187, 3, 11, 455243) Some months later, on being required to vacate the premises, he rented from an Indian landlord a better and larger shop in West Street which had been recently vacated by an Indian merchant, and began to trade there.
('4', 187, 3, 12, 455459) Simultaneously, he applied to the Licensing Officer to have his new address entered on his licence.
('4', 187, 3, 13, 455559) Not only did that Officer reject his application, but he also charged Hoondamal with trading without a licence.
('4', 187, 3, 14, 455671) Legal proceedings were instituted against him in a Magistrates Court, and Sheth Hoon damal was fined.
('4', 187, 3, 15, 455773) The latter thereupon appealed against the Magis trates judgment.
('4', 187, 3, 16, 455838) Before this appeal could be heard, the Town Council dragged Sheth Hoondamal to the Magistrates Court twice or thrice, and each time the Magistrate fined him, and on one occasion the Magistrate, Mr. Stuart, even exceeded his authority and passed an illegal order, asking Sheth Hoondamal to close down his shop.
('4', 187, 3, 17, 456148) The latter, of course, disregarded the order as it was illegal; and through his attorney, Mr. Wyllie, sent a strongly worded note to the Magistrate and the police, saying that, if the order was implemented, the exec uting officials would be held responsible for the consequences.
('4', 187, 3, 18, 456428) The Magistrate was greatly enraged at this, but he was helpless, the order not being lawful.
('4', 187, 3, 19, 456521) The appeal was heard by the Circuit Court when it sat in Durban, and Sheth Hoondamal was found not guilty.
('4', 187, 3, 20, 456628) Thereafter, the police brought another charge against him, and the Magistrate found him guilty.
('4', 187, 3, 21, 456724) The appeal against that judgment was heard by the Supreme Court this month, and to the misfortune of the Indian traders, the jud ges gave their decision against Sheth Hoondamal.
('4', 187, 3, 22, 456902) Sheth Hoondamal
('4', 188, 0, 1, 456918) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 189
('4', 188, 1, 2, 456961) had applied last month for a licence for the current year, which the Licensing Officer rejected.
('4', 188, 1, 3, 457058) An appeal was then field before the Town Council.
('4', 188, 1, 4, 457108) Stating the reason for not granting Sheth Hoondamal a lice nce, the Licensing Officer said that it was not desirable to issue more licences to Asiatics in West Street !
('4', 188, 1, 5, 457277) When this reason for refusal was brought to the Knowledge of the Town Council by Sheth Hoonda mals counsel, the Councillors naturally felt abashed, for the Licen sing Officer had also added that such was the desire of the Councillors as well.
('4', 188, 1, 6, 457520) On hearing this, Mr. Burne, who is a member of the Council and also a renowned lawyer, immediately protested that the Licensing Officer had no warrant to attribute such a desire to the Town Council.
('4', 188, 1, 7, 457719) At this the Officer got up and answered that he had rejected applicat ions on the same ground in the past, and that his decision had always been endorsed by the Council; his claim could not be proved incorrect.
('4', 188, 1, 8, 457930) To prevent this dispute from developing further, a Council lor moved that the appeal be dismissed.
('4', 188, 1, 9, 458029) Another member seconded the resolution, introducing while doing so a further legalistic argume nt that under the law the discretion to grant or refuse licences was ves ted in the Licensing Officer.
('4', 188, 1, 10, 458227) After hearing this point of law, the appli cants counsel answered that even this discretion could only be exer cised in accordance with the law, and that it was no discretion which violated the law or transgressed it.
('4', 188, 1, 11, 458445) The Councillors did not relish this argument.
('4', 188, 1, 12, 458491) Consequently, Sheth Hoondamal was not granted a licence and has had to close down his shop.

('4', 188, 2, 14, 458625) 152. CORPORATION INSANITATION There was submitted, at the ordinary monthly meeting of the Durban Town Council, on the 7th inst., a Report by the Inspector of Nuisances relative to the Eastern and Western Vleis.
('4', 188, 2, 15, 458836) It is noteworthy that this official makes reference to certain areas, the buildings on which are variously described as dilapidated and imperfect as to sani tation and building characteristics, whilst the ground itself is said to be undrained.
('4', 188, 2, 16, 459080) These buildings, moreover, are declared to be used for habitable purposes, and also unfit for human habitation.
('4', 188, 2, 17, 459192) We are forcibly reminded of a meeting held, under the auspices of the Natal Indian Congress, in June of 1903, when emphasis was laid upon an allegation made in the Minute, submitted by the Mayor to the Town Council, concerning the insanitary habits of the Indian popula tion, and urging this as one of several reasons why Indians should be relegated to Locations, or, as they have been euphemistically designa ted, Bazaars.
('4', 189, 0, 1, 459616) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 189, 1, 2, 459658) Lord Milner, it will be remembered, in his memorable Notice No.
('4', 189, 1, 3, 459722) 356 of 1903, drew special attention to the exception that was to be made in respect of Asiatics whose habits of life and social qualities were not repugnant to European ideas or in conflict with sanitary laws.
('4', 189, 1, 4, 459932) We venture to suggest that any doctor or hospital nurse will confirm our assertion that, even amongst higher class Europeans, scientific sanitation is not always favourably regarded.
('4', 189, 1, 5, 460115) That, however, is by the way.
('4', 189, 1, 6, 460145) The real point is that it is not always just that the general opinion of Europeans, who are often most ignorant of what they are most assured, and as often prejudiced against conditions and circumstances that are strange to them, should be taken as a reasonable criterion.
('4', 189, 1, 7, 460418) The opinion of the man in the street is, notoriously, vastly different from, and often opposed to, the opinion of the man in the study, who has greater and more frequent opportunity of collecting, sifting and judging the facts of which he speaks.
('4', 189, 2, 8, 460665) There are Indians and Indians; there are Indians who approach absolutely to the scientific European standard of sanitation, and there are Indians who have not yet adopted other modes of sanitation than those to which they have been accustomed, almost from time immem orial, in the remote districts of India.
('4', 189, 2, 9, 460973) Similar distinctions may, indeed, be made amongst the inhabitants of civilised nations the world over.
('4', 189, 2, 10, 461076) There is always, and will be for long years to come, this difference between the educated and the ill instructed.
('4', 189, 3, 11, 461190) When, then, we hear the charge so frequently levelled against the Indian that he is insanitary, we are impelled to ask: Which Indian do you mean?
('4', 189, 3, 12, 461336) And do you refer to personal cleanliness or to domi ciliary sanitation? For nothing is more important than that those who bring a charge of this impalpable nature should be pinned down to something more definite and less dangerously vague.
('4', 189, 3, 13, 461576) It is a common observation that a generalisation is often a successful catchword to throw to an unthinking man, whereas a definite statement of fact would crush him.
('4', 189, 4, 14, 461742) It is our experience that, generally speaking, the Indian is not insanitary.
('4', 189, 4, 15, 461819) It must be distinctly borne in mind that we do not assert that no Indians are insanitary.
('4', 189, 4, 16, 461909) We argue from a knowledge of the national customs and traditions of the various Indian peoples, and can confidently say that, be these Hindus or Mohamedans, their faith, which is a living one to them, inculcates absolute principles of perso nal cleanliness and, as a corollary, domestic sanitation, even amongst the lowest classes, and this may easily be confirmed by any one who is at all conversant with the normal conditions of Indian life.
('4', 190, 0, 1, 462353) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 191
('4', 190, 1, 2, 462396) But what have we?
('4', 190, 1, 3, 462414) We have the Eastern and the Western Vleis!
('4', 190, 1, 4, 462457) We have heard much hard talk of Bazaars and Locations, of disinf ection and of segregation.
('4', 190, 1, 5, 462549) Somehow or other, the remaining terms of the proposition appear to have been very carefully or, shall we say, carelessly left out of consideration.
('4', 190, 1, 6, 462697) For the benefit of the public that takes an interest in sanitary matters and question of hygiene, we propose to quote from the Report of the Sanitary Committee of the Town Council, published in The Natal Mercury so far back as 1899, and of which Committee the Hon.
('4', 190, 1, 7, 462962) R. Jameson was Chairman.
('4', 190, 1, 8, 462987) 2. We next inspected the compound on what is known as the Western Vlei.
('4', 190, 1, 9, 463059) Here are two corrugated iron buildings accommodating 22 men and 33 women and children.
('4', 190, 1, 10, 463146) These structures were found to be in fairly good condition but to bring them within the terms of our sanitary bye laws, they require to be prov ided with roof, guttering and down pipes, more light and more ventilation, and another latrine, the existing one not being sufficient for decency.
('4', 190, 1, 11, 463437) The fence requires repairs, the houses should be lime washed internally.
('4', 190, 1, 12, 463510) There being a water supply adjacent, a small iron structure should be provided for bathing and washing purposes.
('4', 190, 1, 13, 463623) The open drains in the vicinity should be well opened up before the summer rains set in, as otherwise this site is swampy.
('4', 190, 2, 14, 463746) This is a description of the condition of no less than a Bazaar, or Location, or Compound, or what you will, under the dir ect control of so authoritative a body as the Corporation itself !
('4', 190, 2, 15, 463936) Who is responsible, we ask, if Indians domiciled in such buildings, placed in the very midst of insanitary conditions, are insanitary in their habits?
('4', 190, 2, 16, 464087) The Indians?
('4', 190, 2, 17, 464100) Surely not!
('4', 190, 2, 18, 464112) And yet, to all intents and purposes, this uns avoury area remains in much the same condition at this date as at the time when this report was made, now some five and a half years ago!
('4', 190, 3, 19, 464297) What is the Corporation doing to remedy such a disgusting con dition of affairs?
('4', 190, 3, 20, 464378) It can spare time and energy for licensing prosecu tions; why can it not utilise some of that same energy to do away with this and other centres of disease and death?
('4', 190, 4, 21, 464545) We are told in The Natal Mercury:
('4', 190, 5, 22, 464579) The coolie is not a cleanly individual, and if left to himself he would soon make even a first class villa resemble a piggery more than anything else.
('4', 190, 5, 23, 464730) And it goes on to say:
('4', 190, 6, 24, 464753) But it is the business of his employer, and particularly of the Protector of Immigrants, to see that he is not left to himself in the matter of sanitation, not only for his own sake, but for the sake of the whole community.
('4', 190, 6, 25, 464977) It is also a matter for the Medical Officer of Health for the Colony to see to, and if employers are found providing inadequate and filthy accommodation for their coolies, they ought to be made to mend their ways.
('4', 190, 6, 26, 465191) With the second of these statements we are in entire accord.
('4', 191, 0, 1, 465252) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 191, 1, 2, 465294) Indeed, it goes far to answer those who insist upon the alleged insan itary habits of the Indians as a whole.
('4', 191, 1, 3, 465404) The first assertion requires to be examined before being accepted.
('4', 191, 1, 4, 465471) It is disposed of in the following extract from the Report already quoted: It was specially noted here (Queen Street Compound) that the com pound, being connected with the sewerage system, enabling as it does ample washing, bathing, and latrine needs, was remarkably clean compared with any of the other places inspected.
('4', 191, 1, 5, 465793) So we have it on record that the Corporation has had the evil pointed out to it; that such evils, being permitted to continue, cast a stigma upon the 1body that condones them; and last, but not least, that the Corporation has, in the cases of the Eastern and the Western Vleis, done practically nothing to remedy them.
('4', 191, 1, 6, 466112) Who, then, has a right to add insult to injury by urging the insanitation of the Indian commu nity as a reason why they should wiped out of existence?
('4', 191, 1, 7, 466263) The effect of the Corporations policy of laissez faire is obvious.
('4', 191, 1, 8, 466330) How long will the cause remain undealt with?

('4', 191, 2, 10, 466401) 153. THE PLAGUE
('4', 191, 3, 11, 466417) The question of sanitation as a whole, in so far as the Indian co mmunity is affected, has been already dealt with 1. We now propose to examine the cause of the particular disease that is claiming its unfor tunate victims epidemically, and to discuss the effect of that cause.
('4', 191, 4, 12, 466694) In last Saturdays Mercury, there appeared a lengthy paragraph dealing with the attitude said to be adopted by the Indians towards the authorities, especially in reference to the concealment of plague sickness.
('4', 191, 4, 13, 466904) The writer made a number of curiously inadequate stateme nts, upon which he based several somewhat querulous enquiries, and concluded by suggesting that possibly this conduct (concealment of plague) has much to do with the recrudescence of the disease occa sionally.
('4', 191, 5, 14, 467171) What are the plain facts?
('4', 191, 5, 15, 467197) We have a community composed of whites and Indians, the poor of the former section being, proportiona tely, fewer than those of the latter.
('4', 191, 5, 16, 467337) It follows, then, that the poorer folk amongst the Asiatic population are more liable, numerically, to disease than are the poorer Europeans.
('4', 191, 5, 17, 467479) Next, we have an assertion made that the Indians seriously hamper the authorities by refusing to give information and in every way endeavouring to conceal the where
('4', 191, 6, 18, 467644) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('4', 192, 0, 1, 467671) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 193
('4', 192, 1, 2, 467714) abouts of any suffers.
('4', 192, 1, 3, 467737) Again we ask, What Indians? Surely, it is not intended to saddle the whole Indian community with the fault of a few of its most ignorant section.
('4', 192, 1, 4, 467883) Why are these careless generalisations made?
('4', 192, 1, 5, 467928) Is it not possible to impress upon the intelligent public the fact that there are as many subtle sub divisions amongst Indians as amon gst any other civilised people?
('4', 192, 1, 6, 468095) It is almost disheartening to observe how these mis statements continue to be made, with an utter irrespons ibility that makes one wonder whether the facts of history are ever conned and become a part of our present day philosophy.
('4', 192, 1, 7, 468327) The higher class Indians never cease, both by personal example and by precept, to impress upon their less favoured brethren the necessity of co operating with the authorities in order that the effort to stamp out the fell disease, that is now rife amongst us, may not prove abortive.
('4', 192, 1, 8, 468611) Over and over again, we ourselves have, in our leading columns, both in English and in the vernacular tongues, done our best to point the moral that Cleanliness is next to Godliness.
('4', 192, 1, 9, 468794) And yet we have foolish people asking why the Indians do not co operate with the authorities !
('4', 192, 2, 10, 468889) Moreover, if, class for class, a comparison be made between Europeans and Indians, it will, we feel assured, be found that there is no greater frequency of concealment, no greater reluctance to adver tise cases of plague, amongst the latter than amongst the former.
('4', 192, 2, 11, 469155) We do not lay special stress upon this fact, nor do we care to use the tu quoque argument.
('4', 192, 2, 12, 469246) We are, however, compelled to do so in self defence, for it is distinctly unfair to suggest that such conduct on the part of a few Indians, which no one deplores more than we ourselves, badly prejudices the Indian Community in the eyes of Euro peans.
('4', 192, 2, 13, 469497) There is, however, one important reason why cases of con cealment do occur.
('4', 192, 2, 14, 469573) We are informed that, at the plague hospital, no distinction is made between Indians and Kaffirs, all being herded together indiscriminately.
('4', 192, 2, 15, 469715) Anyone with even the slightest knowledge of Indian habits and prejudices will at once see how great a factor this negligence is in impending the good work initiated by the authorities.
('4', 192, 2, 16, 469900) We can only say that, so long as no separate accommodation is allotted to Indians as such, and so long as no differentiations of creed and caste are made amongst the Indians themselves, with due regard to religious customs and traditional beliefs, so long will the authorities cope in vain with many of the difficulties that could, with a little foresight, be easily avoided.
('4', 192, 3, 17, 470276) We have already shown, in part, how and why insanitary con ditions are created for the poorer Indians.
('4', 192, 3, 18, 470379) Plague has again broken out in Durban.

('4', 192, 3, 20, 470445) Indians.

('4', 196, 5, 18, 480958) According to the Bill, all the present licence hold ers are protected unless they have committed breaches of the law reg arding Sunday trading, the selling of spirituous liquor, or sanitation, or unless the premises have been allowed to become a nuisance to the neighbourhood by reason of the habits of the dealers customers, his associates or himself.

('4', 198, 3, 18, 486315) 157. HINDUISM
('4', 198, 4, 19, 486329) [JOHANNESBURG, March 4, 1905]
('4', 198, 5, 20, 486359) Mr. M. K. Gandhi delivered the first of a series of four lectures on the above subject at the Masonic Temple, Plein Street, on Saturday evening last, under the auspices of the Johannesburg Lodge of the Theosophical Society, Major Peacock, vice president, in the chair.
('4', 198, 5, 21, 486628) Mr. Gandhi introduced his subject by remarking that the endeavours of the Johannesburg Lodge to promote interest in the
('4', 199, 0, 1, 486748) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 199, 1, 2, 486790) study of different religious systems were most praiseworthy, tending, as they did, to widen peoples sympathies, and enlarge their compre hension of the motives and beliefs underlying the actions of those who were strangers in creed and colour.
('4', 199, 1, 3, 487034) He himself had endeavoured, during his eleven years residence in South Africa, to remove the prejudice and ignorance that existed concerning his own people.
('4', 199, 1, 4, 487191) Continuing, the lecturer described what was meant by the title Hindu, referring it to the branch of the Aryan people that had migrated to the trans Indus districts of India, and had colonised that vast country.
('4', 199, 1, 5, 487402) As a matter of fact, Aryanism would have been a better descriptive word than Hinduism, is explanation of the faith accepted by so many millions of his countrymen.
('4', 199, 1, 6, 487565) One of the most remarkable characteristics of the religion professed by Hindus was self abnegation, and this was obviously shown in the name of the religion itself, for, unlike most of the great world religions, it did not derive its name from any prophet or teacher, although it counted some of the greatest within is fold.
('4', 199, 1, 7, 487890) The lecturer further instanced the historic siege of Arcot in support of this con tention, when the Indian soliders, at a time when starvation faced the whole British Army, waived their claim to the rice rations in favour of the British soldiers, they themselves being content to have the water in which the rice had been boiled, although it was customary to throw this water away; and also the case of Prabhu Singh, 1 an indentured British Indian, who was chosen for the post of honour of warning the inhabitants of Ladysmith during the siege, whenever a Boer shell was coming, by ringing a bell when perched in a tree, at imminent risk to himself.
('4', 199, 1, 8, 488540) This man was mentioned several times in despatches by Sir George White.
('4', 199, 1, 9, 488612) The Hindus themselves claimed that the date of their scriptures was veiled in the mist of antiquity, the scriptures themselves being God given.
('4', 199, 1, 10, 488756) As against that, some Europeans contended that the scrip tures were not more than 3,000 or 4,000 years old.
('4', 199, 1, 11, 488864) Mr. Tilak, a well known Indian Sanskritist, has, however, calculated that, from certain astronomical observations made in these works, they were at least 10,000 years old, although they were only committed to writing some three hundred years after Christ.
('4', 199, 1, 12, 489120) The Vedas, as these scriptures were known, consisted of separate hymns, each being held to cover a defi nite period, and quite independent of each other.
('4', 199, 1, 13, 489274) And, typically, not one authors name had passed down to posterity!
('4', 199, 1, 14, 489341) The Vedas had ins pired the thought of many illustrious men of the West, amongst whom
('4', 199, 2, 15, 489427) 1 Vide Letter to Dadabhai Naoroji, 8 10 1900 and Satyagraha in South Africa, Chapter IX.
('4', 200, 0, 1, 489516) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 201
('4', 200, 1, 2, 489559) might be mentioned Arthur Schopenhauer and Professor Max Muller.
('4', 200, 1, 3, 489624) Over two hundred millions of people professed Hinduism, and this faith entered into their every act.
('4', 200, 1, 4, 489725) The key note of Hinduism on the spiritual side was moksha, or salvation; that is, the final absorption of the Soul in the Infinite Soul that pervades all things.
('4', 200, 1, 5, 489887) In regard to religion, pantheism was the chief characteristic, whilst, on the ethical plane, self abnegation was the most notable quality, with its corollary, toleration.
('4', 200, 1, 6, 490058) In social matters, the characteristic of caste was predomin ant, whilst the ceremonial characteristic was the sacrificing of animals.
('4', 200, 1, 7, 490192) At a time when the faith of the Hindus had become more formal, Prince Gautama Buddha, having learnt the spiritual worth of things during a prolonged period of contemplation, commenced to teach that animal sacrifices were despiritualising, and that the highest from of love was expressed by extending that toleration, which was already a tenet of their faith, in the direction of refraining from killing or otherwise detroying living things.
('4', 200, 1, 8, 490633) Hinduism had never, as a religion, been missionary, as were Christianity and Mahomedanism, but, under King Ashoka, the Buddhist priests were sent far and wide to propagate the new belief.
('4', 200, 1, 9, 490821) Buddhism had a reforming effect upon Hinduism, somewhat similar to that of Protestantism upon Catholicism, but there was a great difference in the spirit underlying that reform.
('4', 200, 1, 10, 490999) No Hindu bore the Buddhist any ill will, a statement that could not be made in reference to the Protestants and Catholics.
('4', 200, 1, 11, 491122) Buddhism was sometimes said to have declined in India.
('4', 200, 1, 12, 491177) This was not really so.
('4', 200, 1, 13, 491201) The Buddhist priests had endeavoured to propagate their faith too zealously, and had aroused the jealously, at the time, of the Hindu priesthood, who had driven the Buddhists to the outskirts of the country, to Tibet, China, Japan, Burma and Ceylon.
('4', 200, 1, 14, 491451) But the spirit of the Buddhists rem ained in India, and actuated every principle professed by the Hindus.

('4', 201, 11, 15, 493988) The Medical Officer of Potchefstroom, at the instance of the Town Council, has prepared a report on the condition of the Indian quarters in that town.
('4', 201, 11, 16, 494139) The circumstances under which it was prepared are rather peculiar.
('4', 201, 11, 17, 494206) As our readers are aware, the Potchefstroom, people are very much exercised over the proposed erection of a mos que by the Indian Mahomedans.
('4', 201, 11, 18, 494348) At the Town Council meeting where, in spite of legal opinion to the contrary, the Councillors decided to oppose the erection of the mosque, they also passed a resolution instructing the Medical Officer to make an inspection of that part of
('4', 202, 0, 1, 494588) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 203
('4', 202, 1, 2, 494631) the town and report at once to the Council.
('4', 202, 1, 3, 494675) One would think there is absolutely no connection between the erection of the mosquewhich is purely and simply a building devoted to religious worship and which is never used as a dwelling placeand the sanitary condition of the surrounding houses.
('4', 202, 1, 4, 494923) However, the Town Council of Potchefst room, like the wolf in the fable, wanted some charge to go on with.
('4', 202, 1, 5, 495030) The Medical Officer, Dr. Frielfaithful servant that he is to the Town Councilhas risen to the occasion and submitted a report, according to their desire, which is a curious document.
('4', 202, 1, 6, 495213) The Doctor says:
('4', 202, 2, 7, 495230) The premises were on the whole fairly clean, but if any epidemic broke out, it would be very difficult to disinfect them, as they largely consist of a patch work of shanties of all shapes and sizes.
('4', 202, 2, 8, 495429) The question naturally arises: what has the Officer been doing all this time?
('4', 202, 2, 9, 495507) The plague has been in the Transvaal now for a year, and these premises have not been found a source of danger.

('4', 202, 2, 13, 496070) He does not say how many of the European in Potchefstroom also throw their bath water on the street, and on our own part we strongly suspect the Indians who do so have no other course open to them.
('4', 202, 2, 14, 496268) The Doctor, however, still could not make out a transgression of the bye laws, and so he adds:
('4', 202, 3, 15, 496363) Although they may not actually transgress the bye laws, still the minimum of air space was closely approached in every case, and the rooms were badly ventilated.
('4', 202, 4, 16, 496525) We wonder whether the Potchefstroom Municipal bye laws allow of bad ventilation being tolerated.
('4', 202, 4, 17, 496622) If so, why does not the Muni cipality ask for an amendment of the bye laws, so that they might satisfy the requirements of hygiene and sanitation?
('4', 202, 4, 18, 496769) As a matter of fact, we happen to know that the public health bye laws framed by the Government have been adopted by the Municipality of Potchefst room, and that they are stringent and exacting.
('4', 202, 4, 19, 496964) The Doctor concludes the medical portion of the report, by saying that, taken as a whole, their manner of living is not up to the present day standard, and that houses and their residents in the centre of the town are a continual source of danger to public health.
('4', 202, 4, 20, 497229) We see nothing in the report, which is so frankly contradictory, that would warrant the opinion given by the Doctor.

('4', 203, 1, 3, 497620) Although this report is in our opinion self condemned, it might be worth while producing an impartial opinion about the very dwellings on which Dr. Friel has given his verdict.

('4', 203, 1, 5, 497947) He says: In going through the various premises I am pleased to say I was greatly impressed with the general condition of each place I visited, both internally as well as externally.
('4', 203, 1, 6, 498129) Taking all things into consideration, the backyards are all perfectly clean and sanitary.
('4', 203, 1, 7, 498219) I saw no accumulation of rubbish; this, I understand, is being carried away daily by the contractor.
('4', 203, 1, 8, 498320) The bucket system is in force, as in other parts of the town, which is also attended to by the sanitary department, and I can find no fault from what I saw.
('4', 203, 1, 9, 498477) There appears to me to be no fault as regards sleeping accommodation.
('4', 203, 1, 10, 498547) At the back of each business, in addition, I noticed a kind of mess room capable of seating about 5 to 8 persons, and each has its own kitchens, which are also well kept.

('4', 203, 1, 12, 498803) Here, then, is an unbiassed medical report given by a gentleman having no master to please, and who finds that the Indian dwellings are not open to objection from a sanitary stand point.
('4', 203, 1, 13, 498990) Dr. Friels report, we notice, has been referred by the Town Council to the Government, and we await what it has to say to it.
('4', 203, 1, 14, 499116) It is palpably the effusion of a man whose inclination runs counter to his conscience.

('4', 203, 2, 16, 499229) 160. THE HEALTH OF EDUCATED INDIANS
('4', 203, 3, 17, 499265) When we compare educated persons in India with those in other countries, we are sadly disappointed.
('4', 203, 3, 18, 499365) The formation of a new Liberal Ministry in England is now under consideration.
('4', 203, 3, 19, 499444) The ages of the leaders of this group are very significant for us.
('4', 203, 3, 20, 499511) Mr. Bryce and Mr. John Morley are 67 years old, Lord Bracey and Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman are 69, Earl Spencer is 70, the Duke of Devonshire is 72 and Sir Henry Fowler, 75. Even Sir Charles Dilke, whose inclusion in the Ministry is not very probable, is 60, and Lord Rosebery, 57. Some at any rate of these gentlemen are bound to be in the new Ministry.
('4', 203, 3, 21, 499868) Now, if we look round among Indians in any walk of life, we are unlikely to come by many elderly persons who can boast of sound health and vigour.
('4', 203, 3, 22, 500015) One might attribute it to the Indian climate, but this
('4', 204, 0, 1, 500070) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 205
('4', 204, 1, 2, 500113) can be valid only up to a point.
('4', 204, 1, 3, 500146) Our men of earlier generations enjoyed long life, full of health and vigour.
('4', 204, 1, 4, 500223) They were so tall and well built that our contemporaries look dimunitive beside them.
('4', 204, 1, 5, 500309) If the Indian climate of old was so healthy and bracing, it cannot be that it does not now favour a good physique.
('4', 204, 1, 6, 500424) The real reason is that we are unmindful of the maxims of good health.
('4', 204, 1, 7, 500495) This attitude of negligence, which begins at school or college, continues into maturity.
('4', 204, 1, 8, 500584) We remain engrossed in our work, in earning money and in improving our lot.
('4', 204, 1, 9, 500660) We then hardly stop to realise that it is only natural for the body to wear down under severe strain.
('4', 204, 1, 10, 500762) Most educated Indians do not have the habit of regular physical exercise.
('4', 204, 1, 11, 500836) They seem quite innocent of the fact that the mind needs rest and recreation as well.
('4', 204, 1, 12, 500922) One might find stray clubs and societies [among Indians,] but very few participate in their affairs actively.
('4', 204, 1, 13, 501032) Some of them, who have little to do at home, prefer low types of pleasure to a chat or a game or two of billiards.
('4', 204, 1, 14, 501147) Again, unlike Europeans who have an intelligent appreciation of the importance of health and happiness, they do not go to parties, balls, plays nor have they other pastimes.
('4', 204, 1, 15, 501321) Their lives are dull and mono tonous, if we leave out of account the variety of business that demands their attention.
('4', 204, 1, 16, 501440) Such ways spell the ruin of a whole people; but, unfor tunately, no one can as yet forsee their deleterious consequences.
('4', 204, 1, 17, 501562) Not yet conscious of any ill health themselves free from disease.
('4', 204, 1, 18, 501628) And because they can do their work, digest their food and do not feel any manifest ailment, they consider themselves healthy.
('4', 204, 1, 19, 501754) All of a sudden, this sense of well being ceases; they find themselves in the grip of some serious disease, and they despair.
('4', 204, 1, 20, 501880) We must learn from the exam ple of those who have earlier fallen a prey to this habit, and beware.
('4', 204, 1, 21, 501979) But then we are too slow and careless to profit by such examples.
('4', 204, 1, 22, 502045) That is why we do not find among educated Indians persons of ripe old age.
('4', 204, 1, 23, 502120) This defect is by no means peculiar to any individual or family, rather the entire Indian nation suffers from it.
('4', 204, 1, 24, 502234) A countrywide effort is most essential in order to save Indian youth from being blighted prematurely.

('4', 205, 1, 2, 502420) 161. A WAR OF GIANTS
('4', 205, 2, 3, 502441) JAPAN AND RUSSIA From the news received from the front, it appears that the battle now being fought between Japan and Russia near Mukden bids fair to be considered the greatest in all ancient or modern history.
('4', 205, 2, 4, 502652) To call the battle of Mukden, now in progress, the greatest may be dubbed an exaggeration.
('4', 205, 2, 5, 502743) It is natural that, as a result of the frequent publication of sensational news in the papers, the people in general develop a dislike for such reports and, consequently, calling the battle of Muk den the greatest might be considered an exaggeration.
('4', 205, 2, 6, 502994) Nevertheless, we must point out that tens of thousands of men are now being annihilated on both sides in the battle.
('4', 205, 2, 7, 503111) Japan has here attacked Russia from east, west and south, that is, the attack is not frontal, but on the flanks of the Russian army.
('4', 205, 2, 8, 503244) If is possible that, if the flanks succumb, the van also might give way.
('4', 205, 2, 9, 503317) At the helm of all these manoeuvres of the army stands the heroic figures of Marquis Oyama of Japan.
('4', 205, 2, 10, 503418) The battle covers an area of a hundred miles, and a million men have entered the field.
('4', 205, 2, 11, 503506) The weapons of destruction used range from the smallest rifles to the big gest guns.
('4', 205, 2, 12, 503591) No effort possible for human talent has been spared to bring about the quickest destruction of men.
('4', 205, 2, 13, 503691) Courage and endurance have not been found wanting under any test.
('4', 205, 2, 14, 503757) A hundred thousand men have been utterly destroyed.
('4', 205, 2, 15, 503809) If Japan defeats Russia in this battle, there is strong reason to believe that the end of the war is near at hand.
('4', 205, 2, 16, 503924) Having lost.
('4', 205, 2, 17, 503937) Port Arthur, 1 Russia no more holds any sea power; and it is improbable that she will send more men to Manchuria by land.
('4', 205, 2, 18, 504059) The people in Russia have already begun to detest the war; if, therefore, the army at present in Manchuria sustains a defeat, it will not be necessary for Japan to make any further sacrifices.
