('4', 206, 11, 15, 505113) 163. HINDUISM
('4', 206, 12, 16, 505127) [JOHANNESBURG, March 11, 1905]
('4', 206, 13, 17, 505158) Mr. Gandhi delivered his second lecture on Hinduism under the auspices of
('4', 206, 14, 18, 505232) the Johannesburg Theosophical Lodge, at the Masonic Temple, on Saturday
('4', 206, 15, 19, 505304) evening.
('4', 206, 15, 20, 505313) The hall was well filled.
('4', 206, 16, 21, 505339) The lecturer, after giving a short resume of the previous lecture, said that the second lecture would be devoted to what might be termed the second epoch of Hinduism.
('4', 206, 16, 22, 505506) After the reformation that took place from within, under the influence of the teachings of Buddha, Hindu 
('4', 207, 0, 1, 505612) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 207, 1, 2, 505654) ism was very largely addicted to idolatry.
('4', 207, 1, 3, 505697) Several explanations were offered in extenuation, but the lecturer could not deny the fact that the Hindus seemingly worshipped stocks and stones.
('4', 207, 1, 4, 505844) The Hindu phil osophers easily recognised and worshipped God as the purest spirit, and Pantheism took them to the highest flight.
('4', 207, 1, 5, 505974) It similarly brought down the ignorant masses to the lowest depths.
('4', 207, 1, 6, 506042) If the infant mind could not realise God as a pure spirit, it had no difficulty in worsh ipping Him through His various manifestations.
('4', 207, 1, 7, 506178) Many worship Him through the sun, the moon and the stars, and many worship Him through stocks and stones also, a mode of worship to which philo sophical Hinduism, with its tolerant spirit, had no difficulty in recon ciling itself.
('4', 207, 1, 8, 506409) So the wheel of Hindu life went merrily on, until there arose in the desert of Arabia a power that was destined to revolutionise ideas and to leave a permanent impress.
('4', 207, 1, 9, 506578) Mahomet, whilst yet a boy, on seeing around him people given to idolatry, to lustful indulgences, and to drunkenness, burned within himself with rage.
('4', 207, 1, 10, 506729) He saw also Judaism prostrate and Christianity debased.
('4', 207, 1, 11, 506785) He felt, even as did Moses and Christ, that he was a man with a mission.
('4', 207, 1, 12, 506858) He decided to deliver his mission to the world, and he chose the members of his own family as the first recipients.
('4', 207, 1, 13, 506974) The lecturer was not one of these who believed that the religion of Islam was a religion of the sword.
('4', 207, 1, 14, 507077) Washington Irving, in his work on Islam, had asked a pertinent question, namely, Where had Islam, in its first stage, found men to wield the sword? He beli eved that the success of Mahomedanism was largely due to its simpli city and to its recognition of human weaknesses.
('4', 207, 1, 15, 507350) He [the Prophet] taught that God was One and only One, that he was His Messenger.
('4', 207, 1, 16, 507432) He taught also that prayer was absolutely necessary as an uplifting influ ence, and in order to bring together his followers, if only once in a year, he instituted the pilgrimage to Mecca, for those who could afford it, and recognising that people would amass wealth, he enjoined upon his followers that they set apart a certain portion of it religiously for charitable purposes.
('4', 207, 1, 17, 507812) The key note of Islam was, however, its levelling spirit.
('4', 207, 1, 18, 507870) If offered equality to all that came within its pale, in the manner that no other religion in the world did.
('4', 207, 1, 19, 507979) When, therefore, about 900 years after Christ, his followers descended upon India, Hinduism stood dazed.
('4', 207, 1, 20, 508084) It seemed to carry everything before it.
('4', 207, 1, 21, 508125) The doctrine of equality could not but appeal to the masses, who were
('4', 208, 0, 1, 508195) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 209
('4', 208, 1, 2, 508238) caste ridden.
('4', 208, 1, 3, 508252) To this inherent strength was also added the power of the sword.
('4', 208, 1, 4, 508317) The fanatical raiders who, from time to time, found their way into India, did not hesitate to convert by the sword if they could not do so by persuasion.
('4', 208, 1, 5, 508471) They more or less overran all parts of India, breaking idols after idols, and although the Rajput valour was at the disposal of Hinduism, it was powerless to afford protection against the Mahomedan inroad.
('4', 208, 1, 6, 508677) In keeping with the spirit of Hinduism, an attempt was made at first to bring about reconciliation between the two faiths, and in the city of Benares, there arose a holy man about the 13th century, by name Kabir, who endeavoured, by keeping intact the chief tenets of Hinduism and by borrowing somewhat from Mahom edanism, to bring about a fusion, but the attempt was not quite suc cessful.
('4', 208, 1, 7, 509068) The Punjab, through which the Mahomedan conquerors poured into India, and which bore the first brunt, produced Guru Nanak, the founder of the Sikh religion who drew upon Kabir of his doctrines and added to it militant Hinduism.
('4', 208, 1, 8, 509296) He offered the olive branch by respecting the Moslem susceptibilities, but if that were not accepted, he was equally ready to defend Hinduism from the Moslem aggression, and thus Sikhism was a direct result of Islam.
('4', 208, 1, 9, 509513) It was well known how brave the Sikh was and what service he had rendered to the British Government.
('4', 208, 1, 10, 509614) The influence of Mahomedanism on Hindu ism was that it gave rise to Sikhism and it brought out one of the chief characteristics of the religion, namely, toleration, in its true light and fulness.
('4', 208, 1, 11, 509810) When there were no political influences at work, there was no difficulty about the Hindus and the Mahomedans living side by side in perfect peace and amity, each respecting the prejudices of the other, and each following his own faith without let or hindrance.
('4', 208, 1, 12, 510071) It was Hin duism that gave Mahomedanism its Akbar, who, with unerring insight, recognised the tolerant spirit and adopted it himself in ruling India.
('4', 208, 1, 13, 510221) Hinduism, moreover, showed its elasticity in that, in spite of the fierce struggle, the classes as well as large majority of the masses were left totally untouched, and Hinduism arose out of the struggle braced, as we would rise out of a cold bath, with warm glow.
('4', 208, 1, 14, 510486) The first shock was, no doubt, severely felt, but the Hindu religion soon asserted itself.
('4', 208, 1, 15, 510577) The lecturer also mentioned the Fakirs and the Yogis, and said that they lived almost the same kind of life, although the former belonged to the Islamic faith and the latter to the Hindu faith.
('4', 209, 0, 1, 510771) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 209, 1, 2, 510813) At the end of the lecture several interesting questions were put, and the proceedings terminated after the usual vote of thanks.
('4', 209, 2, 3, 510942) The third lecture 1of the series will be given next Saturday at 8 oclock in the Masonic Temple.
('4', 209, 2, 4, 511038) The synopsis is as follows: The advent of Christianity in India; comparison between Mahomedanism and Christianity as they appeared to the Hindus; influence of Christianity on Hinduism; a mixture of Christianity and modern of western civilisation; the direct failure and indirect success of Christianity in India; Ram Mohan Roy, Keshub Chunder Sen, Dayanand; Theosophy, the Brahmo Samaj and the Arya Samaj; the state of Hinduism to day; its vivacity and the secret of its great staying power.
('4', 209, 3, 5, 511530) The Star, 18 3 1905

('4', 210, 7, 10, 513573) (e) the buildings immediately surrounding the site are nearly all wood and iron and of far inferior construction to the proposed mosque buildings.
('4', 210, 8, 11, 513720) My Association, therefore, respectfully ventures to submit that the British Indian community at potchefstroom is entitled to a declar ation from the Government, disapproving of the manner in which the anti Asiatic agitation is being carried on a Potchefstroom and to an assurance that their persons and property will be fully protected.
('4', 210, 8, 12, 514057) Probably the Government may be aware that the Potchefstroom Vigil ance Association, and such other bodies in the Colony, carry on the agitation with a view, as they have stated, to strengthen the hands of the Government, who, they say, are prepared to fall in with their Demands and who are in their opinion at present engaged in nego tiations with the Home Government, having that end in view.
('4', 210, 9, 13, 514452) My Association cannot conceive that such can be the intentions of the Government, but in its humble opinion the absence of a clear declaration to the contrary by the Government is likely to be misin terpreted and thereby to accentuate the violence of the agitation.
('4', 210, 10, 14, 514718) My Association, therefore trusts that the Government will be pleased to take such steps as may be necessary for protecting the
('4', 211, 0, 1, 514845) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 211, 1, 2, 514887) rights of the inoffensive British Indian in Potchefstroom and other towns in the colony.
('4', 211, 1, 3, 514976) I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant, ABDOOL GANI CHAIRMAN BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION

('4', 211, 3, 5, 515149) 165. THE NATAL MUNICIPAL CORPORATIONS BILL
('4', 211, 4, 6, 515192) We have before us the Natal Government Gazette of the 21st February, 1905, containing a Bill to amend and consolidate the law relating to the Municipal Corporations.
('4', 211, 4, 7, 515358) We give in another column the clauses that bear directly or indirectly on the British Indian question.
('4', 211, 4, 8, 515461) This will be the second attempt of the Government to introd uce this Bill and pass it into law.
('4', 211, 4, 9, 515557) The definitions given of the terms Coloured person and uncivilised races are very unsatisfactory, and are calculated to incorporate into the Bill the mischief that has been already created by the definition of Coloured person.
('4', 211, 4, 10, 515784) Accor ding to the Bill, the term includes, among others, any Hottentot, Coolie, Bushman or Lascar.
('4', 211, 4, 11, 515883) Now the terms coolie and lascar themselves require difining, and it is exceedingly dangerous to leave their interpretation to the administrators of the measure, from the Attorney General down to Kaffir policemen.
('4', 211, 4, 12, 516096) How, for instance, is a Kaffir policeman to know who is a coolie and who a lascar?
('4', 211, 4, 13, 516179) Why, again, should the term coolie be at all retained in the Bill, when it is well known how offensive it has become?
('4', 211, 4, 14, 516297) The definition of the term uncivilised races is an insult to the Indians concerned, and more so to their descendants.
('4', 211, 4, 15, 516415) An infallible test of civilisation is that a man claiming to be civilised should be an intel ligent toiler, that he should understand the dignity of labour, and that his work should be such as to advance the interests of the community to which he belongs.
('4', 211, 4, 16, 516671) Apply this test to the lowest indentured Indian, and he will satisfy it.
('4', 211, 4, 17, 516744) Why, then, should he be called a member of an Indian labourer uncivilised because he undertakes to serve the Colony under indenture, why should the ban be placed upon his descendants?
('4', 211, 4, 18, 516928) The Higher Grade Indian School, about whose pupils the Governor and the late Administrator have spoken in flattering and eloquent terms, contains many children of Indians who have been under
('4', 212, 0, 1, 517119) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 213
('4', 212, 1, 2, 517162) indenture.
('4', 212, 1, 3, 517173) The children would do credit to any community.
('4', 212, 1, 4, 517220) They are intelligent and receive a liberal education.
('4', 212, 1, 5, 517274) Is it right that they should be labelled members of uncivilised races?
('4', 212, 1, 6, 517345) The distinction between such Indians and others would be based purely on an accident, for we assure the framers of the Bill that there are many identured Indians who are quite as good as some Indians who have paid their own passa ge and entered the Colony as free men.
('4', 212, 1, 7, 517614) Indeed, the indentured Indian deserves if anything, better treatment than the free Indian, because the former has been invited and induced to come to the Colony and has contributed not a little to its prosperity.
('4', 212, 2, 8, 517827) Coming to clause 22 of the Bill, contrary to the declarations made by the late Mr. Escombe and the late Sir John Robinson, who, at the time of introducing the political franchise Bill, commended it to the Legislative Assembly on the ground that it left the municipal franchise alone we find the provisions of the Parliamentary Franchise Act being applied to the municipal franchise, and if the Bill, as it stands, become law; no person who is disqualified for the parliamen tary franchise by Act No.
('4', 212, 2, 9, 518327) 8. of 1896, shall be eligible as a municipal voter.
('4', 212, 2, 10, 518379) That is to say, persons belonging to the races which have not hitherto enjoyed representative institutions would be disqualified from being voters at municipal elections, although they may have enjoyed representative municipal institutions in their own country.
('4', 212, 2, 11, 518641) It is well known that India possesses elective Municipalities in all the chief cities, that there are hundreds of such Municipalities and that there are thousands of Indian voters who elect members to them.
('4', 212, 2, 12, 518848) Why should they be disqualified?
('4', 212, 2, 13, 518881) The framers of the Bill have taken no note whatever of the great self control that the Indian community has exer cised in connection with municipal elections.
('4', 212, 2, 14, 519040) They have refrained from having their names placed on the burgess roll, and the clause in question is the one offered to the community as a reward.
('4', 212, 2, 15, 519188) We consider the clause to be a deliberate insult, and we hope that the members of the Assembly will not lend their support to the putting of such an affront upon the Indian community.
('4', 212, 2, 16, 519372) In clause 182, the Municipalities are to be given the power to frame bye laws regulating the use of pavements, foot paths and ricks haws by Coloured persons.
('4', 212, 2, 17, 519530) It is here that the interpretation of the terms coolie an lascar is necessary, and it is not difficult to ima gine what an engine of oppression the bye laws are likely to be, if the present definition is retained.
('4', 212, 2, 18, 519744) This clause, evidently, is a result of the agitation that is still going on in the Transvaal with regard to the use of foot paths by Coloured people, and of the vacillating policy of the Government of that Crown Colony.
('4', 213, 0, 1, 519964) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 213, 1, 2, 520006) Clause 200 makes provision for registration of persons belon ging to uncivilised races, resident and employed within the borough.
('4', 213, 1, 3, 520136) One can understand the necessity for registration of Kaffirs who will not work; by why should registration be required for indentured Indians who have become free, and for their descendants about whom the general complaint is that they work too much?
('4', 213, 1, 4, 520387) Is the son of an indentured Indian, seeking employment as a clerk, to be registered?
('4', 213, 1, 5, 520472) There are other objectionable clauses in the Bill, but we refrain, for the present, from adverting to them in this brief notice of the Bill.
('4', 213, 1, 6, 520613) It is merely one of the many proofs of an attempt that is being made all over South Africa to crush the Indian, because the whole of the agitation that is at present going on, though nominally directed agai nst the Coloured man, is in reality directed against the British Indian.
('4', 213, 1, 7, 520893) The policy that is being followed is the policy that was ascribed to the Boers by Lord Milner with reference to the Uitlanders, in his famous Kimberley speech before the war.
('4', 213, 1, 8, 521068) His Lordship described it as a pin prick policy; yet it will not be doubted that the Uitlanders, in spite of the political disabilities to which they were subject, were infinitely better off and better able to put up with them than the Indians.
('4', 213, 1, 9, 521313) If the treatment of the Uitlanders be described as a policy of pin prick, what shall we say of the policy that is being followed in connection with British Indians in South Africa?
('4', 213, 1, 10, 521494) As a member of the Legislative Ass embly of Natal once said, the Colonial ideal should be to make the position of the British Indians in South Africa as uncomfortable as possible, so that their patience would be exhausted and they would leave the country.
('4', 213, 1, 11, 521750) What, now, is the duty of the British Indians under this trying ordeal?
('4', 213, 1, 12, 521822) The answer is simple.
('4', 213, 1, 13, 521844) Patience is the badge of the Indians, and they must not on any account forget that fact.
('4', 213, 1, 14, 521933) It is a precious heritage, and if they would only add to it a large fund of industry, well susta ined and combined opposition to a usurpation of their rights as subj ects of the King Emperor, they might still gain the victory, even tho ugh the odds may be against them.
('4', 213, 1, 15, 522203) They must have the faith of the undaunted prophet who, with the courage born of a living confidence in his God, was wont to defy the hordes of the enemy, and who, when reminded by his disciples that they were only three against the enor mous numbers of the latter, retorted that they were not three but four, because the invisible presence of the Almightly was with them.
('4', 213, 1, 16, 522575) Indian Opinion, 18 3 1905

('4', 214, 1, 2, 522644) 166. THE CAPE GENERAL DEALERS BILL
('4', 214, 2, 3, 522679) We are glad to see that the British Indians at the Cape have not allowed the grass to grow under their feet with reference to the Deal ers Bill, which is to be introduced during the present session of the Cape Parliament.
('4', 214, 2, 4, 522901) An Indian deputation, headed by Sir William Thorne and the Hon.
('4', 214, 2, 5, 522965) Edmund Powell, has already waited on the Hon.
('4', 214, 2, 6, 523011) The Attorney General.
('4', 214, 2, 7, 523033) We must, however, confess to a feeling of disap pointment about the lame reply given by Mr. Sampson.
('4', 214, 2, 8, 523134) 1 It is all very well for him to say that a Resident Magistrate was not bound to take into regard the question of keeping books in a European language.
('4', 214, 2, 9, 523286) The Bill said he might or might not. We all know what these discretionary powers mean.
('4', 214, 2, 10, 523373) They have been abused before and there is no guarantee that they will not be abused in future.
('4', 214, 2, 11, 523468) We are quite willing to accept the assurance that the Bill is not a hit at the Indian, but so far as the latter is concerned, it would amount to it, if it is capable of being so used.
('4', 214, 2, 12, 523652) We make bold to say that this is undoubtedly a Bill that will lend itself to a great deal of persecution.
('4', 214, 2, 13, 523758) Again, the Attorney General totally missed the point when he conten ded it was a question of keeping books in a European language.
('4', 214, 2, 14, 523889) The Bill goes much further, and authorises a Licensing Officer to refuse a licence on the ground of the applicants not knowing a European language.
('4', 214, 2, 15, 524037) We should have no objection to the books being required to be kept in the English language, which could be done by competent book keepers, but it is a totally different proposition to require the applicant to know some European language.
('4', 214, 2, 16, 524275) If the clause is meant to prevent fraud, we cannot understand why the books should be kept in any other European languages than English.
('4', 214, 2, 17, 524412) Such an alteration, if confined to book keeping and not extended to the licence holders, would take away from the clause the sting of insult to the great Indian languages.
('4', 214, 2, 18, 524584) The learned Attorney General then proceeds to read a lecture to the Indians, and says:
('4', 214, 3, 19, 524671) He was not talking of things that he did not understand.
('4', 214, 3, 20, 524728) He was a fair man and knew the position.
('4', 214, 3, 21, 524769) Take Indian trading on Sundays, for instance.
('4', 214, 3, 22, 524815) Did they mean to tell him that the Indian traders did not carry on trading on Sundays?
('4', 214, 3, 23, 524902) With great deference, we submit that they do not, and that if, in iso lated places, they do, what is his Department doing?
('4', 214, 3, 24, 525025) Is there no
('4', 214, 4, 25, 525037) 1 The Attorney General.
('4', 215, 0, 1, 525061) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 215, 1, 2, 525103) Sunday trading law at the Cape?
('4', 215, 1, 3, 525135) Could not illicit Sunday trading be stopped with a heavy hand?
('4', 215, 1, 4, 525198) And, if we may use the tu quoque argument, is illicit trading confined to Indians?
('4', 215, 1, 5, 525281) Moreover, it is painfully surpri sing to see that the leader of the legal profession at the Cape so far disregards the traditions if law as to bring in support of his no bearing on it, for what possible connection can there be between illicit Sunday trading and knowledge of a European language on the part of an Indian trader?
('4', 215, 1, 6, 525609) How would be prevent Sunday trading by requiring of an applicant for a licence a knowledge of a European language?
('4', 215, 1, 7, 525724) The honourable gentleman proceeds:
('4', 215, 2, 8, 525759) There was another difficulty in regard to Indians.
('4', 215, 2, 9, 525810) They often came out with their families, and the whole of them carried on a business.

('4', 215, 3, 14, 526488) That the sons of the poorer store keepers may do so, we are not prepared to deny, but that would be due more to jealousy regarding education of Indian children than to anything else.
('4', 215, 3, 15, 526671) It is hardly fair to place every obstacle in the way of Indian education and then to say that the parents would not educate their children.
('4', 215, 3, 16, 526811) It this inequality, if such it be, to be avoided by requ iring knowledge of a European language by an Indian store keeper?
('4', 215, 4, 17, 526934) It would have been far better, and more dignified, if Mr. Sam pson had effected a compromise and shewn some respect for Indian sentiment.

('4', 216, 5, 7, 528393) 167. LAWYERS AT THE CAPE
('4', 216, 6, 8, 528418) The Incorporated Law Society at the Cape wishes to promote a Bill whereby they intend to prevent any Coloured men being admitted to the Cape Bar or the Side Bar.

('4', 217, 2, 4, 529863) 22, KENNINGTON ROAD LONDON ENGLAND
('4', 217, 3, 5, 529898) DEAR SIR, A reactionary policy is being followed throughout South Africa regarding the British Indians.
('4', 217, 3, 6, 530002) I commend to your attention the cur rent numbers of Indian Opinion wherein you will find that at the Cape they are trying to introduce a general Dealers Licenses Bill which is calculated to do a great deal of harm to the British Indians settled at the Cape.
('4', 217, 3, 7, 530260) In Natal, as you will see, a Fire arms Bill has been published in the Gazette which needlessly insults British Indians.
('4', 217, 3, 8, 530380) There is, too, a reproduction of the Transvaal anti Asiatic legislation in the district of Vryheid which has been lately annexed to Natal and the Municipal Corporation Bill contains clauses which are most objection able.
('4', 217, 3, 9, 530601) In the Orange River Colony disabilities upon disabilities are being imposed upon Indians through the instrumentality of bye laws, and I venture to draw your attention to the fact that, while a great deal has been done there regarding the Transvaal legislation as also the Natal legislation, I have not yet seen a question out in the House of Commons regarding the Orange River Colony.
('4', 217, 3, 10, 530986) I, therefore hope that this matter will also be taken up.
('4', 217, 3, 11, 531044) The current number of Indian Opi nion deals with the Natal Municipal Bill among other things and the next number will deal with the other matters referred to in this letter.
('4', 217, 4, 12, 531218) I remain,
('4', 217, 5, 13, 531228) Yours faithfully,

('4', 218, 1, 2, 531536) 169. THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY AND ASIATICS
('4', 218, 2, 3, 531578) We have more than once drawn attention to the violently anti Asiatic policy of the Orange River Colony.
('4', 218, 2, 4, 531682) In such policy, the late Boer Government did not nearly approach the present Government, which, in the name of the King Emperor, is setting the seal of its app roval on the prevalent colour prejudice.
('4', 218, 2, 5, 531883) We have waited in vain for the fulfilment of Mr. Chamberlains promise that the anti Asiatic laws of the Orange River Colony would be remodelled in accordance with British ideas.
('4', 218, 2, 6, 532061) They are certainly being remodelled, but we have yet to learn that the way in which they are being altered is consistent with the traditions that have been always associated with the word British.
('4', 218, 2, 7, 532258) The latest instance is to be found in the Government Gazette of the Orange River Colony for the 10th inst.
('4', 218, 2, 8, 532365) In the regulations for the village of Odendaalsrust, which have received the sanction of His Ex cellency the Lieutenant Governor and the Executive Council, are contained some clauses regarding Natives with reference to their living in Locations, the sale and manufacture of Kaffir beer by them, the holding of dance parties in the Locations, the keeping of guests therein, the owning of dogs, etc., by them.
('4', 218, 2, 9, 532773) Now in the regulations, the term Native shall be interpreted and taken to apply to and include a man or men, as well as a woman or women, above the age, or estima ted age, of 16 years, of any native tribe in South Africa, and also all Coloured persons and all who, in accordance with law or custom, are called Coloured persons or are treated as such, of what[ever] race or nationality they may be.
('4', 218, 2, 10, 533171) In the clearest possible language, therefore, the Municipality of the village has been allowed to include in the term Native the British Indians and other Coloured people.
('4', 218, 2, 11, 533343) If such a definition and such regulations were passed in the Legislative Council of the Orange River Colony, they would be subject to veto by the Home Government; but because a village board passes them, and chooses to give an unwarranted definition to the term Native, the Home Government is not to be consulted, and the accommodating local Government has no hesitation in countenancing wholesale restri ctions of the character above mentioned.
('4', 218, 2, 12, 533789) Apparently, it does not matter to that Government whether such regulations offend the feel ings of the Indian subjects of the King Emperor or not.
('4', 218, 2, 13, 533936) We draw the attention of public men in England, who cherish the proverbial sense of justice and fair play, to the scandal revealed by the regulations in question which we reprint in extenso in another column.
('4', 218, 2, 14, 534145) Indian Opinion, 25 3 1905
('4', 219, 0, 1, 534171) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 219, 1, 2, 534213) 170. THE ANTI INDIAN ACTIVITY OF NATAL
('4', 219, 2, 3, 534252) In the Government Gazette of Natal for the 28th February, a Bill is published regulating the use of fire arms.
('4', 219, 2, 4, 534363) Part 4 of the Bill deals with the use of fire arms by Natives Asiatics.
('4', 219, 2, 5, 534435) We give all the sections in another column.
('4', 219, 2, 6, 534479) Evidently the framers of the Bill have associated the Asiatics almost instinctively with the Natives, and it is that attitude of mind against which we have always firmly and respectfully protested.
('4', 219, 2, 7, 534677) Since distinctions are made between one class and another, justice will never be done to the Asiatic unless he is treated as apart from the Natives.
('4', 219, 2, 8, 534826) The Native question is a big question in South Africa.
('4', 219, 2, 9, 534881) The Native population is very large.
('4', 219, 2, 10, 534918) The Native civilisation is totally different from the Asiatic or the European.
('4', 219, 2, 11, 534997) The Native, being the son of the soil, has a right to fair treatment, but being what he is, perhaps some legislation, which may be of a restrictive character, in necessary.
('4', 219, 2, 12, 535170) It can, therefore, never apply to Asiatics.
('4', 219, 2, 13, 535214) In this instance of the fire arms, the Asiatic has been most improperly bracketed with the Native.
('4', 219, 2, 14, 535313) The British Indian does not need any such restrictions as are imposed by the Bill on the Native regarding the carrying of fire arms.
('4', 219, 2, 15, 535446) The predominant race can remain so by preventing the Native from arming himself.
('4', 219, 2, 16, 535527) Is there the slightest vestige of justification for so preventing the British Indian?
('4', 219, 2, 17, 535613) It is a matter of common knowledge that the British Indian who has settled in the Colony is not a military man.
('4', 219, 2, 18, 535725) He is most docile.
('4', 219, 2, 19, 535744) Why should he, then, be insulted by being placed in the same category with the Native?
('4', 219, 2, 20, 535831) Would not a stranger, visiting Natal, and coming across legislation of this kind, come to the conclusion that the British Indians must be a very troublesome community?
('4', 219, 2, 21, 535999) There are occasions when British Indians, living in out of the way places, require to have a gun or a revolver.
('4', 219, 2, 22, 536111) They are then, if the Bill becomes law, to go not to the ordinary authorities, but to the Secretary of Native Affairs, who has not connection with the British Indians, and there beg for permission to own a revolver or a gun, as if the Magistrates were incapable of using their discretion with reference to the possession of fire arms by British Indians.
('4', 219, 2, 23, 536465) We do not know that, in feeding anti Indian prejudice in this wanton manner, the Govern ment are not unnecessarily exasperating the British Indians.
('4', 219, 2, 24, 536614) We hope that an amendment will be made in the Bill when it comes up before the Natal Parliament.
('4', 219, 2, 25, 536711) Indian Opinion, 25 3 1905
('4', 220, 0, 1, 536737) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 221
('4', 220, 1, 2, 536780) 171. THE VALUE OF STRAY MOMENTS
('4', 220, 2, 3, 536812) Some time elapses in merely thinking about a piece of work before it is actually begun.
('4', 220, 2, 4, 536900) Such time is known as stray moments.
('4', 220, 2, 5, 536937) We carelessly allow these bits time to pass.
('4', 220, 2, 6, 536982) If we add up these stray mom ents which are thought to be of little account, they make no mean part of our life; and not to make a proper use of them is to waste life itself.
('4', 220, 3, 7, 537157) Each one of us talks, more or less, about his education and imp rovement.
('4', 220, 3, 8, 537231) We make plans of how best to use our spare time; but, whenever we get a few stray minutes of leisure, we men and women particularly women allow them thoughtlessly to pass away.
('4', 220, 3, 9, 537408) We go on cherishing dreams of the many things we would do, if and when we have the time.
('4', 220, 3, 10, 537497) The time we get is just a quarter or half hour or just a few minutes.
('4', 220, 3, 11, 537567) Then, we say to ourselves, Well, it does not matter, there isnt enough time now.
('4', 220, 3, 12, 537648) Thus we go on dreaming and the golden opportunities slip away.
('4', 220, 4, 13, 537711) What a fool we shall call the person who, needing 10, does not take care of the few shillings he regularly gets!
('4', 220, 4, 14, 537824) Nevertheless, we behave just like him.
('4', 220, 4, 15, 537863) We regret that we do not get time; and yet, we idle away the stray minutes, which put together would make a whole day, just as the stray shillings make a Bank note.
('4', 220, 5, 16, 538028) By making regular, daily use of such minutes, a young Euro pean lady succeeded in learning Italian.
('4', 220, 5, 17, 538128) Another was able to collect an astonishingly large sum of money in a year by knitting for charity during such moments of leisure.
('4', 220, 6, 18, 538258) [From Gujarati]
('4', 220, 7, 19, 538274) Indian Opinion, 25 3 1905
('4', 220, 8, 20, 538300) 172. SLEEP (BEST) RESTORER OF ENERGY
('4', 220, 9, 21, 538337) When a man feels exhausted and is unable to carry on his work, the best remedy is to lie down and sleep and, if possible, to remain in bed for about a week.
('4', 220, 9, 22, 538494) This is the best means to regain lost energy, particularly mental energy, for during sleep the brain enjoys complete rest, and the brain cells that are consumed during active work are then restored through the supply of blood.
('4', 220, 9, 23, 538721) Just as every revolution of the wheel of an imposing streamer is the result of fuel burning in the furnace of the boiler, so also every thought arising in the brain is
('4', 221, 0, 1, 538889) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 221, 1, 2, 538931) caused by the utilisation of its cells during the process of thinking.
('4', 221, 1, 3, 539002) The brain cells thus spent up can only be restored from the life giving substance in the blood, which is formed out of the food we eat.
('4', 221, 1, 4, 539138) The brain is so constituted that it can recover its used up cells only in the quietude of rest or sleep.
('4', 221, 1, 5, 539243) Intoxicating drinks or drugs cannot give any nourishment to the brain.
('4', 221, 1, 6, 539314) They only stimulate it and force it to con sume more of its cells; so much so that the brain gets ultimately exh austed, and has no strength left even to take in the food needed by it, even as a man about to die of hunger and thirst cannot swallow any food or drink.
('4', 221, 2, 7, 539581) [From Gujarati]

('4', 222, 1, 2, 540339) 174. SPEECH AT THEOSOPHICAL LODGE5
('4', 222, 2, 3, 540374) JOHANNESBURG,
('4', 222, 3, 4, 540388) [March 25, 1905]6
('4', 222, 4, 5, 540406) Gandhiji said he had come to the conclusion that Theosophy was Hinduism in theory, and that Hinduism was Theosophy in practice.
('4', 222, 4, 6, 540534) There were many admirable works in Theosophical literature which one might read with the greatest profit, but it appeared to him that too much stress had been laid upon mental and intellectual studies, upon argument, upon the development of occult powers, and that the central idea of Theosophy, the brotherhood of mankind and the moral growth of man, had been lost sight of in these.
('4', 222, 4, 7, 540919) He did not wish to suggest that such studies had no place in a mans life, but he thought that they should follow, not precede, the absolutely certain course which was necessary for every life.
('4', 222, 4, 8, 541112) There were certain maxims of life, which they had not only to get an intellectual grasp of, but which they had to weave into their very being, before they could at all follow the great scriptures of the world.
('4', 222, 5, 9, 541322) When a man desired to qualify in any science, he had first of all to pass an entrance examination, but they seemed to think that when they took up a religious book, no previous preparation in any other direction was necessary, but that they could read these scriptures untaught and interpret them for themselves; and that attitude of mind was considered to be real independence of spirit.
('4', 222, 5, 10, 541711) In his opinion it was nothing but sheer licence taken with things of which they had not the slightest knowledge.
('4', 222, 5, 11, 541824) They were told in all the Hindu scriptures that, before they could even handle these books, they must cultivate absolutely pure and truthful lives, they must learn to control their passions, which took them away from the central point.
('4', 222, 5, 12, 542060) The mind had been likened to an intoxicated monkey, and so it was.
('4', 222, 5, 13, 542127) If they were to analyse their minds, they would find that they had very little reason to think ill of others, and would begin to think ill of themselves, for they would find that they harboured within themselves robbers and murderersterms used by them so glibly in connection with others.
('4', 222, 5, 14, 542416) He wished that they would recognize a limitation in regard to their studies, and that such limitation, instead of hampering
('4', 223, 0, 1, 542540) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 223, 1, 2, 542582) their activity, would further their strength and enable them to soar higher.
('4', 223, 1, 3, 542659) He did not think it at all a part of their lives to extend their scope, but thought it their duty to intensify it both with reference to their studies and to their activities; for, if a man concentrated his attention on a particular thing or idea in life, he was likely to make much better use of himself and of his opportunities than if he divided his attention between this, that, and the next thing.
('4', 223, 2, 4, 543062) Hindu sages told them that to live life, no matter how hampered it might be, no matter with what limitations, was infinitely superior to having a mental grasp of things divine.
('4', 223, 2, 5, 543239) They had taught them that, until, one by one and step by step, they had woven these things into their lives, they would not be able to have a grasp of the whole of the divine teaching; and so he urged them that, if they wanted to live the real life, it was not to be lived in that hall, it was not to be lived in Theosophical libraries, but it was to be lived in the world around them, in the real practice of the little teaching that they might have been able to grasp.
('4', 223, 3, 6, 543710) From a copy: C. W. 11295. Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi; also Mahatma, Vol. I,pp.
('4', 223, 4, 7, 543790) 175. A DOUBLE BARRELLED CIRCULAR
('4', 223, 5, 8, 543823) There is an Act on the Statute book of the Colony of Natal, No.28 of 1897 which is intended as a protection to Indian immi grants who do not come within the scope of the laws affecting inden tured Indians.
('4', 223, 5, 9, 544029) When it was passed, the Indian community suggested that it was a law which could be used as an engine of oppression.
('4', 223, 5, 10, 544146) Its purpose was to give those who would apply for it a certificate to the effect that the holder was not an indentured Indian, so that he might not be arrested on suspicion that he was under indenture and had left his employer.
('4', 223, 5, 11, 544374) It might well be that poor hawkers and such other Indians would really, by taking out a certificate of this description, be protected from molestation.
('4', 223, 5, 12, 544526) But its effect has undoubtedly been to cause a great deal of trouble and heart burning; for although the Act is simply permissive, it has been treated as if it were obligatory, and many an Indian has been detained, and called upon to produce a pass under that Act, or otherwise to show that he is not under indenture.
('4', 223, 6, 13, 544844) A further complication has been added to this Act by a circular relating thereto, issued from the Colonial Secretarys Office to the
('4', 224, 0, 1, 544976) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 225
('4', 224, 1, 2, 545019) Magistrates in Natal.
('4', 224, 1, 3, 545041) Mr. C. Bird, Principal Under Secretary, thus addresses the Magistrates:
('4', 224, 2, 4, 545113) I have to request that, when forwarding an application to the Protector of Indian Immigrants for a pass, under Act No.
('4', 224, 2, 5, 545232) 28 of 1897, you will send with the application, the Certificate of Domicile of the Applicant, or a statement to the effect that this certificate has been produced.
('4', 224, 2, 6, 545396) The intention is quite evident.
('4', 224, 2, 7, 545428) It is to prevent Indians, who may have entered the Colony in breach of the Immigration Restrictions Act, from getting a pass from the Protector under the Act above referred to, and thus defying the Immigration Act.
('4', 224, 2, 8, 545643) But from reports that we have received, the circular has caused a great deal of mischief.
('4', 224, 2, 9, 545733) It punishes a whole community in order that a few guilty ones may be found out.
('4', 224, 2, 10, 545813) It is also calculated to impose an unnecessary fine of two shillings and six pence upon poor people.
('4', 224, 2, 11, 545914) Those who need a pass, under Act 28 of 1897, have first of all to arm themselves with a certificate of domicile, for which a fee of 2/6 has to be paid, and then, when such a certificate has been obtained, a shilling has to be paid for a pass from the Protector.
('4', 224, 2, 12, 546176) Now, as a matter of fact, such cumbersome formalities are totally unnecessary.
('4', 224, 2, 13, 546255) A pass, obtained under Act 28 of 1897, in no way carried with it immunity from prosecution under the Immigration Restrictions Act; and if a certificate of domicile be necessary, the best thing to do is undoubtedly to repeal Act 28 of 1897, so that those Indians who are in the Colony, and are entitled to remain in it under the Immigration Restrictions Act, may take out a certificate of domi cile, should they be afraid of any molestation.
('4', 224, 2, 14, 546696) To expect them to go through the double procedure laid down by Mr. Bird is hardly fair or just, and we question very much whether it is a proper thing, by means of circulars such as the one to which we have drawn attention, to interfere with the administration of law.
('4', 224, 2, 15, 546965) There is nothing in Act 28 of 1897 requiring production of a certificate of domicile.
('4', 224, 2, 16, 547051) We have no doubt that an Indian who insisted could, as a matter of law, compel the granting of the pass by the Protector on application.
('4', 224, 2, 17, 547188) To require, then, the production of a certificate of domicile is to make an unwarranted addition to the Act.
('4', 224, 2, 18, 547297) We, therefore, trust that either the circular in question will be withdrawn, or that the Government will take an early opportunity of repealing Act 28 of 1897.
('4', 224, 3, 19, 547457) Indian Opinion, 1 4 1905

('4', 225, 1, 4, 547872) It confesses to a feeling of disgust at the sordid character of the opposition to British Indians, and has read reports of anti Asiatic proceedings at various places with feelings of humiliation for their unfairness of attitude and inaccuracy of statement.

('4', 225, 1, 7, 548580) The Indian fills his own place in South Africa.
('4', 225, 1, 8, 548628) The prosperity of Natal is very largely dependent upon indentured labour, and, as The Outlook says, in trades that he has made peculiarly his own, the Indian is indis pensable.

('4', 225, 1, 11, 549082) Their confidence in the British sense of Justice remains unshaken, even in the face of harassing regulations such as those to which we have recently drawn attention.
('4', 225, 1, 12, 549248) Ultimately, Justice will be done them.

('4', 225, 1, 14, 549419) We thank our contemporary for this most timely contribution; for, its evident sincerity, moderation and sanity will commend it wher ever The Outlook is read.

('4', 230, 4, 10, 560137) 179. PRAISEWORTHY WORK BY CAPE INDIANS
('4', 230, 5, 11, 560176) MEETING AND DEPUTATION IN CONNECTION WITH THE NEW BILL We congratulate our Indian brethren of the Cape on waking up betimes and actively discharging their duty in regard to the new Bill.
('4', 230, 5, 12, 560363) As soon as the General Dealers Licences Bill was published in draft form in the Cape Government Gazette, the leaders sensed its real purport.
('4', 230, 5, 13, 560505) They held a big meeting in Cape Town 1, expressed their feel ings about the Bill and passed some resolutions, details of which have already been published before 2. Alive to the gravity of the situation, they have not remained content with just this.
('4', 230, 5, 14, 560756) They waited in depu tation upon the Honourable the Attorney General of the Cape Colony, presented these resolutions and discussed them with him.
('4', 230, 5, 15, 560901) In choosing the members of the deputation, they showed tact, and included two respectable local Members of Parliament 3 to lead them.
('4', 230, 5, 16, 561035) The Attonery General, Mr. Sampson, explained to them a number of points about the draft Bill.
('4', 230, 5, 17, 561129) Some of these explanations were all right, but his answers, on the whole, cannot be said to have been satisfactory.
('4', 230, 5, 18, 561245) It is apparent that the Indian leaders will have to be very much on their guard when the Bill comes up before Parliament.
('4', 230, 5, 19, 561367) The question of language, in particular, came in for much discussion at this interview.
('4', 230, 5, 20, 561455) An article in the Bill requires, of every applicant for a licence, a knowledge of at least one European language.
('4', 230, 5, 21, 561569) On this point Mr. Sampson did some plain speaking, but a few other things he said showed that he was being shrewdly evasive.
('4', 230, 5, 22, 561694) The satisfying part of the interview was that he agreed to clarify, in the provision relating to language, that only the account books need be kept in a European
('4', 230, 6, 23, 561856) 1 A meeting of a large number of prominent Indian residents of Cape Town was held under the auspices of the British Indian League at the Masonic Hall, Cape Town.
('4', 230, 6, 24, 562018) 2 Vide Indian Opinion, 18 3 1905, and Indian Opinion, 25 3 1905. 3 Sir William Thorne, M.L.A. and the Hon.
('4', 230, 6, 25, 562125) Edmund Powell, M.L.C.
('4', 231, 0, 1, 562147) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 231, 1, 2, 562189) language and that it was unnecessary [for the authorities] to ensure whether or not the applicant knew the language.
('4', 231, 1, 3, 562306) The Indians have no objection to the books being required to be kept is a European language; even so, the Attorney General passed many strictures [on Indian traders] with reference to this point.
('4', 231, 1, 4, 562502) Although there was little force in his arguments, Indians have to be cautious, particularly about what he said on the subject of discretion being vested in the Magis trate.
('4', 231, 1, 5, 562675) For any matter to be left to discretion nowadays means uncer tainly and endless delay.
('4', 231, 1, 6, 562762) We have seen that, all along, everywhere is South Africa, discretion has had only one result, viz., it invairably goes against Indians.
('4', 231, 1, 7, 562898) Mr. Sampson tried to show that the Indians did not have much to fear but in doing so he somewhat transgressed the limits of his own caution.
('4', 231, 1, 8, 563039) Thus it was he let the cat out of the bag when, in his final reply to Mr. Powell, he said he had spoken vaguely in order to please.
('4', 231, 1, 9, 563171) His reply sounds like a joke.
('4', 231, 1, 10, 563201) It is not at all necessary that the application to the Magistrate should be in English, though it should be intelligible to him. What does this mean?
('4', 231, 2, 11, 563351) From Mr. Sampsons comments on the reasons for the proposed law, it appears that he, too, is suspicious and not well disposed towards Indians.
('4', 231, 2, 12, 563493) He does not appear to have taken the interview seriously; and the illustrations he offered are in our opinion pointless.
('4', 231, 2, 13, 563614) At one point, he said that the Bill was not designed for Indians in particular; and, at another, that such a law had to be enacted, as the Chambers of Commerce and other mercantile bodies had been bringing pressure [on the authorities], complaining that account books of Indians were unsystematic, that he had, as a matter of experience, found it the law courts to obtain the necessary information form the books kept by Indians.
('4', 231, 2, 14, 564044) The law he said, was being enacted to protect European merchants, etc.
('4', 231, 2, 15, 564115) Obviously, this explanation appears to have been given without full consideration.
('4', 231, 2, 16, 564198) He then began to show that he was fair minded and exhibit his knowledge of Indians.
('4', 231, 2, 17, 564282) While doing go, he referred to trading on Sundays and asked if there were not instances of whole Indian families doing business on Sundays.
('4', 231, 2, 18, 564422) In this connection he mentioned a letter he had received, which said that a certain entire Indian family, i.e., including the merchants wife and children, was doing business illegally on Sundays.
('4', 231, 2, 19, 564618) With such people the whites could not compete.
('4', 231, 2, 20, 564665) In this respect the Indians and the Greeks were equally blameworthy, and all of them had to suffer for the sake of the few, etc.
('4', 231, 2, 21, 564794) This drew form Mr. Gool 1 the rejoinder that his correspondent must have been prompted
('4', 231, 3, 22, 564881) 1 Mr. G. M. H. Gool, a prominent Indian Merchant of Cape Twon and one of the members of the deputation.
('4', 232, 0, 1, 564985) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 233
('4', 232, 1, 2, 565028) by jealousy, for his facts were not true.
('4', 232, 1, 3, 565070) If however, any Indian was guilty of this offence, why were they not prosecuted and punished according to law?
('4', 232, 2, 4, 565181) This, in brief, was what transpired at the interview.
('4', 232, 2, 5, 565235) Now, the question that occurs to us is: will a knowledge of English or some other European language prevent these offences?
('4', 232, 2, 6, 565359) We are much sur prised and grieved that the Attorney General who is an able advocate did not hesitate to argue as if it would.
('4', 232, 2, 7, 565486) What relation can there be between a mans language and his character?
('4', 232, 2, 8, 565556) Will the complaints cease if Indian merchants keep their account books in European languages?

('4', 232, 5, 11, 565691) 180. THE PLAGUE HAVOC
('4', 232, 6, 12, 565713) Plague has wrought havoc in India.
('4', 232, 6, 13, 565748) Its virulence this year has been inordinate.
('4', 232, 6, 14, 565793) The Government is helpless and the people despondent.
('4', 232, 6, 15, 565847) In the Punjab, the attack has been so fierce that trade has suffered heavily.
('4', 232, 6, 16, 565925) And even those with a high standard of living who were less susceptible to its attack are no longer so.
('4', 232, 6, 17, 566029) Nevertheless, the dread epidemic is found spreading only among the indigenous popu lation.
('4', 232, 6, 18, 566120) Many people think that this plague is the visitation of Gods wrath on us for our accumulated sins.
('4', 232, 6, 19, 566219) A correspondent of The Times of India has accordingly made a suggestion to the Government that they should fix a day when all India might offer prayers to God to eradicate the epidemic.
('4', 232, 7, 20, 566405) [From Gujarati]

('4', 233, 1, 2, 566488) 181. MEMORIAL TO NATAL LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY 1
('4', 233, 2, 3, 566534) TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY OF THE COLONY OF NATAL, PIETERMARITZBURG April 7, 1905 That your petitioners hereby venture to approach this Hon ourable House in connexion with certain two Bills that will be brought up for your consideration during this session namely, the Bill to amend and consolidate the law relating to the Municipal Corpo rations, and the Bill regulating the use of fire arms, in the follo wing respects: Your petitioners venture to think that the definition of the expression Coloured person in the first Bill above mentioned is very unsatisfactory, in that it means, among others, any coolie or lascar, which themselves require a definition; for, it will be very difficult for a police constable to know whom he is to consider a coolie or a lascar, as the terms do not denote a particular race, but are applied to mean unskilled labourers and seamen respectively.
('4', 233, 3, 4, 567460) In the humble opinion of your petitioners, the definition of the term uncivilised races is also unsatisfactory, and the term itself is offensive to those whom it is intended to include.
('4', 233, 3, 5, 567646) Moreover, your Petitioners fail to understand why the children of indentured Indians should be classed among uncivilised races.
('4', 233, 3, 6, 567774) Many of them have, by industry, risen very high in education and culture, and occupy impor tant positions in the Colony, either as employees or independent men.
('4', 233, 3, 7, 567935) By sub clause (c) in clause 22, persons who are disqualified for the parliamentary franchise by Act 8 of 1896 are disqualified from being placed on the Burgess Roll.
('4', 233, 3, 8, 568101) Act No.
('4', 233, 3, 9, 568109) 8 of 1896 disfranchises those who belong to countries which have not hitherto possessed representative institutions founded on the parliamentry franchise.
('4', 233, 4, 10, 568264) Your Petitioners venture to submit that there is no connexion between the parliamentary franchise and the municipal, and that even though it may be, for the same of argument, true that British Indians do not possess the parliamentary franchise in India, it is capable of conclusive proof that they possess the municipal franchise to a very
('4', 233, 5, 11, 568604) 1 A copy of this memorial on behalf of Abdul Cadir and other British Indians was later annexed to the petition to Lord Elgin dated August 15, 1906, and also reproduced in Indian Opinion, 18 8 1906.
('4', 234, 0, 1, 568802) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 235
('4', 234, 1, 2, 568845) large extent, some of your Petitioners having been, in India, either burgesses or councillors themselves.
('4', 234, 1, 3, 568951) Nor would the past history of the British Indians settled in the Colony justify a disability of the above nature.
('4', 234, 1, 4, 569065) Your Petitioners therefore humbly submit that it would be an unnecessary insult offered to the British Indians should the clause in question receive your approval.
('4', 234, 2, 5, 569229) Your Petitioners have failed to see any justification for authority to the Town Councils in the Colony to make by laws with respect to the use of pavements and foot paths by Coloured persons, and also the use of rickshaws by them, in so far as the term includes Indians.
('4', 234, 2, 6, 569500) It is thus in this connexion that the definition of the term Coloured person comes into play, and is calculated to give rise to a great deal of mischief.
('4', 234, 3, 7, 569654) Your Petitioners also humbly protest against clause 200 of the said Bill, in that it authorises the Council to frame by laws establishing a system of registration of Natives or persons belonging to uncivi lised races.
('4', 234, 3, 8, 569872) In your petitioners opinion, registration of those In dians who are included in the term uncivilised races is totally uncalled for, as Indians have never been found unwilling workers.
('4', 234, 3, 9, 570056) It will furthermore appear, from the clause under discussion, that regis tration would be required of even cultured Indians.
('4', 234, 4, 10, 570181) With regard to the second Bill, your Petitioners venture to submit that it has very much grieved the British Indians residing in the Colony.
('4', 234, 4, 11, 570322) Sections 44 to 47 deal with the use of fire arms by Natives and Asiatics.
('4', 234, 4, 12, 570396) Your Petitioners think that the Indians with the Natives is hardly justified.
('4', 234, 4, 13, 570474) The Indian is a very docile Colonist, and has never given any trouble, and your Petitioners venture respectfully to point out that to bracket Indians and Natives together, and to compel the former to deal with the Native Department before they can obtain a permit to own a fire arm, which may be required for self protection, would be extremely degrading.
('4', 234, 5, 14, 570830) Your Petitioners, therefore, in conclusion, pray that the Bills above mentioned will be so amended as to remove any cause for complaint.
('4', 234, 6, 15, 570967) India, 14 9 1906
('4', 235, 0, 1, 570984) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 235, 1, 2, 571026) 182. MR. LYTTELTON ON THE INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 235, 2, 3, 571077) From a cablegram in the local papers, we notice that Mr. Lyt telton, in reply to a question, has stated that the position of the British Indians in the Transvaal has been bettered by the judgement 1 in the Test Case of Motan v.
('4', 235, 2, 4, 571305) The Government.
('4', 235, 2, 5, 571321) With all due respect, we venture to think that the statement is not in accord with facts; and in any case, why should he or the Government take the slightest credit for any relief in the position because it was obtained in spite of the Government?
('4', 235, 2, 6, 571569) Is it not a fact that the Government opposed the appli cation for a licence made to the Supreme Court?
('4', 235, 2, 7, 571672) They were repres ented by three eminent counsel, and they really drove the Indian com munity to the test case, because it was undertaken after even the old bona fide traders were refused licences to trade, on the ground that they did not hold licences immediately before the outbreak of hosti lities.
('4', 235, 2, 8, 571973) That they traded outside Locations before the war was not held sufficient.
('4', 235, 3, 9, 572048) We are, indeed, strongly reminded of the pre war days.
('4', 235, 3, 10, 572103) Then, too, there was a test case 2 exactly similar to the one referred to by Mr. Lyttelton.
('4', 235, 3, 11, 572195) Then, the British Government assisted the Indians to fight the case.
('4', 235, 3, 12, 572264) They contended, with the Indians, that under Law 3 of 1885, Indian trade outside Locations was not prohibited, but after the Transvaal passed into British hands, a different tune was played.
('4', 235, 3, 13, 572455) The same British Government, in the test case of Motan, instructed Counsel to oppose the Indian contention.
('4', 235, 3, 14, 572563) It is strange that, having this know ledge, Mr. Lyttelton should appropriate credit for the decision of the Supreme Court on the test case.
('4', 235, 3, 15, 572703) But, as we have said, the position of the Indians has not in any way become better than it was during the Boer regime.
('4', 235, 3, 16, 572822) It has certainly become better that it was before the test case, but after the establishment of British Government in the Trans vaal, the decision of the Supreme Court enables the Indians, on pay ment of licence money, to trade where they like.
('4', 235, 3, 17, 573067) Before the war, under the protection of the British Government, the Indians were able to trade where they liked without payment of any licence money.
('4', 235, 4, 18, 573217) 1 The judgment was that Habib Motan, an Indian trader, could not be refused a licence to trade outside locations.
('4', 235, 4, 19, 573331) 2 Vide Letter to the British Agent, 28 2 1898, Letter to G.V. Godfrey, 18 3 1898, A Statement of Account, 25 3 1898 & Notes on the Test Case , 4 4 1898.
('4', 236, 0, 1, 573484) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 237
('4', 236, 1, 2, 573527) true that the Indians tendered the licence money, but the Boer Gove rnment declined to accept it, and were powerless, owing to British opposition, to prosecute the Indians who, with their knowledge and under notice to them, traded outside Locations.
('4', 236, 1, 3, 573777) Thus, the position of the British Indians, so far as regards trade, was better before the war than it is to day.
('4', 236, 1, 4, 573890) In other respects, too, the position is bad enough, and certainly no less gloomy than before the war, and it is unexcusably painful, so far as Indian immigration into the country is concerned.
('4', 236, 1, 5, 574083) Before the war, any Indian was free to enter the Transvaal.
('4', 236, 1, 6, 574143) To day, even a bona fide refuge Indian, who is in a position to show that he has been previously domiciled in the Transvaal, and that he has paid, before the war, the sum of 3 as the price of permission to settle in the Colony, finds it tremendously difficult to obtain a permit to enter the country; and a British Indian, no matter what his qualifications or status may be, if he be not a refugee, cannot possibly enter the coun try.
('4', 236, 1, 7, 574578) His application receives scant treatment at the hands of the Gover nment; and this all but total prohibition of Indian immigration has been brought about, not by fair and open means, but by pressing into service a political ordinance passed, in the first instance, to prevent the entry into the Transvaal of people who might be suspected of having treasonable designs.
('4', 236, 1, 8, 574947) That Ordinance is being now abused to shut the Indian out of the country.
('4', 236, 1, 9, 575021) The religious susceptibilities of the Indians were hardly ever touched during the old regime, but now, though it is true that one cannot say anything against the Government on this point, the fact stands that there is an agitation to day going on in Potchefstroom against the erection of a mosque, not, as has been stated in a prominent place in the town, but in a by lane.
('4', 236, 1, 10, 575395) We could go on recounting the troubles of the Indians, and could show how, contrary to all expectations that were raised in the minds of the Indians by the conduct of the British Government, and by the speeches of British Ministers, the Indians now find themselves face to face with a life and death struggle, and for Mr. Lyttelton to say that the position of the British Indians in the Transvaal has been bettered is, to say the least, extremely misleading.
('4', 236, 1, 11, 575854) Not until the Law 3 of 1885, and other laws dealing with the British Indians, have been erased from the Statute book of the Transvaal Colony, and legislation passed in greater agreement with British ideas of justice, will it be possible for the British Indian in the Transvaal to say that he is once more a British subject, enjoying all the rights that flow from such a status.
('4', 236, 1, 12, 576232) To day he is a step child seeking and yearning for protection on the part of his parents, which protection he does not get.
('4', 236, 1, 13, 576356) Indian Opinion, 8 4 1905
('4', 237, 0, 1, 576381) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 237, 1, 2, 576423) 183. AN IMPORTANT JUDGMENT CONCERNING TRANSVAAL INDIANS
('4', 237, 2, 3, 576479) It is well known that Indians cannot hold land in their own names and that some of them, therefore, purchase land in the names of the whites.
('4', 237, 2, 4, 576621) Mr. Syed Ismail, a resident of Johannesburg, possessed some land which he held in the name of a white friend of his, Mr. Lucas.
('4', 237, 2, 5, 576749) When the Johannesburg Corporation acquired Locations, etc., this land also was taken over by them, and a resolution to pay Mr. Lucas 2,000 as compensation was passed.
('4', 237, 2, 6, 576916) Mr. Lucas died during the war, and his estate was attached for insolvency.
('4', 237, 2, 7, 576991) As his assets were not sufficient to pay off his debtors, in trustees claimed the compen sation payable towards the land held by him on behalf of Syed Ismail.
('4', 237, 2, 8, 577150) Syed Ismail thereupon filed a suit in the High Court claiming that this sum of  2,000 should be paid to him.
('4', 237, 2, 9, 577259) The creditors of Lucas raised two issues: firstly that the amount claimed by Syed Ismail stood in the name of Lucas, and secondly, that, since the land to which Syed Ismail claimed a title was immovable property, he could not enjoy the right of its ownership.
('4', 237, 2, 10, 577519) The rejoinder to this, submitted on behalf of Syed Ismail, was that, as the land was held on ninety nine years lease, it could not be regarded as immovable property and that, therefore, there could be no objection to Indians owning such land.
('4', 237, 2, 11, 577762) And should the Court not hold this argument valid, there was the alternative answer that the law, which prevented Indians from ownership of immovable property, did not lay down that immovable property could not be held by others, such as the whites, in their own names on behalf of Indians.
('4', 237, 2, 12, 578053) Giving the verdict in favour of Syed Ismail, the honourable judge remarked, with regard to the second issue, that land on a ninety nine years lease should 1 be considered immovable property, and such land, therefore, could not stand in the name of an Indian.
('4', 237, 2, 13, 578312) Granting Syed Ismails second plea, however, the judge held that the whites could hold lands for the benefit of Indians, and that the law would protect the rights of an Indian owner if a white holding the propety intended to commit fraud.
('4', 237, 2, 14, 578550) This decision is very satisfactory; therefore, the Indians who are hesitating to purchase land in the names of whites need have no such fear any longer.
('4', 237, 2, 15, 578703) It should, however, be borne in mind that the white concerned must be a turstworthy person and a clear title deed should be obtained from him.
('4', 237, 2, 16, 578846) It appears certain that
('4', 237, 3, 17, 578870) 1 In the original, not seems to have been wrongly placed.
('4', 237, 3, 18, 578928) It would mean could not be considered immovable property.
('4', 238, 0, 1, 578986) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 239
('4', 238, 1, 2, 579029) this decision will strengthen us in our fight with the Government for our rights.
('4', 238, 1, 3, 579111) We learn that the trustees for Lucas estate have preferred an appeal against this decision to the High Court.
('4', 238, 1, 4, 579221) Let us await the outcome of the appeal.
('4', 238, 2, 5, 579261) [From Gujarati]

('4', 238, 4, 7, 579302) 184. CURZONS SPEECH ON INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('4', 238, 5, 8, 579349) A Reuter cable tells us that Lord Curzon made a forceful speech in the Indian Legislature in support of our case.
('4', 238, 5, 9, 579463) He said that the South African Colonies would get no help from India, so long as they did not guarantee that the rights of Indians would be fully safeguarded.
('4', 238, 5, 10, 579622) He added that it was the duty of the Government of India to protect the Indians and that they would continue to discharge that duty.
('4', 238, 6, 11, 579755) These words are bound to gladden us.
('4', 238, 6, 12, 579792) They will certainly have a good effect.
('4', 238, 6, 13, 579832) The speech shows that our efforts here do not go in vain.
('4', 238, 6, 14, 579890) It behoves us to continue to make added effort and, as opportu nity presents itself, agitate for the redress of our grievances.
('4', 238, 6, 15, 580018) We are sure that, given unity and concerted effort, we shall succeed.

('4', 238, 11, 21, 580329) Mr. Lyttelton is reported to have said that, since the decision in the test case in the Transvaal, the position of the British Indians had
('4', 239, 0, 1, 580468) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 239, 1, 2, 580510) become better than before war.
('4', 239, 1, 3, 580541) You will notice a reply to this state ment in Indian Opinion of the 8th April in its first leading article.
('4', 239, 1, 4, 580649) The position generally has certainly not become better [but] has become worse than before war, and the relief that the test case has secured for the Indians simply takes them back to the pre war days; but even for this the Government can hardly take any credit as they opposed the Indian contention strenuously before the Supreme Court.

('4', 239, 7, 11, 581648) 186. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('4', 239, 8, 12, 581682) JOHANNESBURG, April 11, 1905 TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY, BLOEMFONTEIN
('4', 239, 10, 13, 581766) The attention of my Association has been drawn to regulations that are published from time to time in the Government Gazette in connection with the various Municipalities in the Orange River Colony regarding Coloured persons resident therein, and to the Ordinance to supplement and amend the provisions of law with reference to the Municipality of Bloemfontein.
('4', 239, 10, 14, 582128) In the regulations for the Township of Reddersburg, my Asso ciation noticed that the term Native is so defined as to include all Coloured persons, not excepting British Indians, and the regulations
('4', 240, 0, 1, 582326) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 241
('4', 240, 1, 2, 582369) for this Township, as also for that of Vrede, lay down rules for the control of the Coloured people living within those townships, which, in the humble opinion of my Association, are degrading, unjust and in sulting; and while it is very probable that there are no British Indians staying in those townships, the regulations in question are none the less offensive on that account, and should a stray Indian happen to enter any of those townships, he would suddenly find himself hem med in by galling restrictions.
('4', 240, 2, 3, 582884) My Association was pained to see similar powers granted by Ordinance 19 of 1905 to the Municipality of Bloemfontein.
('4', 240, 2, 4, 583001) My Ass ociation ventures to think that such anti colour activity in the Orange River Colony is contrary to British traditions as also the declarations made from time to time by Her late Majestys Ministers, and it is inco mprehensible to my Association why such legislation and regulations are countenanced by the Government of the Orange River Colony.
('4', 240, 3, 5, 583353) My Association will be extremely obliged if you will be pleased to inform me whether it is the intention of the Government to grant any relief in the matter.
('4', 240, 3, 6, 583511) I have the honour to remain, Sir, Your obedient servant, ABDUL GANI, CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 22 4 1905
('4', 240, 4, 7, 583643) 187. MR. BARNETTS CHARGE AND MR. ANCKETILL
('4', 240, 5, 8, 583686) Mr. Ancketill is to be congratulated on having questioned the Colonial Secretary upon the charge levelled by Mr. Barnett, the ex Superintendent of Education, against certain employers of indentured Indians in Natal, in connection with the condition of the latters huts, which he described as piggeries.
('4', 240, 5, 9, 583989) Mr. Maydon 1 has replied, saying that the charge made by Mr. Barnett is greatly exaggerated, and that the Protector of Indians looks after the welfare of the indentured Indians.
('4', 240, 5, 10, 584167) Mr. Maydon promised to lay on the table of the House the report made by the Protector on the
('4', 240, 6, 11, 584260) 1 Colonial Secretary for Natal.
('4', 241, 0, 1, 584292) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 241, 1, 2, 584334) charge.
('4', 241, 1, 3, 584342) We consider the reply of the Colonial Secretary to be unsatis factory in every respect.
('4', 241, 1, 4, 584430) Here is a charge of extreme gravity made with the fullest deliberation before an audience of cultured men, who enjoyed a most responsible position in the Colony.
('4', 241, 1, 5, 584592) Mr. Barnett was then speaking generally on education in Natal, and the above charge is by no means an isolated passage in his address, which is a serious indictment against the system of education prevalent in Natal.
('4', 241, 1, 6, 584809) To call for a report from the Protector of Immigrants in a matter of this kind is very much like setting a man to judge his own case.
('4', 241, 1, 7, 584943) Mr. Barnetts charge, we contend, includes in its condemnation the whole of the Indian Immigration Department.
('4', 241, 1, 8, 585053) We do not say he is right, but we do say that the report drawn [up] by a Department which is condemned contradicting the condemnation is hardly the way to meet the indictment.
('4', 241, 1, 9, 585229) It is not merely a question of consulting the interests of the indentured Indians, it is that of the fair name of the Colony.
('4', 241, 1, 10, 585355) We think that the Government would be extremely ill advised in not probing the question to the bottom, and giving the fullest satisfaction to the public.
('4', 241, 1, 11, 585509) If the result of the independent inquiry in any way supports Mr. Barnetts charge, the sooner the blot is removed the better for the Colony; and if the charge is proved to be incorrect, Mr. Barnett sho uld be called upon, as a past public servant, to offer an explanation.
('4', 241, 1, 12, 585781) We hope, therefore, that Mr. Ancketill will continue to question the Colonial Secretary until what is needful has been done.
('4', 241, 1, 13, 585906) It is to be noticed, also, that Mr. Barnett delivered his attack before an audience that included the ex Prime Minister of Natal, Sir Albert Hime, and many other Natal notabilities.
('4', 241, 1, 14, 586088) Sir Albert Hime made lengthy remarks after the lecturer had finished, and we do not see anywhere a repudiation of the serious charge brought by Mr. Barnett.
('4', 241, 1, 15, 586245) Does the Colonial Secretary not find food for reflection here?

('4', 241, 3, 17, 586334) 188. LECTURES ON RELIGION
('4', 241, 4, 18, 586360) It appears from the Johannesburg newspapers that, on being invited by the Theosophical Society there to deliver a course of lectures on the Hindu religion, Mr. Gandhi gave four speeches on the subject at the Masonic Temple.
('4', 241, 4, 19, 586584) On each occasion the hall was full.
('4', 241, 4, 20, 586620) The last speech was delivered on the 25th of March.
('4', 241, 4, 21, 586672) An account of two of the speeches has already appeared in The Star.
('4', 241, 4, 22, 586740) 1 We give below, on
('4', 241, 5, 23, 586760) 1 Vide Hinduism, March 4, 1905 and March 11, 1905.

('4', 242, 1, 3, 586946) CONTEMPT FOR INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA When the Theosophical Society invited me to deliver these spe eches, I accepted the invitation on two considerations.
('4', 242, 1, 4, 587101) It is now nearly twelve years that I have been living in South Africa.
('4', 242, 1, 5, 587172) Everyone is aware of the hardships suffered by my compatriots in this land.
('4', 242, 1, 6, 587248) People view with contempt the colour of their skin.
('4', 242, 1, 7, 587300) I believe all this is due to a lack of proper understanding; and I have continued to stay in South Africa with a view to helping as much as possible in the removal of this misunderstanding.
('4', 242, 1, 8, 587490) I, therefore, felt that it would to some extent help me in the fulfilment of my duty if I accepted the Societys invitation; and I shall regard myself very fortunate if I am able, through these lectures, to give you a better understanding of the Indians.
('4', 242, 1, 9, 587744) I am to speak to you no doubt about the [Hindus 1]; but the ways and manners of the Hindus and other Indians are all but identical.
('4', 242, 1, 10, 587876) All Indians have similar virtues and vices and are descended from the same stock.
('4', 242, 1, 11, 587958) The other consideration was that there was, among the objects of the Teo sophical Society, this one, viz., to compare the various religions, find out the truth underlying these and show the people how those reli gions were only so many roads leading to the realisation of God, and how one ought to hesitate to dub any of them false.
('4', 242, 1, 12, 588291) I thought that this object, too, would be realised to some extent if I said a few words on the Hindu religion.
('4', 242, 2, 13, 588402) THE HINDUS
('4', 242, 3, 14, 588413) Hindus are not considered to be the original inhabitants of India.
('4', 242, 3, 15, 588480) According to Western scholars, the Hindus as well as most of the European peoples lived at one time in Central Asia.
('4', 242, 3, 16, 588597) Migrating from there, some went to Europe, some to Iran, others moved south eastwards down into India through the Punjab, and there spread the Aryan religion.
('4', 242, 3, 17, 588756) The Hindu population in India exceeds two hundred millions.
('4', 242, 3, 18, 588816) They are called Hindus because they once lived beyond the river Sindhu (Indus).
('4', 242, 3, 19, 588896) The Vedas are their oldest scripture.
('4', 242, 3, 20, 588934) Very devout Hindus believe that the Vedas are of divine origin and without beginning.
('4', 242, 3, 21, 589020) Western scholars hold that these were composed before 2000 B.C. The famous Mr. Tilak of Poona has shown that the Vedas must be at least 10,000 years old.
('4', 242, 3, 22, 589174) 2 The main thing that distinguishes the Hindus is their belief that the Brahman or oversoul is all perva ding.
('4', 242, 3, 23, 589285) What we all have to attain is moksha or liberation, moksha, here

('4', 243, 1, 3, 589584) Humility and even mindedness are the chief qualities of their ethics; while caste reigns supreme in their temporal affairs.
('4', 243, 1, 4, 589708) The Hindu religion underwent its first trial on the advent of Lord Buddha.
('4', 243, 1, 5, 589783) The Buddha was himself the son of a [king 1].
('4', 243, 1, 6, 589829) He is said to have been born before 600 B.C. At that time the Hindus were under the glamour of the outward form of their religion, and the Bra hmins had, out of selfishness, abandoned their true function of defen ding the Hindu faith.
('4', 243, 1, 7, 590064) Lord Buddha was moved to pity when he saw his religion reduced to such a plight.
('4', 243, 1, 8, 590145) He renounced the world and started doing penance.
('4', 243, 1, 9, 590195) He spent several years in devout contemplation and ultimately suggested some reform in the Hindu religion.
('4', 243, 1, 10, 590302) His piety greatly affected the minds of the Brahmins, and the killing of animals for sacrifice was stopped to a great extent.
('4', 243, 1, 11, 590428) It cannot, therefore, be said that the Buddha founded a new or different religion.
('4', 243, 1, 12, 590511) But those who came after him gave his teachings the identity of a separate religion.
('4', 243, 1, 13, 590596) King Ashoka the Great sent missionaries to different lands for the propagation of Buddhism, and spread that religion in Ceylon, China, Burma and other countries.
('4', 243, 1, 14, 590758) A distinctive beauty of Hinduism was rev ealed during this process: no one was converted to Buddhism by force.
('4', 243, 1, 15, 590869) Peoples minds were sought to be influenced only by discus sion and argument and mainly by the very pure conduct of the prea chers themselves.
('4', 243, 1, 16, 591011) It may be said that, in India at any rate, Hinduism and Buddhism were but one, and that even today the fundamental pri nciples of both are identical.
