('4', 248, 6, 10, 601982) A REPLY TO MR. HILLS1
('4', 248, 7, 11, 602004) TO THE EDITOR The Outlook JOHANNESBURG
('4', 248, 9, 12, 602043) Mr. W. Hills has made in his letter to The Outlook statements which are hardly borne out by the facts.
('4', 248, 9, 13, 602146) The Editor has not supported a policy which would hand over the Transvaal to a parasitical race.
('4', 248, 9, 14, 602243) Mr. Hills himself admits, by implication, that the British Indian is very industrious and hard working.
('4', 248, 9, 15, 602347) It is scarcely fair to call a race of such men parasites.
('4', 248, 10, 16, 602405) Mr. Hills says his opposition to Asiatics is not due to colour prejudice but to economic considerations; and in support he states the experience of all Natalians.
('4', 248, 10, 17, 602568) Now the experience of all Natalians it is difficult to know.
('4', 248, 10, 18, 602629) The experience of some, who, moreover, are acc epted as representative of the people of Natal, is on record.
('4', 248, 10, 19, 602738) The late Mr. Saunders, the late Sir Henry Binns, the late Sir John Robinson, the late Mr. Escombe, the present Colonial Secretary, Mr. Maydon, Sir G. M. Sutton, Sir James Hullett, and many other, have testified to the usefulness of the Indian in Natal.
('4', 248, 10, 20, 602991) The late Sir Henry Binns said, in giving evidence before a Commission, that it was when Natal was on
('4', 248, 11, 21, 603092) 1 This appeared, along with Mr. W. Hills Letter of March 14, in The Outlook.
('4', 248, 11, 22, 603169) The editor of that periodical had submitted Mr. Hills letter to one who has made the subject one of special study Gandhiji.
('4', 248, 11, 23, 603293) Both the letter and the reply were later reprinted in Indian Opinion.
('4', 248, 11, 24, 603363) Only the reply is reproduced here.
('4', 249, 0, 1, 603398) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 249, 1, 2, 603440) the brink of bankruptcy that Indian immigration was thought of.
('4', 249, 1, 3, 603504) Sir James Hullett, only a few months ago, giving his evidence before the Native Affairs Commission, said emphatically that Natal owed its pro sperity to the presence of the Indian immigrant, and that it could not do without him.
('4', 249, 1, 4, 603733) The greatest proof, however, in support of the state ment that Natal requires the Indian is given by Mr. Hills himself.
('4', 249, 1, 5, 603853) If the Indian population in Natal has doubled since 1896, what is the cause?
('4', 249, 1, 6, 603930) It is simply that more and more Indians are being required in order to keep going the chief industries of Natal, namely, sugar, tea and coal.
('4', 249, 1, 7, 604072) It should be remembered that the Indian of whom Mr. Hills is thinking is not an intruder, but that he is actually invited to the Colony for its benefit.
('4', 249, 1, 8, 604225) There are still 18,000 applications before the Indian Immigration Trust Board which have to be dealt with.
('4', 249, 1, 9, 604332) The demand for indentured Indian labour is much greater than the supply.
('4', 249, 1, 10, 604405) Verulam always had a large Indian population.
('4', 249, 1, 11, 604451) Mr. Hills, in regretting that it has become an Indian township, forgets that it had either to become an Indian township or cease to be a town at all.
('4', 249, 1, 12, 604601) The north coast of Natal takes in the largest Indian population.
('4', 249, 1, 13, 604666) It has to be dev eloped either by Indian labour or not at all.
('4', 249, 1, 14, 604729) The Natalians have thou ght better, and have not hesitated to cultivate the coast land through Indian labour, and the palatial mansions which the white men occupy even on the north coast, let it be remembered, are due entirely to the assistance of the Indian immigrant, and are owned by the employers of Indian labour, so that the example of Natal is all in favour of the Indian, and the economic considerations on which Mr. Hills lays so much stress have compelled the Natalians to resort to Indian assis tance.
('4', 249, 1, 15, 605242) Again, Mr. Hills makes a mistake when he states that the law, under the late Government as interpreted for 15 years, confined Asia tics to Locations.
('4', 249, 1, 16, 605392) It is a well known fact that, under the late Govern ment, the Indians lived outside Locations with absolute impunity, and, it is because they were able to do so, that the present Government find it difficult to oust them.
('4', 249, 1, 17, 605614) It is true that, as they had British protection then, it could hardly be withdrawn now, and it should be again rem embered that, during the Boer regime, there was no restriction against Indian immigration, whereas, today, as the Chief Secretary for Permits has shown, only those Indians who were settled in the country before the war are allowed to re enter, and then, too, after much questioning and delay.
('4', 249, 1, 18, 606022) Although Mr. Hills talks about the white population in general and its good, in applying his principles, he only takes notice of the Indian licences to trade.
('4', 249, 1, 19, 606181) Is it, then, that he objects only to the Indian traders?
('4', 249, 1, 20, 606238) Mr. Hills again makes the mistake of supposing that
('4', 250, 0, 1, 606290) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 251
('4', 250, 1, 2, 606333) the South African Coloured people are refused licences, whilst the Indians received them freely.
('4', 250, 1, 3, 606430) Under the Supreme Courts ruling, the Government dare not prevent any Coloured people, as such, from getting licences, and if Mr. Hills objection is, after all, as it evidently seems to be, against the trade of the Colony falling entirely or even largely into the hands of Indians, there is not much difficulty in sympathising with him, nor has the Editor of The Outlook suggested that such competition should not be regulated by a statute of general application.
('4', 250, 1, 4, 606893) But to thus regulate Indian trade, and to hound the Indian out of the Colony by all kinds of vexatious legislation, are two dif ferent things.
('4', 250, 1, 5, 607036) With the one, every sensible Colonist will be in perfect agreement, so long as vested interests are not touched, and licences are not refused to Indians as such.
('4', 250, 1, 6, 607198) But it is scarcely in keeping with justice and fair play, for instance, to prevent the Indian from walking on foot paths, from owning landed property, from living, subject to strict municipal regulations, or from building a mosque, anywhere he likes.
('4', 250, 1, 7, 607449) Such restrictions are meaningless, if they do not proceed from colour prejudice, and it is questionable whether those who fan the flame of such prejudice would be doing any good to posterity.
('4', 250, 1, 8, 607641) The facts must be taken as they are.
('4', 250, 1, 9, 607678) India is part of the British Empire, like the Trans vaal, and there ought to be a policy of give and take, whilst there certainly should be nothing done to needlessly wound the feelings of these men, who are, after all, subjects of the same King, and are a people with remarkable traditions and a wonderful ancient civilisation.
('4', 250, 2, 10, 608007) Two simple bills are likely to solve the whole difficulty.
('4', 250, 2, 11, 608066) One would give to the Local bodies control of all trade licences, subject, in exceptional cases, to review by the Supreme Court, and the other would regulate immigration into the Colony after the manner of the Cape Immigration Act.
('4', 250, 3, 12, 608298) One more statement by Mr. Hills needs correction.
('4', 250, 3, 13, 608348) After the correspondence that appeared in The Star, challenging the statement that there are 49 Indian, as against 13 white, store keepers in Pieters burg, some caution, at least, is necessary.
('4', 250, 3, 14, 608542) The British Indian Associa tion has stated 1 definitely that there are only 23 Indian stores in that town.
('4', 250, 3, 15, 608649) Mr. Kleinenberg, whom Mr. Hills has copied, has not been able to refute that statement.
('4', 250, 3, 16, 608737) It is, therefore, necessary for Mr. Hills to ascertain from Mr. Kleinenberg whether the figures he gave The star could be verified.

('4', 253, 7, 18, 615475) 195. MALARIA IN DURBAN
('4', 253, 8, 19, 615498) Malaria has been raging in Durban with great virulence.
('4', 253, 8, 20, 615554) There were only 12 cases in last January, but the number of persons attacked during March was 612. The figure is alarming.
('4', 253, 8, 21, 615677) The only relieving feature is that the rate of mortality is not high.
('4', 253, 8, 22, 615747) Again, according to Dr. Murison, it is largely women, children and others, who mostly keep
('4', 254, 0, 1, 615838) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 255
('4', 254, 1, 2, 615881) indoors, that have caught the infection.
('4', 254, 1, 3, 615922) And it is pointed out that it has spread through mosquitoes from Zululand.
('4', 254, 1, 4, 615997) Dr. Murison suggests the following preventive measures.
('4', 254, 1, 5, 616053) 1. Mosquito curtains with very small holes should be used by every one sleeping on a cot, and care taken to remove any mosquitoes on the bed and tuck in the lower edge of the curtain under the mat tress along the four sides.
('4', 254, 1, 6, 616278) A torn curtain should not be used until it has been properly mended.
('4', 254, 1, 7, 616347) 2. As far as possible, quinine should not be taken as a pre ventive.
('4', 254, 1, 8, 616416) If, however, one has to live in an infected house or to sleep without a mosquito curtain, one should take five grains of quinine every day before breakfast.
('4', 254, 1, 9, 616573) 3. Water should not be allowed to collect in or around the house.
('4', 254, 1, 10, 616639) Drains and gutters should be inspected, and pits and ditches filled up.
('4', 254, 1, 11, 616711) 4. Where there are large pools of stagnant water, they should be sprayed with kerosene until the pits are filled up.
('4', 254, 1, 12, 616828) 5. The authorities should be informed if water collects and stagnates, or there is an overgrowth of useless vegetation around the house within the premises.
('4', 254, 1, 13, 616985) It is necessary for every one to take these precautions.
('4', 254, 1, 14, 617042) The main thing is that one should keep the house and its surroundings clean, not allow mosquitoes to breed, keep ones person clean and take light food.
('4', 254, 1, 15, 617194) The incidence of malaria is greater among the whites than among the Coloured people.
('4', 254, 1, 16, 617279) Of the 612 cases mentioned above, 400 were whites, 185 Asiatics and 27 Kaffirs.
('4', 254, 1, 17, 617359) This shows that some comm unities are more susceptible to certain diseases than others.
('4', 254, 1, 18, 617447) While the Indians are more liable to plague, the whites are particularly suscep tible to malaria.
('4', 254, 1, 19, 617545) But if we consider the matter in this fashion, it would be just like the pot calling the kettle black.
('4', 254, 1, 20, 617648) Nevertheless, malaria is not a deadly disease, while plague is a terrible killer.
('4', 254, 1, 21, 617730) Through proper investigation, the causes of both these diseases can be found out.
('4', 254, 1, 22, 617812) We must not fail in our duty to take all the necessary precautions.
('4', 254, 1, 23, 617880) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 22 4 1905

('4', 261, 3, 8, 631060) 205. THE TRANSVAAL CONSTITUTION
('4', 261, 4, 9, 631092) The Transvaal Constitution has been on the lips of everybody in South Africa ever since its publication.
('4', 261, 4, 10, 631197) We cannot recall an instance when the constitution of a British Colony has evoked so much interest as the one given to the Transvaal.
('4', 261, 4, 11, 631331) Every newspaper has published lea ding articles: every important person in South Africa has offered his judgment on it; and the sum and substance of the great body of opi nion that has gathered round the Constitution appears to be praise not unmixed with unfriendly criticism.
('4', 261, 4, 12, 631608) In fact, Lord Milner, in his valedi ctory address at Johannesburg, anticipated such a result when he said that the Constitution would probably fail to please anybody wholly, but that it would be accepted by all fair minded men as a genuine attempt to bring nearer together the British and the Boers, and to prepare the people in the near future for complete self government.
('4', 261, 4, 13, 631983) The objections that have been taken to the details are, in our opinion, objections taken because of ignorance of the history regar ding Constitutions for the other self governing Colonies.
('4', 261, 4, 14, 632172) The point is that, even wherein there has been strong agitation for the grant of self government, or other representative institutions, there has never been such a close examination of the details before.
('4', 261, 4, 15, 632377) People have hitherto
('4', 262, 0, 1, 632398) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 263
('4', 262, 1, 2, 632441) been satisfied with the granting of a principle, but to day we find them insisting on every detail being arranged according to their notions.
('4', 262, 1, 3, 632583) Hence it is that exceptions are seriously taken to the reservations by the Crown regarding legislation, although, if trouble were taken to examine even Constitutions for the self governing Colonies, it would be found that the power of veto has been always retained, and occasi onally even exercised.
('4', 262, 1, 4, 632883) For instance, when the Australian Common wealth passed its anti Asiatic legislation excluding Asiatics as such, Mr. Chamberlain had no hesitation in disallowing the Act; and simi larly in Natal.
('4', 262, 1, 5, 633078) The first action of the responsible ministry in disfran chising Indians as such was promptly checked by Lord Ripon.
('4', 262, 1, 6, 633194) It is conveniently forgotten that the Constitution which the Transvaal has received is perhaps the most liberal yet known of all the Constitutions granted preliminary to responsible government.
('4', 262, 1, 7, 633388) The other objection taken, that the Orange River Colony has not received the same treat ment as the Transvaal, goes to the root of all government.
('4', 262, 1, 8, 633535) So long as Britain remains the predominant power, and so long as governments must ultimately depend upon force, it is useless to express dissatis faction with what is, in the nature of things, unavoidable.
('4', 262, 2, 9, 633741) Apart, however, from the intrinsic merit of the Constitution, Mr. Lytteltons despatch, which served as preamble to the Constitution itself, is the most important of all.
('4', 262, 2, 10, 633911) It is a humane document worthy of a British minister.
('4', 262, 2, 11, 633965) Coming to the purely Indian standpoint, it is difficult not to feel that the British Indian, as also the British Coloured man, is only the step child, and has been left out in the cold.
('4', 262, 2, 12, 634151) He has no voice in the affairs of the Colony, and he is insulted by deliberate exclusion.
('4', 262, 2, 13, 634241) Mr. Lyttelton says:
('4', 262, 3, 14, 634261) His Majestys Government have been unable, having regard to the Terms of Peace signed in 1902, to make provision for the representation of any of His Majestys coloured subjects.
('4', 262, 3, 15, 634438) And here it may be noted that even Mr. Lyttelton has made the common mistake of including other people in the term Native.
('4', 262, 3, 16, 634561) The Terms of Peace mention only the natives of South Africa.
('4', 262, 3, 17, 634622) Why should other Coloured people, then, be included by inference?
('4', 262, 3, 18, 634688) Mr. Lyttelton proceeds:
('4', 262, 4, 19, 634712) As a protection, however, for the interests of those sections of the population which are not directly represented in the legislature, the Governor will, as now, be required by his instructions to reserve any bill whereby persons
('4', 263, 0, 1, 634942) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 263, 1, 2, 634984) not of European birth or descent may be subjected to any disability or restriction to which persons of European birth are not also subjected.
('4', 263, 1, 3, 635126) It is to be hoped that the reservation will be fully exercised.
('4', 263, 1, 4, 635190) Indian Opinion, 6 5 1905
('4', 263, 2, 5, 635215) 206. EDUCATION OF INDIANS
('4', 263, 3, 6, 635241) Speaking on education in the Natal Parliament, Mr. Wiltshire said that the Government should provide greater facilities for the education of Indians.
('4', 263, 3, 7, 635391) He pointed out that Indians needed them and that a special responsibility devolved on the Government for the education of Natal born Indians.
('4', 263, 3, 8, 635533) We should be thankful to the Hono urable Gentleman for his speech.
('4', 263, 3, 9, 635600) Our condition is likely to improve in every way with the increasing spread of education.
('4', 263, 3, 10, 635689) The Government will no doubt have ultimately to discharge their duty in the matter.
('4', 263, 3, 11, 635773) It appears that, in the absence of a separate school for Indians in Lady smith, the Government have permitted Indians with a high standard of life to be admitted to the existing school.
('4', 263, 3, 12, 635959) Speaking in the Orange River Colony, Mr. Argette, the late Sup erintendent of Education in the Transvaal and the Orange River Colony, declared that he would make special efforts for the education of the Kaffirs in Basutoland.
('4', 263, 3, 13, 636185) He is sufficiently mindful of the need for technical education.
('4', 263, 3, 14, 636249) He was very sympathetic about the education of Indians, and was always trying to start schools for them in the Trans vaal.

('4', 265, 2, 3, 639133) His Excellency Lord Selborne will arrive shortly in Johannes burg.
('4', 265, 2, 4, 639200) From the account of his career given by the well known journ alist, Mr. Stead, in the April issue of the Review of Reviews, it appears that, when His Excellency made the speech about the war on Novem ber 1, 1899, he was secretary to Mr. Chamberlain.
('4', 265, 2, 5, 639450) While recounting, in the course of that speech, the causes of the war, he said that the British Government fought it not in order to deprive the Boers of their rights, but to accord equal rights both to Boer and Briton.
('4', 265, 2, 6, 639670) The British Government was not actuated by self interest or monetary considera tion, but they wanted to determine and uphold the rights of other peoples.
('4', 265, 2, 7, 639824) The British Government were the trustees of the people of Canada and Australia, the Negroes in South Africa and the Indian immigrants in the Transvaal.
('4', 265, 2, 8, 639976) It was, therefore, their duty to wage war for the protection of these peoples.
('4', 265, 2, 9, 640055) Since it was the duty of the British to keep the promises they had made, they were bound to protect the rights of all these peoples.
('4', 265, 2, 10, 640188) It was the duty of the British Government to protect the rights of British subjects wherever they were, whether white or Coloured.
('4', 265, 2, 11, 640319) It was on these grounds that His Excellency defended the war.
('4', 265, 3, 12, 640381) Quoting the above speech of Lord Selborne, Mr. Stead remarks, Let us see how Lord Selborne stands by what he has said.
('4', 265, 3, 13, 640500) Let us hope the noble lord will stick to his words and add luster to the name of England by relieving the Indians of the hardships they are labouring under.

('4', 267, 4, 10, 642823) 211. SIR ARTHUR LAWLEY AND THE BRITISH INDIANS
('4', 267, 5, 11, 642870) His Excellency, the High Commissioner, has been visiting Piete rsburg in connection with an Agricultural Show, and British Indians took the opportunity of presenting His Excellency with a loyal address.
('4', 267, 5, 12, 643073) The action is to be commended.
('4', 267, 5, 13, 643104) They were able to draw from Sir Arthur Lawley some remarks on the Indian question.
('4', 267, 5, 14, 643187) His Exce llency is reported to have said that
('4', 267, 6, 15, 643233) of all the difficulties which presented themselves to the Government at the present time, none was harder than that dealing with the status of British Indians in this country.
('4', 267, 6, 16, 643409) The Government realised the conspicuous and sple ndid services which had been rendered to the Empire by them in India and in other parts.
('4', 267, 6, 17, 643547) The Government appreciated the value of those services fully.
('4', 267, 6, 18, 643609) People in this country, however, recognised that the conditions governing the Indians were not the same as those existing in the land from which the latter came.
('4', 267, 6, 19, 643771) Here prejudices had arisen in the minds of the people owing to past history with coloured classes, and the question of the Indians presence was looked at from an entirely different standpoint.
('4', 267, 6, 20, 643964) He was sure the Indians must recognise this.
('4', 267, 6, 21, 644009) The Government was called on to hold the scales of justice impartially, and the question was still a matter of correspondence be tween the Home Government and the Colonial administration.
('4', 267, 6, 22, 644197) We thank Sir Arthur for his acknowledgement of Indias contribution to the Empire; but the result of such acknowledgement, we are sorry to have to say, is very poor.
('4', 267, 6, 23, 644362) We cannot help recalling His
('4', 268, 0, 1, 644391) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 269
('4', 268, 1, 2, 644434) Excellencys advice to Mr. Lyttelton that promises made to the British Indians, having been made in ignorance, were better broken than fulfilled.
('4', 268, 1, 3, 644579) The British Indian Association has shewn conclusively that promises were made to the Indians in the Transvaal with full know ledge of the circumstances and by no means in ignorance.
('4', 268, 1, 4, 644761) We fear that His Excellency has, shall we say with deference, committed the same mistake in his remarks quoted above.
('4', 268, 1, 5, 644879) Why should he mix up the Indians with other Coloured classes?
('4', 268, 1, 6, 644941) If a majority of the white people in the Transvaal will not see a distinction, is it not the duty of the Government to educate them up to a proper appreciation of it?
('4', 268, 1, 7, 645108) How can Indians be expected to recognise unreasonable prejudice if it is meant thereby that they should bow to it?
('4', 268, 1, 8, 645223) Recognition of such prej udice is undoubtedly necessary; but it is so only in order that it may be removed by calm discussion, and by placing constantly before the public the true facts.
('4', 268, 1, 9, 645410) The Government would hold the scales of justice impartially only when it boldly tackles the question, and instead of indirectly encouraging the current prejudice, endeavours to stem its tide by taking up a firm attitude.
('4', 268, 1, 10, 645631) As to the carrying on of a correspondence with the Home Government, we have good reason to believe that this is meant to wring from the latter a consent to the imposing of further disabilities on British Indians.
('4', 268, 1, 11, 645844) Has His Excellency studied carefully the very moderate propositions made by the British Indians in the Transvaal?
('4', 268, 1, 12, 645958) Has his Government ever told the people of the Transvaal that the claims put forward by the Indians are extremely reasonable, and that they have shewn a laudable desire to meet the views of the white Colonists so far as possible?
('4', 268, 2, 13, 646188) Indian Opinion, 13 5 1905
('4', 268, 3, 14, 646214) 212. JUVENILE SMOKING
('4', 268, 4, 15, 646236) There appears, in a recent issue of the Cape Government Gazette, an interesting Bill to be introduced by Mr. T. L. Schreiner, the well known member of the Cape House of Assembly.
('4', 268, 4, 16, 646415) Mr. Schre iner is known to be a philanthropist and a moralist.
('4', 268, 4, 17, 646478) The Bill we are alluding to is called the Youths Smoking Prevention Bill, and is intended to prohibit smoking by youths of or under the age of 16 years, or appearing to be so.
('4', 268, 4, 18, 646654) The manner in which the Honourable Gentleman wishes to achieve his object is very simple.
('4', 268, 4, 19, 646744) The Bill makes it criminal for any tobacconist to sell tobacco, cigars, or cigarettes to boys appearing to be of 16 years or under.
('4', 268, 4, 20, 646876) It also authorises the police to confiscate and destroy any tobacco, pipe, cigar or cigarettes
('4', 269, 0, 1, 646971) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 269, 1, 2, 647013) found on the person of such youths and authorises the parents or guardians of the latter to sue the seller of the offensive product for a refund of the money paid to him, notwithstanding destruction of the things sold, whilst it also enables teachers in Government schools to punish smoking by boys as a school offence.
('4', 269, 1, 3, 647333) It has been often said that people cannot be made sober by an act of Parliament, and the same may be equally applicable to Mr. Schreiners Bill; but we are not prepared to concur in the view that temperance legislation has not been productive of some good.
('4', 269, 1, 4, 647589) We are inclined to think that this Bill, if it meet with the approval of the Cape House, will be a step in the right direction.
('4', 269, 1, 5, 647717) Smoking, in any case, is neither a desirable nor a clean habit, and whilst, under certain circumstances, it may be of some use, and may also be a great soother of pain, the habit of smoking amon gst boys is undoubtedly harmful, and ought to be checked by all legitimate means.
('4', 269, 1, 6, 647994) The Bill is, perhaps, proof of the existence of the evil to a large extent.
('4', 269, 1, 7, 648070) Indeed, we see the habit often indulged in by telegraph boys and messengers who are much below 16 years.
('4', 269, 1, 8, 648175) The specious plea is often put forward, in defence of juvenile smoking, that, if it is good for adults, it could not be bad for youths.
('4', 269, 1, 9, 648311) A moments thought, however, would convince the casuists that what is good for the one is not necessarily good for the other; and smoking is one of such things which may not be indulged in by boys with impunity.
('4', 269, 1, 10, 648522) It undermines their constitution and weakens their mental capacity.
('4', 269, 1, 11, 648590) We, therefore, hope that Mr. Schreiner will be able to induce the Cape Parliament to accept the Bill.
('4', 269, 2, 12, 648692) Indian Opinion, 13 5 1905
('4', 269, 3, 13, 648718) 213. EARTHQUAKE IN INDIA
('4', 269, 4, 14, 648743) News received by the latest mail from India gives full details of the havoc wrought by the earthquake.
('4', 269, 4, 15, 648846) The Divine wrath that has descended on the people of Northern India is such that it will not be forgotten for years.
('4', 269, 4, 16, 648963) Many an old historical monument, numerous villages, palatial buildings in large cities, the simple huts of the poor and tented camps of the army have all been devastated.
('4', 269, 4, 17, 649134) Several fami lies have been totally wiped out.
('4', 269, 4, 18, 649181) The greatest damage has been done to Dharmasala, the Kangra valley, Palampur and Mussoorie.
('4', 269, 4, 19, 649273) The acco unt of the condition of the victims of the calamity is very pitiable ind eed.
('4', 269, 4, 20, 649360) Men were rendered quire helpless and died for want of food and water, as no news whatever of the peoples condition could be had from certain parts due to a breakdown of telegraphic communica tions.
('4', 269, 4, 21, 649558) The Government evinced great sympathy and ran special trains
('4', 270, 0, 1, 649619) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 271
('4', 270, 1, 2, 649662) to render all possible help to the distressed.
('4', 270, 1, 3, 649709) Subscription lists have been opened in India as well as in Great Britain, and large sums have already been contributed.
('4', 270, 1, 4, 649829) Our readers must already be aware that we, too have started a fund in aid of those unfortunate fellow Indians who have been suddenly reduced to a state of penury.
('4', 270, 1, 5, 649992) We hope everyone will do his duty and contribute to the fund to the best of his capacity.

('4', 270, 4, 8, 650125) 214. LETTER TO ANNIE BESANT
('4', 270, 5, 9, 650153) [JOHANNESBURG,] May 13, 1905 MRS.
('4', 270, 5, 10, 650187) ANNIE BESANT CENTRAL HINDU COLLEGE BENARES CITY
('4', 270, 6, 11, 650235) DEAR MADAM,
('4', 270, 7, 12, 650247) The Managers of the International Printing Press have sent me your letter to them regarding the reprint of your Bhagawad Gita.
('4', 270, 7, 13, 650374) The responsibility for the advice, as to the reprint and inclusion of the por trait, must rest entirely on my shoulders.
('4', 270, 7, 14, 650495) I know that ordinarily it would not be considered a proper thing to reprint a book without the authors permission.
('4', 270, 7, 15, 650610) A gentleman offered to have a translation of the Bhagawad Gita printed for distribution among Hindu boys and other if the Managers printed it at cost price.
('4', 270, 7, 16, 650767) He was also in a hurry.
('4', 270, 7, 17, 650791) Reprint of your translation was suggested.
('4', 270, 7, 18, 650834) The matter was referred to me and, after much careful thought, as there was no time left for reference to you, I advised that your translation might be reprinted for circulation in South Africa.
('4', 270, 7, 19, 651029) I felt that the motive of the management was pure, and that when the circumstances, under which the edition was pub lished, were brought to your notice, you would overlook any apparent impropriety.
('4', 270, 7, 20, 651227) Simultaneously with the publication, a letter, explaining the whole of the circumstances, was sent to you over the signature of the Manager and Proprietor.
('4', 270, 7, 21, 651383) It seems to have miscarried.
('4', 270, 7, 22, 651412) We were all wondering why there was no letter from you, either of disapproval or approval.
('4', 270, 7, 23, 651503) Your letter of the 27th March, however, explains the absence of any previous communication from you.
('4', 270, 7, 24, 651604) As to the portrait, I can only say that, if a mistake has been committed, it has arisen from excessive reverence for yourself.
('4', 270, 7, 25, 651731) When I suggested the inclusion of
('4', 271, 0, 1, 651765) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 271, 1, 2, 651807) the portrait, I had in my mind the interpretation that was likely to be placed upon the act by some people, but I again felt that you would not resent the indiscretion, if such it was, when you came to know that a large number of the copies went to the Indian youths.
('4', 271, 1, 3, 652075) Rightly or wrongly, as you are aware, publication or printing of such portraits in scared works is not uncommon in India.
('4', 271, 1, 4, 652197) Only 1,000 copies were printed.
('4', 271, 1, 5, 652229) Of these, there are perhaps not more than 200 left, and these are being distributed or sold now probably at the rate of 5 per month, and then only among real inquirers.
('4', 271, 1, 6, 652398) I have now placed the whole position before you, and it remains for me to express my deep regret for the offence done to your feelings and to apologise for it.
('4', 271, 1, 7, 652558) If you consider that any public state ment is necessary, or complete withdrawal of the book from further circulation, or simple taking out of the portrait is necessary, your wishes shall be carried out.

('4', 271, 3, 10, 652852) 215. MR. GANDHIS CLARIFICATION 1
('4', 271, 4, 11, 652885) May 13, 1905
('4', 271, 5, 12, 652898) I am glad the Editor forwarded the above letter to me, and I am grateful to Mr. Vavda for having expressed his views.
('4', 271, 5, 13, 653016) There was only one object before me in delivering these speeches, viz., to serve Indians.
('4', 271, 5, 14, 653106) I readily accepted the invitation to give an ideal of the Hindu religion in India and what it stood for.
('4', 271, 5, 15, 653211) While doing so, I found it necessary to compare it with other religions.
('4', 271, 5, 16, 653284) But in this, my one consi deration was to point out, as far as possible, the special excellences of each religion and create a favourable impression on the minds of the whites.
('4', 271, 5, 17, 653461) All the facts stated by me were drawn from history, which we have been learning at school since childhood.
('4', 271, 5, 18, 653568) That Islam was spread by force is a historical fact.
('4', 271, 5, 19, 653621) But along with it, I also pointed out that the potent cause of the spread of Islam was its simplicity and its
('4', 271, 6, 20, 653731) 1 In one of the lectures delivered on the Hindu religion under the auspices of the Theosophical Society, Johannesburg, vide Hinduism, March 10, 1905 and March 18, 1905. Gandhiji, referring to the spread of Islam, had said that the majority of converts to Islam came from the lower classes.
('4', 271, 6, 21, 654021) He had also mentioned fervour or passion as a powerful trait of Islam, which was responsible for many good deeds and someties for bad ones also.
('4', 272, 0, 1, 654166) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 273
('4', 272, 1, 2, 654209) special virtue of regarding all as equals.
('4', 272, 1, 3, 654252) That the majority of converts to Islam were Hindus from the lower classes is also a fact that can be proved; and I, for one, do not consider that to be in any way derog atory.
('4', 272, 1, 4, 654428) To me personally, there is no distinction between a Brahmin and a bhangi 1. And I consider it a merit of Islam that those who were dissatisfied with the social distinctions in Hinduism were able to better their condition by embracing Islam.
('4', 272, 1, 5, 654669) Nor did I suggest that all the converts to Islam came only from the lower classes of Hindu society.
('4', 272, 1, 6, 654769) And I have not the least idea that by the lower classes are meant only the untouchable Dheds.
('4', 272, 1, 7, 654863) While I admit that men from the higher classes such as Brahmins and Kshatriyas also became Muslims, it is universally known that the bulk of converts was not drawn from among them.
('4', 272, 1, 8, 655044) However, the point I want to emphasise is that no stigma attaches to Islam if the Hindus of the lower castes became Muslims.
('4', 272, 1, 9, 655169) On the contrary, it shows its excellence, of which the Muslims should be proud.
('4', 272, 2, 10, 655249) As for the fervour or passion of Islam, I do hold the view I have already stated.
('4', 272, 2, 11, 655331) Mr. Vavdas interpretation of the word fervour or passion is quite mistaken.
('4', 272, 2, 12, 655407) I have used it in a complimentary sense, and have clearly pointed out that it is a strong point of Islam.
('4', 272, 2, 13, 655513) Nothing worth while can be accomplished without real fervour.
('4', 272, 2, 14, 655575) The Turks could resist Russia and Greece successfully only when they fought desperately with real fervour, and now all are afraid of the Turkish soldiers.
('4', 272, 2, 15, 655730) None could lay hands on Rajputana while the Rajputs fought with fervour.
('4', 272, 2, 16, 655803) Japan has been able to take the fort of Port Arthur 2 only because she has been fighting with fervour.
('4', 272, 2, 17, 655906) Fervour is as necessary in other tasks as it is in war, and it is a positive virtue.
('4', 272, 2, 18, 655991) Edison is making inventions because of passion.
('4', 272, 2, 19, 656039) It was the passion of Watt which let to the invention of the steam engine and made travelling in the world easy.
('4', 272, 2, 20, 656152) And we shall be able to come together and succeed in our fight for the redress of our grievances against the whites if we have the same passion.
('4', 272, 2, 21, 656297) This passion is the special merit of Islam.
('4', 272, 2, 22, 656341) We shall benefit immensely if this very passion is brought to bear on other tasks.
('4', 272, 3, 23, 656424) These statements of Gandhiji created a stir among Indian Muslims in South Africa and several letters of protest were received by the Editor, Indian Opinion, who published three of them along with this letter which is Gandhijis reply to Mr. A. E. Vavdas letter dated May 9, 1905. 1 Scavenger.
('4', 272, 3, 24, 656716) 2 The Russian fleet at Port Arthur was defeated by the Japanese on August 10, 1904.
('4', 273, 0, 1, 656800) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 273, 1, 2, 656842) I have nothing more to add.
('4', 273, 1, 3, 656870) I know that the question that arose in the mind of Mr. Vavda has arisen in the minds of others as well.
('4', 273, 1, 4, 656974) I have said what I considered to be true.
('4', 273, 1, 5, 657016) In doing so, I had no intention of offending the feelings of even a single individual.
('4', 273, 1, 6, 657103) To my mind, there is no distinction between a Hindu and a Muslim or Christian.
('4', 273, 1, 7, 657182) I have frequently said so and, I believe, I have been acting accordingly.
('4', 273, 1, 8, 657256) I maintain that Hindu religion teaches us to look upon all with an equal eye without making distinctions between Hindu and Muslim, Brahmin and bhangi, and that is the religion I follow.
('4', 273, 1, 9, 657442) M. K. GANDHI [From Gujarati]

('4', 276, 5, 10, 662961) 219. LETTER TO DADABHAI NAOROJI 1
('4', 276, 6, 11, 662995) [JOHANNESBURG,] May 15, 1905 [SIR,]
('4', 276, 7, 12, 663031) Natal of late has been very active in its anti Indian crusade.
('4', 276, 7, 13, 663094) Attention has been drawn to the various Bills that have appeared in the Government Gazette, and which are now before the Natal Parliament.
('4', 276, 8, 14, 663233) The Firearms Bill, without the slightest justification, brackets the Indians with the Natives, and places them, so far as that Bill is con cerned, under the Native Affairs Department.
('4', 276, 8, 15, 663417) I need hardly say what the moral effect of this is likely to be.
('4', 276, 9, 16, 663482) There is another Bill published which makes occupation by Indians of rural land in Natal no occupation at all.
('4', 276, 9, 17, 663593) The Bill seeks to impose a tax of one halfpenny per annum on every acre of unoc cupied rural land when it is beyond 249 acres owned by one indi vidual or company.
('4', 276, 9, 18, 663756) For the purposes of the Bill, such land occupied by Indians, if they are not owners, would be liable to taxation.
('4', 276, 9, 19, 663870) This is insulting and unjust.
('4', 276, 9, 20, 663900) It is Indians who have made the cultivation of the coast lands possible.
('4', 276, 10, 21, 663973) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 1960.

('4', 281, 4, 9, 670872) 227. LORD CURZON ON THE INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('4', 281, 5, 10, 670920) The Indian mail to hand brings the full text of Lord Curzons remarks, at the time of the Budget debate in the Viceregal Council, on the Indians in South Africa.
('4', 281, 6, 11, 671081) His Excellency made a lengthy reference to the status of the British Indians in South Africa, and the British Indian settlers must feel deeply indebted to him for his strong advocacy.
('4', 281, 6, 12, 671265) His Excellency devoted a considerable portion of his speech to the situation in Natal, and we now understand, for the first time, the nature of the work done by the delegates who proceeded to India some time ago on behalf of the Natal Government.
('4', 281, 6, 13, 671512) Their object was to impose further restrictions on indentured Indians by making their return, at the end of their service, absolutely compulsory.
('4', 281, 6, 14, 671658) Lord Curzon, we are glad to be able to say, repudiated any such suggestion, unless certain concessions were granted by the Natal Government in favour of non indentured Indians settled in the Colony.
('4', 281, 6, 15, 671857) His Lordship asked for the eventual abolition of the 3 tax, amendment of the Dealers Licenses Act, as also of the
('4', 282, 0, 1, 671971) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 283
('4', 282, 1, 2, 672014) regulations in which Indians are classed with barbarous races, and other minor matters.
('4', 282, 1, 3, 672102) All this is extremely satisfactory, and it shews that the Indian appeal to the Viceroy has received very full consideration.
('4', 282, 1, 4, 672227) His Excel lency added that he was able to obtain one concession, namely, that three years residence in the Colony was accepted by the Natal Gove rnment as freeing Indian residents from the prohibition under the Immigration Restriction Act.
('4', 282, 1, 5, 672467) This means that His Lordship has been led to believe that it was a concession granted by the Natal Govern ment.
('4', 282, 1, 6, 672579) If so, we are sorry, because it would be a misleading statement.
('4', 282, 1, 7, 672644) As a matter of fact, the Natal Government were bound to lay down certain rules with reference to the interpretation of the term previous domicile.
('4', 282, 1, 8, 672791) The law, as it stood, stated that those Indians who were previously domiciled in the Colony were free from the educational prohibition.
('4', 282, 1, 9, 672927) In practice, two years residence was accepted by Mr. Smith, as a rule, as evidence of previous domicile; and it was on Mr. Smiths recommendation that the Government have raised the period to three years and embodied it in the Act.
('4', 282, 1, 10, 673158) Also, we may inform His Excellency that three years residence is not necessarily to be acce pted as sufficient evidence of domicile.
('4', 282, 1, 11, 673291) We make bold to say that, but for the amendment of the Act, it would not be possible, even for an Indian who had resided in the Colony for six months, and could prove that he had changed his residence to Natal and intended to be domiciled, to be refused exemption.
('4', 282, 1, 12, 673556) What, therefore, His Lordship considers is a concession, we are, with great deference, obliged to say, is no concession at all.
('4', 282, 1, 13, 673684) The question, however, is whether His Excel lency can safely stop where he has left the question.
('4', 282, 1, 14, 673782) During the current year, the Natal Parliament has been actively pursuing an anti Indian policy.
('4', 282, 1, 15, 673878) We have already drawn attention to Bills containing anti Indian clauses.
('4', 282, 1, 16, 673951) The Dealers Licenses Act is a thing of constant worry and irritation.
('4', 282, 1, 17, 674021) Is it right, then, that Natal should still continue to draw upon India for the staple of her prosperity, and reject the advances of the Indian Government on behalf of free British Indians?
('4', 282, 1, 18, 674210) To say the least, it is a one sided bargain, in which Natal gets all without giving anything in return.
('4', 282, 1, 19, 674314) His Lordship dwelt on the position in the Transvaal.
('4', 282, 1, 20, 674367) His statement is a recapitulation of Mr. Lytteltons despatch, but it shews that he is fully alive to the interests of his wards.
('4', 282, 1, 21, 674496) We hope that his watchful guardianship will, in the near future, cause the Indians to be released from the galling restraints under which they labour in that Crown Colony.
('4', 282, 1, 22, 674668) Indian Opinion, 20 5 1905
('4', 283, 0, 1, 674694) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 283, 1, 2, 674736) 228. ANTI INDIAN LEGISLATION IN NATAL
('4', 283, 2, 3, 674774) In a recent number of the Natal Government Gazette, there are three Bills published which shew how bad the financial position of the Colony is.
('4', 283, 2, 4, 674918) One of the Bill is intended to impose a poll tax of 1 per head on every adult male of the age of 18 years or over.
('4', 283, 2, 5, 675033) It exempts from liability to pay the tax, poor or infirm persons, as also inden tured Indians whilst they are under indenture.
('4', 283, 2, 6, 675160) The second Bill im poses a succession duty on the estates of deceased persons, the mini mum duty, in the case of lineal descendants or ascendants bearing one per cent.
('4', 283, 2, 7, 675328) The two measures are likely, if they are accepted by the Parliament of Natal, to produce a fair amount of revenue.
('4', 283, 3, 8, 675443) It is, however, the third Bill with which we are more immediately concerned, and which raises a very important question, affecting the Indian community.
('4', 283, 3, 9, 675596) The Bill is entitled To Impose a Tax upon Un occupied Rural Lands.
('4', 283, 3, 10, 675663) It is sought thereby to impose a tax of a half penny per acre on every piece of unoccupied rural land of an extent of 250 acres or upwards.
('4', 283, 3, 11, 675803) Clause 5 of the Bill states that
('4', 283, 4, 12, 675836) land shall be deemed to be unoccupied unless the owner or some European has continuously resided thereon for at least nine out of the twelve months prior to the first day of March in any year.
('4', 283, 4, 13, 676029) Thus, any piece of rural land that may be occupied by Indians in the Colony, other than the owners, would, if the Bill becomes law, be considered as unoccupied for the purpose of imposing the halfpenny tax.
('4', 283, 4, 14, 676236) The Bill may affect Indian landlords in the coast districts, where land is cultivated only by Indians.
('4', 283, 5, 15, 676339) This policy of constantly insulting and irritating the Indians without cause ought, in the interests of the Empire, to be checked by Mr. Lyttelton.
('4', 283, 5, 16, 676487) It is true that Natal enjoys complete self government, and it is therefore at liberty to make its own laws; but when liberty becomes license, it is a question whether the authorities in Downing Street, who are the custodians of the honourable traditions of the Empire, should not check legislation which insults British subjects not directly represented in the Legislature.
('4', 283, 5, 17, 676861) Indian Opinion, 20 5 1905
('4', 284, 0, 1, 676887) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 285
('4', 284, 1, 2, 676930) 229. THE IMMIGRATION LAW IN THE CAPE
('4', 284, 2, 3, 676967) The Report of the Immigration Officer of the Cape, Dr. Gre gory, on the working of the Immigration Law in that Colony, has been published.
('4', 284, 2, 4, 677106) We find therein that, of the persons seeking entry into the Cape last month, 298 were not allowed to enter.
('4', 284, 2, 5, 677214) Of these, 56 were disallowed because they were not literate in English, 156 because they were paupers and 74 because they were illiterate and poor; twelve were not allowed to land because they were prostitutes.
('4', 284, 2, 6, 677425) Dr. Gregorys view is that, because of hard times, many who would have otherwise come have not been able to do so, and that, therefore, it is not possible to say what the real effect of this law has been.
('4', 284, 2, 7, 677629) He also believes that many Indians were put to difficulty in not being able to land.
('4', 284, 2, 8, 677714) And even if it is held that this law is good for preventing the entry of Indians, it is questionable whether it is just to prevent British Indian subjects from entering, when Yiddish speaking Hebrews who are actual beggars can do so by borrowing money from their friends.
('4', 284, 2, 9, 677986) It seems from the Report that Dr. Gregory himself regards this law as unjust.
('4', 284, 2, 10, 678064) The Cape Government have promised Indians in the Cape that the provision in the law regarding language would be so amended as to make the knowledge of an Indian language acceptable.
('4', 284, 2, 11, 678246) It is the duty of leading Indians in the Cape to get that promise implemented.
('4', 284, 2, 12, 678325) We are sure that, if they pursue the matter energetically, the Government will make the necessary changes in the Act.
('4', 284, 2, 13, 678443) We hope that the Cape Indians will take up the matter vigorously and see it through.

('4', 284, 5, 16, 678570) 230. THE LATE MR. TATA 1
('4', 284, 6, 17, 678595) A mammoth meeting was held early last April in the Town Hall in Bombay to perpetuate the memory of the late Mr. Tata, with Lord Lamington, the Governor, in the chair.
('4', 284, 6, 18, 678762) The first resolution regarding the raising of a memorial was moved by the popular Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court, Sir Lawrence Jenkins.
('4', 284, 6, 19, 678906) Justice Badruddin
('4', 284, 7, 20, 678924) 1 Sir Jamshedji Nasserwanji Tata (1839 1904), Indian industrialist and philanthropist.
('4', 285, 0, 1, 679011) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 285, 1, 2, 679053) Tyabji, 1 Justice Chandavarkar, the Honourable Mr. Parekh, 2 Sir Bhalchandra 3 and others attended the meeting.
('4', 285, 1, 3, 679165) All the speakers, including the Governor, pointed out that a gentleman as liberal, simple and as sagacious as Mr. Tata had hardly lived before in India.
('4', 285, 1, 4, 679318) In whatever he did, Mr. Tata never looked to self interest.
('4', 285, 1, 5, 679378) He never cared for any titles from the Government, nor did he ever take distinctions of caste or race into consideration.
('4', 285, 1, 6, 679500) As Justice Badruddin observed, the Parsis, the Muslims, the Hindusall were equal to him.
('4', 285, 1, 7, 679589) For him it was enough that they were Indians.
('4', 285, 1, 8, 679635) He was a man of deep compassion.
('4', 285, 1, 9, 679668) Tears came to his eyes at the thought of the sufferings of the poor.
('4', 285, 1, 10, 679737) Though he possessed unlimited wealth, he spent nothing from it on his own pleasures.
('4', 285, 1, 11, 679822) His simplicity was remarkable.
('4', 285, 1, 12, 679853) May India produce many Tatas!
('4', 285, 1, 13, 679883) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 20 5 1905

('4', 292, 6, 11, 689601) 243. EMPIRE DAY
('4', 292, 7, 12, 689617) Empire Daythe anniversary of the birth of the late Queen Empressis a day set apart by universal consent in all parts of the Empire outside Great Britain to commemorate the reign of its most beloved Queen.
('4', 292, 7, 13, 689822) It is but a deeper tribute to her memory that it is becoming known as Empire rather than as Victoria Day; for it is a recognition that no person has done more to draw together the units of those vast Dominions of which she was the Queen Empress.
('4', 292, 7, 14, 690068) By her large heart and wide sympathy; by her abilities and queenly virtues; above all, by her personal goodness as a woman, she has for ever enshrined herself in the hearts of every nation under the British flag.
('4', 292, 7, 15, 690281) The lesser persons who administered her power might make mistakes; injustice even might be committed in her name; but the people ever knew that the mistakes and the injustice came not from Victoria the Good.
('4', 292, 7, 16, 690489) As wife and as mother, she proved herself as worthily as Queen; and knowing that domestic virtue alone makes a household happy and prosperous, she was a firm believer in the scrip tural statement: Righteousness exalteth a nation; but sin is a reproach to any people.
('4', 292, 7, 17, 690756) She saw, before all others, that the British Empire must
('4', 293, 0, 1, 690813) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 293, 1, 2, 690855) be founded on the rock of righteousnessindividual and nationalif it were to have a permanent prosperity.
('4', 293, 1, 3, 690960) Other nations and other Empires the past has held; but all have been broken on this rock of offense.
('4', 293, 1, 4, 691061) From the first, when she spoke those simple words: I will be good, she endeared herself to her subjects the world over.
('4', 293, 1, 5, 691181) It may be noted here that Victoria owed her greatness in very large part, under Providence, to her own wise mother; and both before and since, great men and women without number have dutifully acknowledged the same.
('4', 293, 1, 6, 691397) It is always true that a good mother makes a wise child.
('4', 293, 1, 7, 691454) As another instance of this, we have but to see the universal satisfaction that is felt with the present occupant of the British throne, who by his tack and wisdom has already done so much for the Empire and the world.
('4', 293, 1, 8, 691673) Of all contemporary monarchs, King Edward best exhibits that peculiar genius which constitutes true kingship; and this is due in most part to the influence of his august Mother.
('4', 293, 1, 9, 691851) In every way, then, Victoria is a name worthy to be honoured when we think of the Empire; and it is but fitting that the day set apart should be the anniversary of the hour that brought her into the world.
('4', 293, 1, 10, 692057) To Indians especially, Victoria Day should be sacred.
('4', 293, 1, 11, 692111) No other person has done so much for the liberty of India as the late Queen Empress.
('4', 293, 1, 12, 692196) That this was recognised by the millions of India was apparent by the remarkable demonstrations of mourning that took place throughout India on her decease.
('4', 293, 1, 13, 692353) Speaking of her, the Viceroy said:
('4', 293, 2, 14, 692388) The hearts of all the Indian people had been drawn together by this singular and beautiful combination of mother, woman and queen.
('4', 293, 2, 15, 692519) It was easy to say much about the mark which this marvelous reign had left upon the history of India, and to indicate many points where the sagacious hand and influence of the deceased Sovereign had been felt; but were not all her reign and character summed up in the famous Proclamation of 1858, the Magna Charta of India, and the golden guide of our conduct and our aspirations?
('4', 293, 2, 16, 692900) It might be said of her that she turned Great Britain into a worldwide Empire, with India as its corner stone.
('4', 293, 2, 17, 693011) Victorias interest in India was always personal and profound.
('4', 293, 2, 18, 693073) Not only did she surround herself with Indian servants; not only did she learn to speak and write Hindustani (no light task to one burdened with the cares of State); but she made the Viceroy send an account of the situation in India by every mail.
('4', 293, 2, 19, 693321) And that her knowledge of Indian affairs was intimate is shewn by the following extract from one of her letters to Lord Northbrook.
('4', 293, 3, 20, 693453) The Queen trusts the English are now kinder in their conduct to the
('4', 294, 0, 1, 693521) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 295
('4', 294, 1, 2, 693564) Natives than they used to be.
('4', 294, 1, 3, 693594) It is so essential that these unchristianlike feelings should no longer exist.
('4', 294, 1, 4, 693673) It is everywhere her greatest wish that there should be the kindest and best feeling between classes who, after all, are the same before God.
('4', 294, 1, 5, 693815) The same before God that was the spirit which inspired the great Proclamation; and of which the Empire has scarcely proved itself worthy.
('4', 294, 1, 6, 693953) It is with regret that we say it; and it is with regret that we have to call the attention of our readers and the authorities to various matters in which the spirit of Victoria the Good has been violated, when we would have wished that this issue of our journal at least should be free from anything that would detract from our satisfaction in belonging to the great British Empire.
('4', 294, 2, 7, 694336) Indian Opinion, 27 5 1905
('4', 294, 3, 8, 694362) 244. IN THE NATURE OF A TEST CASE
('4', 294, 4, 9, 694396) An important decision has been given by the Supreme Court in the case in which one Said Ismail and another were plaintiffs, and L. K. Jacobs was defendant in his capacity as Trustee in the Insolvent Estate of one Lucas, deceased.
('4', 294, 4, 10, 694626) The original action was brought in the High Court at Johannesburg.
('4', 294, 4, 11, 694693) The plaintiffs held some landed property there, but being prevented from registering the title in their own names, had it registered in the name of their friend, the deceased Lucas.
('4', 294, 4, 12, 694875) This was in the year 1896. Until recently, they had remained in possession, with the knowledge of the authorities, and they had paid all the assessment and other rates.
('4', 294, 4, 13, 695044) They adopted that course upon the advice of a prominent firm of solicitors in Johannesburg; and in order to protect themselves, they took from the deceased Lucas an irrevo cable power of attorney to deal with the property, and also a lease with a clause as to automatic perpetual renewal.
('4', 294, 4, 14, 695333) Lucas became insolvent before the war and, some time after, died.
('4', 294, 4, 15, 695399) The original Trustee never brought up the property in question, in the schedule.
('4', 294, 4, 16, 695480) In the year 1902, among other properties, this too was expropriated under the Expropriation Ordinance by the Johannesburg Municipality, and compensation was fixed at 2,000. The award was naturally given in the name of the registered owner, namely, Lucas; but as the case was prosecuted by the plaintiffs, and as they claimed the moneythe proceeds of the property which they contended Lucas held in secret trust for themthe money was deposited in the hands of the Master
('4', 295, 0, 1, 695950) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 295, 1, 2, 695992) of the Supreme Court, and the parties were left to have an adjudication as to their rights.
('4', 295, 1, 3, 696084) The plaintiffs, therefore, sued the defendant for a declaration of rights, and demanded that an order should be issued to the Master for payment of the money to them.
('4', 295, 1, 4, 696251) The defence raised was, first, that the plaintiffs, being British Indians, could not, in virtue of Law 3 of 1885, hold landed property, and that, therefore, the agreement on the part of Lucas to hold it for them was illegal and void, and, therefore, not capable of being enforced at law.
('4', 295, 1, 5, 696539) The second ground of defence was that, even if it was competent for Lucas to enter into the agreement with the plaintiffs, the latter had only a personal right against him, and could thus only prove their claim as concurrent creditors, but could not make good their claim to the money on the strength of a universal right, in other words, as preferent creditors.
('4', 295, 1, 6, 696902) Sir William Smith, though not without some hesitation, decided the point in favour of the plaintiffs, and gave judgement with costs.
('4', 295, 1, 7, 697035) From this the defendant appealed, and the Supreme Court has adjudged on the appeal in favour of the defendant, holding, with him on the second defence raised.
('4', 295, 1, 8, 697194) The net result, however, of this important judgement seems to be that the holding by Europeans of land for Indians is not illegal, but that, in the event of the insolvency of such Europeans, the Indians concerned must take the risk, unless their names are registered on the title deeds, as cestuis que trustent.
('4', 295, 1, 9, 697506) This case, therefore, takes the Indians a step further in their fight, and renders Law 3 of 1885 still more ineffective as a weapon to be used against them.
('4', 295, 1, 10, 697663) It would be most interesting to test whether, as a matter of fact, if an Indian insisted on his name being registered as a cestui que trust, his name could be so registered.
('4', 295, 1, 11, 697837) In the event of the successful prosecution of such a test case, Indians would practically be able to hold land in any part of the Transvaal without the slightest risk; and looking at it from a common sense standpoint, we are inclined to think that if follows as a corollary from the judgment of the Supreme Court.
('4', 295, 1, 12, 698151) It would certainly be equitable, seeing that it has now been decided that Natives are free to hold landed property in any part of the Transvaal, and to have it registered in their own names.
('4', 295, 2, 13, 698342) Indian Opinion, 27 5 1905
('4', 296, 0, 1, 698368) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 297
('4', 296, 1, 2, 698411) 245. MAHOMEDAN V. HINDU
('4', 296, 2, 3, 698435) It is with very great regret that we notice some correspondence in an East London journal between a Mahomedan and a Hindu.
('4', 296, 2, 4, 698558) We should have thought that the palpable need for the utmost harmony between all sections of the Indian community in South Africa would have prevented amenities 1 of this nature.
('4', 296, 2, 5, 698737) We do not desire to go into the merits of the letters, but merely to express out disapprobation of this kind of thing.
('4', 296, 2, 6, 698856) We trust the writers will have the good sense to join in our regret and leave the correspondence where it stands.
('4', 296, 2, 7, 698970) There are other and weightier matters that can more usefully employ their attention.
('4', 296, 2, 8, 699055) We may perhaps be allowed to remind our readers that Indian Opinion is a journal specially devoted to the discussion of all Indian affairs in South Africa; and that, if unfortunately differences arise between Indians, our columns are the natural and most fitting medium for their ventilation.

('4', 296, 3, 10, 699374) 246. SIR MANCHERJI AND MR. LYTTELTON
('4', 296, 4, 11, 699411) Sir Mancherji asked Mr. Lyttelton why Indians were excluded from the right to vote in the Transvaal Constitution.
('4', 296, 4, 12, 699525) He asked further whether or not the Constitution would be amended in order to enfranchise them.
('4', 296, 4, 13, 699621) Mr. Lyttelton replied that the Boers interpreted the terms of the Peace Treaty, signed on the cessation of hostilities, to mean that no Coloured person would get the right to vote until the Transvaal attained full self government.
('4', 296, 4, 14, 699852) In deference to this interpre tation, Mr. Lyttelton had excluded the Indians so as not to give any ground to the Boers to doubt the honesty of the British Government.
('4', 296, 4, 15, 700019) The word used in the terms of the Treaty is Native and not Colo ured people.
('4', 296, 4, 16, 700096) Now the word Native can in no way be interpreted to mean Indians.
('4', 296, 4, 17, 700162) That word is invariably used in South Africa for the natives of this country.
('4', 296, 4, 18, 700240) The practice of including Indians and other Coloured people in the term Native is of recent origin, and that too only when it is specifically so laid down in a law.
('4', 296, 4, 19, 700405) It is surprising that Mr. Lytteltton should have given the above expl anation when the word is not normally so interpreted even today.
('4', 296, 4, 20, 700540) If Indians are thus included in the term Native, great harm is likely to done to them.
('4', 296, 5, 21, 700627) 1 Perhaps this word is used satirically in the sense of pleasant manners or is a misprint for enmities.
('4', 297, 0, 1, 700731) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 297, 1, 2, 700773) There is not the slightest likelihood of the Dutch or the British granting the franchise to Indians on the attainment of self govern ment.
('4', 297, 1, 3, 700912) Sir George Farrar, a noted gentleman of the Transvaal, has already declared that the Natives would never be granted the right to vote.
('4', 297, 1, 4, 701047) His views regarding Indians are very unfavourable.
('4', 297, 1, 5, 701098) He would not even dream of granting rights to an Indian, in preference to a Native.
('4', 297, 1, 6, 701182) The meaning of the above interpellation is that we should put up a tough fight whenever an attempt is made to include Indians in the term Native.

('4', 297, 2, 8, 701370) 247. SMALLPOX IN JOHANNESBURG 1
('4', 297, 3, 9, 701402) Smallpox has made its appearance in Johannesburg.
('4', 297, 3, 10, 701452) It is said to have entered through passenger steamers.
('4', 297, 3, 11, 701507) It started with the Malay Location.
('4', 297, 3, 12, 701543) The first case was a Malay one, followed by another of a white.
('4', 297, 3, 13, 701607) According to Dr. Porter, five Indians have also been affected.
('4', 297, 3, 14, 701670) Great strictness is being observed in the Malay Location; peoples houses are being inspected morning and evening.
('4', 297, 4, 15, 701784) Much inconvenience is likely to be caused if smallpox spreads further.
('4', 297, 4, 16, 701855) Compulsory inoculation has been introduced in the Malay Location.
('4', 297, 4, 17, 701921) But that is not all.
('4', 297, 4, 18, 701942) Regulations have been framed by the Town Council, and when they come into force, much difficulty is likely to be felt.
('4', 297, 5, 19, 702061) The remedy lies in the peoples own hands.
('4', 297, 5, 20, 702103) To keep the tenements clean, to bathe daily, to keep water, milk, etc., clean, to put on clean clothes, and to let plenty of air and light into the house; these are the preventive measures for smallpox or any other illness.
('4', 297, 5, 21, 702327) If anyone in the house catches the disease, the fact should immediately be intimated to the authorities.
('4', 297, 5, 22, 702432) The more the people conceal such diseases out of fear, the greater will be their hardships, the more widely will the disease spread, and the greater will be the repression by the authorities.
('4', 297, 5, 23, 702624) The patient is bound eventually to be removed to hospital.
('4', 297, 5, 24, 702683) If, therefore, we inform the authorities of our own accord,
('4', 297, 6, 25, 702743) 1 This appeared as From Our Correspondent.
('4', 298, 0, 1, 702786) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 299
('4', 298, 1, 2, 702829) there is likely to be less hardship.
('4', 298, 1, 3, 702866) No harm will come to the patient if he is removed to hospital; on the contrary, he may recover the sooner for it.

('4', 300, 4, 6, 705597) 251. LETTER TO H. J. HOFMEYR
('4', 300, 5, 7, 705626) Delivered Personal
('4', 300, 6, 8, 705645) [JOHANNESBURG,] June 2, 1905 TO H. J. HOFMEYR, ESQ.
('4', 300, 6, 9, 705697) ZIMANS BLDGS.
('4', 300, 6, 10, 705711) JOHANNESBURG
('4', 300, 7, 11, 705724) DEAR MR. HOFMEYR,
('4', 300, 8, 12, 705742) I must confess that your letter enclosing cheque staggers me because I venture to think that there is a principle at stake.
('4', 300, 8, 13, 705866) The cheque was given to me ear marked.
('4', 300, 8, 14, 705905) You know the money belonged to me.
('4', 300, 8, 15, 705940) It did not come out of anything I had for Said Ismail, and seeing that the property to buy which it was given was not purchased, I think I was entitled to a return of the full cheque.
('4', 300, 8, 16, 706124) I know that I wont come to grief with reference to the charges deducted by you, but, to my mind, it is hardly conducive to the growth of confidential relations which ought to exist between professional men.
('4', 300, 8, 17, 706331) I hope you do not mind my writing to you so frankly, but I thought that I ought to pass on the thoughts that occurred to me when I saw your cheque, letter and the bill.
('4', 300, 8, 18, 706500) Of course, I accept your cheque, so that anything I have said herein does not disturb the deduction made by you.
('4', 300, 8, 19, 706613) I am, Yours truly M. K. GANDHI

('4', 301, 0, 1, 706668) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 301, 1, 2, 706710) 252. BARODA: A MODEL INDIAN STATE
('4', 301, 2, 3, 706744) In a recent number of India, Sir William Wedderburn, one of Indias truest friends, has contributed an appreciative article on the affairs of Baroda, a State in the Presidency of Bombay with a popu lation of two millions, and with territories covering an area of eight thousand square miles; in other words, a State a little bigger than Wales.
('4', 301, 2, 4, 707087) Sir William has based his appreciation on the report of admin istration issued by Mr. R. C. Dutt, 1 at one time Acting Commissioner of Orissa, now Finance Minister of Baroda, and who is known to the literary world as a brilliant author.
('4', 301, 2, 5, 707324) The Maharaja Gaekwar himself, one of the most cultured Princes of India, has surrounded himself with able councillors, of whom Mr. Dutt is the brightest star.
('4', 301, 2, 6, 707483) Mr. Dutt has written works expounding his view as to the amelioration of the poverty of the masses in India.
('4', 301, 2, 7, 707592) His chief remedy is to make the revenue system as elastic as possible, and as soon as he accepted office in Baroda, he was allowed to put his views into force.
('4', 301, 2, 8, 707752) Instead, now, of the cultivator having to pay a fixed tax in coin, he has, under well defined rules, the opportunity of either paying in coin or in kind.
('4', 301, 2, 9, 707906) This takes us back to the pre British period, when the ryot throughout India paid a certain portion of his produce to the paramount lord.
('4', 301, 2, 10, 708044) This was suited to the genius of the people and most convenient to either party.
('4', 301, 2, 11, 708125) The paramount lord then shared the prosperity of the ryot and suffered with him in adversity.
('4', 301, 2, 12, 708219) The Maharajas councillor has also done away with petty, vexatious cesses.
('4', 301, 2, 13, 708293) Nor does Mr. Dutts activity stop at revenue reform.
('4', 301, 2, 14, 708345) He holds decided views on education.
('4', 301, 2, 15, 708382) An advanced district of the State has been selected for an experiment in compulsory education.
('4', 301, 2, 16, 708477) According to Mr. Dutts report, the follo wing is the position of education in Baroda as compared with British India:
('4', 301, 3, 17, 708594) In no department of administration is the far sighted liberality of H. H. the Maharaja Gaekwar more conspicuous than in education, and in none are the results more real and tangible.
('4', 301, 3, 18, 708777) The percentage of the State revenue spent on education is 6.5 in Baroda, as against 1.17 in Bengal, 1.44 in Bombay, 1.33 in Madras, and about 1 per cent in all British India.
('4', 301, 3, 19, 708952) And the percentage of children under instruction to the total population is 8.6 in Baroda, as against 4.0 in Bengal, 6.2 in Bombay, 3.09 in Madras, and less than 3 per cent, in all British India.
('4', 301, 3, 20, 709148) Seven annas is spent on education per head of population in Baroda, as against about one anna in British India.
('4', 301, 4, 21, 709260) 1 Romesh Chunder Dutt, prominent Indian Civilian, presided over the Congress Session at Lucknow in 1890.
('4', 302, 0, 1, 709365) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 303
('4', 302, 1, 2, 709408) Mr. Dutt, again, is very deeply interested in the problem of self government, and reviving or keeping up the great village communities of India, which have been so graphically described by the late Sir Henry Maine as self contained republics.
('4', 302, 1, 3, 709651) Mr. Dutt has, therefore, endowed the villages with control of their own management and has given certain powers to the headman, revived the village school master, and upon the old system he has engrafted real elective repre sentation.
('4', 302, 1, 4, 709886) The village Panchayat, instead of being hereditary, will now be elected by the people.
('4', 302, 1, 5, 709973) It is a bold experiment, and, if it succeeds, it will form a landmark in the government of Indian States, and as Sir William Wedderburn says, it may well be that the British Indian Gov ernment may have to copy Baroda; nor, adds Sir William, need there be any hesitation or shame about it, as it should be a matter of pride to the British Government, which has, after all, given to India the present Maharaja of Baroda, and an administrator of Mr. Dutts remarkable capabilities.
('4', 302, 1, 6, 710451) To our South African readers, a State like Baroda ought to serve as a help to dispel prejudices and illusions about India, for a country which has so much that is good, so much that is progressive, cannot after all be termed a country inhabited by savages or a semi civilised, barbarous race.
('4', 302, 2, 7, 710744) Indian Opinion, 3 6 1905
('4', 302, 3, 8, 710769) 253. AN INDIAN PHILANTHROPIST
('4', 302, 4, 9, 710799) We have been receiving for some time past copies of a journal called The Indian Sociologist, and organ of freedom, and of political, social and religious reform.
('4', 302, 4, 10, 710961) It is edited by Pandit Shyamaji Krishnavarma, M.A. (Oxon.), sometime lecturer at Oxford, and is published in London.
('4', 302, 4, 11, 711078) It is a journal fearlessly edited, and the editor is imbued with the teaching of the late Herbert Spencer.
('4', 302, 4, 12, 711185) The journal is evidently inte nded to model Indian opinion in accordance with Spen cers teachings.
('4', 302, 4, 13, 711284) The Pandit is an Indian scholar of distinction, and has a fair amount of capital at his command.
('4', 302, 4, 14, 711381) He has established several scholar ships for Indian students in order to enable them to carry on their post graduate studies in Europe and America.
('4', 302, 4, 15, 711529) Each scholarship is worth 2,000 rupees and is given to selected graduates from all parts of India, the chief conditions being that the candidates must remain and study for at least two years in Europe or America, and must not, on any account, accept government service.
('4', 302, 4, 16, 711799) The candidates are also expected to enter into an agreement to refund the money thus
('4', 303, 0, 1, 711884) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 303, 1, 2, 711926) advanced in easy instalments after the completion of study.
('4', 303, 1, 3, 711986) As a result of the first competition, the following five candidates have already been selected: Abdullah Al Mahmun Suhrawdy, M.A., Sarat Chandra Mukerji, M.A., Parmeshwar Lall, M.A., Syud Abdul Majid, B.A., and Shaikh Abdul Aziz, B.A. The experiment is a very bold one.
('4', 303, 1, 4, 712256) The donors intentions are patriotic.
('4', 303, 1, 5, 712293) Its success, however, will very largely depend upon the manner in which the first scholars use their oppor tunity.
('4', 303, 1, 6, 712408) Their scholastic qualifications certainly betoken a happy aug ury.
('4', 303, 1, 7, 712475) We wish every success to Pandit Shyamaji Krishnavarma in his enterprise.
('4', 303, 1, 8, 712548) His example may well be copied by the Indian merchants in South Africa and elsewhere.

('4', 304, 3, 12, 714929) Writing to the London Times, he makes the following suggestions: (1) Three capable Indians, to be nominated by the Viceroy, should be given seats on the India Council in England; (2) at least one Indian should be appointed to the Viceroys Executive Council; (3) one member each from [the Presidencies] of Calcutta, Bombay and Madras should be sent to the British Parliament.

('4', 304, 3, 15, 715501) He further adds that the greatest malady India suffers from is poverty.
('4', 304, 3, 16, 715573) In order, therefore, to make the people happy and contented, the land revenue should be settled permanently and should not be excessive.
('4', 304, 3, 17, 715710) If the Government would consider these suggestions of Mr. Smith, it will surely yield good results.

('4', 305, 2, 8, 716863) 258. PLAGUE IN INDIA
('4', 305, 3, 9, 716884) There occurred in India 65,780 cases of plague during the last week of April, of which 57,702 proved fatal.
('4', 305, 3, 10, 716992) There were 23,387 deaths in the United Provinces, 1 19,015 in the Punjab, 3,056 in the Bombay Presidency and 9,703 in Bengal.
('4', 305, 3, 11, 717118) The Liberty Review has passed severe strictures on the British Government whom it holds responsible for the epidemic, and for this large number of deaths, for, it adds, there is extreme starvation in the land.
('4', 305, 3, 12, 717328) It has been estimated that only three out of the thirty crores of the people get even one meal a day.
('4', 305, 3, 13, 717430) This much is certain, that if a man obliged to starve, his body gradually gets weaker and at last becomes so reduced in resistance that it becomes more easily susceptible to infection or an attack of germs.
('4', 305, 3, 14, 717637) Nevertheless, we must say that the criticism of the Liberty Review is to a certain extent unjustified.
('4', 305, 3, 15, 717740) We can say from experience that the pla gue does not attack only the starving.
('4', 305, 3, 16, 717819) We see that even those with a high standard of living are victimised by it.
('4', 305, 3, 17, 717895) Moreover, we can add the following from experience:
('4', 305, 4, 18, 717947) 1. Very often all the persons in a house affected by plague get the attack.
('4', 305, 5, 19, 718023) 2. When once plague has spread in a village, it is never totally eradicated.
('4', 305, 5, 20, 718100) 3. Persons observing the rules of hygiene are less susceptible to the plague.
('4', 305, 6, 21, 718178) 1 Now Uttar Pradesh.
('4', 306, 0, 1, 718199) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 307
('4', 306, 1, 2, 718242) 4. Those who leave an infected village are saved.
('4', 306, 1, 3, 718292) 5. The whites are not as susceptible to the plague as Indians.
('4', 306, 1, 4, 718355) 6. The whites live more cleanly and observe the rules of health.
('4', 306, 1, 5, 718420) 7. Wherever plague breaks out outside India, it is immediately eradicated.
('4', 306, 1, 6, 718495) We can see from this that plague has not much to do with starvation.
('4', 306, 2, 7, 718564) Doubtless the main thing to do in the case of plague is to observe cleanliness.
('4', 306, 2, 8, 718644) Cleanliness does not mean merely bathing and washing.
('4', 306, 2, 9, 718698) It is well to maintain personal cleanliness.
('4', 306, 2, 10, 718743) But in addition to it, the house also should be kept clean; sufficient light and sunshine should be let into it; latrines should be kept clean; and in a house which is affected, things should be so arranged that the things used for the patient are not used by others.
('4', 306, 2, 11, 719011) How to deal with plague is a wide subject, and we cannot say much about it here.
('4', 306, 2, 12, 719092) However, our readers should remember that there is no other disease so deadly as the plague.
('4', 306, 2, 13, 719185) Cholera has always been considered a deadly disease, but it is nothing as compared to plague.
('4', 306, 2, 14, 719279) Moreover, plague is increasing daily in India and not on the decline.
('4', 306, 2, 15, 719349) For, whereas there were 2,72,000 deaths in 1901, there were 5,00,000 in 1902 and 8,00,000 in 1903; and this year the attack has been so virulent that the number might easily shoot up to a million.
('4', 306, 2, 16, 719546) The average number of deaths per month this year comes to about 1,20,000 1. If mortality continues at this rate and goes on increasing from year to year, it will be little wonder if the whole of India becomes depopulated within 15 years.
('4', 306, 2, 17, 719784) Several villages have already been laid waste.
('4', 306, 2, 18, 719831) At many places in the Punjab, public works have come to a stop.
('4', 306, 2, 19, 719895) Men who have survived the plague have deserted the villages.
('4', 306, 2, 20, 719956) This should set every Indian thinking.
('4', 306, 2, 21, 719995) Every Indian should search his heart and realise what his duty is.
('4', 306, 3, 22, 720062) [From Gujarati]
('4', 306, 4, 23, 720078) Indian Opinion, 3 6 1905
('4', 306, 5, 24, 720103) 1 The figure 12,000 in the original is evidently a slip.
