('4', 309, 4, 15, 723989) 263. LORD SELBORNE AND THE INDIANS
('4', 309, 5, 16, 724024) In another column we print an interesting report of a pres entation by the British Indians in the Transvaal to Lord Selborne.
('4', 309, 5, 17, 724150) The text of the address, 1 suitably to the occasion, is colourless, but it shows that, in spite of the irritating circumstances that surround British Indians, they do not forget their inherent courtesy, and they showed this by their welcome to His Majestys representative in South Africa.
('4', 309, 5, 18, 724439) It is a pity that the address was not presented, as it should have been, publicly, but evidently there was no mistake made by the Indians.
('4', 309, 6, 19, 724578) 1 Vide Address to Lord Selborne, May 28, 1905.
('4', 310, 0, 1, 724625) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 311
('4', 310, 1, 2, 724668) They seem to have made preparations long ago, and to have faithfully carried out the requirements of the private secretary to His Excel lency.
('4', 310, 1, 3, 724811) Although the receptions given to Lord Selborne were non political, we notice that the Mayors both at Pretoria and Johannesburg could not refrain from alluding to the Indian question.
('4', 310, 1, 4, 724994) Opinion would be divided as to the appropriateness of bringing the question thus early to the notice of Lord Selborne.
('4', 310, 1, 5, 725113) The Mayor of Johannesburg, Mr. George Goch, who is otherwise a most liberal minded gentleman, and who has often taken up the cause of the Coloured races in South Africa, allowed himself, in reply to the toast on his health, to remark that the last despatch from Sir Arthur Lawley on the British Indian question, addressed to Mr. Lyttelton, showed the true position, and that the community owed him much
('4', 310, 2, 6, 725516) for lifting up that question on a plane which was far above that which any of them could conceive, and has given a basis in that despatch for the settlement of a most intricate and most difficult question in the new legislature, which by and by they would have under his guidance.
('4', 310, 2, 7, 725797) Now we have shown, conclusively we think, how that despatch is full of inaccuracies and sentiments hardly creditable to a British statesman.
('4', 310, 2, 8, 725938) We have a very high regard for Sir Arthur Lawley.
('4', 310, 2, 9, 725988) We believe him to be actuated by excellent motives; but we regret to have to say that he has been entirely misled on this question, and has been over mastered by the prevailing prejudice to which he has succumbed.
('4', 310, 2, 10, 726202) He has not hesitated to advise the Colonial Secretary to break the oft repeated promises of the British Government, and has no doubt unc onsciously misquoted facts in support of such dangerous advice.
('4', 310, 2, 11, 726403) The strength of the British Government lies very largely in its rectitude and in its scrupulous observance of promises.
('4', 310, 2, 12, 726523) It is true that, on many an occasion, there has been a departure from it, and on each such occ asion, British prestige has suffered.
('4', 310, 2, 13, 726656) No statesman recalls such depar tures with pride, but either glosses them over, or offers to explain them away, thus indirectly showing the British statesmen do not intend to fall away from the high standard.
('4', 310, 2, 14, 726865) It is, therefore, a disquieting sign to find a gentleman of Mr. George Gochs standing ranging himself on the side of those who favour a policy which is calculated to revolutio nise British methods.
('4', 310, 2, 15, 727063) It nevertheless shows the temper of the Transvaal community on the British Indian question, and practical politicians have to take note of that feeling.

('4', 311, 1, 2, 727284) 264. THE CHINESE AND THE KAFFIRSA COMPARISON
('4', 311, 2, 3, 727329) A good deal of discussion is still going on in England regar ding the employment of the Chinese in the Johannesburg mines.
('4', 311, 2, 4, 727452) To pacify the minds of the people in the matter, Lord Milner had, before leaving South Africa, sent some communication to England, which has now been published.
('4', 311, 2, 5, 727613) Lord Milner states therein that the per capita expenditure of recruiting and bringing the Kaffirs to Johannesburg has been 10 15 0 during the last three years, while the cost of getting the Chinese is 16 11 3 per head.
('4', 311, 2, 6, 727832) From this, Lord Milner wants to suggest that the miners do not stand to gain in recruiting the Chinese.
('4', 311, 2, 7, 727936) Moreover, the cost of maintaining the Chinese in Johannesburg is greater than that of maintaining the Kaffirs.
('4', 311, 2, 8, 728047) For, while a Kaffir costs 5 3 4 d.
('4', 311, 2, 9, 728082) per day, a Chinese costs 11d.
('4', 311, 2, 10, 728112) Lord Milner, therefore, concludes that, if the Kaffirs can be had in sufficient numbers, the miners would leave the Chinese alone.
('4', 311, 2, 11, 728243) But 30,980 Chinese have already entered the Transvaal.
('4', 311, 3, 12, 728298) In all this computation, Lord Milner has overlooked one fact, viz., that, while the Kaffir hardly works for six months, the Chinese have to do so continuously for three years.
('4', 311, 3, 13, 728474) Moreover, the Chinese being more active than the Kaffirs, much more work can be taken from them than from the latter.
('4', 311, 3, 14, 728592) This is a very important point, but His Lordship utters not a word about it.
('4', 311, 3, 15, 728669) Unless this is taken into account, Lord Milners figures are of no use whatever.
('4', 311, 3, 16, 728749) Were it not so, those who pay a higher salary to the more efficient make, according to Lord Milner, a mistake.
('4', 311, 3, 17, 728860) We, therefore, feel that Lord Milners communi cation is not likely to have much effect in England.

('4', 311, 6, 20, 729001) 265. JAPAN AND RUSSIA
('4', 311, 7, 21, 729023) Japans star seems to be in the ascendant.
('4', 311, 7, 22, 729065) She stormed the Fort of Port Arthur, captured Mukden and has done other deeds of valour.
('4', 311, 7, 23, 729154) But all these pale into insignificance before her latest exploit.
('4', 311, 7, 24, 729220) Not only did she defeat the great Russian fleet, but wounded its great Admiral and did not leave intact a single Russian man of war.
('4', 311, 7, 25, 729353) No one ever imagined that Japan was capable of such bravery.
('4', 311, 7, 26, 729414) Many had thought that Japan would find herself in a difficult situation once the
('4', 312, 0, 1, 729495) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 313
('4', 312, 1, 2, 729538) Russian fleet reached Singapore.
('4', 312, 1, 3, 729571) It was also known that the Japanese Navy was not very strong, that is to say, it had fewer battleships than Russia.
('4', 312, 1, 4, 729687) But in scouting and watchfulness, Japan surpassed all the others.
('4', 312, 1, 5, 729753) Admiral Togos spies were very accurate in their intelligence, and he pounced upon the Russian fleet just when it was most vulnerable.
('4', 312, 1, 6, 729887) This was no ordinary deed of daring.
('4', 312, 1, 7, 729924) Such courage is incomparable; but we consider supreme the patience and the cool composure shown by Admiral Togo in achieving his objective.
('4', 312, 1, 8, 730064) Nothing was done with a view to winning honours or showing off their bravery to the world.
('4', 312, 1, 9, 730155) Togo had only one objective, viz., to strike at Russia at the opportune moment and at the strategic place.
('4', 312, 1, 10, 730262) That he has done; and Russia, which only two years ago was considered to be almost invincible, has now very nearly fallen into the hands of Japan.
('4', 312, 1, 11, 730409) It is said that history has nothing which can bear comparison with this naval battle.
('4', 312, 1, 12, 730495) England won a great [naval] victory in the sixteenth century.
('4', 312, 1, 13, 730557) The invincible Spanish Armada was then destroyed in the English Channel, and the British Admiral was triumphant.
('4', 312, 1, 14, 730670) That too has been considered a very fierce battle; but the Heavens then came to the succour of England.
('4', 312, 1, 15, 730774) The Spanish Armada was very large, and the Channel narrow.
('4', 312, 1, 16, 730833) And just as the battle was raging, a strong wind began to blow, which the Armada could not withstand, while it proved favourable to the English fleet.
('4', 312, 2, 17, 730984) In the nineteenth century, Nelson scored a great victory off the Cape 1 of Trafalgar and the British Navy won for itself a pre eminent position; but the powerful steamers we see today did not then exist nor the dangerous weapons of the present age.
('4', 312, 3, 18, 731233) Japan did not receive any unexpected help.
('4', 312, 3, 19, 731276) She had only the firm determination to win, and this determination has proved her true ally.
('4', 312, 3, 20, 731369) In this war Japan has not known defeat.
('4', 312, 4, 21, 731409) What, then, is the secret off this epic heroism?
('4', 312, 4, 22, 731458) We have repeatedly to ask ourselves this question and find an answer for it.
('4', 312, 4, 23, 731535) The answer is: unity, patriotism and the resolve to do or die.
('4', 312, 4, 24, 731598) All the Japa nese are animated by the same spirit.
('4', 312, 4, 25, 731649) No one is considered greater than the other, and there is no rift of any kind between them.
('4', 312, 4, 26, 731741) They think of nothing else but service to the nation.
('4', 312, 4, 27, 731795) They have so identified themselves with their motherland that they consider themselves prosperous [only] if they bring prosperity to the country in which they are born, bred, and destined to pass their lives; that, if the country
('4', 312, 5, 28, 732025) 1 The original has in the Strait of Trafalgar.
('4', 313, 0, 1, 732072) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 313, 1, 2, 732114) rose, they rose; if she enjoyed political power, they were partners in that power.
('4', 313, 1, 3, 732197) Such is their patriotism.
('4', 313, 1, 4, 732223) This unity and patriotic spirit together with a heroic indifference to life [or death] have created an atmosphere in Japan the like of which is nowhere else to be found in the world.
('4', 313, 1, 5, 732406) Of death, they do not entertain any fear.
('4', 313, 1, 6, 732448) To die in the service of their country, they have always regarded as wholly good.
('4', 313, 1, 7, 732530) If, after all, one has to die some day, what does it matter if one dies on the battle field?
('4', 313, 1, 8, 732623) There is no certainty that, if one stays home and does not go to the front, one will live longer.
('4', 313, 1, 9, 732721) And even if one did live very long, what was the good of living as a subjugated people?
('4', 313, 1, 10, 732809) Reasoning along these lines, the Japanese have become defiant of death.
('4', 313, 1, 11, 732881) What wonder, then, that those, who thus sacrifice their flesh, blood and bones, should prove invincible on the battle field?

('4', 313, 1, 19, 733526) This is the condition most of us are in.

('4', 314, 2, 7, 734915) 267. MEASURES TO ERADICATE PLAGUE IN INDIA
('4', 314, 3, 8, 734958) Dr. Turner of Bombay has addressed a long letter to the Gover nment of that Presidency, stating that plague was on the increase from year to year and that the only way to eradicate it was for the people to have themselves inoculated.
('4', 314, 3, 9, 735192) The Doctor believes that those who are inoculated rarely suffer an attack of the plague.
('4', 314, 3, 10, 735281) But the great problem is how to persuade people to get themselves inoculated.
('4', 314, 3, 11, 735359) Dr. Turner says that it is not possible to compel people to do so.
('4', 314, 3, 12, 735426) It would be indeed very good, if the employers compelled their workers, but that takes time, so that will not do either.
('4', 314, 3, 13, 735547) Finally Dr. Turner suggests that the Government should insure the life of the inoculated person, and endorse a document to the effect that, if the person dies within a year of the inoculation, they would pay his relatives Rs. 100. The Doctor hopes that this will induce many persons to undergo inoculation.
('4', 314, 3, 14, 735854) Another doctor suggests instituting a lottery for those who get them selves inoculated.
('4', 314, 3, 15, 735942) Chits bearing the names of the inoculated should be prepared, lots drawn, and prizes awarded to winners.
('4', 314, 3, 16, 736047) Thus are these good men struggling in vain to eradicate the plague.
('4', 314, 4, 17, 736115) It is possible that some men may be able to save themselves through inoculation.
('4', 314, 4, 18, 736196) But we see no advantage in this.
('4', 314, 4, 19, 736229) This remedy of inoculation is just like the means adopted by men, given to the pursuit of pleasure, to escape the consequences of their indulgence.
('4', 314, 4, 20, 736377) Inocula tion does not extirpate the causes of the plague and unless these are removed, no real benefit can accrue.
('4', 314, 4, 21, 736492) If, by chance, one does get rid of plague, another disease will appear in its place.
('4', 314, 4, 22, 736577) Just as a tree is not destroyed unless its roots are pulled out, so also the plague will not disappear unless its causes are removed.

('4', 319, 1, 2, 743083) 274. LETTER TO THE STAR 1
('4', 319, 2, 3, 743109) [Prior to June 24, 1905]
('4', 319, 3, 4, 743134) [TO THE EDITOR The Star JOHANNESBURG]
('4', 319, 4, 5, 743172) SIR, I see that Mr. Loveday has again repeated his statement about the influx of Indians into the Colony, in total disregard of the evidence that he admits having seen after he first gave currency to those statements.
('4', 319, 4, 6, 743390) Mr. Loveday thinks that the Permit Department does not keep out British Indians, and that non refugees have been entering the Colony.
('4', 319, 4, 7, 743524) In the face of the report of the Chief Secretary for Per mits, one can only come to the conclusion that Mr. Loveday declines to believe the report.
('4', 319, 4, 8, 743672) I can only say that even the British Indian refu gees find it extremely hard to enter the Colony.
('4', 319, 4, 9, 743770) I have before me a letter, addressed from the Permit Office to a British Indian, who applied some seven months ago for a permit asking him whether he still requires a permit.
('4', 319, 4, 10, 743945) The poor refugee being friendless, after having waited months for making good his right as a refugee to enter the Transvaal, has gone back to India, and the letter has been sent to me by the gentleman whose address he gave.
('4', 319, 4, 11, 744169) Nor is this a solitary ins tance.
('4', 319, 4, 12, 744203) Whereas Europeans, whether they are refugees or not, obtain their permits for the asking, the Indian refugees, many of whom have paid the sum of  3 as the price of being allowed to remain in the country during the old regime, have to wait at least two months before they are admitted, and then, too, each applicant has to go through a number of formalities and a good deal of expense before he can enter the Colony.
('4', 319, 4, 13, 744619) He must call at the Permit Offices in the coast towns for an application form.
('4', 319, 4, 14, 744698) He has to get it filled in, for which, as a rule, he pays a fee.
('4', 319, 4, 15, 744763) On receipt by the Permit Office in Johannesburg, letters are sent down to those whose names have been given as references.
('4', 319, 4, 16, 744886) These letters have to make affidavits on which a half crown stamp has to be affixed.
('4', 319, 4, 17, 744971) If the evidence produced as to previous residence is considered satisfactory, a notification is sent to the applicant authori sing him to enter the Colony.
('4', 319, 4, 18, 745127) Nor is this all.
('4', 319, 4, 19, 745144) He must then proceed to
('4', 319, 5, 20, 745168) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion under the caption Refutation of Mr. Lovedays Inaccuracies.
('4', 320, 0, 1, 745267) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 321
('4', 320, 1, 2, 745310) Johannesburg, call at the Permit Office and submit himself for cross examination, and if he satisfies the examining officer, he receives a permanent authority to stay in the Colony.
('4', 320, 1, 3, 745492) I know cases in which many have been sent back because they were not able to satisfy the examining officer that they were refugees.
('4', 320, 1, 4, 745624) If, therefore, any one could possibly complain against the Permit Department, it would be the British Indians; and they do not belong to the criminal class mentioned by Mr. Hosken.
('4', 320, 1, 5, 745805) Mr. Loveday has once again brought up the statistics published by the Mayor of Pietersburg, and yet the Mayor of Pieters burg has not taken up the challenge of the British Indian Association, although it was he who provoked it.
('4', 320, 1, 6, 746033) I venture to quote from the letter addressed to you by the Chairman of the British Indian Association on the 9th December.
('4', 320, 2, 7, 746156) I deny that there are at present 49 Indian traders in Pietersburg.
('4', 320, 2, 8, 746223) There are only 28 stores owned by Indians within the township, as distinguished from the Location, and of these some are held by the same Indians.
('4', 320, 2, 9, 746370) Within the township before war, there were at least 23 Indian stores.
('4', 320, 3, 10, 746440) The names of all these store keepers have been given in the same letter.
('4', 320, 3, 11, 746513) This statement has never been disproved, but Mr. Loveday says the Asiatic Traders Commission report that there was only one Indian trader in Pietersburg without a licence before war.
('4', 320, 3, 12, 746696) This is misleading.
('4', 320, 3, 13, 746716) I have before me the full report of the Asiatic Traders Commission.
('4', 320, 3, 14, 746784) In the first place, it is an interim report.
('4', 320, 3, 15, 746829) In the second place, the Com missioners do not pretend to have ascertained the number of Indians who were trading without licences.
('4', 320, 3, 16, 746961) All that the Commissioners have done is to mention the respective claims placed before them, and they state that there was only one British Indian claim for Pietersburg.
('4', 320, 3, 17, 747131) They had in all only 233 claims presented to them.
('4', 320, 3, 18, 747182) That surely does not exhaust the list of Asiatic traders before war.

('4', 322, 2, 13, 752210) 276 CORRUPTION DURING WAR TIME It is true that patriotic fervour surges in everyones breast du ring times of war.
('4', 322, 2, 14, 752324) This fervour is very beneficial.
('4', 322, 2, 15, 752357) Many a patriot has, under the stimulus of zeal, performed, with only a small army, feats that have astounded the world.
('4', 322, 2, 16, 752477) While, on the one hand, some people abound with such enthusiasm, hundreds, thousands, nay, lakhs, of lives have, on the other, been lost, ruined or reduced to a state of depen dence, through the doings of some selfish people who took adv antage of the inability of officials to exercise sufficient control during war.
('4', 322, 2, 17, 752795) Taking advantage of the chaos, normal persons have added to the prevailing disorder by committing, during war, misdeeds which they will not think of at other times.
('4', 322, 2, 18, 752960) It seems that the rules of honesty and good conduct are entirely forgotten during times of war.
('4', 322, 2, 19, 753056) The viola 
('4', 323, 0, 1, 753067) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 323, 1, 2, 753109) tion of these rules is more in evidence during a bigger war than a sma ller one.
('4', 323, 1, 3, 753190) For it is said that it is during a crisis that a mans character is put to the test.
('4', 323, 1, 4, 753274) It cannot be claimed that he has been put to the test until he has had the chance successfully of committing a crime but remains steadfast in spite of the opportunity.
('4', 323, 1, 5, 753442) Such steadfastness at a critical time may be found in a handful of men.
('4', 323, 1, 6, 753514) It is indeed all too rare.
('4', 323, 2, 7, 753541) The bigger the war, the bigger the extent of chaos.
('4', 323, 2, 8, 753593) The fraud and trickery, that were exposed during the Crimean War 1, and other sundry happenings that have later come to light, are most distressing.
('4', 323, 2, 9, 753742) During that war, a large stock of boots was purchased and despatched to the front for the use of soldiers, but they all were found to be for the left foot!
('4', 323, 2, 10, 753898) A large quantity of foodstuff for the army was sent from England; but when it was consumed, instead of helping to feed the army, it proved deleterious being very rotten meat.
('4', 323, 2, 11, 754073) It was not only merchants who wanted to become millionaires, but even the generals on the front, the politicians who were out to sacrifice a large number of precious lives, and leaders who called themselves benefactors of the state, committed fraud.
('4', 323, 2, 12, 754323) Large stock of useful medicines sent out for soldiers and officers on their deathbed disappeared mysteriously before reaching the hospitals for which they were bound, and not a trace of them was found.
('4', 323, 2, 13, 754525) Merchants, the so called patriotic generals and high Government officials thus went on misappropriating hun dreds of useful and valuable articles to fill their pockets at the expense of hundreds of poor soldiers who had gone to the front to fight for their country, leaving their homes and hearths.
('4', 323, 2, 14, 754824) When a news corres pondent sent a full account of this, describing the condition of the army encamped at Sebastapol, the whole nation was so enraged that the ministry in power had to resign.
('4', 323, 2, 15, 755015) In addition to this, there was a long list of oppressive tyrannies.
('4', 323, 2, 16, 755083) But all these are insignificant inci dents compared to those of the last Boer War.

('4', 327, 6, 11, 761931) 280. LETTER TO THE STAR
('4', 327, 7, 12, 761955) JOHANNESBURG, June 27, 1905 TO THE EDITOR The Star
('4', 327, 9, 13, 762006) I trush you will allow me to trespass on your courtesy to enable me to reply to certain statements made by your correspondent at Potc hefstroom with reference to a letter I wrote to you on Mr. Lovedays statements at the Inter Colonial Council meeting.
('4', 327, 9, 14, 762258) Your correspondent states that I regretted the continued stream of Indians, particularly those of the lower class.
('4', 327, 9, 15, 762373) I am not aware of having ever expressed any such regret for the simple reason that I have never believed in a continued stream of Indians pouring into Potchefstroom or elsewhere.
('4', 327, 9, 16, 762552) I speak with certain knowledge when I deny any such influx at all.
('4', 327, 9, 17, 762619) That there has been some increase in the number of Indian traders in Potchefstroom, as well as in other places, is not to be denied, but the increase in the number of white traders is out of all proportion to the increase in the number of Indian traders.
('4', 327, 9, 18, 762874) In your leaderette on the Krugersdrop meeting, you say that Pietersburg has undoubtedly been one of the favourite places to which the Asiatic traders have gravitated of late.
('4', 327, 9, 19, 763049) This has been shown to be wrong.
('4', 327, 9, 20, 763082) The fact is that
('4', 328, 0, 1, 763099) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 329
('4', 328, 1, 2, 763142) Pietersburg had a fair proportion of Indian traders before the war but there has been no great influx since.
('4', 328, 1, 3, 763251) In this connection, may I say that the British Indian community in the Transvaal has never received sufficient credit for the spirit of conciliation and compromise it has throughout shown.
('4', 328, 1, 4, 763440) Whilst all kinds of impossible remedies are being suggested, the only two infallible tests proposed by the British Indian Association still remain untried.
('4', 328, 1, 5, 763596) In order to prevent any possibility of the Indians invading the cou ntry, an Immigration Restrictions Act on the Cape model has been suggested.
('4', 328, 1, 6, 763740) The Act has been tried not only there, but in Australia, Natal and elsewhere, and has not been found wanting.
('4', 328, 1, 7, 763850) It is useless to say that there cannot be strict watch on the border.
('4', 328, 1, 8, 763920) Natal has suc ceeded in keeping that watch.
('4', 328, 1, 9, 763964) Many an Indian has found out to his cost that he cannot enter Natal territories through Charlestown or any other inland stations, unless he can prove that he is entitled to enter the Colony under the Immigration Act.
('4', 328, 1, 10, 764181) To prove that the Indians do not in any way mean to usurp the European trade, they accept municipal control over the licences, in such a manner that any Municipality will have the power either to refuse or to grant a licence to trade, subject in extreme cases to revision by the Supreme Court.
('4', 328, 1, 11, 764475) It is true that such legislation will not be class legislation, and will be of general appli cation.
('4', 328, 1, 12, 764576) Does it, however, matter?
('4', 328, 1, 13, 764602) It can be passed without any bother, if all parties agree upon the main principles, and it will set at rest the unhealthy agitation against the Asiatics that springs up in the Colony from time to time, and settle the minds of the Indians.
('4', 328, 1, 14, 764841) There is no finality to any legislation under a progressive Government.
('4', 328, 1, 15, 764913) If, there fore, the two measures above mentioned are, in practice, found not to answer, it will be time to consider what more is necessary.` The Indians need not accept any such compromise, especially in view of Mr. Lytteltons emphatic declaration that nothing that they enjoyed before the war would be taken away from them.
('4', 328, 1, 16, 765238) They certa inly enjoyed the rights of free immigration and free trading, and it is exactly [on] these two points that they have offered the above compr omise; if only the very un British Law 3 of 1885, and other harsh and needless regulations, which have nothing to do with the economic conditions, be removed from the Statute book.
('4', 328, 1, 17, 765571) Mr. Brodrick has only lately stated that British trade with India is greater than that with Aust ralia, Canada and South Africa put together, and that, therefore, Impe rially considered, India occupies a place second only to Great Britain.
('4', 328, 1, 18, 765811) Will the Colonists continue to subject the inhabitants of that country to constant pin pricks?
('4', 328, 1, 19, 765906) We are told that the Chinese guilds have been successful in bending the American Government.
('4', 328, 1, 20, 765999) Lord Curzon has already talked
('4', 329, 0, 1, 766030) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 329, 1, 2, 766072) of retaliation.
('4', 329, 1, 3, 766088) It is not possible, then, to realise what India could do if retaliation were seriously taken up?
('4', 329, 1, 4, 766185) China and America are not under the same flag, whereas South Africa and India are.
('4', 329, 1, 5, 766268) Would it not be a calamity if there arise permanent estrangement between the local Governments in South Africa and the Indian Government, and if Lord Curzon carries out his threat deliberately uttered in the Imperial Legislative Council at Calcutta?
('4', 329, 1, 6, 766518) Some such thing is inevitable unless the Colonists see the sweet reasonableness of the compromise above offered.
('4', 329, 2, 7, 766631) I am, etc., M. K.GANDHI Indian Opinion, 8 7 1905
('4', 329, 3, 8, 766680) 281. LETTER TO THE RAND DAILY MAIL
('4', 329, 4, 9, 766715) [JOHANNESBURG,] June 28, 1905 TO THE EDITOR The Rand Daily Mail
('4', 329, 5, 10, 766779) SIR, Perhaps you will allow me to make a few remarks on your lead ing article in the Daily Mail of the 26th instant anent the Krugersdorp anti Asiatic meeting.
('4', 329, 6, 11, 766939) After admitting that pledges were given before the war by the Home Government regarding the British Indians, you go on to advise them that they must admit that their competition has driven out many white traders.
('4', 329, 6, 12, 767152) With all due respect, I venture to think that you are advising the Indian community to admit what does not exist.
('4', 329, 6, 13, 767266) There has not yet been given, at any of these meetings, one authentic instance of the white trader having been driven out by Indian compet ition.
('4', 329, 6, 14, 767412) This can only be proved by the appointment of a commission to investigate the charge.
('4', 329, 6, 15, 767498) In the meanwhile, the presumption is wholly in favour of the Indian contention that Indian competition has not ruined white trade, or driven out any such traders.
('4', 329, 6, 16, 767661) In the Trans vaal itself, as well before the war as now, the white traders have held their own.
('4', 329, 6, 17, 767757) At the Cape, in spite of the greatest freedom of trade gran ted to Asiatics, the white trader is largely predominant.
('4', 329, 6, 18, 767875) In Natal, where there is the largest Indian population, Sir James Hullett only the other day said, in his evidence on oath, that the Indian traders had not serio usly affected the white traders.
('4', 329, 6, 19, 768070) I submit that this competition has been quite healthy, in that it has kept down the prices of the necessaries of
('4', 330, 0, 1, 768183) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 331
('4', 330, 1, 2, 768226) I am free to admit that the Indian scores by his simplicity of life, but this is more than counterbalanced by the white traders knowledge of the English language his superior organising ability, and better facilities for making connections with wholesale houses in Europe.
('4', 330, 1, 3, 768499) But, Sir, the Indians are prepared to concede all that can reason ably be expected of them, without having to make the admission you advise them to make.
('4', 330, 1, 4, 768653) They are prepared, in place of Law 3 of 1885 and other unnecessarily stringent regulations, to accept municipal control over the licences in general, whereby the local bodies will have the right either to grant or to refuse licences, subject, in special cases, to revision by the Supreme Court.
('4', 330, 1, 5, 768948) Their trading rights are the greatest cause of irritation, and this can be allayed without the slightest difficulty, and without loss of time, by accepting the compromise above suggested.
('4', 330, 1, 6, 769136) You seem to think that the Indians now here have certain moral claims which will have to be dealt with by fresh legislation.
('4', 330, 1, 7, 769261) This is not in accord with facts.
('4', 330, 1, 8, 769295) They have a moral claim, certainly, to be placed on an equality with the Europeans, so far as the rights of trade, ownership of property and locomotion are concerned, but they have, today, a legal right to trade and live where they like, as has been laid down by the Supreme Court, and it is not capable of being restric tively dealt with by fresh legislation, as has been said, both by Mr. Lyttelton and Mr. Brodrick; and yet, in order to conciliate public opinion, the Indian community is prepared to accept a restriction on trade, on general and non racial lines, under the proviso above men tioned.
('4', 330, 2, 9, 769898) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('4', 334, 10, 24, 776060) 287. NATAL LEGISLATION
('4', 334, 11, 25, 776083) There are four Bills published in the Natal Government Gazette Extraordinary, dated the 21st June, all of which are more or less
('4', 335, 0, 1, 776212) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 335, 1, 2, 776254) objectionable.
('4', 335, 1, 3, 776269) The first is to amend the laws relating to liquor licences and other licences in their application to the province of Zulu land.
('4', 335, 1, 4, 776398) In this Bill, which is very largely aimed at British Indians, a hawker is to be called upon to take out a licence from month to month, and this applies even to hawkers in goods not imported, although for the latter there is no licensing fee required.
('4', 335, 1, 5, 776649) The fee for a hawkers licence to trade in imported goods is to be l per month.
('4', 335, 1, 6, 776728) Moreover, licences under Act 18 of 1897 are not to be granted unless with the approval of the Colonial Secretary, whose decision is to be absolutely final, and from whose decision there shall be no appeal to any court of law or authority.
('4', 335, 1, 7, 776967) Another Bill dealing with British Indians is the one to impose a tax upon unoccupied rural lands.
('4', 335, 1, 8, 777065) This is a reproduction of the Bill with which we have already dealt 1 and in which land is to be deemed unoccupied unless the owner or some European has continuously resided thereon for at least nine of the twelve months reckoned from January to December in each year.
('4', 335, 1, 9, 777334) The third Bill is the one to provide for the licensing of private Locations.
('4', 335, 1, 10, 777411) A private Location is defined therein to mean any number of huts or dwellings occupied by Natives or Asiatics on any private lands or any piece of Crown land in process of alienation.
('4', 335, 1, 11, 777595) Thus, by a stroke of the pen, every piece of ground which may be occupied by Indians is to be turned into a private Location, and the landlord of the place on which the private Location is established is to take out a licence in respect of which he has to pay 10/ 2 per year per hut or dwelling.
('4', 335, 1, 12, 777891) Licence fee is not to be paid in respect of any huts occupied by Asiatics or Native employees.
('4', 335, 1, 13, 777986) The net result of this would be that every room occupied by an Indian, unless he is the owner or in the employ of the owner, shall be liable to an annual tax of 10/ , to say nothing of the insult which is implied in calling the Asiatics habitations Locations.
('4', 335, 1, 14, 778246) The fourth Bill is to impose a tax on occupied dwelling houses.
('4', 335, 1, 15, 778310) This is of general application, and probably the framers of the Bill had not in their minds British Indians at all; but in the end the Bill will tell far more heavily against Indians than any other class of the community.
('4', 335, 1, 16, 778532) The Bill contemplates the levy of a tax of 1 10 on every house valued at under 750. The tax rises to 20 for a dwelling house
('4', 335, 2, 17, 778657) 1Vide Anti Indian Legislation in Natal, 20 5 1905
('4', 335, 3, 18, 778707) 2Shillings
('4', 336, 0, 1, 778718) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 337
('4', 336, 1, 2, 778761) exceeding 4,000 in value, and the word dwelling house means a house or a part of a house used as a dwelling and including domesticservants quarters, stables, out buildings and other buildings forming the adjuncts of a dwelling house, in so far as they serve the residential purposes of the house, and this tax has to be paid not by the owners, but by the occupier.
('4', 336, 1, 3, 779126) Therefore, every occupier of a room even if it is worth only 50 will have to pay an annual tax of  l 10. There are many rooms which are made of wood and iron for which, probably, only five shillings per month is paid.
('4', 336, 1, 4, 779344) The Government proposes to add a monthly half a crown to such rental.
('4', 336, 1, 5, 779414) To say the least of it, there should have been some free limit under which the tax should not be levied.
('4', 336, 1, 6, 779519) As it is, the Bill is open to very serious objection.
('4', 336, 1, 7, 779573) These Bills are a sample of the activity of the new ministry.
('4', 336, 1, 8, 779635) 1 We feel constrained to say that the stamp of inexperience is to be seen on every one of them.
('4', 336, 1, 9, 779731) Every true citizen must sympathise with the Government in their efforts to bring the Colony out of its difficult pecuniary position; but the means adopted by them to raise revenue are almost without precedent in modern times, except during war time, and are opposed to sound economic principles.
('4', 336, 1, 10, 780027) We hope that, for the sake of the fair name and fame of the Colony, these Bills will receive short shrift at the hands of the Assembly and the Council.
('4', 336, 2, 11, 780179) Indian Opinion, 1 7 1905
('4', 336, 3, 12, 780204) 288. MR. BRODRICK2 AND BRITISH INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 336, 4, 13, 780260) Sir Mancherji 3 has drawn from Mr. Brodrick an important reply on the status of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('4', 336, 4, 14, 780374) The member for Bethnal Green pressed for some solution of the Indian question, and Mr. Brodrick has stated emphatically that nothing of what the Indians enjoyed before the war would be taken away from them; that every pressure that could be brought to bear on the Transvaal was being brought, but that it was difficult to interfere with a self governing Colony dealing with the immigration of such people as it may consider to be undesirable.
('4', 336, 4, 15, 780817) The first statement made by Mr. Brodrick
('4', 336, 5, 16, 780858) 1Headed by C. J. Smythe.
('4', 336, 5, 17, 780883) 2St. John Brodrick, Secretary of State for India, 1903 5 3 Sir Mancherjee Merwanjee Bhownaggree (1851 1933).
('4', 336, 5, 18, 780992) Indian Barrister settled in England; Member of Parliament and of the British Committee of the Indian National Congress.
('4', 337, 0, 1, 781112) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 337, 1, 2, 781154) can only mean that it is the intention of the Imperial Government to see that Indians are not deprived of such rights as they may have enjoyed during the Boer regime.
('4', 337, 1, 3, 781321) Such intention is not at present being carried out.
('4', 337, 1, 4, 781373) To take only one instance: there was no restriction on the immigration of British Indians.
('4', 337, 1, 5, 781464) At present, as these columns have shown repeatedly, no new Indians are being allowed to enter Transvaal territory, and the old residents are only allowed to enter in small numbers, and after they have undergone tedious, inconvenient and expensive formalities.
('4', 337, 1, 6, 781724) That pressure is being brought by the Imperial we know and appreciate.
('4', 337, 1, 7, 781795) We question, however, whether the pressure is commensurate with the gravity of the situation.
('4', 337, 1, 8, 781889) For the third statement made by the Right Honourable Gentleman gives rise to many a misgiving.
('4', 337, 1, 9, 781984) It betrays a feeling of helplessness.
('4', 337, 1, 10, 782022) The Transvaal is not yet a self governing Colony, 1 but, by implication, Mr. Brodrick has considered it as such.
('4', 337, 1, 11, 782135) Mr. Brodrick does not deny the promises referred to by Sir Mancherji; nor can it be denied that, when the promises were made, the responsible ministers knew what was coming.
('4', 337, 1, 12, 782309) They knew that there was to be only one conclusion to the war, and that after the declaration of peace self government was bound to come.
('4', 337, 1, 13, 782447) It, therefore, means that the Home Government are now prepared, in their eagerness to conciliate the Transvaal European opinion, even to recede from their promises.
('4', 337, 1, 14, 782612) It is apposite here to inquire why, so soon as peace was declared, the promises made to the Indians were not immediately fulfilled; also, why, even now, as suggested by Sir William Wedderburn 2, so long as the Transvaal has not received actual self government, the Home Government do not repeal the old restrictions on the British Indians, and thus throw on the Council that would be elected, under complete self government, the onus of repealing such legislation and proving the necessity for it.
('4', 337, 2, 15, 783110) About the same time that Mr. Brodrick made the above statement, in a different place, but still as Secretary of State for India, he informed his audience that India had the first claim on their consideration, next only to Great Britain itself, in that the trade of Great Britain with India was larger than that done with Canada, Australia and South Africa combined.
('4', 337, 2, 16, 783476) Had the interests of British
('4', 337, 3, 17, 783505) 1It became one in 1906. 2Distinguished member of the Indian Civil Service, later connected with the Indian National Congress.
('4', 338, 0, 1, 783631) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 339
('4', 338, 1, 2, 783674) Indians in the Transvaal been considered in such a spirit on the conclusion of war, when Lord Milner 1 put his pen through scores of old Transvaal Ordinances which were not consistent with British principles, he would not have hesitated to do likewise in connection with the anti Indian legislation.
('4', 338, 1, 3, 783974) Nor was it a matter of oversight; for immediately the country was opened up, British Indians approached Lord Milner for a cancellation of the anti Indian laws.
('4', 338, 1, 4, 784134) If that step had been taken, nothing would have been heard, probably, of anti Indian agitation to day; nor, in our opinion, is it yet too late to put into practice the theory propounded by Mr. Brodrick.

('4', 338, 2, 6, 784362) 289. LORD SELBORNE2 AND SELF GOVERNMENT In view of what we have already said with reference to Mr. Brodricks statement, 3 it is interesting to examine the definition of self government given by Lord Selborne to a deputation that waited on him last week in the Orange River Colony, in order to request the grant of self government to that Colony.
('4', 338, 2, 7, 784708) His Excellency has thus defined that within the British Empire responsible government means, in strictly local affairs, absolute independence; it means absolute local independence so long as that independence does not encroach on the general harmony of the British Empire, or infringe any of those principles on which it is founded, or any of those imperial considerations which bind it together.
('4', 338, 2, 8, 785105) This is a definition worthy of a distinguished representative of the King Emperor, and it is in accord with the professions repeatedly made by the Imperial Colonial Secretaries.
('4', 338, 2, 9, 785283) The question, then, is whether the disabilities which British Indians suffer in the Transvaal do not encroach on the general harmony of the British Empire, or infringe any of those Imperial considerations which bind it together.
('4', 338, 2, 10, 785512) The question is self answered.
('4', 338, 2, 11, 785543) Let us hope that His Excellency, when he is called upon to deal with the Indian question, will apply the definition given by him, and remove the present anomaly.
('4', 338, 2, 12, 785705) Indian Opinion, 1 7 1905

('4', 339, 1, 2, 786031) 290. DISCRIMINATION IN PUBLIC SERVICES
('4', 339, 2, 3, 786070) Lord Curzon 1 has frequently declared that, in making public appointments, he made no discrimination between the white and the Coloured.
('4', 339, 2, 4, 786207) On one occasion, he burst out with vehemence saying that Indians had no reason to complain in the matter of appointments.
('4', 339, 2, 5, 786329) Moreover, he published a statement with figures to prove that quite a number of appointments were given to Indians.
('4', 339, 2, 6, 786445) But the statement was misleading, for he had cleverly included in it many Indians drawing a salary of Rs. 75. The Hon.
('4', 339, 2, 7, 786564) Mr. Gokhale 2 has exposed this hollow pretence.
('4', 339, 2, 8, 786612) 3 He has shown that those who receive high salaries are almost all Europeans and that all the newly created posts have gone to them.

('4', 339, 4, 11, 786786) 291. MAXIM GORKY4
('4', 339, 5, 12, 786804) A comparison can be made, up to a point, between the people of Russia and our own.
('4', 339, 5, 13, 786887) Just as we are poor, the Russian people are also poor.
('4', 339, 5, 14, 786942) We have no voice in conducting the affairs of State and have to pay taxes without demur; the same is true of the Russians also.
('4', 339, 5, 15, 787070) Seeing such oppression, some Russians do come out bravely against it from time to time.
('4', 339, 5, 16, 787158) Some time ago, there was a rebellion in Russia and one of the chief participants was Maxim Gorky.
('4', 339, 5, 17, 787256) This man was brought up in extreme poverty.
('4', 339, 5, 18, 787300) At first he served as an apprentice to a shoe maker, who discharged him.
('4', 339, 5, 19, 787373) Afterwards he served as a soldier for some time.
('4', 339, 5, 20, 787422) While in the army, he evinced a desire for education, but being poor could not get himself admitted to any good school.
('4', 339, 5, 21, 787542) He then served under a lawyer and finally worked as a hawker at a bakers.
('4', 339, 5, 22, 787616) All this time he continued educating himself through his own efforts.
('4', 339, 5, 23, 787686) The very first book he wrote in 1892 was so excellent that he soon became famous.
('4', 339, 5, 24, 787768) Thereafter, he wrote many things, all of them with a single purpose, viz., to stir up the people against the tyrannies they were labouring under, to warn the authorities and to render public service, in so far as this was possible.
('4', 339, 5, 25, 788000) Without caring to make

('4', 340, 2, 6, 788690) 292. THE CHINESE AND THE INDIANS IN SINGAPORE Singapore can be said to be as near to the Chinese as it is to us.
('4', 340, 2, 7, 788803) In that Colony an Indian has all the facilities a Chinese has.
('4', 340, 2, 8, 788866) Despite this, our people there cannot hold their own against the Chinese.
('4', 340, 2, 9, 788940) Many Chinese are in Government service, in the Public Works Department or are contractors, and are all very well off.
('4', 340, 2, 10, 789058) Some even own motor cars.
('4', 340, 2, 11, 789084) The number of Chinese who entered Singapore territory was 200,947 in 1900, 178,778 in 1901, 207,l56 in 1902 and 220,321 in 1903; while the number of Indians who migrated there was 21,000 a year, most of them from Madras.
('4', 340, 2, 12, 789305) This shows how much is yet to be achieved by our people in the matter of emigration to, and settling in, foreign territories.
('4', 340, 2, 13, 789431) It is a shame that we cannot keep abreast of the Chinese.

('4', 340, 3, 15, 789530) 293. LETTER TO HIGH COMMISSIONERS SECRETARY
('4', 340, 4, 16, 789574) JOHANNESBURG July 1, 1905
('4', 340, 6, 17, 789600) THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE HIGH COMMISSIONER JOHANNESBURG
('4', 340, 7, 18, 789675) SIR, I have the honour to enclose herewith copies of communications exchanged between the Government of the Orange River Colony and my Association, 1 in connection with the bye laws from time to time
('4', 340, 8, 19, 789875) 1Vide Letter to Colonial Secretary, 11 4 1905 to which the Government had replied that no legislation for the restriction of the powers Of municipalities in the Colony was contemplated.
('4', 341, 0, 1, 790061) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 341, 1, 2, 790103) sanctioned by His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor of the Colony, regarding Coloured persons.
('4', 341, 1, 3, 790199) My Association ventures to draw His Excellencys attention to the fact that no fresh legislation has been asked for in my letter.
('4', 341, 1, 4, 790328) In the humble opinion of my Association, the powers already possessed by the Lieutenant Governor enable him to veto bye laws which are contrary to British traditions and to the Letters Patent.
('4', 341, 1, 5, 790521) My Association is informed that such legislation as the municipalities have been allowed to pass would have to be reserved for His Majestys assent, if it were passed by the Legislative Council.
('4', 341, 1, 6, 790715) My Association also ventures to think that the last paragraph of the letter, written by the Acting Colonial Secretary, is a complete justification for the complaint made by my Association, for, if the question raised is of no practical importance as there are so few British Indians, it cannot be of practical importance to pass legislation of the character referred to in my communication.
('4', 341, 1, 7, 791106) While it is of no use in the Colony, it wounds, unnecessarily, the feelings of the British Indian community in South Africa, and my Association, therefore, ventures to trust that His Excellency will be graciously pleased to inquire into the bye laws that have been passed and sanctioned for the various municipalities in the Orange River Colony, and grant the necessary relief.
('4', 341, 1, 8, 791484) I have the honour to remain,
('4', 341, 3, 9, 791513) Your obedient servant, ABDUL GANI, CHAIRMAN BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Indian Opinion, 8 7 1905

('4', 342, 6, 9, 792459) 295. ORANGE RIVER COLONY LEGISLATION
('4', 342, 7, 10, 792496) We publish two important communications in this issue on the status of British Indians in the Orange River Colony.
('4', 342, 7, 11, 792611) The one is a short and belated reply from the Colonial Secretary of that Colony to the protest of the British Indian Association at Johannesburg, against the anti Asiatic municipal legislation that has been sanctioned by the Lieutenant Governor from time to time by the municipalities of the Orange River Colony.
('4', 342, 7, 12, 792924) The second letter is from Mr H. R. Fox Bourne the Secretary of the Aborigines Protection Society, addressed to Mr. Lyttelton.
('4', 342, 7, 13, 793050) 1 The two communications are a contrast The Colonial Secretary writes saying that the Government are not contemplating any legislation with a view to restricting the powers of local government at present enjoyed by municipalities in the Orange River Colony.
('4', 342, 7, 14, 793308) This , in our opinion, is purely begging the question.
('4', 342, 7, 15, 793363) The British Indian Association has never asked for any legislation to restrict the powers, because the veto is already [vested] in the Lieutenant Governor.
('4', 342, 7, 16, 793519) No bye laws are of any force unless sanctioned by the Lieutenant Governor, and we know of no statute, even for the Orange River Colony, which compels the Lieutenant Governor to sanction any bye laws that the municipalities may pass.
('4', 342, 7, 17, 793752) On the contrary, the instructions issued to His Excellency are that he is not tosanction any colour legislation; and one would suppose that, if he may not do that in respect of laws applying to the whole of the Colony, he cannot also do so in respect of laws applying to a particular municipality in that Colony.
('4', 342, 7, 18, 794065) The reason given by the Colonial Secretary is sarcastic.
('4', 342, 7, 19, 794122) He says: As there are so few British Indians in the Colony, I think you will agree that the question raised by you is not of great practical importance.
('4', 342, 7, 20, 794275) The word practical is underlined in the letter.
('4', 342, 7, 21, 794323) What is the meaning?
('4', 342, 7, 22, 794344) It simply shows that the
('4', 342, 8, 23, 794369) 1Alfred Lyttelton, Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1903 5
('4', 343, 0, 1, 794432) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 343, 1, 2, 794474) gates of the Orange River Colony are for ever to remain barred against the British Indian, and also that, if he ever entered the Colony, he would do so in the face of all the restrictive powers, and if he protests, he would be told that such laws could not be repealed.
('4', 343, 1, 3, 794744) Too late will be flung in his face.
('4', 343, 1, 4, 794780) May we not ask the Colonial Secretary why, as there are so few British Indians in the Orange River Colony, the wanton insult is offered at all?
('4', 343, 1, 5, 794924) Is it practical statesmanship to wound the feelings of a whole nation, even when there is not an iota of justification for it?
('4', 343, 1, 6, 795051) Surely the municipalities of the Orange River Colony could not be so unreasonable as not to listen to expostulations from the Lieutenant Governor on a matter which, on the Colonial Secretarys own showing, is of no importance to them, unless they delight in heaping unnecessary insults on a community which has never done them any harm.
('4', 343, 1, 7, 795387) But we would not pursue the examination of the letter any further.
('4', 343, 1, 8, 795454) We are glad that the British Indian Association has already moved in the matter, and approached the High Commissioner.
('4', 343, 2, 9, 795573) In pleasant contrast to the letter we find Mr. Fox Bournes communication to the Colonial Secretary.
('4', 343, 2, 10, 795673) We invite the attention of all South African Imperialists to this important communication, which we have copied from our contemporary, India.
('4', 343, 2, 11, 795815) Much has been often said in South Africa against the Aborigines Protection Society.
('4', 343, 2, 12, 795899) We hope, however, that the South African Press and South African readers will treat each act on its own merits, and not condemn, by reason of pre conceived prejudice, anything that may emanate from the Aborigines Protection Society, which, after all, counts among its members some of the noblest of Britons.
('4', 343, 2, 13, 796207) Mr. Fox Bourne has also assurances to be fulfilled in this matter.
('4', 343, 2, 14, 796274) He has reminded the Colonial Secretary that, before the war, in reply to his Societys representations, certain promises were given.
('4', 343, 2, 15, 796406) He, therefore, ventures to hope that no time will be lost in fulfilling those assurances, and he is encouraged in the hope, at any rate as regarding Coloured persons who are British subjects and not uncivilised, by remarks made by Lord Milner.
('4', 343, 2, 16, 796650) The Imperial Government have a hard nut to crack.
('4', 343, 2, 17, 796700) They have either to adopt the advice of Sir Arthur Lawley 1 and boldly commit a breach of their promises, or to fulfil them in accordance with British traditions.
('4', 343, 3, 18, 796863) Indian Opinion, 8 7 1905
('4', 343, 4, 19, 796888) 1 Former High Commissioner in the Transvaal
('4', 344, 0, 1, 796932) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 345
('4', 344, 1, 2, 796975) 296. THE CHINESE AND ABUSIVE LANGUAGE
('4', 344, 2, 3, 797013) A deputation on behalf of whites from the Transvaal mines waited upon Lord Selborne on July l, and prayed for protection for the whites against Chinese labourers.
('4', 344, 2, 4, 797176) It stated that the whites did not behave badly towards the Chinese; that, since thirty or forty Chinese worked under a white supervisor, it was not difficult for the Chinese to take his life in the event of a riot; that the Chinese frequently insulted their white boss by using foul language and making indecent gestures; and that the language they used was so foul that it was impossible for the deputation to reproduce it.
('4', 344, 2, 5, 797601) They said that a white man would not take such an insult lying down.
('4', 344, 2, 6, 797670) In his reply, Lord Selborne said that there had been only twenty cases of assault by the Chinese until then, though the Chinese labour numbered 40,000; that their complaint about the language was without substance, for the white himself used abusive language and set a bad example.
('4', 344, 2, 7, 797952) It was harmful to the whites themselves to indulge in drink and indecent behaviour in the presence of the Chinese.
('4', 344, 2, 8, 798067) If one uses abusive words while addressing persons utterly ignorant of the language, they pick them up parrot like, and it is then very difficult to mend matters.
('4', 344, 2, 9, 798230) Moreover, he said, the whiteness of the whites should not be limited to their skin only but should permeate within also, that is, they should have the art of inducing respect, obedience and awe in others by their own exemplary conduct.
('4', 344, 2, 10, 798466) Then only could they be called white in reality.
('4', 344, 2, 11, 798515) In brief, he held the whites themselves responsible for the ugly behaviour of the Chinese, and indicated the need of winning the Chinese over by their own good behaviour.
('4', 344, 2, 12, 798686) Several other difficulties also were placed by the deputationists before Lord Selborne, who promised to give adequate attention to them.
('4', 344, 2, 13, 798823) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 8 7 1905

('4', 344, 4, 15, 798887) HUTCHINSONS STRONG CRITICISM
('4', 344, 5, 16, 798916) The tax levied on salt in India has always been a subject of criticism.
('4', 344, 5, 17, 798988) This time it has been criticised by the well known Dr. Hutchinson, who says that it is a great shame for the British Government in India to continue it, while a similar tax previously in force in Japan has been abolished.
('4', 344, 5, 18, 799210) The tax should be immediately
('4', 345, 0, 1, 799240) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 345, 1, 2, 799282) abolished.
('4', 345, 1, 3, 799293) Salt is an essential article in our dietary.
('4', 345, 1, 4, 799338) It could be said that to a certain extent, the increasing incidence of leprosy in India was due to the salt tax.
('4', 345, 1, 5, 799451) Dr. Hutchinson considers the salt tax a barbarous practice, which ill becomes the British Government.

('4', 351, 1, 2, 807155) 306. THE CAPE IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION ACT
('4', 351, 2, 3, 807197) We publish in another column the text of a letter received by the Chairman of the British Indian League at Cape Town from the Colonial Secretarys Office, in reply to representations of the League on the working of the Cape Immigration Act.
('4', 351, 2, 4, 807437) The Colonial Secretary brushes asidein a single sentence the request made by the League as to the recognition of the Indian languages.
('4', 351, 2, 5, 807572) We hope that the British Indian League will not leave the question at that.
('4', 351, 2, 6, 807648) With reference to the interpretation of the term domicile, the reply is most unsatisfactory.
('4', 351, 2, 7, 807741) It is not every Indian who can show possession of immovable property, or presence of wife and children in the Colony.
('4', 351, 2, 8, 807859) If such an interpretation is insisted upon, it cannot but cause unnecessary hardship, in spite of the intention of the Colonial Secretary not to do so.
('4', 351, 2, 9, 808011) A man may leave his business at the Cape, pay a temporary visit to India, and find himself for ever shut out of the Cape, because his wife and children are not in the Colony, or he does not own immovable property.
('4', 351, 2, 10, 808225) It would then simply mean ruin to the poor store keeper who, under a false sense of security, may have gone to India, leaving his business in temporary charge of his manager.
('4', 351, 2, 11, 808400) Nor is this illustration an imaginary one, for we understand that cases of such Indians having been refused re entrance have actually happened.
('4', 351, 2, 12, 808544) The least, therefore, that Colonel Crewe 1 could do to satisfy the requirements of justice is to recognise the rights of those who may have left business or employment in the country to re enter.
('4', 351, 2, 13, 808740) It will then be possible for them to talk of an exercise of leniency, for, in the definition given by him, so far there has been no leniency but a very strict application of the law; and then only will it be possible for the British Indian League to recognise the reasonable attitude of the Government.
('4', 351, 2, 14, 809043) For the present, we think, with the greatest deference, that it is unjust, unreasonable and calculated to impose very serious hardship on the British Indians residing in the Cape Colony.
('4', 351, 3, 15, 809230) Indian Opinion, 15 7 1905
('4', 351, 4, 16, 809256) 1 Colonial Secretary, Cape Colony
('4', 352, 0, 1, 809290) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 353
('4', 352, 1, 2, 809333) 307. MR. WACHA1 AND INDIANS
('4', 352, 2, 3, 809361) Mr. Wacha, the genial Joint Secretary of the National Congress, has written to us a letter which is full of encouragement, hope and suggestion.
('4', 352, 2, 4, 809505) We reproduce the main portion of it in another column.
('4', 352, 2, 5, 809560) He has given a parallel case which is of some importance in the controversy that is going on in South Africa over the status of British Indians.
('4', 352, 2, 6, 809705) The settlers, says Mr. Wacha,
('4', 352, 3, 7, 809735) on your side, seem to have forgotten how merchants and traders themselves used to complain in the bitterest terms of the East India Co., which, up till the Act of 1833, interdicted them from trading in India.
('4', 352, 3, 8, 809944) Those who came were styled interlopers, but the interlopers were persevering and earnest,
('4', 352, 4, 9, 810034) and we know that they succeeded.
('4', 352, 4, 10, 810067) Earnestness and perseverance are also the keynote to the situation in South Africa.
('4', 352, 4, 11, 810151) We have far greater justice on our side than they of 1833. British Indians have a threefold right to have their status made good in South Africa.
('4', 352, 4, 12, 810297) The Proclamation of 1858, no matter what may be said to the contrary, guarantees them full British subject rights.
('4', 352, 4, 13, 810412) They have shown themselves to be industrious, sober, law abiding and honest in South Africa, and, as has been often admitted, they have been very useful in developing its resources.

('4', 356, 5, 21, 818077) 313. LETTER TO THE DAILY EXPRESS
('4', 356, 6, 22, 818110) JOHANNESBURG, [After July 17, 1905]
('4', 356, 8, 23, 818146) THE EDITOR The Daily Express
('4', 356, 9, 24, 818175) SIR, I trust you will allow me to reply to your correspondent who, under the elegant pseudonym of Sinkramsam, has attacked British
('4', 357, 0, 1, 818306) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 357, 1, 2, 818348) Indians through your columns in your issue of the 17th instant.
('4', 357, 1, 3, 818412) There is a homely Indian saying that you can take a horse to a watercourse but cannot compel him to drink the water.
('4', 357, 1, 4, 818529) So also those who shut their eyes to facts placed before them are not to be disabused of their misconceptions.
('4', 357, 1, 5, 818640) Your correspondent, I very much fear, belongs to that category.
('4', 357, 1, 6, 818704) For his information, however, I ask again the question, if there were only thirteen Indian (not coolie, as your correspondent would have it) store keepers, traders and hawkers before the war, how is it that the challenge issued by the Chairman of the British Indian Association has not been taken up by Mr. Kleinenberg 1?
('4', 357, 1, 7, 819026) Remember that the names of these store keepers have been supplied to the Press.
('4', 357, 1, 8, 819106) I note that your correspondent has gone one better, in that he makes bold to say that the number thirteen includes store keepers, traders and hawkers.
('4', 357, 1, 9, 819257) Unfortunately for him, he has chosen a fatal number, and I am prepared to deposit with you the sum of 100 to be forfeited to any anti Indian Association your correspondent may name if I fail to prove to the satisfaction of two arbitrators, one to be chosen by him and the other by me, with power to them to appoint an umpire, that there were more than twice the number of store keepers, traders and hawkers mentioned by your correspondent prior to the war in the town of Pietersburg; provided that he forfeits to the British Indian Association an equal sum in the event of the award being in my favour.
('4', 357, 1, 10, 819860) So much for Sinkramsams figures.
('4', 357, 1, 11, 819893) As to the charge that the Native is being fleeced by British Indians, I can only refer your correspondent to Sir James Huletts testimony 2 bet fore the Native Affairs Commission as to which is the greater evil doer, the European or the Indian.
('4', 357, 1, 12, 820137) With reference to the other charges made by your correspondent, and based on information supplied to him, I can only say that sensible people will rate them at their true value.
('4', 357, 1, 13, 820315) If there is any nefarious trade done by Indians, and he has received the information, surely the remedy is in his own hands, and if the question of trading licences is not yet settled once and for all, it is because Sinkramsam and his coadjutors would not accept the very reasonable compromise suggested by British Indians, whereby the control of new licences would be handed to the Town Councillors to be elected largely by Sinkramsam and his friends.
('4', 357, 1, 14, 820768) You, Sir, have some experience of the British Indian question as it was prior to the war.
('4', 357, 1, 15, 820858) You have experience of British Indians also.
('4', 357, 1, 16, 820903) You have adopted an independent attitude in journalism.
('4', 357, 1, 17, 820959) I am sure
('4', 357, 2, 18, 820969) 1 Vide Mr. Klinenberg and Mr. Abdool Gani, 7 1 1905 & Potchefstroom Churlishness, 7 1 1905 2 Vide Sir J.L. Hulett and Indian Traders, 24 9 1903
('4', 358, 0, 1, 821113) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 359
('4', 358, 1, 2, 821156) you do not wish racial hatred between the component parts of the British Empire to grow.
('4', 358, 1, 3, 821245) It must be within your knowledge that some of the facts stated by your correspondent are untrue.

('4', 361, 0, 1, 825747) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 361, 1, 2, 825789) 318. MR. BRODRICKS BUDGET
('4', 361, 2, 3, 825815) There are features in the Budget statement made by the Secretary of State for India to the House of Commons on the motion that the House should go into committee on the East India Revenue accounts.
('4', 361, 2, 4, 826013) It is a happy augury that Mr. Brodrick has presented his statement almost for the first time, within recent times, during the middle of the session instead of, as usual, at the end, when the Indian Secretary goes through the farce of addressing empty benches.
('4', 361, 2, 5, 826273) The departure, too, has been deliberate.
('4', 361, 2, 6, 826314) Discussion, said Mr. Brodrick, at this earlier period is more likely to lead to useful criticism and efficient administration.
('4', 361, 2, 7, 826441) He hoped, too, that the precedent would be followed, whether in future he was the holder of the high office or an honourable member from the Opposition benches.
('4', 361, 2, 8, 826602) Mr. Brodrick took occasion to show most clearly the extent of the services rendered to the Empire by much maligned India, and both the services he laid so much stress upon are such as to command attention and appreciation in South Africa.
('4', 361, 3, 9, 826841) Of the one hundred and forty three million pounds of trade in 1902 and1903, sixty two million pounds was trade directly with Great Britain.
('4', 361, 3, 10, 826981) Of the trade of last year, one hundred and seventy four million, seven hundred and forty eight thousand pounds, seventy seven million pounds was directly to and from Great Britain.
('4', 361, 3, 11, 827162) That is not an inconsiderable item in the trade of Great Britain, and if we compare these figures, as some people from different points of view are now occupied in comparing the trade of the Colonies with the trade of India, I could point out that the exports from the United Kingdom to India in 1902, which were thirty three million five hundred thousand pounds, were equal to the exports to Canada, the British Colonies, and North America, and to Australia, and last year those exports, which had grown to forty million pounds, equalled the whole of the exports from this country to Australia, to Canada and to Cape Colony combined.
('4', 361, 3, 12, 827797) There was no difficulty in Mr. Brodricks drawing the natural deduction.
('4', 361, 3, 13, 827869) He, therefore, went on:
('4', 361, 4, 14, 827893) I trust I shall carry every member of this House with me when I say that the trade of India with the United Kingdom tends continually to increase.
('4', 361, 4, 15, 828040) The stake of the United Kingdom in the trade of India and the stake of India in the trade of the United Kingdom are such that we are entitled to claim a first place for India in all the discussions that may take place as regards trade within the Empire.
('4', 361, 5, 16, 828294) Another statement that Mr. Brodrick made was with reference to the defences of the Empire.
('4', 361, 5, 17, 828385) India forms a training ground for
('4', 362, 0, 1, 828419) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 363
('4', 362, 1, 2, 828462) seventy five thousand British troops and a breeding ground for one hundred and forty thousand British Indian troops which are held at the disposal of the Empire in any emergency.
('4', 362, 1, 3, 828641) The whole cost is borne by India, representing an expense of twenty and a half millions out of a revenue of eighty two millions.
('4', 362, 1, 4, 828770) Distinguished generals from Lord Roberts downwards have testified to the efficacy of the services of the Indian Army.
('4', 362, 1, 5, 828888) Sir George White and his army gave a striking illustration of this preparedness during the Boer War.
('4', 362, 1, 6, 828989) These are all facts pregnant with meaning.
('4', 362, 1, 7, 829032) They ought to be studied and pondered by South African politicians; and, after they have done so, we respectfully suggest to them that they should ask themselves the question whether it would pay, even from a purely selfish standpoint, to continuously treat the inhabitants of India as complete aliens undeserving of any consideration whatsoever at their hands.
('4', 362, 2, 8, 829394) Indian Opinion, 22 7 1905
('4', 362, 3, 9, 829420) 319. ASIATIC BAZAARS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 362, 4, 10, 829458) A recent issue of the Transvaal Government Gazette contains a Draft Ordinance which has the following amongst other clauses:
('4', 362, 5, 11, 829583) (1) The Council may, with the approval of the Lieutenant Governor, set apart, maintain, and carry on bazaars or other areas exclusively for occupation by Asiatics, and control and supervise the same in accordance with Regulations made from time to time by the Lieutenant Governor, and may lease the land and any buildings or other erections thereon to Asiatics upon such terms and at such rents as may be prescribed from time to time by such Regulations aforesaid.
('4', 362, 6, 12, 830048) (2) The sites of any bazaars or other places pointed out under the provisions of Law 3 of 1885 or any amendment thereof may be transferred by the Lieutenant Governor to any Council of a Municipality, subject to existing leases thereover, and every such transfer shall be free of transfer stamp duty, and registration or other charges, and any such bazaar or site so transferred shall be deemed to be a bazaar or area set apart under sub section (I) of this section.
('4', 362, 7, 13, 830514) (3) The provisions of section two of this Ordinance shall, mutatis mutandis, apply for the purpose of enabling a Council to close such bazaars and areas and lay out other land suitable for the same.
('4', 362, 8, 14, 830713) (4) The term Council in this section shall include a Council of a Municipality whether constituted under the Municipal Corporations
('4', 363, 0, 1, 830845) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 363, 1, 2, 830887) Ordinance, 1903, the Municipal Corporations Amendment Ordinance, 1904, or under any special law.
('4', 363, 1, 3, 830984) The British Indian Association at Johannesburg has lost no time in protesting against the contemplated transfer of the control of the Bazaars to the municipalities.
('4', 363, 1, 4, 831149) 1 The objections to such transference are, in our opinion, unanswerable.
('4', 363, 1, 5, 831222) The whole of the Asiatic question is still pending, and is the subject of correspondence between the Imperial Government and the local Government.
('4', 363, 1, 6, 831369) Law 3 of 1885, as both the Parties have stated, is only a stopgap to be swept away as soon as possible.
('4', 363, 1, 7, 831473) Any legislation, therefore, based on that law and amplifying the restrictions is inconsistent with the attitude of openness which the local Governments are bound to maintain.
('4', 363, 1, 8, 831648) If not, what becomes of Mr. Lytteltons statement that at least the status quo ante bellum would be kept up?
('4', 363, 1, 9, 831756) Moreover, the prejudices of the town councils and local boards of the Transvaal are very strong on the colour question.
('4', 363, 1, 10, 831876) They do not hesitate to proclaim them from house tops, and some of the councils and boards would even go so far as to use violence, if they could.
('4', 363, 1, 11, 832023) Under the circumstances, whilst there is a position of uncertainty as to the future, it seems strange that the Transvaal Government should bring in legislation as if Law 3 of 1885 were never to be erased from the Statute book.
('4', 363, 1, 12, 832250) Indian Opinion, 22 7 1905

('4', 363, 3, 14, 832299) Our contemporary, the Transvaal Leader, publishes a message from its Pretoria Correspondent to the effect that His Excellency Sir Arthur Lawley granted a private interview to the leaders of the anti Asiatic Convention, among whom were present Messrs Loveday and Bourke.

('4', 363, 3, 19, 832960) Why, then, should there be so much secrecy about Asiatic affairs?

('4', 364, 2, 7, 833892) 321. INDIANS IN KRUGERSDORP
('4', 364, 3, 8, 833920) The Town Council of Krugersdorp has received the doctors report after the meeting about Indians was held there.
('4', 364, 3, 9, 834032) 1 The doctor says that the houses Of Indians are found to be mostly unclean; that they spit all around; that their lavatories are very dirty and water collects on the floor and never dries; and that they sit and sleep on the counters, etc.
('4', 364, 3, 10, 834272) We know that much of this is untrue, and it is now up to the Indians in Krugersdorp to obtain another report to counter all this.
('4', 364, 3, 11, 834402) Nevertheless, we will have to assent to these accusations to some extent.
('4', 364, 3, 12, 834476) Nobody can deny that we spit any and everywhere and allow the lavatories to remain dirty.
('4', 364, 3, 13, 834566) Our people are generally disinclined to cleaning lavatories themselves.
('4', 364, 3, 14, 834638) We feel it necessary to overcome this.
('4', 364, 3, 15, 834677) It is an established fact that many diseases spread through lavatories.
('4', 364, 3, 16, 834749) It is very easy to keep them clean.
('4', 364, 3, 17, 834785) One should spread dry dust or ashes into the bucket every time after use, wash the wooden planks with a disinfectant liquid and wipe them clean.
('4', 364, 3, 18, 834930) If done regularly, this does not take much time and the cause for this antipathy disappears.
('4', 364, 4, 19, 835023) The matter of spiting also needs to be thought about.
('4', 364, 4, 20, 835077) Everything considered, it is very necessary to cultivate the habit of spitting into a handkerchief or a spittoon, instead of all over the house or shop.

('4', 365, 1, 2, 835333) 322. INDIAN HOTELS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 365, 2, 3, 835369) No laws have so far been enacted in respect of Indian hotels in the Transvaal.
('4', 365, 2, 4, 835448) Licences are taken out for Kaffir eating houses and European hotels.
('4', 365, 2, 5, 835517) Chinese hotels came to be opened when the number of Chinese increased in the Transvaal.
('4', 365, 2, 6, 835605) No licences are necessary for them.
('4', 365, 2, 7, 835641) But the Chinese, apprehending trouble in the future, applied of their own accord to the Government for licences.
('4', 365, 2, 8, 835754) The latter replied that no licences were necessary.
('4', 365, 2, 9, 835806) The Chinese believed that no hotel could be opened without a licence, and, therefore, applied to the Government saying that a licensing law should be enacted.
('4', 365, 2, 10, 835965) A Bill on the subject has now been published in the Government Gazette, which shows how one has to suffer the results of ones actions.
('4', 365, 2, 11, 836100) 1 The Indian hotel keepers will now have to take out licences.
('4', 365, 2, 12, 836163) It is not even possible to oppose the Bill.
('4', 365, 2, 13, 836207) All Indian innkeepers in the Transvaal should, therefore, take heed.
('4', 365, 2, 14, 836276) We believe that licences will be granted only if the premises are quite clean.
