('4', 365, 4, 16, 836371) Indian Opinion, 22 7 1905
('4', 365, 5, 17, 836397) 323. JOSEPH MAZZINI A REMARKABLE CAREER Italy as a nation came into existence recently.
('4', 365, 5, 18, 836485) Before 1870 Italy comprised a number of small principalities, each with its petty chief.
('4', 365, 5, 19, 836574) Before 1870, she was like the India or Kathiawad of today.
('4', 365, 5, 20, 836633) Though the people spoke the same language and had the same character, they all owed allegiance to different petty states.
('4', 365, 5, 21, 836755) Today Italy is an independent European country and her people are regarded as a distinct nation.
('4', 365, 5, 22, 836852) All this can be said to be the achievement of one man.
('4', 365, 5, 23, 836907) And his nameJoseph Mazzini.
('4', 365, 5, 24, 836935) Joseph Mazzini was born in Genoa on June 22, 1805. He was a man of such sterling character, so good natured and so patriotic, that great preparations are being made throughout Europe to commemorate the centenary of his birth.
('4', 365, 5, 25, 837161) For, although he dedicated his whole life to the service of Italy, he was so broadminded that he could be regarded a citizen of every country.
('4', 365, 5, 26, 837304) It was his constant yearning that every nation should become great and live in unity.
('4', 365, 6, 27, 837390) 1 The original has What is wrought by the hand hits the heart,
('4', 366, 0, 1, 837453) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 367
('4', 366, 1, 2, 837496) Even at the early age of thirteen, Mazzini showed great intelligence In spite of great scholarship that he evidenced, he gave up his books out of patriotism and undertook the study of law, and began using his legal knowledge gratuitously to help the poor.
('4', 366, 1, 3, 837752) Then he joined a secret organization which was working for the unification of Italy.
('4', 366, 1, 4, 837837) When the Italian chiefs learnt of this, they put him into prison.
('4', 366, 1, 5, 837903) While still in prison, he continued to advance his plans for freeing his country.
('4', 366, 1, 6, 837985) At last he had to leave Italy.
('4', 366, 1, 7, 838016) He went to Marseilles and lived there.
('4', 366, 1, 8, 838055) The Italian princes, however, using their influence, had him banished from that city.
('4', 366, 1, 9, 838141) Though obliged to fly from place to place, he did not lose heart and kept on sending his writings secretly to Italy, which gradually influenced the minds of the people.
('4', 366, 1, 10, 838310) He suffered a lot in the process.
('4', 366, 1, 11, 838344) He had to run about in disguise to evade spies.
('4', 366, 1, 12, 838392) Even his life was frequently in danger, but he did not care.
('4', 366, 1, 13, 838453) At last he went to England in 1837. He did not suffer so much there but had to live in extreme poverty.
('4', 366, 1, 14, 838557) In England he came into contact with the great leaders of that country and sought their aid.
('4', 366, 1, 15, 838650) In 1848 Mazzini returned with Garibaldi to Italy, and set up the self governing State of Italy.
('4', 366, 1, 16, 838746) But it did not last long, thanks to the activities of crafty persons and though Mazzini had to flee the country once again, his influence did not fade.
('4', 366, 1, 17, 838898) The seed of unity that he had sown endured and, though Mazzini remained in banishment, Italy became a single united kingdom in 1870. Victor Emmanuel became its king.
('4', 366, 1, 18, 839064) Mazzini was gratified to see his country thus united.
('4', 366, 1, 19, 839118) But as he was not permitted to enter the country, he used to go there in disguise.
('4', 366, 1, 20, 839201) Once when the police went to arrest him, he opened the door for them as if he were an usher and gave them the slip.
('4', 366, 1, 21, 839317) This great man died on March, 1873. His foes had now become his friends.
('4', 366, 1, 22, 839390) People had come to recognise his true worth.
('4', 366, 1, 23, 839435) Eighty thousand people joined his funeral procession.
('4', 366, 1, 24, 839489) He was buried at the highest spot in Genoa.
('4', 366, 1, 25, 839533) Today Italy and the whole of Europe worship this man.
('4', 366, 1, 26, 839587) In Italy he is considered one of the greatest of men.
('4', 366, 1, 27, 839641) He was a pious and religious man, ever free from selfishness and pride.
('4', 366, 1, 28, 839713) Poverty was for him an ornament.
('4', 366, 1, 29, 839746) The sufferings of others he regarded as his own.
('4', 366, 1, 30, 839795) There are very few instances in the world where a single man has brought about the uplift of his country by his strength of mind and his extreme devotion during his own lifetime.
('4', 366, 1, 31, 839974) Such was the unique Mazzini.

('4', 367, 1, 2, 840087) 324. IMPORTANT SUGGESTIONS FOR INDIANS GOING TO THE TRANSVAAL1
('4', 367, 2, 3, 840150) Indians are now a days being subjected to very great severity in the matter of permits in the Transvaal.
('4', 367, 2, 4, 840255) Many persons who were staying on false permits have been deported.
('4', 367, 2, 5, 840322) Some, whose permits did not bear their thumb impressions, have been sentenced to imprisonment for six weeks.
('4', 367, 2, 6, 840431) It is probable that many more personswill be subjected to hardships.It is also believed that Permit Officers will visit different villages for investigation.
('4', 367, 2, 7, 840589) It is therefore necessary that those who hold false permits should immediately leave the Transvaal.
('4', 367, 2, 8, 840689) They should not under any circumstances make use of false permits; otherwise they will have to suffer imprisonment.
('4', 367, 3, 9, 840805) So far boys under sixteen and women were allowed to enter without a permit; but since the scrutiny of permits started, greater strictness is being exercised on the border.
('4', 367, 3, 10, 840977) Boys under sixteen not accompanied by their fathers and women not accompanied by their husbands are being detained for want of permits.
('4', 367, 3, 11, 841113) A woman proceeding to the Transvaal was made to detrain at Volksrust as she was not accompanied by her husband.
('4', 367, 3, 12, 841225) Indians entering the Transvaal should therefore bear the following things in mind:
('4', 367, 4, 13, 841308) (1) one should not enter with a false Permit;
('4', 367, 5, 14, 841354) (2) unless accompanied by their husbands, women should not enter without a permit;
('4', 367, 6, 15, 841437) (3) boys, even if under sixteen, will be able to enter without a permit only when accompanied by their fathers.

('4', 369, 3, 9, 843884) 328. THE INNER STORY OF THE BALTIC FLEET
('4', 369, 4, 10, 843925) Admiral Rozhdzhestvenskys 2 letter addressed to the Czar setting forth all Acts about the defeat sustained by the Baltic Fleet makes sad reading.
('4', 369, 4, 11, 844071) Though the letter is written by a defeated Admiral, no one will take the reasons he has mentioned therein as excuses to explain his defeat.
('4', 369, 4, 12, 844211) The secret facts, now revealed, clearly show that the crushing defeat sustained by the Fleet was only to be expected.
('4', 369, 4, 13, 844329) The ablest of the worlds naval officers used to say that the Baltic Fleet would teach the Japanese the lesson of their lives.
('4', 369, 4, 14, 844455) They made this forecast because the men of war in the Fleet were gigantic, they were very well equipped with armaments, and could move very swiftly.
('4', 369, 4, 15, 844604) They carried the best artillery of the latest type, and their admirals were considered very capable.
('4', 369, 4, 16, 844705) But, as Admiral Rozhdzhestvensky says, the greatness of the Fleet existed on paper only.
('4', 369, 4, 17, 844794) In his letter to the Czar, he says that, thanks to the corruption in the administration, not only was the building of the ships disgraceful, but they were not in fact properly equipped with the necessary armaments, etc.
('4', 369, 4, 18, 845014) The guns were incapable of discharging shots as desired; enough coal could not be stored in the hulk; the speed of the ships was falsely praised; the engines always made a creaking noise as if in a ramshackle condition; two thirds of the sailors were unfit for their jobs; the gunners had no sense of duty; and the worst of it all was that, after leaving
('4', 369, 5, 19, 845369) 1 Published in two instalments in Indian Opinion issues of July 8 and 15, 1905. 2 Rear Admiral Rozhdzhestvensky, Commander of the Baltic Fleet
('4', 370, 0, 1, 845512) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 371
('4', 370, 1, 2, 845555) Madagascar, all the men on board became rebellious.
('4', 370, 1, 3, 845607) When such a fleet joins battle, defeat can be the only result.
('4', 370, 1, 4, 845670) The letter gives a graphic account of what happened after they left Formosa.
('4', 370, 1, 5, 845747) The Admiral was already aware of this condition of his Fleet; and the fact that he undertook to fight under these circumstances and showed such bravery is sufficient testimony to his loyalty.

('4', 370, 4, 8, 845981) 329. INDENTURED INDIANS IN NATAL
('4', 370, 5, 9, 846014) Mr. James A. Polkinghorne has issued his yearly report ending 31st December last.
('4', 370, 5, 10, 846096) As a contemporary states, the report is belated, as are most of the Government reports in Natal; consequently, there is no doubt there is not the same interest taken in them that would be if they were issued promptly.
('4', 370, 5, 11, 846314) The present report is a document of more than ordinary interest in that it throws a good deal of light on the working of the Immigration Law as to re indenture and poll tax.
('4', 370, 5, 12, 846488) It gives also a more accurate census of the indentured Indian population than hitherto.
('4', 370, 5, 13, 846576) The information given by the Protector is an eye opener.
('4', 370, 5, 14, 846633) The Indian population has increased very considerably during the past three years.
('4', 370, 5, 15, 846716) Between 1876 and 1896, it was 31,712, in 1902, it was 78,004, at the end of 1904, it was 87,980, showing an increase in two years of nearly 10,000; and yet the Protector states in another place that he has not been able to supply the full number applied for in 1902, namely, 19,000. The demand for such labour is so great that it has been necessary to refuse fresh applications altogether.
('4', 370, 5, 16, 847106) The reason for this large increase is obvious.
('4', 370, 5, 17, 847153) This class of labour is very popular and is daily growing in popularity in the Colony.
('4', 370, 5, 18, 847240) The men who come out give great satisfaction, and the bread and butter of thousands of Colonist depends very largely upon a steady inflow of indentured labour from India.
('4', 370, 5, 19, 847411) The moral, too, is obvious.
('4', 370, 5, 20, 847439) The noise that we find here about the Indian being an undesirable citizen is largely hypocritical or selfish.
('4', 370, 5, 21, 847549) We had a striking corroboration of the deduction to be made from the above figures in the observation srecently made by His Excellency the Governor of Natal at the time of the opening of the Agricultural Show, when he stated that the Indian agriculturist was indispensable for the development of the coast lands of Natal.
('4', 370, 6, 22, 847871) The Protector is very much dissatisfied with the working of the Law as to the poll tax and re indenture.
('4', 370, 6, 23, 847976) He states that the Law is very
('4', 371, 0, 1, 848007) 372 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 371, 1, 2, 848049) much evaded, and that it has failed in inducing the time expired Indian to return to India.
('4', 371, 1, 3, 848141) Many of those who have remained have succeeded in escaping the poll tax.
('4', 371, 1, 4, 848214) Last year, 888 men and 345 women completed their indenture under the new Law.
('4', 371, 1, 5, 848292) Out of this number, only 137 men and 32 women offered themselves for re indenture.
('4', 371, 1, 6, 848375) 201 men and 58 women returned to India, 375 men and 146 women paid the tax, and 170 men and 105 women were at the time of drawing up the report unaccounted for.
('4', 371, 1, 7, 848536) Nor is this to be wondered at.
('4', 371, 1, 8, 848567) The poll tax is never at any time a satisfactory mode of raising revenue.
('4', 371, 1, 9, 848641) It has not been a deterrent to settlement in the Colony.
('4', 371, 1, 10, 848698) The framers of the act never expected any such result.
('4', 371, 1, 11, 848753) It constitutes a source of irritation to the indentured Indian.
('4', 371, 1, 12, 848817) It levies from them unjustifiable contribution and constitutes a blot on the fair name of Natal.
('4', 371, 1, 13, 848914) What is more, it is imposed on men whose services are considered, as has been already shown, to be indispensable to the welfare of the Colony.
('4', 371, 1, 14, 849057) Indian Opinion, 5 8 1905
('4', 371, 2, 15, 849082) 330. WHY DID JAPAN WIN?
('4', 371, 3, 16, 849106) The reply given by Baron Komura to a question from the Press representatives in New York wanting to know the cause of Japans victory deserves to be inscribed in ones mind.
('4', 371, 3, 17, 849278) One reason he gave was that Japans demand was just; the second was that she was united; there was no corruption either among the officers or the people; every one did his duty; the Japanese were not indolent; they did not shirk work; and they lived in great simplicity.
('4', 371, 3, 18, 849548) Thanks to this simplicity, they were able to hold their own against the Russians.
('4', 371, 3, 19, 849630) As their needs by way of clothing and food were few, these could be transported to the soldiers in fewer vehicles.
('4', 371, 3, 20, 849745) Consequently, it was not very difficult for the Japanese to transport large numbers of men over long distances.

('4', 378, 12, 23, 859698) 341. FALLING INTO LINE
('4', 378, 13, 24, 859721) Thanks to the action of the Rand Pioneers, the Church Council of Johannesburg has awakened to a sense of their duty.
('4', 378, 13, 25, 859838) A deputation representing the Council has waited on Lord Selborne on the question of the Native land tenure in the Transvaal to urge upon His
('4', 379, 0, 1, 859980) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 379, 1, 2, 860022) Excellency the desirability of not tampering with the rights of the Natives as they existed before the war.
('4', 379, 1, 3, 860130) The Attorney General of the Transvaal has shown how the Native was free to own land in the Transvaal before the war.
('4', 379, 1, 4, 860247) He was able even to cite an instance when the late President Kruger 1 informed certain petitioners, who wanted to curtail the rights of the Natives regarding land, that he could not comply with their request.
('4', 379, 1, 5, 860456) It is true that the Natives were not, in practice, allowed to have their titles registered in their own names, but as the Attorney General has clearly shown, the registration of a Native title in the name of the Commissioner for Native Affairs did not clothe that official with any discretionary power.
('4', 379, 1, 6, 860759) He was bound to take transfer in his name in trust for a Native and was equally bound to take in any other Native as a cestui que trust at the instance of the original holder.
('4', 379, 1, 7, 860935) In reply to the clamour of the anti Native agitators led by Sir George Farrar, 2 Sir Richard Solomon has, much against his own inclinations, promised to introduce legislation to legalise the practice of registration of Native titles in favour of the Commissioner for Native Affairs.
('4', 379, 1, 8, 861218) Against this, the Rand Pioneers have again commenced an agitation.
('4', 379, 1, 9, 861285) They insist on the Native Commissioner having the power to refuse to act as trustee.
('4', 379, 1, 10, 861370) If the request were granted, it would undoubtedly take away from the right of the Native to hold land as it existed before the war.
('4', 379, 1, 11, 861502) It is against agitation of this nature that the Church Council has raised its voice.
('4', 379, 1, 12, 861587) The deputation led by Mr. Hosken made it clear to Lord Selborne that the treatment the Coloured races have been receiving in the Transvaal since British occupation is worse than before.
('4', 379, 1, 13, 861773) He and his fellow members also showed that the war was justified in the opinion of many because they considered it a war of emancipation.
('4', 379, 1, 14, 861911) The Rev.
('4', 379, 1, 15, 861920) Mr. Philips said that he went at his own expense to England to preach the crusade because he could not bear the hardships that were inflicted under the Boer regime on the Coloured races.
('4', 379, 1, 16, 862107) But the reverend gentleman now found that these races were no better off under the British rule.
('4', 379, 2, 17, 862204) Lord Selbornes reply was as was to be expected.
('4', 379, 2, 18, 862252) He had not sufficiently studied the question.
('4', 379, 2, 19, 862298) He could not, therefore, pronounce an opinion.
('4', 379, 2, 20, 862345) But His Excellency added: If in any respect the British administration is unjust to the Native, civilised or uncivilised, it is a blot and a stain on our administration, and one
('4', 379, 3, 21, 862523) 1 Stephanus Johannes Paulus Kruger, (1825 1904), Boer leader, President of the Transvaal, 1883 1900 2 A nominated member of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal.
('4', 380, 0, 1, 862689) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 381
('4', 380, 1, 2, 862732) which I feel personally as an implication of disgrace.
('4', 380, 1, 3, 862787) These are the words spoken by one who is the ruler of the Transvaal.
('4', 380, 1, 4, 862856) May His Excellency have sufficient courage and strength to initiate the policy he has thus boldly enunciated!
('4', 380, 1, 5, 862966) The interview is not without significance for the British Indians.
('4', 380, 1, 6, 863033) What the deputation submitted to His Excellency applies equally to them.
('4', 380, 1, 7, 863106) And the policy laid down by Lord Selborne is the policy applicable to all British subjects.
('4', 380, 1, 8, 863198) It is a matter for congratulation that in Lord Selborne the Transvaal has a Governor and South Africa a High Commissioner who is determined to hold the scales evenly between conflicting interests.

('4', 380, 3, 10, 863421) 342. THE NEW LAWS OF NATAL

('4', 381, 2, 5, 864984) 344. TREATY BETWEEN ENGLAND AND JAPAN
('4', 381, 3, 6, 865022) As the time for reviewing the treaty between England and Japan draws near, it is being discussed in English political circles.
('4', 381, 3, 7, 865149) A peace treaty, to hold good for five years, was signed between the two countries on January 30, 1902. But, if by the end of the fourth year, no notice to terminate the treaty was given by either party, the treaty would continue to be in force even beyond the five years, and thereafter the party desiring to end the treaty would have to give a years notice.
('4', 381, 3, 8, 865508) Moreover, if at the end of the treaty period either of the parties was engaged in war, the treaty would remain effective till peace was restored.
('4', 381, 3, 9, 865654) Moreover, if either party had to go to war against a third power, the other contracting party should strive to prevent any other power from joining it.
('4', 381, 3, 10, 865806) And if any such power rendered help to the party opposing either of the signatories to the treaty, the other signatory should rush to the help of the former.
('4', 381, 3, 11, 865964) If, therefore, a notice in accordance with the above terms to end the treaty is not served by either party by January 30, next year, it will remain operative beyond five years.
('4', 381, 3, 12, 866141) If on the contrary such a notice is served in the meanwhile and Japans war with Russia continues, the treaty would remain in force till the end of the war, even if the period of the treaty as originally stipulated had come to an end.
('4', 381, 3, 13, 866375) This treaty has proved very advantageous to both England and Japan.
('4', 381, 3, 14, 866443) As a matter of fact, the whole world can be said to have benefited from it.
('4', 381, 3, 15, 866519) For, if a third power had entered the war to help Russia, England would have been obliged to go to the aid of Japan, and this would have obviously disturbed world peace.
('4', 381, 3, 16, 866689) There is, therefore, every reason to hope that this treaty will continue further.
('4', 381, 3, 17, 866771) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 12 8 1905
('4', 382, 0, 1, 866813) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 383

('4', 382, 16, 28, 868139) I have read over these lectures in English again and I must say that there is
('4', 382, 17, 29, 868217) 1 A series of four lectures on Hindu Religion.
('4', 382, 17, 30, 868264) Vide Hinduism, 4 3 1905, Letter to Dadabhai Naoroji, 11 3 1905 & Lectures on Religion, 15 4 1905
('4', 383, 0, 1, 868361) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 383, 1, 2, 868403) not a single hard word about any religion.
('4', 383, 2, 3, 868446) I have expressed appreciation of every religion and pointed out the distinctive merit of each.

('4', 385, 1, 2, 871454) side, the people of Bengal argue that the Bengalis are quite distinct from the Assamese; they are highly educated, and they have been living together for generations.
('4', 385, 1, 3, 871621) It would therefore be an act of grave injustice to separate and thus weaken them and tag large numbers of them on to Assam.
('4', 385, 1, 4, 871745) A lot of discussion has already taken place over this matter, and a few days ago Mr. Brodrick declared that he had approved Lord Curzons proposal.

('4', 385, 1, 11, 872477) We must admit that our people have learnt these tactics from China.

('4', 386, 2, 3, 873997) There are many reasons why the British should be ruling over us and why we are in such a deplorable condition.
('4', 386, 2, 4, 874108) One of the reasons is that in modern times the British seem to have produced a larger number than we of brave and pious men and women of high principles.
('4', 386, 2, 5, 874262) Nevertheless we believe that we are bound to benefit from a knowledge and constant contemplation of the lives of such devout men and women, and we therefore propose to give the stories of their lives from time to time.
('4', 386, 2, 6, 874481) We hope that the readers of this journal will read their lives and follow them in practice and thus encourage us.
('4', 386, 2, 7, 874595) We have suggested earlier that each one of our subscribers should maintain a file of Indian Opinion.
('4', 386, 2, 8, 874696) We remind them of it on this occasion.
('4', 386, 2, 9, 874735) Mrs. Elizabeth Fry lived in England a century ago.
('4', 386, 2, 10, 874786) She was a very religious minded lady and it was her constant concern to help mitigate the sufferings of man.
('4', 386, 2, 11, 874895) Though herself a chronic invalid she did not care; she was not to be daunted by personal suffering.
('4', 386, 2, 12, 874995) There is a prison called the Newgate Prison in England where, a hundred years ago, men and women prisoners were huddled together somehow and lived quite uncared for.
('4', 386, 2, 13, 875161) They were in an extremely bad state.
('4', 386, 2, 14, 875198) Crime among them, instead of diminishing, was on the increase.
('4', 386, 2, 15, 875261) Their life was more like that of cattle.
('4', 386, 2, 16, 875302) Consequently, the condition of Newgate prisoners who were released after their sentences became very pitiable.
('4', 386, 2, 17, 875413) This misery, the good Elizabeth could not bear to see.Her heart was deeply grieved, and she dedicated her life to the amelioration of their condition.
('4', 386, 2, 18, 875564) Having obtained permission of the authorities, she began helping, in particular, the women prisoners, whom she used to comfort.
('4', 386, 2, 19, 875692) But she did not stop here.
('4', 386, 2, 20, 875719) By her writings and personal effort she got a number of reforms introduced through the authorities.
('4', 386, 2, 21, 875819) As a result of her efforts the condition of prisoners improved much.
('4', 386, 2, 22, 875888) But this she considered quite inadequate.
('4', 386, 2, 23, 875930) In those days, prisoners used to be deported to Australia.
('4', 386, 2, 24, 875989) They were subjected to great harassment while on board ships.
('4', 386, 2, 25, 876051) Even the honour of women prisoners was not safe.
('4', 386, 2, 26, 876100) Elizabeth saw that all her good work was being undone on board the ships while the prisoners were being thus transported.
('4', 386, 2, 27, 876222) To remedy this evil, she visited the ships at great personal inconvenience.
('4', 386, 2, 28, 876298) At last she succeeded in putting an end to the
('4', 386, 3, 29, 876345) 1 Elizabeth Fry, (1780 1845), belonged to the Society of Friends.
('4', 386, 3, 30, 876411) She was a pioneer of prison reform.
('4', 387, 0, 1, 876447) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 387, 1, 2, 876489) sufferings of prisoners on the ships.
('4', 387, 1, 3, 876527) Further, she effected some improvement in the miserable condition of the prisoners in Australia; and a law was accordingly passed to the effect that prisoners, on reaching Australia, were to be passed on to others for service after being trained there for six months.
('4', 387, 1, 4, 876795) While thus sharing in the sufferings of many unfortunate persons, this good lady forgot her own suffering, and breathed her last, praying to God.

('4', 392, 5, 16, 889423) It is believed that the greatest and the noblest man of the last century was Abraham Lincoln.
('4', 392, 5, 17, 889517) He was born in America in 1809 of very poor parents.

('4', 392, 6, 22, 889951) At one place he got the job of a shop assistant.
('4', 392, 6, 23, 890000) He was then twenty years old.
('4', 392, 6, 24, 890030) Once he had a job it occurred to him that he might study further.
('4', 392, 6, 25, 890096) Thereupon, he bought a few books and began to study them by himself.

('4', 393, 1, 5, 890562) No sooner had the thought occurred to him than he decided, in accordance with American practice, to stand for election to the Senate.

('4', 393, 1, 7, 890753) He put up a strong fight; but he met with defeat as he was yet an unknown man, while his opponent was well known.
('4', 393, 1, 8, 890867) But the defeat only whetted his zeal.
('4', 393, 2, 9, 890905) His fervour became more intense.
('4', 393, 2, 10, 890938) Only a person who has a clear picture in his mind of the America of those days, can properly appreciate Lincolns virtues and his services.
('4', 393, 2, 11, 891077) From north to south, America was at this time a camp of slaves.
('4', 393, 2, 12, 891141) Nobody saw anything wrong in openly selling Negroes and keeping them in slavery.
('4', 393, 2, 13, 891222) The high and the low, the rich and the poor saw nothing strange in owning slaves.
('4', 393, 2, 14, 891304) No one thought it was wrong to do so.
('4', 393, 2, 15, 891342) Religious minded men, priests and the like saw nothing amiss and did not protest against the system of slavery being kept up.
('4', 393, 2, 16, 891468) Some even encouraged it, and all of them thought that slavery also was a divine dispensation and that the Negroes were born to it.
('4', 393, 2, 17, 891599) Few could then see that the slave trade was very wicked and irreligious.
('4', 393, 2, 18, 891672) And even those who did, preferred to remain silent, being unable to assert themselves.
('4', 393, 2, 19, 891759) There were some who were content to play a minor role in the amelioration of the condition of slaves.
('4', 393, 2, 20, 891861) Even today our hair stands on end to hear the accounts of the atrocities inflicted on slaves.
('4', 393, 2, 21, 891955) They were tied up and beaten; they were forced to work, they were branded and handcuffed.
('4', 393, 2, 22, 892045) And all this was not done just to one person but to all of them.
('4', 393, 2, 23, 892110) It may be said without fear of contradiction that Lincoln alone, of all men, made and put into execution his resolution to change the ideas of men, ideas which were indelibly carved on their minds, to wage war against those hundreds of thousands of men who depended for their living on the system and to set free the slaves from bondage.
('4', 393, 2, 24, 892448) He was so tender by nature, his faith in God was so great, and his compassion so deep that he began to convert the minds of men through his speeches and writings as well as by the example of his own life.
('4', 393, 2, 25, 892653) Eventually there came into existence two parties in America: one headed by Lincoln, another by his opponents; and a big civil war broke out;but Lincoln remained undaunted.
('4', 393, 2, 26, 892825) By this time he had risen so high up the ladder that he was already the President.
('4', 393, 2, 27, 892908) The war went on for many years, but Lincoln abolished slavery from the whole of North America by l858 9. The bonds of the slaves were broken, and wherever Lincolns name was mentioned, he was hailed as a great emancipator of men in distress.
('4', 393, 2, 28, 893149) The language of the powerful speeches he delivered during
('4', 394, 0, 1, 893207) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 395
('4', 394, 1, 2, 893250) these stormy days is so sublime that they rank very high in English literature.
('4', 394, 2, 3, 893330) Although he had achieved such eminence Lincoln remained full of humility.
('4', 394, 2, 4, 893404) He always believed that a powerful nation or individual ought to use that power to remove the miseries of the poor and the weak, not to crush them.
('4', 394, 2, 5, 893552) Though America was his motherland and he was an American, he regarded the whole world as his native land.
('4', 394, 2, 6, 893658) Just when he was at the height of his glory, and despite the fact that he was such a good man, some wicked men felt that he had ruined many people by abolishing slavery.
('4', 394, 2, 7, 893828) So when it was known for certain that Lincoln was going to visit a theatre, a plot was hatched to assassinate him.
('4', 394, 2, 8, 893943) Even the players at the theatre had been seduced, and a leading actor had undertaken to shoot him.
('4', 394, 2, 9, 894042) As Lincoln was sitting in his special box, the despicable fellow entered it, closed the door after him and shot at Lincoln.
('4', 394, 2, 10, 894166) The good man fell dead.
('4', 394, 2, 11, 894190) The people who witnessed this dreadful deed tore the assassin to pieces before he could be taken to a law court.
('4', 394, 2, 12, 894303) 1 In this tragic manner occurred the death of the greatest President of America.
('4', 394, 2, 13, 894384) It may safely be said that Lincoln sacrificed his life in order to put an end to the sufferings of others.
('4', 394, 2, 14, 894491) But Lincoln can be said to be still alive; for the changes he made in the American Constitution are still in force.
('4', 394, 2, 15, 894607) And Lincolns name will be known as long as America endures.
('4', 394, 2, 16, 894667) It will thus be seen that Lincoln has become immortal, for his greatness consisted not in his talent or his wealth, but in his innate goodness.
('4', 394, 2, 17, 894811) A nation that has such good qualities as Lincolns is bound to rise.

('4', 396, 1, 2, 896556) 359. LETTER TO CHIEF SECRETARY FOR PERMITS
('4', 396, 2, 3, 896599) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('4', 396, 3, 4, 896626) P. O. BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, September 1, 1905
('4', 396, 4, 5, 896674) TO THE CHIEF SECRETARY FOR PERMITS P. O. BOX 1199 JOHANNESBURG
('4', 396, 6, 6, 896737) My Association has been informed that a new rule has been introduced in the Permit Office whereby British Indian refugees are required to furnish two European references instead of any two known references, as hitherto.
('4', 396, 6, 7, 896957) My Association submits that the proposed rule is, first, an insult to the British Indian community in that it implies want of faith in Indian testimony, and secondly, is impracticable in that there are few Indians who are known to the European residents by name.
('4', 396, 6, 8, 897220) Store keepers, assistants, salesmen and domestic servants in the employ of British Indians rarely come into contact with Europeans, and to expect them to produce European references would be tantamount to rejection of their application for a permit.
('4', 396, 6, 9, 897470) Thirdly, it would put a premium on perjury, as it is quite conceivable that a few unscrupulous Indians will not find it difficult to find a few unscrupulous Europeans who would be prepared to perjure themselves for a consideration.
('4', 396, 7, 10, 897702) My Association, therefore, submits that the only safeguard is to be found in the respectability of references, irrespective of race or colour.
('4', 396, 7, 11, 897845) Even then it is quite likely that some cases of perjury would happen, but that would be purely a matter for action against those who would lend themselves to such practices.
('4', 396, 7, 12, 898019) One or two successful prosecutions would certainly do away with them.
('4', 396, 7, 13, 898089) At the same time, my Association draws your attention to the fact that such questionable practices in the face of enormous temptations have been comparatively rare in connection with the permits.
('4', 396, 7, 14, 898285) It is indisputable that there were over 15,000 British Indian male adults resident in the Transvaal before War.
('4', 396, 7, 15, 898397) Only about 12,000 appear on your register.
('4', 396, 7, 16, 898440) It is reasonable, therefore, to presume that most of the men who have received their permits are pre War residents of the Transvaal.
('4', 397, 0, 1, 898573) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 397, 1, 2, 898615) My Association respectfully trusts that the rule will be withdrawn, and that the refugees who are now awaiting permission to return will have their applications granted without delay, as, in accordance with the information in possession of my Association, theyare suffering very severe inconvenience and loss.

('4', 397, 5, 16, 899670) He has acquired through his own labours over 300 acres of land near Phoenix.
('4', 397, 5, 17, 899747) There he imparts education to his brethren, teaching them various trades and crafts and preparing them for the battle of life.

('4', 397, 5, 20, 900170) It was unfair to burden the Negroes with taxes; also it was like cutting down the very branch one was sitting on.

('4', 397, 5, 24, 900501) For them there was no country other than South Africa; and to deprive them of their rights over lands, etc., was like banishing them from their home.

('4', 398, 4, 7, 901295) 361. COUNT TOLSTOY
('4', 398, 5, 8, 901314) It is believed that, in the western world at any rate, there is no man so talented, learned and as ascetic as Count Tolstoy.
('4', 398, 5, 9, 901439) Though he is now nearly eighty years old, he is quite healthy, industrious and mentally alert.
('4', 398, 6, 10, 901534) Tolstoy was born of a noble family in Russia.
('4', 398, 6, 11, 901580) His parents had enormous wealth, which he inherited.
('4', 398, 6, 12, 901633) He is himself a Russian nobleman, and has, in his youth, rendered very good service to his country by fighting gallantly in the Crimean War.
('4', 398, 6, 13, 901774) In those days, like the other noblemen of his time, he used to enjoy all the pleasures of the world, kept mistresses, drank and was strongly addicted to smoking.
('4', 398, 6, 14, 901936) However, when he saw the carnage and bloodshed during the war, his mind brimmed over with compassion.
('4', 398, 6, 15, 902038) His ideas changed; he began a study of his own religion and read the Bible.
('4', 398, 6, 16, 902114) He read the life of Jesus Christ which made a deep impression on his mind.
('4', 398, 6, 17, 902189) Not satisfied with the then current Russian translation of the Bible, he studied Hebrew, the language in which it was originally written, and continued his researches into the Bible.
('4', 398, 6, 18, 902372) It was also about this time that he discovered in himself a great talent for writing.
('4', 398, 6, 19, 902458) He wrote a very effective book on the evil consequences of war.
('4', 398, 6, 20, 902522) His fame spread throughout Europe.
('4', 398, 6, 21, 902557) To improve the morals of the people he wrote several novels which can be equalled by few books in Europe.
('4', 398, 6, 22, 902663) The views expressed by him in all these books were so very advanced that the Russian clergy were displeased with him, and he was excommunicated.
('4', 398, 6, 23, 902808) Disregarding all this, he kept up his efforts and began to propagate his ideas.
('4', 398, 6, 24, 902888) His writings had a great effect on his own mind.
('4', 398, 6, 25, 902937) He gave up his wealth and took to a life of poverty.
('4', 398, 6, 26, 902990) He has lived like a peasant for many years now and earns his needs by his own labour.
('4', 398, 6, 27, 903076) He has given up all his vices, eats very simple food and has it in him no longer to hurt any living being by thought, word or
('4', 399, 0, 1, 903202) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 399, 1, 2, 903244) He spends all his time in good works and prayer.
('4', 399, 1, 3, 903293) He believes that: 1. In this world men should not accumulate wealth; 2. no matter how much evil a person does to us, we should always do good to him.
('4', 399, 1, 4, 903443) Such is the Commandment of God, and also His law; 3. no one should take part in fighting; 4. it is sinful to wield political power, as it leads to many of the evils in the world; 5. man is born to do his duty to his Creator; he should therefore pay more attention to his duties than to his rights; 6. agriculture is the true occupation of man.
('4', 399, 1, 5, 903787) It is therefore contrary to divine law to establish large cities, to employ hundreds of thousands for minding machines in factories so that a few can wallow in riches by exploiting the helplessness and poverty of the many.
('4', 399, 1, 6, 904010) These views he has very beautifully supported by examples from various religions and other old texts.
('4', 399, 1, 7, 904112) There are today thousands of men in Europe who have adopted Tolstoys way of life.
('4', 399, 1, 8, 904194) They have given up all their worldly goods and taken to a very simple life.
('4', 399, 2, 9, 904270) Tolstoy is still writing with great energy.
('4', 399, 2, 10, 904314) Though himself a Russian, he has written many strong and bitter things against Russia concerning the Russo Japanese War.
('4', 399, 2, 11, 904435) He has addressed a very pungent and effective letter to the Czar in regard to the war.
('4', 399, 2, 12, 904522) Selfish officers view him with bitterness, but they, and even the Czar, fear and respect him.
('4', 399, 2, 13, 904616) Such is the power of his goodness and godly living that millions of peasants are ever ready to carry out his wish no sooner than it is spoken.

('4', 399, 5, 16, 904800) 362. THE RISE OF JAPAN
('4', 399, 6, 17, 904823) The world over, all eyes are turned today towards Japan.
('4', 399, 6, 18, 904880) Every one admires that countrys bravery and sagacity.
('4', 399, 6, 19, 904934) Count Okuma, a former Minister of Japan, has written an article in the North American Review, wherein he says that the present greatness of Japan is the result of reforms carried out over the centuries.
('4', 399, 6, 20, 905137) She had remained backward in the eyes of the world simply because of her defective system of education.
('4', 399, 6, 21, 905241) Japan found that she could not possibly keep
('4', 400, 0, 1, 905286) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 401
('4', 400, 1, 2, 905329) foreigners out of the country.
('4', 400, 1, 3, 905360) She therefore thought of sending out her sons to foreign lands for learning the various sciences and arts.
('4', 400, 1, 4, 905467) The patriotism shown by her in this regard saved the countrys prestige.
('4', 400, 1, 5, 905539) She introduced the best educational methods from foreign lands.
('4', 400, 1, 6, 905603) She also introduced compulsory education for boys and girls.
('4', 400, 1, 7, 905664) At the same time, she did not fail to attend to crafts and industry.
('4', 400, 1, 8, 905733) She employed foreign experts until her own young men and women had completed their training.
('4', 400, 1, 9, 905826) When the educational scheme came into full operation, the Mikado issued an order to be read out in every school.
('4', 400, 1, 10, 905939) It ran: May you, our subjects, be devoted to your parents; be loving towards your brothers and sisters; live in peace and amity with your husband or wife; be straightforward in your conduct; be increasingly good and helpful to others; develop your virtues and intellect; bring credit to your country by benevolent deeds; honour the laws in accordance with the Constitution and, when occasion demands, throw yourself into public service and show your valour. Speaking in New York, Baron Keneko said that this was the foundation of Japans greatness.
('4', 400, 1, 11, 906487) For soldiers and sailors also the following seven instructions were issued: l.
('4', 400, 1, 12, 906566) Be straightforward and loyal, and stay clear of untruth; 2. respect your superiors, be loyal to your comrades, and eschew arrogance and injustice; 3. obey the orders of your superiors without hesitation; 4. be courageous and brave, and give up unmanliness and cowardice; 5. do not boast of cruel deeds of daring; do not insult or quarrel with others; 6. be virtuous and thrifty; avoid extravagance; 7. preserve your self respect, and guard against barbarity and niggardliness.
('4', 400, 1, 13, 907043) These orders of the Japanese Emperor have promoted virtue in the people, the army and the officials and welded all of them into a united nation.
('4', 400, 1, 14, 907188) The greatness of Japan today owes much to the above orders.

('4', 401, 4, 7, 907608) We have come to know that it is the intention of the Government to change the Higher Grade Indian School at Durban into a school for Coloured children generally, and to observe no distinction as to girls and boys.
('4', 401, 4, 8, 907822) We humbly submit that the decision to open the school for all Coloured children is unjust to the Indian community, and is a departure from the assurance given by the then Minister of Education, as also Sir Albert Hime and Mr. Robert Russell, that the school will be reserved for Indian children only.
('4', 401, 4, 9, 908123) It was established when the Government decided not to admit Indian children to the general schools in the Colony, 2 and we understand that even then a question was raised as to establishing a school for all Coloured children, but after mature consideration the Government decided to give a school to the Indian children alone, and it was on that account that it was given the name it bears today.
('4', 401, 4, 10, 908520) Moreover, the term Coloured children is an elastic term.
('4', 401, 4, 11, 908577) Everyone knows the meaning ofthe expression British Indian, but there is no fixed meaning for the term Coloured person, and seeing that the Government have adopted a policy of making distinctions, it is only fair that British Indians should have in the largest town in the Colony a school reserved for them.
('4', 401, 4, 12, 908885) The Superintendent of Education, the other day, was pleased to say that the Indian parents did not object in the other places in Natal to such a mixture.
('4', 401, 4, 13, 909039) We respectfully submit, however, that it is hardly fair to draw an analogy from the small townships of Natal.
('4', 401, 4, 14, 909149) It is Durban which contains the largest free and well to do Indian population, and it is, therefore, only natural that the difficulty about such matters would be
('4', 401, 5, 15, 909311) 1 Vide Speech at Indian School, 21 12 1900 & Speech at Indian School, 28 6 1901. 2 Vide Notes, 3 9 1900.

('4', 402, 1, 2, 909459) felt keenly in Durban.
('4', 402, 1, 3, 909482) As to the question of non separation of girls and boys, we can only say, as parents having had considerable experience, and speaking for Indian sentiment, that the decision is calculated to give rise to such legitimate complaint.
('4', 402, 1, 4, 909712) There are not only practical serious objections to such a course being followed, but in many instances there is also the religious sentiment to be considered, and we doubt not that the Government will be pleased to give full consideration to such sentiments.
('4', 402, 1, 5, 909971) In conclusion, therefore, we hope that the instructions regarding the two matters referred to would be withdrawn, and that the Govern ment would be pleased to carry out the assurance given to the Indian community when the Higher Grade Indian School was established.

('4', 403, 1, 2, 911309) 365. ATROCITIES ON CHINESE MINERS
('4', 403, 2, 3, 911343) In his reply to a question by a Member of Parliament on the above subject, Mr. Lyttelton had promised to make an inquiry and to put an end to the flogging.
('4', 403, 2, 4, 911499) The description of how the Chinese are flogged, given by The Daily Express of Johannesburg, makes pitiful reading.
('4', 403, 2, 5, 911614) We give below a summary of the same.
('4', 403, 2, 6, 911651) The correspondent says that the facts given by him have been either personally witnessed by him, or are supported by the evidence of those who had ordered thousands of men to be flogged.
('4', 403, 2, 7, 911838) On an average 42 Chinese were flogged in a Johannesburg mine every day, not excluding even Sundays, towards the beginning of this year.
('4', 403, 2, 8, 911974) In the first instance, the Overseer complained against an offending miner, who was then taken to the office of the Compound Manager; the latter, in accordance with the nature of the offence, ordered ten, fifteen or twenty strokes to be administered.
('4', 403, 2, 9, 912224) Then two Chinese policemen took him about fifteen steps away; the offender stopped at the policemans word of command, took off his trousers and other clothes, and lay with face to the ground; one of the policemen held down the legs of the offender and the other his head, then the executor of the punishment beat him mildly or violently, according to orders, on his back with a wooden stick three feet long and with a flat end three inches broad.
('4', 403, 2, 10, 912671) If in the meanwhile, the man made the slightest movement, unable to bear the pain, another pressed him down with his foot on his back, and the number of strokes ordered was completed.
('4', 403, 2, 11, 912855) In some of the mines, the whip is used instead of the stick 1, and its strokes are so severe that they cause the flesh to swell and cut the skin.
('4', 403, 2, 12, 913001) When Mr. Cook was Manager at the Norsedippe mines, he used to order any Chinaman, who failed to do 36 inches of drilling, to be punished.
('4', 403, 2, 13, 913139) His method of punishment was even more cruel than the one described above.
('4', 403, 2, 14, 913214) That gentleman ordered the use of stout sticks and the blows to be given on the back of the thighs where they were most unbearable; the full number of blows was inflicted even if blood streamed out from the wounds.
('4', 403, 2, 15, 913429) Sometimes the injury was so severe that the poor Chinaman had to be sent to a hospital.
('4', 403, 2, 16, 913517) One Mr. Place was later appointed to replace the cruel Mr. Cook.
('4', 403, 2, 17, 913582) Being considered rather a gentleman among thieves, he ordered Bubber batons to be used instead of sticks.

('4', 404, 5, 19, 915718) We have in an earlier issue of the journal published an account of the career of the benevolent lady, Elizabeth Fry.
('4', 404, 5, 20, 915835) Just as she brought about an improvement in the condition of prisoners and devoted her life to their service, so also Florence Nightingale sacrificed herself in the service of the men in the army.

('4', 404, 6, 22, 916110) 1 (1820 1910), famous nurse and pioneer of hospital reform

('4', 405, 1, 7, 916634) Surgery was not as efficacious then as it is today.

('4', 405, 1, 10, 916932) She was heart stricken to learn of the sufferings of the soldiers.
('4', 405, 1, 11, 916999) Born of a noble and rich family, she gave up her life of ease and comfort and set out to nurse the wounded and the ailing, followed by many other ladies.
('4', 405, 1, 12, 917153) She left her home on October 21, 1854. She rendered strenuous service in the battle of Inkerman 1. At that time there were neither beds nor other amenities for the wounded.
('4', 405, 1, 13, 917326) There were 10,000 wounded under the charge of this single woman.
('4', 405, 1, 14, 917391) The death rate among the wounded which was 42 per cent.
('4', 405, 1, 15, 917447) before she arrived, immediately came down to 31 per cent., and ultimately to 5 per cent.
('4', 405, 1, 16, 917536) This was miraculous, but can be easily visualized.
('4', 405, 1, 17, 917587) If bleeding could be stopped, the wounds bandaged and the requisite diet given, the lives of many thousands would doubtless be saved.
('4', 405, 1, 18, 917721) The only thing necessary was kindness and nursing, which Miss Nightingale provided.
('4', 405, 1, 19, 917805) It is said that she did an amount of work which big and strong men were unable to do.
('4', 405, 1, 20, 917891) She used to work nearly twenty hours, day and night.
('4', 405, 1, 21, 917944) When the women working under her went to sleep, she, lamp in hand, went out alone at midnight to the patients bedside, comforted them, and herself gave them whatever food and other things were necessary.
('4', 405, 1, 22, 918148) She was not afraid of going even to the battle front, and did not know what fear was.
('4', 405, 1, 23, 918234) She feared only God.
('4', 405, 1, 24, 918255) Knowing that one has to die some day or other, she readily bore whatever hardships were necessary in order to alleviate the sufferings of others.
('4', 405, 2, 25, 918401) This lady remained single all her life, which she spent in such good work.
('4', 405, 2, 26, 918476) It is said that, when she died, thousands of soldiers wept bitterly like little children, as though they had lost their own mother.
('4', 405, 3, 27, 918608) No wonder that a country where such women are born is prosperous.

('4', 408, 4, 9, 922907) 371. EARTHQUAKE IN ITALY
('4', 408, 5, 10, 922932) A severe earthquake rocked Calabria 1 in Italy a few days ago rendering thousands of people homeless and pitiably crying for aid.
('4', 408, 5, 11, 923062) The King of Italy has donated 4,000 for relief.
('4', 408, 5, 12, 923110) The numbers of those either dead or seriously injured are 300 at Parghelly, 200 at Geplo, and 2,000 at Martereno.
('4', 408, 5, 13, 923224) The big quake was followed by another mild one after two or three days.
('4', 408, 5, 14, 923296) The people are panic stricken and are running about from place to place, and some are even leaving the country.
('4', 408, 5, 15, 923408) It is estimated that the injured and the dead total 5,000. The earthquake of 1857 which involved a larger area took a toll of about ten thousand lives.
('4', 408, 5, 16, 923560) Calabria has frequently had such calamities.
('4', 408, 5, 17, 923605) During the 75 years preceding 1857, the total loss of life was 1,11,000, giving an annual average of 1,500 lives.
('4', 408, 5, 18, 923719) There have been several earthquakes in Calabria during the last fifty years, but none of them caused so much damage as the present one.
('4', 408, 5, 19, 923855) Many villages have been wiped out, and about a hundred thousand people have been rendered homeless.
('4', 408, 5, 20, 923955) The government of the country is trying its utmost to give them all possible help.

('4', 409, 2, 3, 924221) There are many Chinese living in Johannesburg.
('4', 409, 2, 4, 924268) They cannot be said to be economically better off than the Indians.
('4', 409, 2, 5, 924336) Many of them are merely artisans.
('4', 409, 2, 6, 924370) A few days ago I had the occasion to observe how they lived.
('4', 409, 2, 7, 924431) On seeing their way of life and comparing it with our own, I felt very sad.
('4', 409, 3, 8, 924507) They have founded the Chinese Association for public work, and for this purpose, they maintain a spacious hall.
('4', 409, 3, 9, 924619) It is a strong structure built of brick and is kept clean and tidy.
('4', 409, 3, 10, 924687) They meet the expenses for its maintenance by sub letting the large plot of land they have taken out on lease.
('4', 409, 3, 11, 924798) Since the Chinese have no facilities for lodging, they have started a Cantonese Club, which serves as a meeting place, a lodge and also as a library.
('4', 409, 3, 12, 924948) They have acquired for the Club land on a long lease and have built on it a pucca one storeyed building.
('4', 409, 3, 13, 925053) There they all live in great cleanliness and do not stint themselves in the matter of living space; and seen within and from outside, it would look like some good European Club.
('4', 409, 3, 14, 925231) They have in it separate rooms marked drawing, dining, meeting, committee room and the Secretarys room and the library, and do not use any room except for the purpose for which it is intended.
('4', 409, 3, 15, 925424) Other rooms adjoining these are let out as bedrooms.
('4', 409, 3, 16, 925477) It is such a fine and clean place that any Chinese gentleman visiting the town can be put up there.
('4', 409, 3, 17, 925577) The entrance fee is 5, and the annual subscription varies according to the members profession.
('4', 409, 3, 18, 925672) The club has about 150 members who meet every Sunday and amuse themselves with games.
('4', 409, 3, 19, 925758) The members can avail themselves of club facilities on week days also.
('4', 409, 4, 20, 925829) We have nothing similar to boast of.
('4', 409, 4, 21, 925866) In no city Of South Africa have we a place of our own where an Indian visitor can be put up.
('4', 409, 4, 22, 925959) Our hospitality is no doubt excellent, but it is bound to be limited.
('4', 409, 4, 23, 926029) If we had something like a club, it could be used in a variety of ways.
('4', 409, 4, 24, 926101) It would be very profitable if people could spend their leisure hours at such a public place instead of in one anothers homes: no single person is taxed thereby; friendship grows; and our prestige, too, is enhanced.
('4', 409, 4, 25, 926317) The rules of cleanliness also can be better observed.
('4', 409, 4, 26, 926371) There is no doubt that this activity is quite essential and can be carried on without much cost.
('4', 409, 4, 27, 926468) It is up to us to take a lesson from the club founded by the

('4', 410, 4, 7, 926854) 373. ISHWARCHANDRA VIDYASAGAR
('4', 410, 5, 8, 926884) We have already given in these columns brief biographical sketches of a few good men and women of Europe.
('4', 410, 5, 9, 926990) The purpose of these sketches is to enlighten our readers and to enable them to make their own lives fruitful by emulating these men and women.
('4', 410, 6, 10, 927134) The strong movement that is being carried on in Bengal to boycott British goods is of no mean significance.
('4', 410, 6, 11, 927242) Such a movement has been possible there because education is more widespread and the people in Bengal are more alert than in other parts of India.
('4', 410, 6, 12, 927389) Sir Henry Cotton has remarked that Bengal holds sway from Calcutta to Peshawar.
('4', 410, 6, 13, 927469) It is necessary to know the reasons for this.
('4', 410, 7, 14, 927515) There is no gainsaying the fact that a nations rise or fall depends upon its great men.
('4', 410, 7, 15, 927603) The people who produce good men cannot but be influenced by them.
('4', 410, 7, 16, 927669) The main reason for the special distinction that we find in Bengal is that many great men were born there during the last century.
('4', 410, 7, 17, 927800) Beginning with Rammohan Roy 1, one heroic figure after another has raised Bengal to a position higher than that of the other provinces.
('4', 410, 7, 18, 927936) It can be said that Ishwarchandra Vidyasagar was the greatest among them.
('4', 410, 7, 19, 928010) Vidyasagar, which means an ocean of learning, was an honorific of Ishwarchandra, conferred on him by the pundits of Calcutta for his profound Sanskrit learning.
('4', 410, 7, 20, 928171) But Ishwarchandra was not an ocean of learning only; he was an ocean of compassion, of generosity, as well as of many other virtues.
('4', 410, 7, 21, 928304) He was a Hindu, and a Brahmin too.
('4', 410, 7, 22, 928339) But to him, Brahmin and Sudra, Hindu and Muslim, were all alike.
('4', 410, 7, 23, 928404) In any good deeds that he performed, he made no distinction between high and low.
('4', 410, 7, 24, 928486) When his professor had an attack of cholera, he himself nursed him.
('4', 410, 7, 25, 928554) As the professor was poor, Ishwarchandra called in the doctors at his own cost and himself attended to the patients toilet.
('4', 410, 8, 26, 928678) 1 (1774 1833), A great social and religious reformer, founder of the Brahmo Samaj, supported abolition of Sati and worked hard for the spread of education.
('4', 411, 0, 1, 928834) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 411, 1, 2, 928876) He used to buy luchi 1 and curds and feed the poor Muslims at his own cost, in Chandranagar 2, and helped with money those who needed it.
('4', 411, 1, 3, 929014) If he saw a cripple or any one in distress by the roadside, he took him to his own house and nursed him personally.
('4', 411, 1, 4, 929130) He felt grief at other peoples sorrows and joy at their joys.
('4', 411, 1, 5, 929192) Himself he led a very simple life.
('4', 411, 1, 6, 929227) His dress consisted of a coarse dhoti, a shawl of a similar kind to cover his body, and slippers.
('4', 411, 1, 7, 929325) In that dress he used to call on Governors, and in the same dress he greeted the poor.
('4', 411, 1, 8, 929412) He was really a fakir, a sannyasi or a yogi.
('4', 411, 1, 9, 929457) It behoves us all to reflect on his life.
('4', 411, 1, 10, 929499) Ishwarchandra was born of poor parents in a small village in the Midnapur taluka 3. His mother was a very saintly woman, and many of her virtues were inherited by Ishwarchandra.
('4', 411, 1, 11, 929677) Even in those days, his father knew some English, and decided to give his son a better education.
('4', 411, 1, 12, 929775) Ishwarchandra began his schooling at the age of five.
('4', 411, 1, 13, 929829) At the age of eight, he had to walk sixty miles to Calcutta to join a Sanskrit college.
('4', 411, 1, 14, 929917) He had such a prodigious memory that he learnt the English numerals by looking at the figures on the milestones while walking along the road.
('4', 411, 1, 15, 930059) At sixteen he became well versed in Sanskrit, and was appointed a Sanskrit teacher.
('4', 411, 1, 16, 930143) Rising step by step, he at last became the Principal of the College where he had studied.
('4', 411, 1, 17, 930233) The Govern ment held him in great respect.
('4', 411, 1, 18, 930276) But, being of an independentnature,he could not adjust himself to the Director of Public Instruction and resigned his post.
('4', 411, 1, 19, 930400) Sir Frederick Halliday, the Lieutenant Governor of Bengal, sent for him and requested him to withdraw his resignation, but Ishwarchandra flatly declined.
('4', 411, 1, 20, 930554) His nobility and humanity had their true blossoming after he had given up his job.
('4', 411, 1, 21, 930637) He saw that Bengali was a very good language, but appeared poor for want of fresh contributions.
('4', 411, 1, 22, 930734) He, therefore, began writing books in Bengali.
('4', 411, 1, 23, 930781) He produced very powerful books, and it is mainly due to Vidyasagar that the Bengali language is at present in full bloom and has spread throughout India.
('4', 411, 1, 24, 930936) But he also realised that merely writing books was not enough; and so he founded schools.
('4', 411, 1, 25, 931026) It was Vidyasagar who founded the Metropolitan College in Calcutta.
('4', 411, 1, 26, 931094) It is staffed entirely by Indians.
('4', 411, 1, 27, 931129) Considering that elementary education was quite as necessary as higher education, he started primary schools for the poor.
('4', 411, 1, 28, 931252) This was a stupendous task in which he needed government help.
('4', 411, 2, 29, 931315) 1 A kind of unleavened and fried bread made from flour.
('4', 411, 3, 30, 931371) 2 In Wesr Bengal, then a French possession
('4', 411, 4, 31, 931414) 3 In West Bengal
('4', 412, 0, 1, 931431) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 413
('4', 412, 1, 2, 931474) Lieutenant Governor assured him that the Government would bear the cost; but the Viceroy, Lord Ellenborough 1, was opposed to this and the bills preferred by Vidyasagar were not passed.
('4', 412, 1, 3, 931660) The Lieutenant Governor was very sorry and suggested that Ishwarchandra might file a suit against him.
('4', 412, 1, 4, 931763) Brave Ishwarchandra replied: Sir, I have never gone to a court of law to get justice for myself.
('4', 412, 1, 5, 931860) How, then, is it possible for me to proceed against you? At that time other European gentlemen who used to help Ishwarchandra in his work rendered him good financial aid.
('4', 412, 1, 6, 932031) Not being very rich himself, he often ran into debt by helping others out of their difficulties; nevertheless, when a proposal was made to raise a public subscription for him, he turned it down.
('4', 412, 1, 7, 932226) He did not rest satisfied with thus putting higher and elementary education on a sound footing.
('4', 412, 1, 8, 932322) He saw that, without the education of girls, the education of boys alone would not be enough.
('4', 412, 1, 9, 932416) He found out a verse from Manu which said that the education of women was a duty.
('4', 412, 1, 10, 932498) Pressing it into service, he wrote a book on the subject and, in collaboration with Mr. Bethune founded the Bethune College for imparting education to women.
('4', 412, 1, 11, 932656) But it was more difficult to get women to go to college than to found it.
('4', 412, 1, 12, 932730) As he lived a saintly life and was very learned, he was respected by all.
('4', 412, 1, 13, 932804) So he met prominent people and persuaded them to send their womenfolk to the College; and thus, their daughters began to attend the College.
('4', 412, 1, 14, 932945) Today there are in that College many well known and talented women of sterling character, so much so that they can by themselves carry on its administration.
('4', 412, 2, 15, 933103) Still not satisfied, he started schools imparting elementary education to small girls.
('4', 412, 2, 16, 933190) Here food, clothing and books were supplied free of charge.
('4', 412, 2, 17, 933250) Consequently, one can see today thousands of educated women in Calcutta.
('4', 412, 3, 18, 933323) To meet the need for teachers he started a Teachers Training College.
('4', 412, 4, 19, 933393) Seeing the very pitiable condition of Hindu widows, he advocated the remarriage of widows; he wrote books and made speeches on the subject.
('4', 412, 4, 20, 933533) The Brahmins of Bengal opposed him, but he did not care.
('4', 412, 4, 21, 933590) People threatened to kill him, but he went on undaunted.
('4', 412, 4, 22, 933647) He got the Government to pass a law legalizing remarriage of widows.
('4', 412, 4, 23, 933716) He persuaded many men and arranged the remarriage of daughters of prominent men widowed in childhood.
('4', 412, 4, 24, 933818) He encouraged his own son to marry a poor widow.
('4', 412, 5, 25, 933867) 1 Governor General of India, 1842 4
('4', 413, 0, 1, 933903) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 413, 1, 2, 933945) The kulin or high born Brahmins were given to taking a number of wives.
('4', 413, 1, 3, 934017) They were not ashamed of marrying as many as twenty of them.
('4', 413, 1, 4, 934078) Ishwarchandra wept to see the sufferings of such women; and he carried on his effort till the end of his life to eradicate this wicked custom.
('4', 413, 2, 5, 934221) When he saw thousands of poor people in Burdwan suffering from malaria, he maintained a doctor at his own cost and personally distributed medicines among them.
('4', 413, 2, 6, 934381) He went to the houses of the poor and gave them the necessary help.
('4', 413, 2, 7, 934449) In this way he worked ceaselessly for two years, secured government help and called for more doctors.
('4', 413, 3, 8, 934551) In the course of this work, he saw the necessity of a knowledge of medicine.
('4', 413, 3, 9, 934628) So he studied homeopathy, attained proficiency in it, and began to prescribe medicines to the sick.
('4', 413, 3, 10, 934728) He did not mind travelling long distances in order to help the poor.
('4', 413, 4, 11, 934797) He was equally a stalwart in helping big princes out of their difficulties.
('4', 413, 4, 12, 934873) If any of them had injustice done to him or was reduced to poverty, Ishwarchandra used to help him with his influence, knowledge and money, and mitigate his distress.
('4', 413, 5, 13, 935040) While he was engaged in these activities, Vidyasagar passed away in 1890, at the age of seventy.
('4', 413, 5, 14, 935137) There have been few in this world like him.
('4', 413, 5, 15, 935181) It is said that had Ishwarchandra been born among a European people, an imposing column, like the one raised by the British for Nelson, would have been erected as a memorial to him.
('4', 413, 5, 16, 935363) However, a column to honour Ishwarchandra already stands in the hearts of the great and the small, the rich and the poor of Bengal.
('4', 413, 6, 17, 935495) It will now be clear to us how Bengal provides an example for the other parts of India to follow.
('4', 413, 7, 18, 935593) [From Gujarati]
('4', 413, 8, 19, 935609) Indian Opinion, 16 9 1905
('4', 414, 0, 1, 935635) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 415
('4', 414, 1, 2, 935678) 374. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LT. GOVERNOR
('4', 414, 2, 3, 935727) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('4', 414, 3, 4, 935754) BOX NO.
('4', 414, 4, 5, 935762) JOHANNESBURG, September 16, 1905
('4', 414, 5, 6, 935795) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LT. GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('4', 414, 6, 7, 935864) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, No.
('4', 414, 6, 8, 935954) LG 97/3, making certain enquiries about a letter addressed by me to the Chief Secretary for Permits 1 on the lst day of September current.
('4', 414, 6, 9, 936093) The writer of this letter has been in the Colony since 1883 with but brief interruptions, and has been in very close touch with the Indian community whom he has had the honour to represent now for over twelve years, and the first proof, therefore, that is respectfully submitted in support of the statement that there were over 15,000 British Indian male adults resident in the Transvaal before War is the writers own experience.
('4', 414, 6, 10, 936523) My Association further submits the following in support of the statement: 1. In the year 1899, the British Agent submitted to His Majestys Government a report giving roughly the British population, and the figures were published in the newspapers.
('4', 414, 6, 11, 936771) To the best of the writers recollection as to the British Indians, the figures given were 15,000. 2. In the year 1895, a petition was presented to His Majestys Secretary of State for the Colonies by British Indians in the Transvaal which is published in a Blue Book on the grievances of the British Indians in South Africa.
('4', 414, 6, 12, 937095) A rough estimate was made of the British Indian population in the Transvaal at the time and, in accordance with it, there were at least 5,000 adult male Indians, but those who were in South Africa between 1895 and 1899 know that the largest increase in the Indian population of the Transvaal
('4', 414, 7, 13, 937387) 1 Vide Letter to Chief Secretary for Permits, 1 9 1905
('4', 415, 0, 1, 937442) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 415, 1, 2, 937484) took place between 1895 and 1899. The increase was considered to be so alarming that the late President Kruger was urged by some of the present anti Indian agitators to take steps, but happily, so far as Indian immigration was concerned, the late President turned a deaf ear to any such suggestion.
('4', 415, 1, 3, 937783) It was in 1896 that India was visited by the plague followed by two successive famines of extraordinary dimensions.
('4', 415, 1, 4, 937899) The largest known exodus from India took place during that time.
('4', 415, 1, 5, 937964) The steamers Courland, Naderi, Hooseni, and Crescent were specially run between Bombay and South African ports, each having on board per voyage over 400 Indians bound for South Africa.
('4', 415, 1, 6, 938149) Most of these, it was then a matter of common knowledge, found their way to the Transvaal.
('4', 415, 1, 7, 938240) 3. It was in the early part of 1897 that the Natal Immigration Act, was passed.
('4', 415, 1, 8, 938320) In the December of 1896, the Durban Demonstration 1 took place in connection with the Courland and the Naderi which brought together over 800 passengers of whom in that month alone 500 went to the Transvaal.
('4', 415, 1, 9, 938528) Each of these steamers made four trips per year, and, if they brought for the Transvaal without allowing for domiciled Indians only 300 per trip, there would be a yearly increase of 4,800 Indians between the four steamers alone, not to take into consideration Indians brought from the other parts of India by the Kings Line and the British Indian Steam Navigation Co.
('4', 415, 1, 10, 938896) The facts as to the number of passengers per these steamers can easily be verified by reference to the steamship companies or the Port Authorities in Natal.
('4', 415, 1, 11, 939053) The writers opinion is supported by that of other British Indians who are very old residents of the Transvaal.
('4', 415, 1, 12, 939164) 4. As to the opposite view, if reference is made to the public statements that have been made by what may be termed the anti Indian party, it is difficult to speak of its representa tions with moderation.
('4', 415, 1, 13, 939369) In almost every material particular, the allegations made by the members of that party have been over and over again challenged and even disproved, and yet they have not scrupled to reiterate them and to inflame the prejudices of the people against British Indians.
('4', 415, 1, 14, 939635) To take only three instances.
('4', 415, 1, 15, 939665) Certain figures were given by them regarding the number of traders in Pieters burg before War and after War.
('4', 415, 1, 16, 939774) Both these Statements have
('4', 415, 2, 17, 939801) 1 Vide Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies, 15 3 1897
('4', 416, 0, 1, 939867) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 417
('4', 416, 1, 2, 939910) been challenged.
('4', 416, 1, 3, 939927) Names of the persons trading before War have been produced, and yet the original statement has been reiterated.
('4', 416, 1, 4, 940039) They have said that it was impossible for British Indians before War to enter the Transvaal and not be registered.
('4', 416, 1, 5, 940154) My Association has no hesitation in saying that the statement is entirely devoid of truth.
('4', 416, 1, 6, 940245) Hardly one third of the people who entered this country were actually registered, and they were only those who had to take out trade licences and even then the number did not necessarily include partners.
('4', 416, 1, 7, 940450) My Association is in a position to prove from unimpeachable testimony that there were British Indians in the Transvaal before War who never paid the registration fee.
('4', 416, 1, 8, 940617) Some of them are well known and can be identified by respectable European merchants.
('4', 416, 2, 9, 940702) The third statement that has been made is with reference to the alleged Indian exodus to Potchefstroom from Natal.
('4', 416, 2, 10, 940817) Those that have made this statement can know nothing of the conditions of the working of the Naval laws regarding indentured labourers, and the statement has been made to the effect that it is men drawn from this class who have crowded into Potchefstroom.
('4', 416, 2, 11, 941073) The detractors of Indians have, so far as my Association is aware, never yet succeeded in introducing any proof in support of the many statements they have made, and have never taken into account the great fact that it was Johannesburg which, before War, supported the largest Indian population, and it is from Johannesburg that the Indians have now radiated into other parts of the Colony.
('4', 416, 2, 12, 941464) The trade in Johannesburg before War, so far as the Indians were concerned, as it was confined to the Dutch and the Natives, was very fair.
('4', 416, 2, 13, 941604) Both the Dutch and Native trade at present stands at its lowest ebb.
('4', 416, 2, 14, 941673) The result is that many traders who found it impossible to eke out a living in Johannesburg have now established in the different parts of the Transvaal.
('4', 416, 2, 15, 941827) The Johannesburg Location supported a large number of Indian landlords.
('4', 416, 2, 16, 941899) These have not only been impoverished, but have been obliged to leave Johannesburg and go to other parts of the Colony.
('4', 416, 2, 17, 942019) If the original condition of Johannesburg was resumed and security of tenure re assured to the British Indians which they enjoyed before War, most of the Indian population, which is dispersed over the different areas in the Colony, would again gravitate to Johannesburg and the anti Indian gentlemen would have the satisfaction of knowing that the Indians have certainly disappeared from the many townships.
('4', 416, 3, 18, 942427) My Association will be pleased, if an enquiry were to be held, to adduce proof to verify every word of the statements made above.
('4', 417, 0, 1, 942557) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 417, 1, 2, 942599) the Chief Secretary for Permits has forwarded my letter of the 1st September to His Excellency for direction, may I venture to express the hope that what appeared to my Association to be impossible rules, as to European references, will be withdrawn without delay.
('4', 417, 1, 3, 942864) While all kinds of unsupportable statements are being made with reference to British Indians, innocent and honest men have to suffer much inconvenience and loss without any fault of their own, a hardship which they were never obliged to undergo when they were under a flag not their own.
('4', 417, 2, 4, 943152) I HAVE &C., ABDUL GANI, CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
