('4', 417, 4, 6, 943258) 375. THE HOONDAMAL CASE AGAIN1
('4', 417, 5, 7, 943289) The Supreme Court had another opportunity of deciding upon a point arising out of the Dealers Licenses Act of Natal.
('4', 417, 5, 8, 943406) This time it was a review of the decision, some time ago published in these columns, of the Town Council of Durban, confirming that of the Licensing Officer, who refused to register the transfer of Mr. Hoondamals licence from Grey Street to West Street.
('4', 417, 5, 9, 943660) The judgment given by the learned Chief Justice is most disappointing.
('4', 417, 5, 10, 943731) It may be in accordance with law but certainly not with justice or equity.
('4', 417, 5, 11, 943806) The obvious answer to this is that judges have to interpret and not to make law, but we respectfully think that it must be a serious state of law if it does not provide a remedy for an admitted evil.
('4', 417, 5, 12, 944006) The Licensing Officer has extensive powers with reference to granting of licences to trade in the Colony.
('4', 417, 5, 13, 944112) The learned Chief Justice said that, under the law, he was not to exercise judicial discretion.
('4', 417, 5, 14, 944208) It, therefore, amounts to this, that the Licensing Officer may, in order to spite a personal enemy, decline to grant him his licence, and the Courts would be powerless to intervene.
('4', 417, 5, 15, 944390) The dividing line between political animus and personal enmity, so far as such cases are concerned, is very narrow.
('4', 417, 5, 16, 944506) The Dealers Licenses Act is an administrative enactment.
('4', 417, 5, 17, 944563) It is not a political law, in any sense of the term.
('4', 417, 5, 18, 944616) In not granting the licence to Mr. Hoondamal, the Licensing Officer has been undoubtedly guided by political animus against the class to which the appellant belongs.
('4', 417, 6, 19, 944782) 1 Vide Hoondamals Licence, 15 10 1904
('4', 418, 0, 1, 944820) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 419
('4', 418, 1, 2, 944863) Indeed, he has said so in his reason, which is that it was not advisable to grant further licences to Asiatics in West Street.
('4', 418, 1, 3, 944990) However, the mischief is done.
('4', 418, 1, 4, 945021) The highest tribunal in the country has felt itself powerless to correct the evil.
('4', 418, 1, 5, 945104) Every Indian licence is at stake; and if there is to be any relief secured, British Indian merchants must gird up their loins, rise to the occasion, and carry on ceaseless warfare until the disgraceful Act is blotted out of the Statute book.
('4', 418, 1, 6, 945346) Representations must be made to the Government, to the local Parlia ment, and to the Colonial Secretary, inviting their attention to the matter.
('4', 418, 1, 7, 945491) If the local Parliament, whose members, in the words of the late Sir John Robinson, are trustees for the unrepresented British Indians, would not listen, the India Office, which is the paramount trustee for the millions of India, should intervene and induce Natal to grant the very small measure of justice to which Indians are entitled.
('4', 418, 1, 8, 945829) The late Mr. Harry Escombe, at the time of introducing the Bill, said that the success of the measure would depend upon the moderation with which the powers given under the Act were used, and that, if the local authorities failed to exercise their powers moderately, they might have to be taken away.
('4', 418, 1, 9, 946130) The Act has been in operation for over eight years, and no one can deny it has been capriciously enforced on many an occasion, and it has always hung like Damocles sword over the heads of the Indian merchants in the Colony.
('4', 418, 1, 10, 946354) It is time that the sword was removed, and that the sufferers were permitted to feel that they are under British constitutional rule and not under Russian autocracy.
('4', 418, 2, 11, 946520) Indian Opinion, 23 9 1905
('4', 418, 3, 12, 946546) 376. MR. GOCH AND INDIANS
('4', 418, 4, 13, 946572) Mr. George Goch, the Mayor of Johannesburg, let himself go, as the phrase goes, at the meeting recently held in Potchefstroom under the auspices of the Transvaal Progressive Association.
('4', 418, 4, 14, 946759) He spoke, not as simple Mr. Goch holding independent views, but as a representative of the Progressive Association, and as one bound to express the official views, whether they coincided with his own conscientious opinions or not.
('4', 418, 4, 15, 946990) Mr. Goch, in 1903, was among the few who raised their voices in favour of British Indians, at the deliberations of the Johannesburg Municipality.
('4', 418, 4, 16, 947136) He then considered Asiatic competition to be quite healthy.
('4', 418, 4, 17, 947196) He considered the British Indian as a desirable citizen, because he was industrious, thrifty and law abiding.
('4', 418, 4, 18, 947306) Mr. Goch, the Mayor of Johannesburg, does not hesitate to retail the falsehoods that were set in motion by Mr. Loveday and his friends.
('4', 418, 4, 19, 947442) He does not
('4', 419, 0, 1, 947454) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 419, 1, 2, 947496) scruple to vilify British Indians.
('4', 419, 1, 3, 947531) He sees in them a danger to the white community, whereas only a short time ago he considered them to be a strength to any community in which they were placed.
('4', 419, 1, 4, 947690) To him, Asiatics are, to day,
('4', 419, 2, 5, 947720) totally different in their social conditions, whom it is not fair to allow to com pete against the white traders, because they could not compete against each other.
('4', 419, 2, 6, 947885) The Asiatics have very little sense of the burden of citizenship in the country.
('4', 419, 2, 7, 947966) They avoid all the necessary burdens and duties which the white people have to undertake, and consequently, says Mr. Goch, triumphantly,
('4', 419, 3, 8, 948103) it is not fair to pit the white trader against the Asiatic and to allow the white trader to go to the wall because there is some far fetched sentiment (to which, by the way, he himself succumbed in 1903) that, because the Asiatic is a British subject from another section of the Empire, he has the right to their sympathy.
('4', 419, 3, 9, 948426) Mr. Goch has not told us what constitutes the burden of citizenship.
('4', 419, 3, 10, 948495) If it consists in giving public entertainments, if it consists in opening champagne bottles, we must confess that the poor Asiatic has very little sense of such burden; but if it means a readiness to comply with the laws of the country, to pay ones taxes, to earn ones livelihood by the sweat of ones brow instead of becoming a public charge, to conform to the social laws relating to morality, to assist in defending ones country of domicile, no matter how or in what humble capacity, then we have no hesitation in saying that the Indian has well discharged the burden of citizenship.
('4', 419, 3, 11, 949081) We are afraid, however, that there is no arguing with people who would wilfully mislead.
('4', 419, 3, 12, 949170) Mr. Goch knows all that we have been saying about the Indian, but expediency, an eagerness to snatch votes, required from him a change of front.
('4', 419, 3, 13, 949315) Mr. Gochs example shows to what pass public life has come under modern conditions.
('4', 419, 3, 14, 949398) The gods must be pleased at any cost.
('4', 419, 3, 15, 949436) Nothing is too sacred to be sacrificed in order to appease them, and if this is to be the outcome of popular government, the time is not far distant when it will stink in the nostrils, and become a byword for hypocrisy and insincerity.

('4', 420, 1, 2, 949741) 377. INDIANS IN THE O. R. C.
('4', 420, 2, 3, 949770) We publish in another column the correspondence 1 between Lord Selborne and the British Indian Association at Johannesburg with reference to the status of British Indians in the Orange River Colony.
('4', 420, 2, 4, 949969) Lord Selbornes reply is extremely courteous, but equally disappointing.
('4', 420, 2, 5, 950041) In spite of His Excellencys anxiety and desire to soothe British Indians, he has been undoubtedly led away by the reports from the local officials who have smartly succeeded in confusing the real issue.
('4', 420, 2, 6, 950244) The British Indian Association naturally protested against Indians being classed with all sorts of Coloured people, including the Natives of South Africa.
('4', 420, 2, 7, 950399) It resented the application of regulations aimed at the Natives of the soil to the Indians who may go to the Colony.
('4', 420, 2, 8, 950516) The injustice is all the more serious because, in practice, very few Indians are affected, as the application of such legislation to them is not called for by the circumstances of the case.
('4', 420, 2, 9, 950706) The utility of the registration of servants has never been questioned.
('4', 420, 2, 10, 950777) The regulations that have been reproduced in these columns from time to time have been shown to be restrictive of the personal liberty and insulting to those affected by them.
('4', 420, 2, 11, 950953) It was of such legislation that the British Indian Association has rightly complained.
('4', 420, 2, 12, 951040) What does it get in return ?
('4', 420, 2, 13, 951069) An illustration, shown from Ceylon, to justify registration of servants, which has never been questioned!
('4', 420, 2, 14, 951175) The Association, in its concluding reply, l has also very properly drawn Lord Selbornes attention to the fact that British Indians do expect in the near future to have the right to enter the Orange River Colony, and if the expectation is justly entertained, restrictive legislation in anticipation is open to exception.
('4', 420, 2, 15, 951495) The matter is one that calls for immediate action, and we hope that Lord Selborne will be pleased to see that justice is done to British Indians who have now settled in the Orange River Colony, or who may have to go there in the future.

('4', 421, 1, 2, 951848) 378. THE FIRST COLONIAL BORN INDIAN BARRISTER1
('4', 421, 2, 3, 951895) We extend a hearty welcome to Mr. Bernard Gabriel, who has just returned a full fledged barrister from England.
('4', 421, 2, 4, 952007) Under ordinary circumstances, it would be no cause to specially notice a lad becoming a barrister, but the event in which we are now interested is very significant.
('4', 421, 2, 5, 952172) Mr. Gabriel comes of Indian parents who are among the earliest settlers in the Colony and who are drawn from the indentured class.
('4', 421, 2, 6, 952303) It reflects the highest credit on them that they and their elder sons sacrificed almost all they had in order to give their youngest son a sound education.
('4', 421, 2, 7, 952459) It speaks well for their public spirit and parental love.
('4', 421, 2, 8, 952517) They have raised the poor Indians, who for their livelihood have to serve under indenture, in the estimation of all right thinking men.
('4', 421, 2, 9, 952653) Mr. Bernard Gabriel has also shown that, under the circumstances, the children of poor Indians are capable of attaining to a high degree of proficiency, and we think that the Colonists, too, ought to take pride in the event.
('4', 421, 2, 10, 952878) There is another aspect.
('4', 421, 2, 11, 952903) Whilst, as an Indian, Mr. Bernard Gabriel has every right to congratulate himself on being a barrister in legal education, he has to recognise the fact that his career is only commencing.
('4', 421, 2, 12, 953091) He has to consider himself as trustee for his fellow young men in the same walk of life, and it is his example which, if well set, will induce other parents to send their children to England to finish their education.
('4', 421, 2, 13, 953309) He has adopted an honourable profession, but if it be used as a means for amassing wealth, there may be failure staring him in the face.
('4', 421, 2, 14, 953446) If his attainments are placed at the service of the community, they will grow more and more.
('4', 421, 2, 15, 953539) We hope, therefore, that Mr. Gabriel has brought with him a real knowledge of the traditions of his profession, and that in all he does he will be prudent, calm, humble and patriotic.
('4', 421, 2, 16, 953723) Indian Opinion, 23 9 1905
('4', 421, 3, 17, 953749) 1 An address couched in similar terms was presented to Bernard Gabriel on September 19 at a meeting of Durban Indians in the Congress Hall (Indian Opinion,, 23 9 1905).
('4', 421, 3, 18, 953918) Though Gandhiji does not appear to have been present and is not among the signatories, it is not unlikely that he had a hand in drafting the address, which contains the following sentence: We have no doubt but that the interest and betterment of your countrymen, and the advocacy of their cause in South Africa will have your warm support, and that your influence for their well being will ever be used on their behalf.

('4', 422, 1, 2, 954381) 379. PERMIT REGULATIONS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 422, 2, 3, 954422) STRONG REPRESENTATION BY BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION Recently the Permit Office has introduced a regulation to the effect that persons seeking permits can get them only on furnishing the names of two Europeans for reference.
('4', 422, 2, 4, 954646) This is outrageous.
('4', 422, 2, 5, 954666) The Association has made a strong representation against it.
('4', 422, 2, 6, 954727) It has been stated therein that there could be very few cases where a European would know Indians by name.
('4', 422, 2, 7, 954834) The making of such a regulation only means that the Government does not intend to allow any more Indians to enter the Transvaal.
('4', 422, 2, 8, 954963) This regulation will, moreover, encourage fraudulent practices; for many dishonest Europeans will come forward who will not hesitate to take a false oath for the sake of money.
('4', 422, 2, 9, 955140) So far only 12,000 Indians have entered the Transvaal.
('4', 422, 2, 10, 955195) Before the war their number was 15,000. Hence there is reason to believe that 3,000 more of the former residents are still to return.
('4', 422, 2, 11, 955329) They are suffering many hardships, and it is the duty of the Government to admit them without delay.
('4', 422, 2, 12, 955430) The permit Officer had forwarded the petition to H. E. the Lieutenant Governor, who wanted to know the grounds on which it had been stated that there were 15,000 Indians before the war.
('4', 422, 2, 13, 955616) In its reply the Association has submitted the following grounds : (1) the personal experience of the President, Mr. Abdul Gani; (2) the personal experience of other early Indian residents; (3) the Report of the British Agent before the war in which the Indian population was shown to be about 15,000; (4) the population in 1895 was stated as 5,000. It would not be surprising if those who entered the Transvaal between 1895 and 1899 were to number 10,000. Thousands of men left India, because of the plaque in 1896 and the severe famine in 1897 8. Again stringent laws were enacted in Natal in 1897. All this resulted in many Indians entering the Transvaal.
('4', 422, 2, 14, 956275) Though there was at that time alien rule in the Transvaal, Indians could freely enter the country.
('4', 422, 2, 15, 956374) The late Mr. Kruger did not listen to the suggestion that this be stopped.
('4', 422, 2, 16, 956449) At the time, four steamships, the Naderi, the Courland, the Hooseni, and the Crescent used to ply between Bombay and South Africa, and each of them brought hundreds of Indians to South Africa.
('4', 422, 2, 17, 956642) Each of the steamers made four trips a year, and calculating at the rate of three hundred passengers per trip, the sixteen trips in a year
('4', 423, 0, 1, 956781) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 423, 1, 2, 956823) must have resulted in the immigration of 4,800 Indians.
('4', 423, 1, 3, 956879) Besides laying this evidence before the Government, the Association has also shown the statements of Mr. Loveday 1 and others to be quite untrue and has made an appeal to the Government to pay no attention to them and immediately admit the poor Indians that still remain stranded outside.
('4', 423, 1, 4, 957168) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 23 9 1905
('4', 423, 2, 5, 957210) 380. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI JOHANNESBURG, September 23, 1905
('4', 423, 3, 6, 957276) MY DEAR CHHAGANLAL, Your letter to hand.
('4', 423, 3, 7, 957317) What you write bout Kitchin is astounding.
('4', 423, 3, 8, 957360) You have nothing to do with his temperament.
('4', 423, 3, 9, 957405) He is not your boss.
('4', 423, 3, 10, 957426) You can certainly reply to what he says without losing your temper.
('4', 423, 3, 11, 957494) You are both equals, and can discuss matters as such.
('4', 423, 3, 12, 957548) When I say, You should tolerate him whatever he might say, it does not mean that you should not reply; it only means that you should not get excited while opposing his statements.
('4', 423, 3, 13, 957728) I know the West incident.
('4', 423, 3, 14, 957754) There the mistake was mine.
('4', 423, 3, 15, 957782) I had asked him to go to Kitchin; but I forget the fact that the venerable Mr. Kitchin cannot tolerate anybodys presence.
('4', 423, 3, 16, 957904) This is his shortcoming which we should ignore.
('4', 423, 3, 17, 957952) I have made it quite clear to you that I do not care in the least even if Kitchin or any other person goes away.
('4', 423, 3, 18, 958065) The press will not close down on that account.
('4', 423, 3, 19, 958112) My ultimate reliance is on you and West.
('4', 423, 3, 20, 958153) The press is not going to close down so long as you two are there.
('4', 423, 3, 21, 958220) It in spite of this you entertain any doubt, I would call that a weakness in you.

('4', 428, 3, 4, 965935) 384. LEGISLATIVE ACTIVITY IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 428, 4, 5, 965978) Although Sir Richard Solomon, the Attorney General for the Transvaal, stated that no contentious legislation would be introduced during the present session of the Transvaal Legislative Council, the latest Government Gazette to hand gives a list of ordinances passed by the dying Council, some of which are without doubt highly contentious, if, that is to say, the feelings of those whom they are intended to affect are of any consequence.
('4', 428, 4, 6, 966417) There is, for instance, the Municipal Amending Ordinance which gives any Town Council in the Transvaal the power with the approval of the Lieutenant Governor to close any Locations for Natives established or laid out by it or under its control, provided that the Lieutenant Governor may, before giving his approval to the closing of such Location, require the Council to lay out other land suitable for a Location.
('4', 428, 4, 7, 966832) It makes further provision for compensation to be paid to the Natives for the value of their huts, etc.
('4', 428, 4, 8, 966936) Section 10 gives the Council the power to set apart and maintain Asiatic Bazaars, and it makes the provision with reference to Native Locations above referred to applicable to the Asiatic Bazaars, which means that there is only this distinction between the two, namely, that, whereas Natives may be compelled to reside in the Location, Asiatics may not be compelled to remove to the Locations, which are euphemistically described as Bazaars.
('4', 428, 4, 9, 967378) This legislation regarding Asiatic Bazaars arises from the struggle of the Pretoria Municipality for obtaining control over the Asiatic Bazaars at Pretoria.
('4', 428, 4, 10, 967535) In theory, there may be no difference between governmental and municipal control; but, in practice, it will very largely depend upon the temper of the municipality that may happen to be in authority.
('4', 428, 4, 11, 967735) Instead, therefore, of there being a continuity of policy regarding Bazaars, there will now be differences in accordance with the fancy of each municipality.
('4', 428, 4, 12, 967893) It is very difficult to know why such legislation has been passed during the last days of the existing Coun cil, in view of the fact that the whole of the Asiatic question is still a matter of correspondence between the Home Government and the Transvaal Government.
('4', 428, 4, 13, 968159) Many more important and pressing matters have been naturally held in abeyance, in view of the establishment next year of an elective Council.
('4', 428, 4, 14, 968301) The amending ordinances, however,
('4', 429, 0, 1, 968335) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 429, 1, 2, 968377) authorise the municipalities to impose licences for tea rooms or eating houses which may be used exclusively by Asiatics.
('4', 429, 1, 3, 968499) For this, we believe the Asiatics in the Transvaal have to thank some Chinese store keepers, who, in their eagerness to open Chinese eating houses and not knowing that licences were not required for them, petitioned the Government to let them have facilities for opening such eating houses.
('4', 429, 1, 4, 968790) The Government have met the petitioners with what they deserve, and all Asiatic boarding housekeepers will now have the pleasure of having municipal control over even small Asiatic refreshment rooms.
('4', 429, 1, 5, 968990) Municipal control, for the sake of sanitation, we can quite understand and even welcome; but the imposing of licences over businesses which we apprehend are hardly lucrative, so far as British Indians are concerned, is simply preposterous.
('4', 429, 1, 6, 969230) But British Indians are Asiatics; therefore, if there must be eating house licences imposed for the catering of 45,000 Chinamen, the Transvaal Government argue there must also be licences imposed for eating houses for 12,000 Indians.
('4', 429, 1, 7, 969464) It did not occur to them that Indian eating houses are very rare, as the custom of the community does not as a rule require them.
('4', 429, 1, 8, 969594) Indeed, they are so few that hitherto they have not been even noticed.
('4', 429, 1, 9, 969665) There is, again, the Revenue Licence Ordinance which requires hawkers and pedlars to take out certificates from magistrates, Justices of the Peace, or Police Officers before being entitled to a licence, exception being made in favour of those who may be already in possession of their licences, provided that these fortunate men, within fourteen days before the expiry of their licences, hand them to the Revenue Officers within their districts.
('4', 429, 1, 10, 970111) The Johannesburg Land Ordinance makes it
('4', 429, 2, 11, 970152) lawful for the Lieutenant Governor to grant to the Councils of the Municipality of Johannesburg in such manner and on such conditions as it may deem advisable and subject to all servitudes at present subsisting therein in favour of any person the land described in schedule attached to the ordinance.
('4', 429, 3, 12, 970453) Among the lands thus dealt with is the Malay Location in Johannesburg.
('4', 429, 3, 13, 970524) This Location has been in existence for the last twelve years or more.
('4', 429, 3, 14, 970595) There has never been any objection raised to it either on account of the habits of the inhabitants or its situation.
('4', 429, 3, 15, 970712) The inhabitants, under a sense of security fostered by the different British Agents who represented the Government before the war, have built substantial houses.
('4', 429, 3, 16, 970874) The tenure, however, from a legal standpoint is only a monthly tenancy.
('4', 429, 3, 17, 970946) What, then, are the inhabitants to receive as
('4', 430, 0, 1, 970992) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 431
('4', 430, 1, 2, 971035) compensation, assuming that they will be removed ?
('4', 430, 1, 3, 971086) We cannot but here recall the invidious distinction that has been drawn between one portion of Vrededorp and the other portion, for the whole of the Malay Location is part of Vrededorp.
('4', 430, 1, 4, 971272) That portion which is inhabited by the old indigent burghers has received most favourable treatment at the hands of the Government.
('4', 430, 1, 5, 971404) As our readers must have seen from these columns, they are not only not to be dispossessed but they are to have their monthly tenure converted into long leases.
('4', 430, 1, 6, 971565) Why should not the same facility be given to the inhabitants of the Malay Location?
('4', 430, 1, 7, 971649) It will be for the latter to see to their rights being properly safeguarded.
('4', 430, 1, 8, 971726) These are only a few samples of legislation which has been termed non contentious.
('4', 430, 1, 9, 971809) It has in some shape or other dealt with the rights of the Coloured people who have no choice whatsoever in their government.
('4', 430, 1, 10, 971935) Indian Opinion, 30 9 1905
('4', 430, 2, 11, 971961) 385. THE CAPE IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION ACT
('4', 430, 3, 12, 972003) The following appears in the Cape Government Gazette for the 19th September, 1905: In the event of a Prohibited Immigrant having entered this Colony in contravention of the Act, it shall be lawful, after due enquiry into the facts by the Magistrate of the District in which Prohibited Immigrants shall have been found, to order such Immigrant to be detained and accommodated in such place as the Minister may from time to time direct, pending the removal of such Immigrant from within the territorial limits of the Colony, and where such Immigrant is in possession of sufficient means, the whole or the part of the cost of such removal to such port or other place as the Minister may direct shall be borne by such Immigrant.
('4', 430, 3, 13, 972728) The provision is very drastic.
('4', 430, 3, 14, 972759) The Restriction Act has been passed in the supposed interests of the Colony.
('4', 430, 3, 15, 972836) It is quite conceivable that a man may unwittingly enter it in contravention of the Act.
('4', 430, 3, 16, 972925) It is hardly just, then, if he is found to be in possession of just enough to pay the cost of his removal to make him bear the burden.
('4', 430, 3, 17, 973060) Although ignorance of law is in theory held to be no excuse, there are, perhaps, cases in which in practice ignorance is a valid plea.
('4', 430, 3, 18, 973195) There is already in the Act a clause requiring the masters of all steamers that may bring Prohibited Immigrants to take them back.
('4', 430, 3, 19, 973326) If a Prohibited Immigrant enter the Colony, it shows also lack of supervision on the part of the authorities, and it seems hardly fair that an innocent man should be punished, either because there is not complete supervision at the Cape,
('4', 431, 0, 1, 973564) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 431, 1, 2, 973606) or because the masters of vessels have been careless in selecting passengers.
('4', 431, 1, 3, 973684) We, therefore, trust that the British Indians at the Cape, whom the new Rule is likely to affect most, will take the necessary steps to have the Rule amended.
('4', 431, 2, 4, 973843) Indian Opinion, 30 9 1905
('4', 431, 3, 5, 973869) 386. THE CHINESE AND THE AMERICANS
('4', 431, 4, 6, 973904) The loss already sustained by the United States on account of the boycott of American goods by the Chinese is estimated at 5,000,000. This has led the American traders and merchants to urge their Government to abolish the anti Chinese laws 1. To counter this move, the working classes there have held large meetings and passed resolutions demanding that the anti Chinese laws should not be repealed, whatever the loss they might cause to the traders.
('4', 431, 4, 7, 974355) Thus, on the one hand, there is a split between the traders and the working classes in America, and on the other, the cablegrams received from China show that the Chinese boycott is gathering strength.
('4', 431, 4, 8, 974557) This resolution by the Chinese is sought to be applied to all the places where anti Chinese laws are in force.
('4', 431, 4, 9, 974668) Moreover, it is also said that the feeling against the whites has become so strong in China that fears are being entertained about the safety of those residing in the interior.
('4', 431, 4, 10, 974845) It is difficult to say what all this agitation will lead to.
('4', 431, 5, 11, 974906) The great advances said to have been made in the nineteenth century are now being put to the test in the twentieth.
('4', 431, 5, 12, 975022) And it would appear that the present century might witness great upheavals.
('4', 431, 5, 13, 975098) In all this commotion one thing stands out clear, namely, that where there is unity, there alone is strength, and also victory.
('4', 431, 5, 14, 975226) This deserves to be carefully borne in mind by every Indian.
('4', 431, 5, 15, 975287) The Chinese, though weak, appear to have become strong on account of their unity, thereby bearing out the truth of the Gujarati verse, Thus do ants when united take the life of a fierce snake.
('4', 431, 5, 16, 975480) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 30 9 1905

('4', 432, 6, 10, 976391) 388. SCHOOLS IN NATAL
('4', 432, 7, 11, 976413) THE REPORT OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION
('4', 432, 8, 12, 976459) In his Annual Report, Mr. Mudie, Superintendent of Education in Natal, states that sufficient attention is not being paid to the cleanliness of children in the schools for Indians and other Coloured people.
('4', 432, 8, 13, 976666) This comment by Mr. Mudie deserves careful consideration.
('4', 432, 8, 14, 976724) Though Mr. Mudie is not one of our well wishers, we ought to ponder over our shortcomings when he points them out to us.
('4', 432, 8, 15, 976845) Parents should give enough attention to this matter.
('4', 432, 8, 16, 976898) Though we may not ourselves observe rules of cleanliness, it is very essential to teach them to our children.
('4', 432, 8, 17, 977008) If they learn to follow them, muchimprovement is likely to result in the course of a generation.
('4', 432, 8, 18, 977105) The following points about children should be borne in mind: (1) Their teeth should be clean.
('4', 432, 8, 19, 977199) They should be made to rinse them every morning and again before retiring at night.
('4', 432, 8, 20, 977283) (2) Their hair should be clean.
('4', 432, 8, 21, 977315) It should be cut short and washed and brushed every day.
('4', 432, 8, 22, 977372) No oil need be used.
('4', 432, 8, 23, 977393) (3) Their nails should be clean, clipped from time to time and always washed clean.
('4', 432, 8, 24, 977477) (4) Their clothes and shoes, however simple, should be neat and tidy.
('4', 433, 0, 1, 977547) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 433, 1, 2, 977589) (5) Their satchels and books, too, should be clean likewise.
('4', 433, 1, 3, 977650) They should handle books with clean hands.
('4', 433, 1, 4, 977693) We need hardly add that it will accrue to the benefit of the children if these rules are kept in mind and they are made to follow them.

('4', 433, 3, 7, 977871) 389. INTIMATION TO RESIDENTS OF JOHANNESBURG
('4', 433, 4, 8, 977916) We find from the Johannesburg newspapers that the season for epidemic fever has set in there.
('4', 433, 4, 9, 978010) The Municipality has issued a public notice that those who keep their latrines unclean will be prosecuted.
('4', 433, 4, 10, 978117) The local rules require that after a person has used a latrine, he should spread dry dust, ashes or some disinfectant powder over the faeces so as to cover them over completely.
('4', 433, 4, 11, 978295) The latrine should not be wet or smelly.
('4', 433, 4, 12, 978336) Any default in this respect is punishable with a fine up to 5. This is a very good rule.
('4', 433, 4, 13, 978425) Ashes or dry dust can be had free of charge.
('4', 433, 4, 14, 978470) We earnestly appeal to our readers to keep a tin filled with dust in the latrine and cover the faeces with dust or ashes.
('4', 433, 4, 15, 978592) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 30 9 1905
('4', 433, 5, 16, 978634) 390. GEORGE WASHINGTON
('4', 433, 6, 17, 978657) THE FIRST PRESIDENT OF AMERICA
('4', 433, 7, 18, 978688) Students of English must have read in their text books about one George who one day cut off, for the fun of it, a berry plant that was dear to his father.
('4', 433, 7, 19, 978843) When he saw the fate of the plant, his father asked the boy about it.
('4', 433, 7, 20, 978913) George replied: Father, I wouldnt tell a lie.
('4', 433, 7, 21, 978959) I cut the plant. When the father, who questioned him in an angry tone, heard this straight reply from George who had tears in his eyes, he was pleased and forgave him.
('4', 433, 7, 22, 979127) George was then a mere child.
('4', 433, 7, 23, 979157) The boy, on whose mind devotion to truth was thus firmly imprinted, became at fifty five the first President of America, which is today the admiration of the world.
('4', 433, 7, 24, 979322) When he was elected to the presidency, the American people offered to crown him king, but he simply rejected the proposal.
('4', 433, 7, 25, 979445) George Washington was born in a wealthy family in the city of Westmoreland in Virginia on February 22, 1732. Little is known about
('4', 434, 0, 1, 979576) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 435
('4', 434, 1, 2, 979619) the first sixteen years of his life.
('4', 434, 1, 3, 979656) Until then he had read little.
('4', 434, 1, 4, 979687) Later, he was appointed manager of some estate.

('4', 434, 2, 17, 981237) The result was that the English armies were defeated, and America became independent.
('4', 434, 2, 18, 981323) And once the task was accomplished, Washington relinquished his post.
('4', 434, 2, 19, 981393) But the people had found in him a gem which they would not part with.
('4', 434, 2, 20, 981463) So, when the American Republic was founded in 1787, George Washington was elected its first President.

('4', 434, 3, 25, 981817) Washington was elected President for a second time.

('4', 440, 4, 7, 991064) 396. COMPULSORY EDUCATION IN INDIA Whilst every attempt is being made in South Africa to discourage Indian education, signs are not wanting to show that in India itself the desire for education has taken deep root in the hearts of the people, and that, before many years are out, we may even find compulsory education adopted in the advanced parts of India.
('4', 440, 4, 8, 991422) Macaulay penned the famous Education Minute in l836. 1 It was then that Indian education received its real impetus, and yet in the census of 1901, it was found that only one in ten of the female population were literate.
('4', 440, 4, 9, 991643) Mr. H. D. Kantavala, the Director of Pu blic Instruction in the State of Baroda, contributes a very valuable paper to East and West for August.
('4', 440, 4, 10, 991787) According to our authority, the number of students of all grades in 1901 was 3,268,726, and the expenditure incurred on the education of these students was less than two crores of rupees, that is, one and a third million pounds.
('4', 440, 4, 11, 992016) Of this amount, a little over one fourth was spent on primary education.
('4', 440, 4, 12, 992089) The expenditure on education represents 1.5 per cent.
('4', 440, 4, 13, 992143) of the total revenue of Government.
('4', 440, 4, 14, 992179) It is admitted that primary education has not received sufficient attention in India, and the main reason is that the Government of India has found it impossible to spend more owing to lack of funds.
('4', 440, 4, 15, 992379) We will not at present go into the question of why money has not been available for further development of education, but we may say that the matter no longer remains absolutely in the hands of the Government.
('4', 440, 4, 16, 992589) Those who have appreciated the sweets of education are eager that their less fortunate brethren should have a share.
('4', 440, 4, 17, 992706) The Corporation
('4', 440, 5, 18, 992722) 1 Thomas Babington Macaulay, (1800 59 President of the General Committee of Public Instruction and Law Member of the Executive Council of the Governor General, wrote his Minute on February 2, 1835 in favour of introducing English education in India.
('4', 440, 5, 19, 992972) Til1 this issue was decided as between opposite schools of thought, the Government could not launch a unified scheme of education in India.
('4', 441, 0, 1, 993112) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 441, 1, 2, 993154) of Bombay has lately passed a resolution approving of the system of compulsory education.
('4', 441, 1, 3, 993244) His Highness the Maharaja Gaekwar has taken a practical step, and it is the experiment that is now being tried in Baroda in compulsory education that Mr. Kantavala has largely dealt with in his paper.
('4', 441, 1, 4, 993445) It was in l892 that His Highness expressed his intention to introduce compulsory education in some portions of his territories and Mr. Kantavala was entrusted with this responsibility.
('4', 441, 1, 5, 993630) He laid down the following principles for his own guidance.
('4', 441, 1, 6, 993690) (1) Before applying the compulsory law to a place, the Government should provide it with means of education.
('4', 441, 1, 7, 993799) (2) The law of compulsion should be made applicable to both sexes.
('4', 441, 1, 8, 993866) (3) The age of compulsion should be from seven to twelve in the case of boys, and seven to ten in the case of girls.
('4', 441, 1, 9, 993983) (4) The course of study should be elementary.
('4', 441, 1, 10, 994029) (5) Compulsory attendance should not exceed l00 days in the year.
('4', 441, 1, 11, 994095) (6) The defaulters should not be dealt with criminally but only civilly, and be subject to a fine recoverable only by a civil process.
('4', 441, 1, 12, 994230) With characteristic energy, and undaunted by serious difficulties of a complex nature, Mr. Kantavala selected a group of ten villages, the most backward in the State (as it was the Gaekwars intention to see the working of the system at its worst), and enforced the principles above laid down.
('4', 441, 1, 13, 994523) Several interviews which the Director of Education had with headmen, how he lived down all opposition, how he brought round to his way of thinking the recalcitrant spirits, are all very interesting incidents.
('4', 441, 1, 14, 994732) We would, however, state the result only in the writers own language:
('4', 441, 2, 15, 994802) It was thus that I was able to introduce compulsory education in the most backward part of the Baroda State within a very short time.
('4', 441, 2, 16, 994936) I had to pay special attention for months in order to work out the scheme successfully.
('4', 441, 2, 17, 995024) By the end of the year, almost all children within the age of compulsion, that is, over 99 per cent.
('4', 441, 2, 18, 995125) entered school, a result which, even in England and other advanced countries, is not achieved.
('4', 441, 2, 19, 995220) The successful working of themeasure induced His Highness to extend compulsory education by taking up fresh groups of ten villages at a time.
('4', 441, 2, 20, 995362) Compulsory education in the Amreli Taluka has stood the test of more than a dozen years, showing always that nearly cent.
('4', 441, 2, 21, 995484) per cent.
('4', 441, 2, 22, 995494) of the children attend the school, and that people have never raised any complaint of a serious nature against it.
('4', 441, 2, 23, 995609) His Highness has recently sanctioned a scheme for applying to two parts of his territories the law of compulsory education to those children whose parents have a certain annual income.
('4', 442, 0, 1, 995794) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 443
('4', 442, 1, 2, 995837) This is a remarkable achievement, and yet it is only a little germ, when we consider the illiterate millions in India.
('4', 442, 1, 3, 995956) No one can foretell to what stature the germ will grow in course of time.
('4', 442, 1, 4, 996030) The experiment is not without its lesson to us in South Africa.
('4', 442, 1, 5, 996094) It is but right that we should expect the different governments to provide suitable education for Indian children.
('4', 442, 1, 6, 996209) It is the duty of those Indians who are better situated and who see the advantages of education to see that, if the governments in South Africa will not help them, they themselves make suitable provision for the education of Indian children.

('4', 442, 3, 8, 996477) 397. THE G. O. M. OF INDIA1
('4', 442, 4, 9, 996505) Our Indian exchanges bring news with reference to the meetings held to commemorate the eighty first birthday of Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, the Grand Old Man of India, on the 4th September last.
('4', 442, 4, 10, 996694) Public meetings were held all over India.
('4', 442, 4, 11, 996736) The services rendered by Mr. Naoroji to India, in our humble opinion, are far greater than the services rendered by Englands Grand Old Man 2 to England.
('4', 442, 4, 12, 996889) Mr. Naorojis work has been pioneer work, and when he commenced it, few indeed were his helpers.
('4', 442, 4, 13, 996985) The self sacrificing devotion with which he has pushed forward the cause of India, in season and out of season, has hardly any parallel in India; and it is no wonder that he stands unequalled by any one in the estimation of millions of his countrymen.
('4', 442, 4, 14, 997237) The spectacle of an old man of over eighty years wooing a British constituency, not for the sake of glory or honours, but in order that he may serve India the more, is most pathetic and mag nificent.
('4', 442, 4, 15, 997437) If the electors of North Lambeth send Mr. Naoroji to the new Parliament, they will have done themselves a unique honour.
('4', 442, 4, 16, 997558) We echo the prayers that were offered by the millions in India for long life and health to Mr. Naoroji.

('4', 443, 1, 2, 997906) 398. THE INSULT TO SIR MANCHERJI
('4', 443, 2, 3, 997939) It is with great regret that we notice the insult that has been offered to Sir Mancherji Bhownaggree at Calcutta recently.
('4', 443, 2, 4, 998062) Because he differed from the [common] opinion on the Partition of Bengal 1, he was burnt in effigy on College Square.
('4', 443, 2, 5, 998180) Sir Mancherji may surely hold his own opinion, even though it is seldom allowed nowadays to individual members of that temple of freedomthe British House of Commons.
('4', 443, 2, 6, 998346) To offer such flagrant insult to a member of that assembly, who has proved his zeal in the cause of India, is unwise; nay, it is stupid.
('4', 443, 2, 7, 998483) Indians may not always see eye to eye with Sir Mancherji, but they cannot fail to acknowledge that he is ever loyal to his native India and that he has always her interests at heart.
('4', 443, 2, 8, 998666) Indians in South Africa will especially feel this insult; for he has proved himself a true friend to the unrepresented thousands here.
('4', 443, 2, 9, 998801) Indians will do very wrong to value a man according to the power of his invective and the bitterness of his denunciation of Britains perfidy.
('4', 443, 2, 10, 998943) The more moderate opinions of a man like Sir Mancherji have far greater weight than the extravagances of hot headed Radicals.
('4', 443, 2, 11, 999069) It is the conviction of calm reasoning alone that will get the full measure of justice for India; and for this reason Sir Mancherji is, of all men, the least deserving of the ingratitude of his fellow countrymen.

('4', 443, 4, 13, 999308) 399. THE BOYCOTT
('4', 443, 5, 14, 999325) From cables and Indian papers recently to hand, it is evident that the boycott movement in Bengal is not destined to fizzle out in an in glorious fashion.
('4', 443, 5, 15, 999480) Though there appears to be a deal of mob law in preventing persons from buying British goods, the movement is so general as to show that it results from deep feeling on the part of the people.
('4', 443, 5, 16, 999673) Whatever may be the result of the present agitation against the Partition, the effect of the boycott will be productive of only good to India.
('4', 443, 5, 17, 999816) It has resulted in a wonderful stimulation of native industries which, we trust, will grow more and more.
('4', 443, 5, 18, 999922) It is a result unlooked for, but not the less eminently desirable.
('4', 443, 5, 19, 999989) The great need of India is that
('4', 443, 6, 20, 1000021) 1 On grounds of administrative convenience, Bengal was divided into two provinces, one of which was predominantly Hindu and the other Muslim.
('4', 443, 6, 21, 1000163) The Partition, which raised a storm of protest throughout India and led to the movement for boycott of British goods, was finally annulled in 1911.
('4', 444, 0, 1, 1000311) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 445
('4', 444, 1, 2, 1000354) national characteristics should be fostered and improved.
('4', 444, 1, 3, 1000412) If the resolve to use only Indian goods, so far as possible, be maintained, it will be no small help in developing the national spirit.
('4', 444, 1, 4, 1000548) Indian Opinion, 7 10 1905
('4', 444, 2, 5, 1000574) 400. DR.
('4', 444, 2, 6, 1000583) BARNARDO
('4', 444, 3, 7, 1000592) The news of Dr. Barnardos death last month has been cabled throughout the world.
('4', 444, 3, 8, 1000673) Our readers must be eager to know who this Dr. Barnardo was.
('4', 444, 3, 9, 1000734) We are, therefore, giving this time in these columns an account of the worthy doctors life.
('4', 444, 4, 10, 1000826) Dr. Barnardo was regarded as the father of orphans and waifs.
('4', 444, 4, 11, 1000888) In his early years the doctor felt deeply depressed whenever he happened to see an orphan.
('4', 444, 4, 12, 1000979) But he had then no means of helping them.
('4', 444, 4, 13, 1001021) Although he was poor, the idea occurred to him that he should undertake to bring up orphans and thus earn his own livelihood.
('4', 444, 5, 14, 1001147) As the Gujarati saying, giving a needle in charity after stealing an anvil, goes, we want first to earn plenty of money and then spend it on some good cause.
('4', 444, 5, 15, 1001305) The entire lives of many are spent in the process of amassing wealth.
('4', 444, 5, 16, 1001375) Some others forget their original resolution when they have earned enough, yet others, when they have amassed money, do not know how to use it properly, waste it on all sorts of things and feel satisfied that they have spent it well.
('4', 444, 5, 17, 1001609) Never having been benevolent, they cannot use the money properly.
('4', 444, 5, 18, 1001675) The intelligent Dr. Barnardo had seen all this.
('4', 444, 5, 19, 1001723) So he told himself: My heart is pure; those who trust me and give me money will also realise that I too must support myself with it.
('4', 444, 5, 20, 1001856) At the same time, if I undertake to shelter and bring up orphans, I shall earn their blessings and the people, too, will see that I have no intention of making money for myself. With these thoughts in his mind, the brave doctor plunged into the work, and opened the first Home for orphan waifs at Steveny Causeway in London.
('4', 444, 5, 21, 1002181) People at first opposed him, many saying that he had only found a fine way of making money by deceiving the public.
('4', 444, 5, 22, 1002297) Dr. Barnardo, however, was not to be discouraged.
('4', 444, 5, 23, 1002347) He collected money from those who trusted him.
('4', 444, 5, 24, 1002394) By and by, more and more children began to flock to his Home.
('4', 444, 5, 25, 1002456) Instead of becoming vagabonds, they became studious, honest and industrious and secured employment.
('4', 444, 5, 26, 1002556) All the children thus brought up served as good publicity for Dr. Barnardos Home.
('4', 444, 5, 27, 1002638) They saw that Dr. Barnardo looked after them better than their own parents would have done.
('4', 444, 5, 28, 1002730) The doctor founded more such Homes, till at last he established a colony
('4', 445, 0, 1, 1002803) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 445, 1, 2, 1002845) for orphans in a wood, six miles away from London.
('4', 445, 1, 3, 1002896) There he put up fine buildings, churches, etc., and the place has now become so famous that many people visit it and feel they are on a pilgrimage; and in course of time similar homes have been founded in many parts of the world.
('4', 445, 1, 4, 1003126) Dr. Barnardo himself brought up in this way during his lifetime 55,000 homeless children.
('4', 445, 1, 5, 1003216) There were some wicked parents who took unfair advantage of the facility provided by the doctor.
('4', 445, 1, 6, 1003313) They quietly left their children at night in Dr. Barnardos backyard and went away.
('4', 445, 1, 7, 1003396) Undaunted, the doctor brought them up with careand returned them to their parents when they claimed them.
('4', 445, 1, 8, 1003502) Every year, in the big Albert Hall in London, a fair is held in which the children from these Homes take part and thousands of people pay to visit it.
('4', 445, 1, 9, 1003653) It has come to be known after the doctors death that he had insured his life for 70,000. He has enjoined in his will that all this money should be spent on the maintenance of the Homes founded by him.
('4', 445, 1, 10, 1003854) Such was this great man, Dr. Barnardo.
('4', 445, 1, 11, 1003893) He was pious and very kind.
('4', 445, 1, 12, 1003921) Though acts like insuring ones life, etc., do not accord well with our idea of religion, it was according to Western practice wise on the part of the doctor to have done what he did.
('4', 445, 1, 13, 1004104) Dr. Barnardo has provided us, during the present age, a very good example of what a poor man could accomplish by dint of enthusiasm and kindness.
('4', 445, 2, 14, 1004250) [From Gujarati]
('4', 445, 3, 15, 1004266) Indian Opinion, 7 10 1905
('4', 445, 4, 16, 1004292) 401. AN.
('4', 445, 4, 17, 1004301) INDIAN POET By his English translations of the poems of Hali, Mr. Ward has made the poet widely known.
('4', 445, 4, 18, 1004404) It is said that there is no other poet who can equal him.
('4', 445, 4, 19, 1004462) His full name is Maulvi Sayed Altaf Hussain Ansari.
('4', 445, 4, 20, 1004514) He was born in Panipat, near Delhi.
('4', 445, 4, 21, 1004550) Most of his poems are in Urdu, though he has written quite a lot in Persian also.
('4', 445, 4, 22, 1004632) The poem he wrote on the occasion of the Jubilee of 1887 1 was so excellent that it resounded throughout North India.
('4', 445, 4, 23, 1004750) His works do not concern themselves with the pleasures of life, but with such useful themes as the duty of Muslims in the present age, the way both Hindus and Muslims should acquit themselves, and the way to know God.
('4', 445, 4, 24, 1004968) Sheth Abdul Kadar of Lahore tells us how during their school days he and his mates used to read Halis poems, how they read them also when
('4', 445, 5, 25, 1005106) 1The Golden Jubilee of Queen Victorias reign
('4', 446, 0, 1, 1005151) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 447
('4', 446, 1, 2, 1005194) they were grown up, and sang them at community gatherings.
('4', 446, 1, 3, 1005253) He further tells us that they listen to them even now at their anjumans 1, and seldom feel tired of reading and hearing them again and again.
('4', 446, 1, 4, 1005395) He has written in very eloquent language of the life of the great poet Sheikh Saadi 2. Writing about the work of the poet Hali, Prof.
('4', 446, 1, 5, 1005529) Morrison says: What this poor poet has done unaided for the community far surpasses what the wealthy Muslims have done with their money. In appreciation of the services rendered by the poet to the community, the Government have conferred on him the title of Shams ul Ulema.
('4', 446, 1, 6, 1005803) We are sorry we do not have with us his Urdu poems, but we recommend that our readers obtain and read them.

('4', 447, 1, 2, 1007112) 403. ADDRESS TO LORD SELBORNE1
('4', 447, 2, 3, 1007143) [POTCHEFSTROOM, Before October 9, 1905]
('4', 447, 3, 4, 1007183) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY We, the undersigned, representing British Indians residing in Potchefstroom, hereby extend to Your Excellency a hearty and loyal welcome to this historic city.
('4', 447, 3, 5, 1007373) We venture to hope that you will carry with you pleasant recollections of your stay among the people of Potchefstroom.
('4', 447, 3, 6, 1007492) The difficulties that we labour under in Potchefstroom are common to British Indians all over the Transvaal.
('4', 447, 3, 7, 1007601) A charge has been laid 2 against British Indians in Potchefstroom as to their mode of life and the manner in which their business premises are kept.
('4', 447, 3, 8, 1007750) We would venture respectfully to invite Your Excellencys inspection of the premises 3 and form your own conclusions about them.
('4', 447, 3, 9, 1007878) We are most anxious, so far as it is possible, to conform to local customs, and to conciliate popular sentiment.
('4', 447, 3, 10, 1007991) All we ask for is freedom of locomotion, trade, residence, and ownership of property under such general sanitary and other regular general regulations as may be necessary without introducing class legislation.
('4', 447, 3, 11, 1008201) We approach Your Excellency with all confidence that we will receive justice at your hands.
('4', 447, 3, 12, 1008293) We beg you to convey sentiments of our attachment to Their Most Gracious Majesties the King Emperor and the Queen Empress.
('4', 447, 3, 13, 1008416) S. D. ROBERT, PRESIDENT, E. H. GETTA, E. M. PATEL, M. E. NANABHAY, HAJEE OMAR, A. E. GONGAT, A. M. CASSIM,
('4', 447, 4, 14, 1008523) 1 The address was presented on behalf of the Potchefstroom Indian Association.
('4', 447, 4, 15, 1008602) Similar addresses were presented at Rustenburg, Klerksdorp and Krugersdorp.
('4', 447, 4, 16, 1008678) Vide Lord Selborne on Trek, Indian Opinion, 14 10 1905.
('4', 447, 5, 17, 1008734) 2 By the Potchefstroom Vigilants Association
('4', 447, 6, 18, 1008779) 3 This is evidently a slip and should read: We would venture respectfully to invite Your Excellency to have an inspection of the premises and form your own conclusions about them.

('4', 448, 1, 3, 1009106) Indian Opinion, 14 10 1905
('4', 448, 2, 4, 1009133) 404. POTCHEFSTROOM INDIANS STATEMENT1
('4', 448, 3, 5, 1009171) [POTCHEFSTROOM, Before October 9, 1905]
('4', 448, 4, 6, 1009211) MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY, Did we not know that what has been called the anti Asiatic Vigilance Society is to make representations to Your Excellency with reference to the British Indians, so far as regards Potchefstroom, we would not have given any trouble whatsoever to Your Excellency, especially as we are aware that Your Excellency is to meet very shortly a deputation of the British Indian Association at Johannesburg.
('4', 448, 4, 7, 1009640) Mr. Loveday it was who stated that Potchefstroom was being inundated with indentured Indians from Natal.
('4', 448, 4, 8, 1009745) To this we beg to give an emphatic contradiction.
('4', 448, 4, 9, 1009795) Some of us know the Natal laws, and we [know that it] is next to impossible for an indentured Indian to escape.
('4', 448, 4, 10, 1009907) In any case not a single instance has been brought forward to prove the statement above referred to.
('4', 448, 4, 11, 1010008) Another statement was made by the Mayor of Johannesburg when he was here.
('4', 448, 4, 12, 1010082) He is reported to have said that, whereas there were nineteen licences issued to Asiatics before the war, now there were ninety six traders licences and thirty seven hawkers licences.
('4', 448, 4, 13, 1010266) This statement, so far as traders are concerned, is not true.
('4', 448, 4, 14, 1010328) We supplied before the war a list of British Indian traders in the town of Potchefstroom to the British Agent, and there were twenty two British Indian stores in the town of Potchefstroom, as distinguished from the district.
('4', 448, 4, 15, 1010553) We have a true copy of the list that was sent to the British Agent, and we are to day in a position, not only to give the names, but to locate each of the store keepers.
('4', 448, 4, 16, 1010723) Seeing that Mr. Goch mentions
('4', 448, 5, 17, 1010753) 1 This was read out by Mr. Abdool Rahman, Secretary, Potchefstroom Indian Association, after he had presented the address to Lord Selborne.
('4', 449, 0, 1, 1010893) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 449, 1, 2, 1010935) ninety six traders licences in connection with the nineteen before the war, we take it that he refers to ninety six traders licences for the town of Potchefstroom.
('4', 449, 1, 3, 1011099) If so, this is grossly untrue.
('4', 449, 1, 4, 1011130) There are only twenty four British Indian stores in this town at the present day.
('4', 449, 1, 5, 1011212) We state this with a full sense of responsibility and knowledge, and we challenge our detractors to prove the contrary.
('4', 449, 1, 6, 1011332) A third statement that has been made against us in Potchefstroom is with reference to the so called insanitary condition of our dwellings and shops.
('4', 449, 1, 7, 1011481) These, indeed, speak for themselves, but when the charge was made, we took the opportunity of showing our places to the District Surgeon of Potchefstroom, and the following is the report that he gave:
('4', 449, 2, 8, 1011682) In going through the various premises, I am pleased to say I was greatly impressed with the general condition of each place I visited, both internally as well as externally.
('4', 449, 2, 9, 1011856) Taking all things into consideration, the backyards are all perfectly clean and sanitary.
('4', 449, 2, 10, 1011946) I saw no accumulation of rubbish, this I understand being carried away daily by the contractor.
('4', 449, 2, 11, 1012042) The bucket system is enforced as in other parts of the town, which is also attended to by the Sanitary Department, and I can find no fault from what I saw.
('4', 449, 2, 12, 1012198) There appears to me to be no overcrowding as regards sleeping accommodation.
('4', 449, 2, 13, 1012275) At the back of each business premises, in addition, I noticed a kind of mess room capable of seating about five to eight persons, and each has its own kitchen; these are also well kept.
('4', 449, 2, 14, 1012461) We mention these things to show under what disadvantages we have to labour, and what misrepresentations are made against us.
('4', 449, 2, 15, 1012586) We have no hesitation in saying that the whole of the anti Asiatic agitation is due to trade jealousy.
('4', 449, 2, 16, 1012689) Nothing can be further from our wish than to enter into an unfair competition with the white store keepers.
('4', 449, 2, 17, 1012797) Much has been said against our mode of life.
('4', 449, 2, 18, 1012842) We are proud to think that we are sober and simple in our habits, and if thereby we have an advantage over the rival white traders, we hardly think that it should be brought up against us in order to traduce and degrade us.
('4', 449, 2, 19, 1013066) It is totally forgotten, in this connection, by those who denounce us, that the white traders have other advantages which we cannot dream of having, namely, their European connection, their knowledge of the English language, and their better organising powers.
('4', 449, 2, 20, 1013327) Moreover, we are able to carry on our trade only because of the goodwill of the poor whites, and our ability to please the poorest class of customers; also, we have the support of wholesale European houses.
('4', 449, 2, 21, 1013534) It has been said that our competition resulted in many European shops being closed.
('4', 449, 2, 22, 1013618) We deny this.
('4', 449, 2, 23, 1013632) In the first instance, some of the shops that have been closed were not shops with which we could possibly enter into
('4', 450, 0, 1, 1013750) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 451
('4', 450, 1, 2, 1013793) competition, for instance, hairdressers and others.
('4', 450, 1, 3, 1013845) Some general goods stores have undoubtedly closed, but to connect their closing with Asiatic competition would be [as] unfair as to connect the closing of several Asiatic shops with European competition in this town.
('4', 450, 1, 4, 1014062) There is trade depression all over South Africa, and it has only resulted in getting rid of overtrading that was indulged in soon after the war, based, as it was, on high expectations which have never been fulfilled.
('4', 450, 2, 5, 1014279) May we also, in this connection, state that much of the agitation against us is kept up not by bona fide British subjects but by aliens who can have very little indeed to complain of against us.
('4', 450, 2, 6, 1014474) The policy adopted to drive us out of the township is a policy of irritation and insults which, though petty in themselves, are galling enough to be very much felt by us.
('4', 450, 3, 7, 1014645) Without the slightest occasion, we are now served at special counters in the Post Office.
('4', 450, 3, 8, 1014735) We are debarred from having a breath of fresh air in a park which is called a public park, and which is kept up from rates which we are called upon to pay in common with other citizens.
('4', 450, 3, 9, 1014921) We mention these instances to draw Your Excellencys attention to the awkward position in which we are placed without any fault of ours.
('4', 450, 3, 10, 1015057) No opportunity is missed of degrading us and humiliating us.
('4', 450, 3, 11, 1015118) We do not wish to burden Your Excellency with such other instances.
('4', 450, 3, 12, 1015186) We have a right, we submit, to expect the British Government to protect us from such humiliation, and insure for us that freedom to which, as loyal British subjects, we are entitled wherever the Union Jack flies.
('4', 450, 3, 13, 1015399) We beg to thank Your Excellency for giving us a patient hearing, and in conclusion hope that, as a result of Your Excellencys visit to this township, there will be an amelioration in our condition.
('4', 450, 4, 14, 1015597) Indian Opinion, 14 10 1905
('4', 450, 5, 15, 1015624) 405. LORD SELBORNE AND INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('4', 450, 6, 16, 1015672) His Excellency the High Commissioner has made, during his tour in the Transvaal, two very important speeches on the status of the British Indians in that Colony.
('4', 450, 6, 17, 1015834) His speech at Potchefstroom, which will be found in another column, is the more important.
('4', 450, 6, 18, 1015925) Lord Selborne has shown therein that, during his short stay, he has studied the question.
('4', 450, 6, 19, 1016015) He holds the honour of the Government very dear to him, and recognises the fact that there were promises made to British
('4', 451, 0, 1, 1016136) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 451, 1, 2, 1016178) Indians before the war which have to be carried out.
('4', 451, 1, 3, 1016231) His Lordship, weare further glad to notice, interprets the Indians Proclamation 1 as an assurance of the rights of Indians as full British subjects all the world over.
('4', 451, 1, 4, 1016399) For all this, and a great deal more, we are truly thankful to His Excellency.
('4', 451, 1, 5, 1016477) When there is such an evident desire to hold the scales evenly between conflicting interests, there is every ground for hope that, in the near future, a solution will be found for this difficult problem which will be generally accepted.
('4', 451, 1, 6, 1016714) One thing, however, that Lord Selborne is reported to have promised, fills us with disquiet.
('4', 451, 1, 7, 1016807) These are the reported words:
('4', 451, 2, 8, 1016837) No Indians who were not here before the war will be admitted into the country till you have your own parliament, and by your own representatives you can express your own opinion.
('4', 451, 2, 9, 1017016) I give you that assurance as your Governor and your High Commissioner.
('4', 451, 2, 10, 1017087) We are sure that His Excellency could not have, at the time of making the promise, measured the full consequence of its operation.
('4', 451, 2, 11, 1017218) His Excellency is anxious to draw the distinction between Indians already settled in the country and those who may come hereafter.
('4', 451, 2, 12, 1017349) He impressed upon his audience the necessity of giving fair treatment to the old Indian settlers.
('4', 451, 2, 13, 1017447) Now the fact that Indian merchants must draw upon India for confidential clerks, managers, and other trustworthy servants has only to be mentioned to convey conviction.
('4', 451, 2, 14, 1017616) It is well nigh impossible for them to continue to do business with any degree of safety without such facilities.
('4', 451, 2, 15, 1017730) Are we, then, to understand that, unless the incoming Transvaal Parliament chooses to do otherwise, Indian businesses are to be starved into surrender for want of reliable men?
('4', 451, 2, 16, 1017907) His Excellency says again that it is not practical statesmanship to allow Indians to compete with white men without restriction.
('4', 451, 2, 17, 1018036) We have often discussed this proposition in these columns, and we think we have shown how hollow it is.
('4', 451, 2, 18, 1018140) For that which is true in it has been admitted by the Indians, and that which is not true arises only from pure trade jealousy.
('4', 451, 2, 19, 1018268) The soundness of the Indian position must be apparent to any but the most prejudiced man, when it is explained that, with proper safeguards, new Indian licences may be granted only at the option of the local boards, which consist largely of traders.
('4', 451, 2, 20, 1018518) But the anti Asiatic agitators, who are bent on driving every Indian out of the Colony, will not be satisfied until they succeed in making his life totally unbearable.
('4', 451, 2, 21, 1018686) It is against attempts such as these that the Indians have a right to expect Lord Selborne to protect them.
('4', 451, 2, 22, 1018794) Indian Opinion, 14 10 1905

('4', 452, 1, 2, 1018898) 406. THE VISIT OF LORD SELBORNE Today Lord Selborne arrives in Durban, having spent most of the week in Natal 1. In common with the rest of the community, we most heartily give our humble Welcome.
('4', 452, 1, 3, 1019095) Lord Selborne has been in South Africa only a short while, but already he has gained the confidence of all sections of the people that he will do his duty to everyone without Ear or favour.
('4', 452, 1, 4, 1019285) In many ways, His Excellency will find Natal different from the sister Colonies.
('4', 452, 1, 5, 1019366) Natal presents some interesting problems for study, in that it has a large Native population with a comparatively small white population, which is dependent for the chief industries under As control upon a large indentured Indian population.
('4', 452, 1, 6, 1019608) The presence of the latter has naturally attracted to the Colony Indians of the trading class.
('4', 452, 1, 7, 1019703) We trust that, during his short stay, Hi Excellency be able to give stay of hi valuable time to a study of the British Indians in Natal who form by common consent one of the most loyal and law abiding sections of Hi Majestys subjects.
('4', 452, 1, 8, 1019938) And we hope with the rest of the community that His Excellency and family will enjoy their visit to the Garden Colony and carry with them pleasant recollections.

('4', 452, 2, 10, 1020127) 407. THE BUBONIG PLAGUE
('4', 452, 3, 11, 1020151) Plague has come to stay.
('4', 452, 3, 12, 1020176) It is the annual messenger which, year after year, comes as a warning against darkness, filth and overcrowding.
('4', 452, 3, 13, 1020288) Wherever it has once appeared, it has hitherto unfailingly reappeared with more or less regularity.
('4', 452, 3, 14, 1020388) News has arrived that it has travelled as far as Chinde 2. From there to Durban is not a far cry.
('4', 452, 3, 15, 1020486) It, therefore, behoves every good citizen to take the necessary precautions to ward off the Send.
('4', 452, 3, 16, 1020584) There should be no disguising of the fact that Indians are more susceptible to the ravages of plague than other communities, even as are the whites more liable to catch typhoid fever than the Indians.
('4', 452, 3, 17, 1020785) The latter, therefore, have to be doubly careful.
('4', 452, 3, 18, 1020835) All the surroundings of dwelling houses and business premises should be kept perfectly clean.
('4', 452, 3, 19, 1020929) People should get as much light, sun and air as possible, and all

('4', 453, 4, 11, 1021960) 409. SIR HENRY LAWRENCE
('4', 453, 5, 12, 1021984) This great man was born in Ceylon on June 28, 1806. As he was born in the city of Matara 1, in jest, his mother called him the Jewel of Matara, and he proved to be a real jewel indeed.
('4', 453, 5, 13, 1022169) In 1823 he went to Calcutta, where he got employment in the Bengal Artillery.
('4', 453, 5, 14, 1022247) The first responsible work entrusted to him was during the First Burmese War 2. While discharging his duty during that war, he fell ill and had to go to England where, instead of passing his time in sports and amusements, he devoted it to study.
('4', 453, 5, 15, 1022493) He returned to India in 1830, and rejoined his battalion.
('4', 453, 5, 16, 1022551) He then studied Hindustani and Persian.
('4', 453, 5, 17, 1022591) He spent all his free time in solitude.
('4', 453, 5, 18, 1022631) One of his r easons for doing so was that he wanted to save as much money as possible for his mother.
('4', 453, 5, 19, 1022733) In the meanwhile, he was appointed to a very important and responsible post, where he fully utilized the knowledge he had acquired during his illness in England.
('4', 453, 5, 20, 1022895) The work entrusted to him was that of carrying out a survey in the North West Province for the purpose of levying taxes from the people there.
('4', 453, 5, 21, 1023038) The real merits of Lawrence came to be known then.
('4', 453, 5, 22, 1023089) Though a soldier, he had a very tender and merciful heart.
('4', 453, 5, 23, 1023148) The survey work brought him into close contact with the poor, and this enabled him to understand the feelings and the manners and customs of the people.
('4', 453, 5, 24, 1023301) He became one of them

('4', 454, 1, 2, 1023403) and mixed freely with them.
('4', 454, 1, 3, 1023431) As he was very hard working and persevering, the idlers under him hated him.
('4', 454, 1, 4, 1023508) He did not hesitate to use compulsion against shirkers.
('4', 454, 1, 5, 1023564) Once it happened that one of the survey officers committed a blunder, to rectify which Lawrence ordered him to visit the place again.

('4', 454, 1, 11, 1024084) After this the man shed this obstinate habit and began to do very good work under Lawrence.
('4', 454, 2, 12, 1024176) We have heard that in the days of old, a brother was often ready to die for a brother, a friend for a friend, a mother for a son, sons for parents and a wife for her husband.
('4', 454, 2, 13, 1024351) But Lawrence acted in this manner in modern times.
('4', 454, 2, 14, 1024402) His elder brother had been taken prisoner in the Afghan War, and was released on parole for a few days by the Pathan Chief.
('4', 454, 2, 15, 1024526) He was bound to return after the period of parole was over.
('4', 454, 2, 16, 1024586) Considering that his brothers services were more useful, Lawrence offered to take his place in the prison.
('4', 454, 2, 17, 1024693) Although the brother refused to agree to the proposal, Lawrence as good as did it.
('4', 454, 2, 18, 1024776) While Lawrence was serving as ambassador in Nepal, his kind hearted wife spent her days in good works.

('4', 454, 2, 20, 1025045) Similar institutions have since been built all over India, and all of them have been called Lawrence Asylums.

('4', 454, 2, 23, 1025326) After the War, he did very good work as Her Majestys representative in Lahore, for which knighthood was conferred upon him.
('4', 454, 2, 24, 1025450) When in 1849 it was proposed to annex the Punjab, Lawrence alone opposed it and stood up to a Governor General of the calibre of Lord Dalhousie.

('4', 454, 2, 26, 1025746) For he had earlier come into very close contact with the Sikhs who greatly loved and admired him.
('4', 454, 2, 27, 1025844) It is because of this that the Punjab was pacified.

('4', 456, 5, 18, 1029388) If it is very often strong to protect, it is also often powerless to defend against a palpable injustice.

('4', 457, 4, 19, 1031538) 412. THE EVILS OF SMOKING
('4', 457, 5, 20, 1031564) The Government of South Australia has noticed that smoking, besides consuming a lot of money, badly undermines the health of the people.
('4', 457, 5, 21, 1031701) More harm is done by cigarettes than by cigars, for the former, being smaller and cheaper, are consumed in excess.
('4', 457, 5, 22, 1031816) The Government therefore propose to introduce a Bill prohibiting the manufacture and sale of cigarettes.
('4', 457, 5, 23, 1031921) The evil habit of smoking cigarettes has nowadays become very widespread among us, both young and old.
('4', 457, 5, 24, 1032024) This is sheer imitation of the English.
('4', 457, 5, 25, 1032064) Formerly, people were no doubt in the habit of smoking bidis or country cigarettes, but they used to keep it within limits.
('4', 457, 5, 26, 1032188) They felt ashamed of smoking any and everywhere.
('4', 457, 5, 27, 1032237) They did it at specific times and that, too, in privacy.
('4', 457, 5, 28, 1032294) It was considered lack of decency to smoke publicly in the streets at all hours of the day, and people rarely smoked outside their homes.
('4', 457, 5, 29, 1032432) Hence the saying about tobacco, that it spoils a corner [in the house] of one who chews it, the whole house of one who smokes it, and the clothes of one who sniffs it.
('4', 457, 5, 30, 1032600) But the English today never mind smoking anywhere and everywhere, and we
('4', 458, 0, 1, 1032673) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 459
('4', 458, 1, 2, 1032716) too are copying them.
('4', 458, 1, 3, 1032738) When the people in a country like South Australia have begun to realise the harm done by smoking, we also, we hope, will learn a lesson and come to some decision in the matter.

('4', 458, 2, 5, 1032958) 413. RAJA SIR T. MADHAV RAO
('4', 458, 3, 6, 1032986) Sir T. Madhav Rao was born in 1828 in the city of Kumba konam 1. His father, Shri R. Langa Rao, had been the Dewan of Travancore, and his uncle, Rai R. Venkat Rao, had been the Dewan as well as Revenue Commissioner of Travancore.
('4', 458, 3, 7, 1033216) Sir Madhav Rao had spent his childhood and received his education in Madras.
('4', 458, 3, 8, 1033293) He studied at Presidency College [Madras] under Mr. Powell.
('4', 458, 3, 9, 1033353) Madhav Rao was a hard working student, and was proficient in Mathematics and Science.
('4', 458, 3, 10, 1033439) He had learnt astronomy while sitting on the stairs of Mr. Powells house, and he made a microscope and a telescope from bamboo with his own hands.
('4', 458, 4, 11, 1033586) Unwilling to part with such an intelligent student, Mr. Powell appointed him Professor of Mathematics and Physics under himself.
('4', 458, 4, 12, 1033715) Later, Madhav Rao got a good post in the office of the Accountant General, and after some time, on being invited to work as a tutor to the princes of Travancore, he accepted the offer.
('4', 458, 4, 13, 1033900) This was how he entered,for the first time, the service of a Native State.
('4', 458, 4, 14, 1033975) Theprinces in his charge became good students, and their career as rulers also proved to be very successful.
('4', 458, 4, 15, 1034084) After working as a tutor for four years, he was given the responsible post of an assistant to the Dewan.
('4', 458, 4, 16, 1034189) He was later appointed Deputy Dewan, in which post he earned a good name.
('4', 458, 4, 17, 1034263) The State had been in a very bad condition.
('4', 458, 4, 18, 1034307) The late Mr. J. Bruce Norton has said of him: He was a great scholar and a political administrator.
('4', 458, 4, 19, 1034407) In the short space of a year he established peace in the land.
('4', 458, 4, 20, 1034470) To everyone he meted out justice without fear or favour.
('4', 458, 4, 21, 1034527) He greatly reduced theft, treachery and deceit.
('4', 458, 5, 22, 1034575) The Dewan of Travancore was a very weak man, and the Maharaja too was ill informed.
('4', 458, 5, 23, 1034659) He did not know how the administration was going on, and the officers of the State too had become debased and corrupt.
('4', 458, 5, 24, 1034778) Their salary, moreover, was very low and sometimes fell into arrears for months.
('4', 458, 5, 25, 1034859) The loan advanced by the British Government had not yet been repaid, and the treasury was

('4', 459, 1, 2, 1035009) The taxes being heavy, trade was in a very bad state and the people were reduced to utter poverty.
('4', 459, 1, 3, 1035108) This caught the attention of Lord Dalhousie 1 who resolved to take over the administration of the State on behalf of the British Government and proceeded to Octacamund with a view to annexing the State to Madras Presidency.
('4', 459, 1, 4, 1035332) At this time, the Maharaja appointed Madhav Rao to the post of Dewan and he successfully pleaded with the British Government to give him seven years time to improve the State administration.
('4', 459, 1, 5, 1035523) In this way, at: the early age of 30, by dint of personal effort and honesty, Madhav Rao attained a distinguished position.
('4', 459, 1, 6, 1035647) The notable event of his career as Dewan pertained to the State revenues.
('4', 459, 1, 7, 1035721) The State finances were in a bad way when he took charge as Dewan.
('4', 459, 1, 8, 1035788) He abolished the excessive land revenue and other taxes imposed in the past as they were harmful to the prosperity of the people.
('4', 459, 1, 9, 1035918) He also abolished the system of monopoly for revenue collection.
('4', 459, 1, 10, 1035983) He met the deficit in the annual revenues by levying an export duty of 15 per cent.
('4', 459, 1, 11, 1036067) on all goods.
('4', 459, 1, 12, 1036081) As the State went on prospering, he gradually reduced the rate of this duty and brought it down to 5 per cent.
('4', 459, 1, 13, 1036192) Next he abolished the monopoly in tobacco also and permitted State subjects to buy it directly from outside, replacing the former system of Government first buying it at its own risk from the contractors and then selling it to the people.
('4', 459, 1, 14, 1036431) The tariff burden being thus made light, imports received much encouragement.
('4', 459, 1, 15, 1036509) He then removed many other petty taxes and cesses as they did not yield much revenue and were also harmful to the prosperity of the merchants.
('4', 459, 1, 16, 1036652) He reduced, at one stroke, the very heavy land tax in a certain village.

('4', 459, 2, 22, 1037481) He had many works of public utility executed and promoted agriculture by reducing land revenue.

('4', 461, 4, 9, 1040697) JOHANNESBURG
('4', 461, 5, 10, 1040710) DEAR SIR, We, the undersigned, on behalf of the Reception Committee, hereby extend to you a hearty welcome to Johannesburg.
