('4', 462, 2, 3, 1041985) 415. HISTORY OF THE PLAGUE IN JOHANNESBURG
('4', 462, 3, 4, 1042028) The long promised report of the bubonic plague that broke out in Johannesburg last year is now published.
('4', 462, 3, 5, 1042134) It is a bulky volume covering one hundred and three pages, and containing many charts giving a graphic report of the epidemic.
('4', 462, 3, 6, 1042261) Dr. Pakes, the author of the report has given an immense amount of labour to the work, and has presented to the public a very learned disquisition.
('4', 462, 3, 7, 1042409) The most interesting part of the report must necessarily be the origin of the plague, and while, if the premises laid down by Dr. Pakes were correct, the conclusions drawn by him would be justified we fear that many of his most important premises are totally incorrect.
('4', 462, 4, 8, 1042679) It is, perhaps, extremely unfortunate that a proper judicial inquiry was not made as to the origin of the plague before so much valuable time and money were spent over the report.
('4', 462, 4, 9, 1042859) In giving the startling reason that Dr. Pakes has done, he has run counter to the findings of the Vienna Commission, as also the Commission that was appointed by the Natal Government when the plague first broke out in Natal as also, indeed, to the cablegram that was received by the late Mr. Escombe from the Indian Government.
('4', 462, 4, 10, 1043187) Dr. Pakes contends that the origin of the first cases was the plague infected rice imported from Bombay.
('4', 462, 4, 11, 1043292) The authorities we have just quoted came to the conclusion that rice was not a carrier of plague infection.
('4', 462, 4, 12, 1043400) Amongst the premises that have led Dr. Pakes to his conclusion are that the first cases were those of store keepers, that the Indian store keepers were importing rice from Bombay in December 1903, that they said very definitely this rice contained rat droppings, and that no special precautions were taken at Bombay to prevent the export of probably and possibly infected rice.
('4', 462, 4, 13, 1043778) Now, unfortunately for Dr. Pakes theory, all these premises are without foundation.
('4', 462, 4, 14, 1043862) The very first mistake that has been committed in drawing up the report is to accept only the official date of the outbreak, and to ignore the whole of the previously known history.
('4', 462, 4, 15, 1044044) It was then contended, indeed proved beyond doubt, that
('4', 463, 0, 1, 1044100) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 463, 1, 2, 1044142) plague had existed in Johannesburg before the 18th March.
('4', 463, 1, 3, 1044200) In spite of the correspondence 1 that was brought to the notice of the plague authorities in their official capacity, Dr. Pakes has seen fit to ignore the whole of it in his report.
('4', 463, 1, 4, 1044382) He has also ignored the case of the late Dr. Marais, which points unmistakably to the existence of the plague long before he himself succumbed to it.
('4', 463, 1, 5, 1044532) The theory, therefore, that the plague started with store keepers falls to the ground.
('4', 463, 1, 6, 1044619) Nay, more, the two names given by Dr. Pakes as those of store keepers were not those of store keepers at all, as we happen to know.
('4', 463, 1, 7, 1044751) The first cases, taking the outbreak as from the 18th March, were amongst the labourers who came from the mines.
('4', 463, 1, 8, 1044864) We should very much like to know where the information, that rice was being imported from Bombay, comes from.
('4', 463, 1, 9, 1044974) As a rule, rice is not imported from Bombay but from Calcutta, and, even when it does come from Bombay, the bags are made up in Calcutta.
('4', 463, 1, 10, 1045112) It is a serious reflection upon the Indian Government to state that no special precautions are taken at Bombay to prevent the export of probably and possibly infected rice.
('4', 463, 1, 11, 1045285) Those who know anything of Indian travelling know that precautions taken at Bombay are very severe.
('4', 463, 1, 12, 1045385) Therefore, all the material premises leading to the conclusion that Dr. Pakes has arrived at are not, in our opinion, capable of being proved.
('4', 463, 1, 13, 1045528) How is it, again, that Johannesburg had remained free from the plague in spite of rice having been imported by Indians before also ?
('4', 463, 1, 14, 1045661) For it is not to be contended that rice was for the first time introduced into Johannesburg in 1904. What the real cause of the epidemic was will probably never be known, but so long as it is not found, so long will measures to prevent an outbreak fail.
('4', 463, 1, 15, 1045915) We do not suggest that there will be a recurrence in Johannesburg, for the plague epidemic, in an altitude so high as that of Johannesburg, is hardly possible, except under the most aggravating circumstances.
('4', 463, 1, 16, 1046124) In spite of his usual fairness, we fear that Dr. Pakes has failed to do justice in entirely ignoring the Herculean efforts that were made by the Indian community to prevent an outbreak of plague by placing at the disposal of the authorities all the information of suspected cases, as also warning them of the state of the Location after it passed into the hands of the Municipality.
('4', 463, 1, 17, 1046507) We feel that Dr. Pakes has shirked the real issue by giving extracts from the evidence of Dr. Porter before the Insanitary Area Commission in his work as to the then state of the Indian Location.
('4', 463, 1, 18, 1046703) The measures that were taken to eradicate the
('4', 463, 2, 19, 1046749) 1 Vide Letter to Dr. Porter, 11 2 1904 /15 2 1904 & Letter to Dr. Porter, 18 
('4', 463, 3, 20, 1046827) 3 1904.
('4', 464, 0, 1, 1046835) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 465
('4', 464, 1, 2, 1046878) outbreak are all accurately described in the report in question, and they reflect very high credit on the worthy Doctor and his assistants.
('4', 464, 1, 3, 1047018) The manner in which the Location and the Johannesburg Market were dealt with was worthy of very high praise, and it was no doubt due to the energetic action taken by Dr. Pakes and his able assistant, Dr. Mackenzie, that the disease was so promptly stamped out.
('4', 464, 1, 4, 1047279) Indian Opinion, 28 10 1905
('4', 464, 2, 5, 1047306) 416. A CORRECTION
('4', 464, 3, 6, 1047324) The Potchefstroom Budget has.
('4', 464, 3, 7, 1047354) noticed our remarks on Lord Selbornes speech wherein His Excellency has promised in his official capacity that no Indians except those who were here before the war will be admitted into the Transvaal until the introduction of representative government.
('4', 464, 3, 8, 1047607) Our contemporary says:
('4', 464, 4, 9, 1047630) This is a new phase of the grievances, and is evidently the initiation of a policy which will do much to alienate the sympathy that hasbeen extended to the Indians already here by the moderate section of the white population.
('4', 464, 4, 10, 1047856) If they are wise they will refrain, in their own interests, from forcing us to believe that, after all, their ultimate aim is to make the Transvaal a dumping ground for thousands of Indian subjects.
('4', 464, 4, 11, 1048055) Indian Opinion talks glibly about an attempt to drive every Indian out of the Colony.
('4', 464, 4, 12, 1048141) As far as the Potchefstroom policy is concerned, this is absolutely untrue, because it has been amply proved that the desire of the people of this district is to show the utmost consideration to the Indians holding vested rights by reason of their old established businesses.
('4', 464, 4, 13, 1048417) When, however, we are asked to tolerate an importation that will tend only to perpetuate an undoubted evil, the spirit of moderation will, we fear, be eliminated.
('4', 464, 4, 14, 1048580) We are quite at a loss to perceive how the importation of a few necessary clerks can be making the Transvaal a dumping ground for thousands of Indian subjects, but it is perhaps too much to expect the Budget to view the Asiatic question with even a modicum of common sense.
('4', 464, 4, 15, 1048854) The justice of our remarks is, surely, self evident.
('4', 464, 4, 16, 1048907) The entire shutting out of new Indians would mean the ultimate driving out of most Indians from that Colony; and, however desirable such a consummation may be to a section of the Transvaal population, we can scarcely be expected to view the matter in quite the same light.
('4', 464, 4, 17, 1049180) We make bold to say that there is absolutely nothing in our remarks to justify the inference above mentioned.
('4', 464, 4, 18, 1049290) We have never advocated that the Transvaal should be made a dumping ground for Indians.
('4', 464, 4, 19, 1049378) But we do maintain that, if elementary justice is to be done, Indians already residing in the Transvaal ought to be allowed to draw upon India for a
('4', 465, 0, 1, 1049527) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 465, 1, 2, 1049569) necessary supply of clerks and such assistants, whether they are old residents of the Transvaal or not.
('4', 465, 1, 3, 1049673) These men can only number a very few per year.
('4', 465, 1, 4, 1049720) Our contemporary may not know that such facility is given even in the self governing Colonies of the Cape and Natal, where also there are restriction laws.
('4', 465, 1, 5, 1049876) We have no hesitation in saying that to deny the right of Indian merchants to depend upon India for necessary skilled assistance is undoubtedly to contemplate slow starvation of the already resident Indian population.
('4', 465, 1, 6, 1050094) The position we have laid down is by no means novel.
('4', 465, 1, 7, 1050147) We refer the Budget to Lord Milners despatch wherein he has most clearly laid down that Indians of education, means and ability should not be prevented from entering the Transvaal, whether they be new immigrants or not.

('4', 465, 4, 11, 1050526) The celebrations that took place on the 21st day of this month suggest very serious reflections, and to the Indian mind they should vividly show the secret of Britains success.
('4', 465, 4, 12, 1050703) Max Mller has acknowledged in his writings that in Indianphilosophy the meaning of life is summed up in four letters speltDUTY.
('4', 465, 4, 13, 1050831) Probably at the present day such a meaning of life is not apparent in the conduct of the average Indian.
('4', 465, 4, 14, 1050936) A contemplation of Lord Nelsons life, then, presents in a most striking manner an illustration of duty lived from first to last.
('4', 465, 4, 15, 1051065) The historic signal England expects that every man will do his duty is enshrined in the British heart.
('4', 465, 4, 16, 1051168) The signal was sanctified by the unflinching performance of its author, and has been hallowed by a century of its translation into deeds.
('4', 465, 4, 17, 1051306) The measure of Englands success is the measure of her peoples acceptance of Nelsons signal in the conduct of their own lives.
('4', 465, 4, 18, 1051432) If the sun never sets on the Empire, of which Nelson was one of the founders, it is because her sons have hitherto followed the path of duty.
('4', 465, 4, 19, 1051574) Nelson is worshipped today as no other man is worshipped in the Empire, not because he was a naval hero, not because he was a man who never received an answer to his question as to what fear was, 2
('4', 465, 5, 20, 1051772) but because he was a living embodiment of duty.

('4', 466, 1, 9, 1052226) In a continent like South Africa, where there are constant deflections from the straight path shown by Nelson, it is well to remind ourselves of a life like his.

('4', 468, 4, 7, 1056577) 420. OUR DUTY
('4', 468, 5, 8, 1056591) It has come to our knowledge that some Indians are offended by our article on the plague.
('4', 468, 5, 9, 1056681) We are sorry, but not surprised.
('4', 468, 5, 10, 1056714) We should rather be complimented on drawing attention to the subject, but we are being blamed because we do not hesitate to mention others faults.
('4', 468, 5, 11, 1056861) Thanks to the plague, many villages in India have been laid waste, numerous families entirely wiped out, and people are running in fright from one place to another.
('4', 468, 5, 12, 1057026) Wherever there has been plague outside India, our people have largely been responsible for importing it, and its quick eradication from those parts has been due to the fact that the task of combating it is generally in the hands of other people.
('4', 468, 5, 13, 1057272) What is the duty of the Press, that is, our duty, on such an occasion ?
('4', 468, 5, 14, 1057344) We could easily win the applause of the people by suppressing their faults.
('4', 468, 5, 15, 1057420) But we would fail utterly in our duty if we did so.
('4', 468, 5, 16, 1057472) Our duty is to serve the people.
('4', 468, 5, 17, 1057505) While championing their rights, if we happen to observe any of their shortcomings, we must bring these to their notice.
('4', 468, 5, 18, 1057625) If instead of doing so we went on flattering them, we would be playing the part of an enemy.
('4', 468, 5, 19, 1057718) As we said at the very outset, we shall boldly defend our people if our opponents speak ill of them; but at the same time, if we notice any shortcomings in our people, we shall fearlessly expose them to the public gaze and urge their removal.
('4', 468, 5, 20, 1057961) Who will do this if we dont ?
('4', 468, 5, 21, 1057991) We have never cherished, nor do we do so now, the idea of doing anything simply to please others.

('4', 470, 2, 5, 1060976) 422. AN ABLE INDIAN
('4', 470, 3, 6, 1060996) The Daily Mail, a well known English paper, has narrated a story of great loyalty shown by an Indian in India.
('4', 470, 3, 7, 1061107) He was a surveyor named Khan Bahadur Mohiuddin.
('4', 470, 3, 8, 1061155) It fell to his lot in 1903 to survey arid waste land in Rajputana.
('4', 470, 3, 9, 1061222) He had with him four messengers, four assistant surveyors and two camels.
('4', 470, 3, 10, 1061296) Once, travelling at night, they found their water bag burst and all the water drained.
('4', 470, 3, 11, 1061383) The messengers advised return, but brave Mohiuddin was not the man to turn back.
('4', 470, 3, 12, 1061464) He sent one of the messengers in search of water, which was fetched but was found to be exceedingly brackish.
('4', 470, 3, 13, 1061574) Marching on they came upon some water which, however, soon gave out.
('4', 470, 3, 14, 1061643) The Khan Bahadur had by then become absorbed in deep thought.
('4', 470, 3, 15, 1061705) The camel drivers were tied to the camels, and the animals allowed to go as they pleased, for meanwhile the men had fainted, owing to thirst.
('4', 470, 3, 16, 1061847) At last they came to a watering place and regained consciousness.
('4', 470, 3, 17, 1061913) When in search of water thus, Mohiuddin strayed from his men, and ultimately, lost his life while doing his duty.
('4', 470, 3, 18, 1062027) However, infected with his enthusiasm, the men bravely completed the task.
('4', 470, 3, 19, 1062102) We rarely come across examples of such bravery and devotion to duty.
('4', 470, 3, 20, 1062171) The Khan Bahadurs body was given an honourable burial and his companions, who survived him, were handsomely rewarded by the Government.

('4', 472, 7, 24, 1067007) The Southwark Council in England has had an inquiry made into the benefits or otherwise of tea.
('4', 472, 7, 25, 1067103) We give below some of the notable facts collected.
('4', 472, 8, 26, 1067154) The Chinese began taking tea in the ninth century and have done so ever since.
('4', 472, 8, 27, 1067233) Tea was first introduced into England in 1660. By the eighteenth century it had spread all over the country, and at the turn of that century, twenty million pounds of tea were imported into England every year.
('4', 472, 8, 28, 1067443) In the first decade of the nineteenth century, the per capita [annual consumption of tea in England was a pound and a half, but during the last decade, the consumption has increased so
('4', 473, 0, 1, 1067628) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 473, 1, 2, 1067670) much that it now comes to six pounds.
('4', 473, 2, 3, 1067708) The first to raise his voice against tea was the famous John Wesley.
('4', 473, 2, 4, 1067777) He was a very great religious preacher.
('4', 473, 2, 5, 1067817) He was subject to fits of giddiness; but he did not suspect that it was due to tea, because everyone thought it wholly beneficial.
('4', 473, 2, 6, 1067948) Once, all of a sudden, he swooned and fell down and then resolved to give up tea; his giddiness ceased.
('4', 473, 2, 7, 1068052) Sir Andrew Clarke, a famous doctor, has said that tea weakens the nerves.

('4', 473, 2, 9, 1068327) The officer in charge of the Southwark inquiry says that tea becomes all the more injurious if it is boiled.
('4', 473, 2, 10, 1068436) It is best of course to do without it; but if the habit cannot be given up, the best way of making tea is to pour boiling water over the tea leaves, and immediately pour it out into a cup.
('4', 473, 2, 11, 1068625) The brew should not at all be red, it should rather be the colour of hay.

('4', 473, 3, 13, 1068754) In India, there is no need for it, but if, in imitation of the whites, people do want to have some drink, they should instead drink coffee or cocoa which are less harmful.

('4', 475, 4, 13, 1073573) 426. A PAINFUL DISCOVERY
('4', 475, 5, 14, 1073598) The Prisons Reform Commission gives rise to many misgivings as to the condition of indentured Indians on some of the estates in Natal.
('4', 475, 5, 15, 1073733) At Verulam recently, according to a Reuter telegram published in the Transvaal Leader, evidence was given by gaol officials to the effect that it is customary with certain estates employing large numbers of Indians to get their coolies, when ill, convicted of some minor offence in order that they may be cured of their sickness at the expense of the Government and returned fit for work.
('4', 475, 5, 16, 1074122) Had such a charge been made by an outsider, he would undoubtedly have been hooted out of court, so inhuman and unbelievable does it appear at first sight.
('4', 475, 5, 17, 1074277) We ourselves are loth to credit it but those who have given the testimony must have spoken with a full sense of responsibility, and we may assume that they have rather understated than overstated facts.
('4', 475, 5, 18, 1074480) The matter is too serious to be left where it is.
('4', 475, 5, 19, 1074530) And it is a serious thing also that the public of Natal should get the first news of so grave an allegation from outside its borders.
('4', 475, 5, 20, 1074664) We believe the Natal Press has been wholly silent on this matter, though The Natal Mercury noticed in aneditorial note the shocking state of the Verulam gaol.
('4', 475, 5, 21, 1074823) We must be content to wait the usual length of time for the publication of the Report before we can know exactly what the evidence was.
('4', 475, 5, 22, 1074959) We have said we cannot bring ourselves to believe that the charge can be generally sustained, but while thinking it somewhat improbable, we cannot forget the hideous things that were brought to light by a Commission on the treatment of indentured Indians in British Guiana about forty years ago.
('4', 475, 5, 23, 1075255) Then, things far more inhuman
('4', 476, 0, 1, 1075285) VOL. 4 : 23 MAY, 1904 4 NOVEMBER, 1905 477
('4', 476, 1, 2, 1075328) and unbelievable were proved to have occurred, and not in isolated instances.
('4', 476, 1, 3, 1075406) The treatment of sick Indians especially was peculiarly bad, and that in spite of excellent laws for their protection.
('4', 476, 1, 4, 1075525) This can be to some extent understood when it is remembered that a sick indentured Indian is a dead weight on his employer.
('4', 476, 1, 5, 1075649) It is to be hoped that the estate owners will themselves insist on a thorough investigation for the sake of their fair name.
('4', 476, 1, 6, 1075774) It is not right that the misdeeds of one or twoif the charge be proven should reflect on others whose aim it is to treat their indentured and helpless employees not only with justice but with something more.

('4', 476, 3, 8, 1076008) 427. DIVIDE AND RULE
('4', 476, 4, 9, 1076029) The title of this article is a maxim as old as the hills, and the policy underlying the maxim was enunciated by a British statesman in connection with British rule in India.
('4', 476, 4, 10, 1076203) The cablegram from India that has appeared lately in the newspapers brings the aphorism vividly home to us.
('4', 476, 4, 11, 1076311) It is said that twenty thousand Mahomedans at Dacca, the capital of the new province partitioned from Bengal, assembled together and offered prayers of thanksgiving to the Almighty for the partition, and their consequent deliverance from Hindu oppression.
('4', 476, 4, 12, 1076567) We cannot bring ourselves to believe that the movement could possibly be spontaneous.
('4', 476, 4, 13, 1076653) It is absurd on the face of it.
('4', 476, 4, 14, 1076685) Assuming that there was any oppression on the part of the Hindus, relief could be obtained without partition, because the might of the British power was there to protect one community against another.
('4', 476, 4, 15, 1076886) It is, therefore, we consider, a response to the very powerful agitation that has been set up in Bengal against partition.
('4', 476, 4, 16, 1077009) The boycott has spread with an intensity never known before.
('4', 476, 4, 17, 1077070) It has permeated classes as well as masses, and, if it is nursed long enough, it bids fair to weld together all the communities in Bengal, not excluding the Mahomedans.
('4', 476, 4, 18, 1077239) Those, therefore, who believe in the maxim above quoted, naturally wanted an antidote and they have found it amongst a few Mahomedans in Dacca.
('4', 476, 4, 19, 1077383) It is short sighted statesmanship to contemplate the government of millions of human beings on the principle of setting one class against another.
('4', 476, 4, 20, 1077530) We know that such a suggestion would be vehemently repudiated, and we know also that pure British statesmanship would revolt against the idea.
('4', 476, 4, 21, 1077673) At the same time, thepolicy itself is deep rooted, has been followed before with
('4', 477, 0, 1, 1077754) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('4', 477, 1, 2, 1077796) temporary effect, and the tamasha 1 in Dacca is but a continuation of it.
('4', 477, 1, 3, 1077870) If the Anglo Indian administrators, who have really built up the Indian Empire, and who depended for its continuance on the goodwill of the people, were to rise from their graves today, they, in our opinion, would be the first to encourage the boycott agitation, at the same time, conciliating public opinion, which has become so excited.
('4', 477, 1, 4, 1078209) What can be more natural than for the people to wish to clothe themselves, to feed themselves, and to supply their luxuries out of home grown products and home manufactures ?
('4', 477, 1, 5, 1078384) We see such movements worked out more extensively in many Colonies.
('4', 477, 1, 6, 1078452) It is a legitimate and healthy growth amongst the people, not in the slightest degree inconsistent with a feeling of loyalty to the British Crown.
('4', 477, 1, 7, 1078599) It is only a fulfilment of the prophecy uttered by Macaulay in connection with India.
('4', 477, 2, 8, 1078685) But, if the rulers of India will not see the reasonableness of the movement, why should not the Indians ?
('4', 477, 2, 9, 1078791) It is true that, to a certain extent, the introduction of British rule was possible by reason of internal dissensions but it is the peculiar province, as also the privilege, of Great Britain to bring together the two great communities in India, and to leave to them an heritage for which she would receive not only the gratitude of the millions in India, but the unstinted admiration of the whole world.
('4', 477, 2, 10, 1079195) It behoves, then, both communities to seize the opportunity offered to them, and to sink material 2 jealousies and dissensions for their common good.
('4', 477, 2, 11, 1079345) Better far, that two brothers should suffer at the hands of each other, than that a third party should step into the breach and gain an advantage over them.
('4', 477, 2, 12, 1079502) We would ask those who see these lines, no matter who they be, to join with us in the prayer that the present agitation in Bengal, which has in it the germs of the unification of the different communities, may grow in strength, and that the people of Dacca or elsewhere, whether Hindus or Mahomedans, may have the good sense to refrain from doing anything that may mar the glorious possibilities that are opened up to the people of India.

Charles Theophilus Metcalfe, who uttered these words and acted up to them, was born in Calcutta on January 30, 1785. After receiving an indifferent sort of education in England he gave up his studies at the early age of fifteen and [came to] Calcutta the following year.
('4', 479, 4, 8, 1083346) In those days the East India Company was very strict in selecting its employees, and inexperienced youths without proper education were not admitted to its service.
('4', 479, 4, 9, 1083511) Metcalfe was therefore obliged to enter the college at Calcutta.
('4', 479, 4, 10, 1083576) Thus, after receiving education for some time, Metcalfe was appointed to a subordinate post.
('4', 479, 4, 11, 1083669) At nineteen, he became Head Clerk to General Lake.
('4', 479, 4, 12, 1083720) General Lake and the officers under him were annoyed to find the young man in the civil department.
('4', 479, 4, 13, 1083820) Metcalfe took the hint and made up his mind to prove his valour in war.
('4', 479, 4, 14, 1083892) He took the lead in storming the fort of Dig 1 and put in such excellent work that General Lake became greatly pleased with him.
('4', 479, 4, 15, 1084021) Three years later Metcalfe was assigned a very responsible piece of work.

('4', 480, 1, 4, 1085334) The kingdom of man is controlled by the kingdom of God.
('4', 480, 1, 5, 1085390) The Almighty can bestow a kingdom in a moment and take it back in another.
('4', 480, 1, 6, 1085465) Mans ingenuity avails not before His command.
('4', 480, 1, 7, 1085511) The duty of the rulers, therefore, is only to advance the well being of their subjects.
('4', 480, 1, 8, 1085599) If we but discharge this duty, our Indian subjects will be grateful to us, and the world will for ever sing our praises.
('4', 480, 1, 9, 1085720) What if in future a rebellion should break out as a result of such a policy?
('4', 480, 1, 10, 1085797) Well, if out of the base fear of a future danger we should oppress the subjects, we shall deserve the attacks that may be made against us.
('4', 480, 1, 11, 1085936) And, when we are driven to such a position, the world will scorn us, will spit upon us and call us all sorts of names.
('4', 480, 1, 12, 1086055) Sympathizing with the ryots in their woes, young Metcalfe wrote such noble words.
('4', 480, 1, 13, 1086137) Metcalfe was later appointed Resident at the Nizams Court.
('4', 480, 1, 14, 1086196) The Nizams Government was at that time in great financial difficulty.
('4', 480, 1, 15, 1086266) Some crafty but powerful Englishmen had lent him large sums on interest.
('4', 480, 1, 16, 1086339) Metcalfe was much pained to learn of this.
('4', 480, 1, 17, 1086382) Without caring for what the Governor General might think, he did his duty and got rid of the crafty men.
('4', 480, 1, 18, 1086487) In 1827 Metcalfe became a member of the Viceroys Executive Council at Calcutta.
('4', 480, 1, 19, 1086567) The good Lord William Bentinck was the Viceroy then.
('4', 480, 1, 20, 1086620) When Bentinck was obliged for reasons of health to proceed suddenly to England, Metcalfe was appointed in his place as Acting Governor General.
('4', 480, 1, 21, 1086764) At this time he did the greatest deed of his life.
('4', 480, 1, 22, 1086815) He enacted the famous law giving freedom to the Indian Press, which displeased his masters the Board of Directors.
('4', 480, 1, 23, 1086930) But Metcalfe did not care.
('4', 480, 1, 24, 1086957) When prominent Englishmen opposed him, he made the following reply:
('4', 480, 2, 25, 1087025) If the argument of my opponents be that the spread of knowledge may be harmful to our rule in India, I say that, whatever be the consequences, it is our duty to educate the people.
('4', 480, 2, 26, 1087206) If British rule can be preserved only by keeping the people in ignorance, our rule then would be a curse on the country and ought to come to an end.
('4', 480, 2, 27, 1087355) But I personally think that we have much more to fear if the people remain ignorant.
('4', 480, 2, 28, 1087440) The spread of knowledge, I hope, will remove their superstitions, will enable them to appreciate the benefits of our government, will promote the goodwill between the rulers and the ruled and will eliminate the differences and disunity amongst the Indians themselves.
('4', 480, 2, 29, 1087708) We, however, do not know what the will of the Almighty is in respect of the future of India.
('4', 480, 2, 30, 1087801) Our duty clearly is to execute the work entrusted to us for the good of the people.
('4', 480, 2, 31, 1087885) Metcalfe, thereafter, was appointed Governor General of Canada.
('4', 480, 2, 32, 1087949) There he fell seriously ill, but disregarding his illness went on doing his duty till the last.
('4', 480, 2, 33, 1088045) He was a deeply religious man.
('4', 480, 2, 34, 1088076) Having served the Queen loyally and won the love of the people, he died in 1840. [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 4 11 1905
